HEADLINE: Life Is Just a Bowl of Rhubarb Crisp (And So Easy!)

BYLINE: By JILL GERSTON 

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
MARTHA STEWART IS CUTting up. Maybe it's because she has spent three hours sprinkling fistfuls of dried rose petals and lavender blossoms into little sachet bags over and over in front of a television crew crammed into her country kitchen. Or maybe it's because she has forgotten that she is wearing a hidden microphone.
Whatever the reason, Ms. Stewart, who has inspired legions of women to tie leek ribbons around their lamb chops and dip chocolate truffles in gold leaf, is drolly parodying her image as Our Lady of Gracious Living. "If you really want to be an obnoxious house guest, take your hostess a pie kit," she deadpans, displaying a basket of fresh peaches, a porcelain pie dish, a rolling pin, a frozen pie crust and a handwritten recipe card an assistant arranges before her. "It will force her to bake you a pie." The crew cracks up. 
 Don't expect such levity on Ms. Stewart's weekly syndicated how-to show, "Martha Stewart Living," which began its second season last month. On camera she is an earnest, omnicompetent perfectionist who reassures viewers that with just a little effort and a lot of time, they, too, can make sugared rose petals. But, then, Ms. Stewart seems supremely accomplished in virtually all she undertakes, with the market for her life-style empire burgeoning as robustly as her 125 varieties of roses.
During its first season, her television series had an average national audience of nearly two million viewers, according to the Nielsen ratings -- healthy numbers considering that the show is broadcast at the crack of dawn in some cities. And her magazine, Martha Stewart Living, with its circulation of 800,000, recently switched from 6 to 10 issues a year. "We get about 500 subscription requests a week from viewers who phone the 800 number given on the show," marvels Eric G. Thorkilsen, the magazine's publisher, who oversees all Martha Stewart Living projects at Time Inc. Ventures. "The show and the magazine are incredibly complementary."
That's not all. Ms. Stewart's 11 sumptuously illustrated books have sold more than 2.8 million copies, and a new one, "Menus for Entertaining," is due later this month. She appears every other week on the "Today" show demonstrating topics from her magazine to a bemused Katie Couric and Bryant Gumbel. K Mart, which sells her collections of sheets and towels, recently renewed her consulting contract. American Express tapped her to do the first commercial for their Optima True Grace card. Never mind that Ms. Stewart's fans include domestically challenged multitudes who are dumbstruck at the thought of making topiary Easter baskets, the numbers are impressive indeed.
Yet it is the television series that is perhaps her most potent marketing medium. Just what are the ingredients in each half-hour episode? Guidance on how to do everything -- cut a grapefruit, build a trellis, bake a rhubarb crisp, plant succulents in a wall garden -- offered with the flair and perfection you would expect from a woman who once catered parties for Ralph Lauren and Paloma Picasso. "My viewer absolutely knows I'm using a delicious fresh-roasted espresso for my ice cubes and not some awful coffee," she says, discussing a segment on making flavored ice cubes. "Not that you can taste it over television, but you can imagine that it tastes really good. It's not just the how-to tip but the way it's done."
And the way it looks. The series is shot primarily on location at Ms. Stewart's renovated 1805 "farmette," a lush six-acre spread in Westport that includes fruit orchards, gardens, a croquet lawn, a pool, a barn and a "palais des poulets" for her exotic Araucana chickens, which lay pastel-blue eggs. "We could never duplicate this place as a set," says Leslie McNeil, the executive producer of the show.
Nor could they duplicate Ms. Stewart, 53, whose outdoorsy, tawny blond looks, preppy clothes and finishing-school voice make her the consummate guide to the world of upper-middle-class suburban "homekeeping." For the lure of "Martha Stewart Living" isn't learning to construct a gingerbread mansion with a copper-leaf mansard roof or grilling Cornish game hens in a marinade of Grand Marnier and orange juice. Instead it is the fascination of watching Martha --
 
devotees call her Martha, never Ms. Stewart -- enact her perfectly fabulous "Martha Stewart Living" life.
Watch Martha clean her vast collection of copper pots. Watch Martha, dressed as a rare bird with a little nest of twigs and faux quail eggs on her head, ride a hay wagon to a Halloween party. Watch Martha garnish her Easter ham with pea vines plucked from her garden. Watch Martha to escape from a world of plastic shower curtains and microwaved pizza into a fantasy of flawless domesticity.
"Remember when those shows 'Dallas' and 'Dynasty' were really popular?" Ms. Stewart says of the television series that epitomized the unembarrassed extravagance of the 1980's. "People were living vicariously through them. I think my approach is so much more simple and so much nicer a life style. People understand."
Understand? Crave is more like it. Ms. Stewart's followers swoon over her every piece of Depression glass, her every copper pudding mold. One besotted disciple requested the pedigree of Ms. Stewart's cats so she could buy the same.
In person Ms. Stewart is funny and vivacious and exudes an aura of brisk efficiency. "I rarely, rarely sit down and do nothing," she says, over a salad at a Westport restaurant during a break from shooting. "I hate to waste time," an assertion confirmed by Richard Z. Chesnoff, a senior correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, who has known Ms. Stewart for nearly 20 years.
"Once my wife and I were with Martha at her house in Easthampton, and I noticed her light was on very late at night," he says. "She told me she keeps her light on all night so if she wakes up she can immediately read. It sounds obsessive, but it's not. It's just Martha's determination not to waste time."

IT'S HER SUPERWOMAN IMage, along with her penchant for painstaking, time-consuming projects, that irritates Ms. Stewart's detractors. "How do you manage to do all that gardening and still keep up with the other stuff, the writing, the editing, the designing, the TV shows, the lectures, the autograph sessions?" wrote Diane White, a columnist for The Boston Globe, who has devoted several irreverent columns to Ms. Stewart. "Have you had yourself cloned?"
Ms. Stewart shrugs off such grousing. "I really can't be bothered by it," she says. "For people to criticize me, I think, is pretty stupid because I'm not doing anything bad or distasteful. If they think that freezing ice cubes in different flavors is too complicated and will clutter their lives, you have to take it with a grain of salt."
While Ms. Stewart's spectacular success may lead some to think she has lead a totally charmed life, her background reveals otherwise. Born Martha Kostyra, the eldest daughter of a pharmaceuticals salesman and a schoolteacher, Ms. Stewart was raised in a large Polish-Catholic family in Nutley, N.J. A straight-A student, she won a partial scholarship to Barnard College and worked as a model to help pay expenses.
At the end of her sophomore year, she married Andrew Stewart, a law student at Yale. She graduated from Barnard in 1963 and two years later gave birth to a daughter, Alexis (29 now and the owner of the Bridgehampton Motel, on Long Island). For eight years Ms. Stewart worked as a stockbroker but quit Wall Street during the 1973 recession.
That year, the Stewarts relocated to Westport, where they renovated the large Federal-style farmhouse that now serves as the primary set for her show. In 1976 Ms. Stewart, who learned how to cook as a child and catered her first party in high school, started a catering business with a friend. The partnership soon dissolved, but Ms. Stewart forged ahead, working out of her kitchen with a staff of assistants. Within a decade Martha Stewart Inc. had ballooned into a $1 million business.

IN 1982 MS. STEWART PUBlished "Entertaining," a lavish coffee-table cookbook that launched the Martha craze. Quicker than you could say "creme brulee," there appeared videos, lectures, seminars, dinner-music CDs, cable-television specials and more books.
But Ms. Stewart's frenetic business schedule took a toll on her private life. In 1987 while she was on a publicity tour for her book "Weddings," her husband moved out of their Westport house after 26 years of marriage. The bitter breakup ended in divorce in 1989.
Alas, real life is never perfect. Roses wilt, roasts burn and marriages crumble. Does she like being single? "Not necessarily," she replies tersely.
Who, then, does America's premier homemaker make a home for? "I make a home for myself," she says evenly. "I love my home."
Homes, to be precise. In addition to her Westport residence, where she lives with her two chows and six Himalayan cats, Ms. Stewart has a beach house in Easthampton. There is also a New York pied-a-terre that she has owned for five years but in which she has never spent a night. And her 35-acre property near Fairfield, Conn., is, as she puts it, "my major gardening project."
Is there anything missing from her life?
"I wish I had had more kids, but I'm gratified that I have a lot of nieces and nephews," she says, glancing at her watch. Lunch is over. It's time to hurry back to shooting.
"I'm not an unhappy person," she adds, momentarily reflective. "I wish people understood me better. I'd like to have my negotiations on all my business things be shorter. Silly things like that. But on the whole, I haven't had many disappointments. I've really been pretty lucky."

HEADLINE: Where Children Are Supposed to Be Heard, Not Simply Seen

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
LITTLE people scurry about the old wooden building, sliding down a pole in a miniature firehouse, yelling, squealing, tossing plastic fruit and vegetables into a basket in a little grocery store, ringing a cash register, making the lights flash on a rail crossing signal, feeling the skull of a grizzly bear or a real crocodile's skin, shaking plastic bottles that show how waves and hurricanes form.
This is the old East Lyme Library building on Main Street in the village of Niantic. Once known as a place to be quiet, it is now the Children's Museum of Southeastern Connecticut. 
It is now also a place to be noisy as well as a hands-on museum in the purest sense of the word. The people who run it want children to have fun in it, to explore all its objects close up, to feel them, turn them over, play with them, talk, laugh, yell if they feel like it. And, not incidentally, gain some knowledge.
"We call it low-tech learning," said Anthony W. Mollica. "We build a kite to explain aerodynamics. It's down-home kind of stuff."
Mr. Mollica, burly and bearded, is the museum's executive director. He brings to the job the enthusiasm of a 4-year-old although he is a 40ish-year-old. And the job does have its moments.
One day last fall, he said, an older woman dropped in at the museum and offered the contents of a cardboard box as a gift. "My husband had this up in the attic for years," she said, "and I don't want to keep it another minute." Inside the box, in some disorder and wrapped in a New York Times of the 1970's, was a human skeleton. "I think her husband was a doctor or something," said Mr. Mollica. In any case, he happily accepted the offering. Now, with all bones in their right places, the skeleton has joined the museum as one more exhibit.
He doesn't think the skeleton will scare children, who have a natural sense of curiosity. It might scare some adults, but the museum is not for adults.
Adults, said Mr. Mollica, are out of place in this museum: "Kids are the bosses here. This place empowers kids." And many times the empowered children amaze him and other adults, mostly volunteers, who work at the museum. Most children are content to slam away at the keys of an organ made especially for, and donated to, the museum. "But one day this 8-year-old kid came in and played Beethoven on it," Mr. Mollica said. "It was beautiful."
The private nonprofit museum represents a real grass-roots effort. It was originated by two local men, Andy Pappas, who runs Constantine's Restaurant, and Jay Gionet, an engineer at the Millstone Point nuclear power plant. "We're both young guys with families," Mr. Pappas said, "and we thought we needed something for the quality of life for young kids growing up here."
On Nov. 7, 1992, the something became a reality. The children's museum was officially opened in the old library building that had been vacant for some time. The metamorphosis into a museum was accomplished by some 150 volunteers, including many skilled people, with advice and guidance from educators and parents, lots of donated materials and 1,500 persons who took out memberships in the venture.
Within months after the opening, however, the founders realized they had become victims of their own success. "When we went to the Board of Selectmen for permission to use the old library, we thought the museum might get 30,000 people a year," Mr. Pappas said. But visitors were showing up at twice the numbers projected and the founders realized they were amateurs in a complicated business. They decided they needed professional help.
Mr. Mollica was hired in 1993. A native of New York, he had been director of the Children's Museum of Maine at Portland for seven years. He was willing to leave there, he said, because he and his wife had two young sons and he felt they were growing up in a limited environment with no racial or ethnic variety.
The actual attendance for the first full year of 1993 was 57,000. This year it is anticipated it will be between 60,000 and 75,000. The museum is much more than a regional attraction. The visitor's log, Mr. Mollica said, contains names of people from all 50 states and 17 foreign countries. "We get people regularly from the Bronx and Brooklyn," he said.
The success already has spurred plans for a larger museum. An application for a state grant for $2 million, half of the proposed cost, has been submitted. For a small hometown enterprise that did not even exist two years ago, with almost no advertising budget, with precious little parking in its present location, in a state suffering many economic woes, the children's museum has proven to be a big surprise.
One theory has it that the success is a spinoff, reflecting the increased traffic to Southeastern Connecticut engendered by the Mashantucket Pequot casino in Ledyard. But a look inside the museum on any day rather discounts that. The people inside are parents, or grandparents, with young children. It does not appear that their next stop is a slot machine.
The real reason for its popularity appears to be that it is a place to have fun, a haven for parents and grandparents seeking safe and enjoyable places to take children.
Mr. Mollica also feels the success of the museum is in line with a burst of enthusiasm for children's museums generally. The museums represent a real growth industry, proliferating at a spectacular pace over the past two decades, not only in the United States but around the world, he said.
The first such museum in this country, he said, was the Brooklyn Children's Museum, founded in 1892. By 1960, however, fewer than a dozen existed in the United States. By the mid-1970's, the figure had mushroomed to about 75. That figure has more than tripled since. Now there are some 250 in this country and another 50 in other countries.
The man most responsible for creating the modern image of the children's museum, Mr. Mollica said, was Michael Spock, head of the Boston Children's Museum in the 1960's and 1970's.
Before Mr. Spock, son of the baby doctor Benjamin Spock, children's museums were mostly showcases for toys, games and even clothes, generally seen behind ropes or under glass. Mr. Spock redesigned the concept on the basis that children learn by smelling and touching and doing. The day of the "hands-on" children's museum had arrived.
On a recent day, a young mother from Albany, N.Y., Linda Collet, watched her 3-year-old daughter, Amanda, frolic around the Niantic museum. She admired the place, and then perhaps best summed up the secret of its success. "They allow children to be children here," she said.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
When Housing Comes, Can Stores Be Far Behind?

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
ONE day last year Charles J. Diven Jr. was operating a backhoe at Park Avenue and 179th Street in the Bronx. He was approached by a stranger.
"I've got to get a hole dug over on Third Avenue," the stranger said. "How much would you charge me?" 
 The contractor dug the hole. One thing led to another and now Mr. Diven is putting the final touches on a 9,600-square-foot commercial structure on Prospect Avenue for that stranger, George Hatzis, who never owned a commercial building in his life. It has fallen to the 56-year-old Mr. Hatzis, who emigrated from Greece in 1968, to be the first entrepreneur to stake his personal financial future on new commercial construction in what until recently was one of the most blighted South Bronx neighborhoods.
Mr. Hatzis has operated a succession of modest pizza parlors with a touch of Greek cuisine over the last 10 years. Once he was a renter in a structure on the very site where he is now building. It burned down.
The new building is at 839 Prospect Avenue, at 160th Street, just off Westchester Avenue. Looming over it is the Prospect Avenue station stop for the Nos. 2 and 5 subway trains, which run a long elevated course along Westchester Avenue en route to Pelham Parkway and beyond.
Old-timers remember Prospect Avenue as a thriving commercial strip at the eastern edge of Morrisania near Hunts Point. "It had three movie theaters, a Woolworth's and a bank," said John Robert, the district manager of Bronx Community Board 2.
But it staggered in the 70's under the pressure of housing abandonment and commercial withdrawal. Great stretches of city-owned land nearby were ultimately cleared.
The most visible sign of the current comeback is a wave of new residential construction launched under the Nehemiah Plan name with city assistance by South Bronx Churches Inc. on 20 blocks west of Westchester Avenue. Attached single-family houses have sold to moderate-income buyers for $56,000, and now condominiums in three-story buildings are on the market for $61,000 to $69,000.
As in other locations of the city, new housing has paved the way for commercial construction. The construction loan for the Hatzis project on Prospect Avenue has come from the Community Preservation Corporation, a consortium of banks better known for its lending to multifamily housing in New York City. It has a lending office in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx and an arrangement to sell the loan, once the project is successfully completed, to the New York City Employees Retirement System. The permanent loan will be insured by the State of New York Mortgage Agency, the key to making financing available.
Long hoping to own his own store, Mr. Hatzis had bought land at Third Avenue and Courtlandt Avenue at a city auction in the 80's. He got so far as to put in footings for the foundation. But he found himself unable to get financing that he had hoped for through the Small Business Administration. He said he had borrowed $100,000 on the equity in his house, and spent $35,000 on site work.
About eight years ago he also bought the land on Prospect Avenue from its Korean owners. "I worked with a pizza guy on that site from 1968 to 1971," he said. Later he opened his own place on the corner. But the building, which was owned by the Goldman-DiLorenzo real-estate organization, burned down in the early 80's, he said.
Mr. Diven, who is 29, is in partnership with Leonard P. Gorski, 33, in LPG Associates, a construction management and contracting firm based in Mount Vernon in Westchester County. It has rehabilitated vacant residential buildings with Community Preservation Corporation financing. Mr. Diven brought Mr. Hatzis to the lender with the proposal for the project, which got a construction loan and a commitment for a $645,000 permanent loan at 8.17 percent.
The simple masonry building has 75 feet of frontage on Prospect Avenue and runs 125 feet deep along 160th Street. The basic individual store area is 12 1/2 feet by 90 feet.
THE operator of a coin laundry and dry cleaners has leased two spaces, Mr. Hatzis said. He also has deals for a fish store and a Chinese restaurant, and he himself will operate a store. He calls it a coffee shop although he will mainly offer pizza and Greek specialties. There is a possibility an ice cream company will take space at the rear of the building.
Another neighborhood retail project in the Bronx that is getting financing through the Community Preservation Corporation is at 1316 Boston Road, in Morrisania. There will be four stores totaling 3,800 square feet of space. The builder is Steve Zervoudis, who has also rehabilitated 15 multifamily buildings in the area.
To get new retailing established in formerly blighted urban neighborhoods that have had a surge in new or rehabilitated housing has proved a challenge, said Michael D. Lappin, president of the Community Development Corporation. Many retailers are skeptical about safety and the purchasing power of neighborhood residents.
But housing improvement brings change. Mr. Lappin gave lower Harlem as an example. With the completion of 3,500 new apartments in rehabilitated buildings, commercial activity has picked up along 116th Street west of Malcolm X. Boulevard, he said.
Mr. Hatzis, in the Bronx, will find a neighborhood with a substantial housing build-up thanks to the Nehemiah program. The plan already approved calls for 780 housing units, 380 of them in one-family houses and 400 in three-family buildings, according to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The city is providing a subsidy of $15,000 a unit.
Near Westchester Avenue many single-family houses have already been completed and occupied, and the three-families are in construction. Each building provides two duplex apartments above a single-level flat, with pad parking typically at the rear.
BUYERS are offered two- and three-bedroom units, with air-conditioning, washers and dryers and one and a half baths for a down payment of $7,500. The monthly carrying cost is advertised as $450. Buyer incomes can range from $20,000 to $53,000.
Lee Stuart, lead organizer of South Bronx Churches for the Industrial Areas Foundation, a Long Island-based organization that mobilizes religious institutions for social causes, gave the following progress report on the Nehemiah program in the Bronx: 224 single-family houses and 84 condominiums completed and occupied; 144 condominiums under construction, with 36 due to close in the next few weeks; plans already submitted for the next 90 condominiums.
Eighty percent of the buyers thus far have been from a Hispanic background, Ms. Stuart said. One buyer was Mary Martinez, a legal secretary who said she feels as though she is living in a "whole different world" since she was able to leave public housing in Mott Haven after 20 years and move with her sister, mother and 4-year-old daughter into a single-family house on Eagle Avenue last October. "I don't feel threatened anymore," she said.
Ms. Martinez was a volunteer worker for South Bronx Churches, as was Lorraine Lett, who moved with her husband, John, a retired schoolteacher, into a duplex condominium on Cauldwell Avenue in June. The Letts lived for 30 years in a public housing project on 170th Street. Mr. Lett had wanted to move out of New York City for years because he was "fed up with the crime," his wife said. For a long time he didn't care for the idea of a Nehemiah house either.
"But when he saw the new buildings he dragged me over there and he never mentioned leaving New York again," she said. Now she sees a need for more neighborhood shopping. "We need banks, bakeries, a restaurant, even a mall, anything that will bring services into the community," Mrs. Lett said.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Astor Row on West 130th;
In Harlem, Restoration of Rowhouses at Mid-Stage

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE New York Landmarks Conservancy's restoration of Astor Row, the little brick houses at 8 to 62 West 130th Street, is now at a middle stage, with some houses still almost derelict, some in mid-restoration and some completed.
But this half-done phase helps make it interesting, and a trip to one of the most memorable blocks in the city will repay anyone who makes the journey. 
 The Astor Estate, worth $80 million in the mid-1870's, began a particularly aggressive building program in 1878, eventually putting up structures like the old Waldorf-Astoria, the St. Regis and other big buildings. But it also built more modestly, and from 1880-1883 William Astor built 28 brick rowhouses for investment at 8 to 62 West 130th Street, designed by Charles Buek.
In 1883 The Real Estate Chronicle described them as "Philadelphia-style" and they are unique in Manhattan -- 14 pairs of houses set back 20 feet from the street, three stories high, with wooden porches and recessed light courts partly separating each pair. The intelligence and ingenuity of their planning rebukes the standard high-stoop brownstones built across the street.
In 1920 the row was still sound but buffeted by changing conditions. A real estate collapse in Harlem around 1905 had given blacks their first toehold in the neighborhood, previously almost exclusively white.
The 1920 census shows that Astor Row's tenants were all white. But in late 1920 the Astor Estate, headed by the young Vincent Astor, announced that it would open the houses to blacks, noting that the whites were on leases with 90-day cancellation clauses.
The exact reasoning behind the decision was not reported. One typical hypothesis is that whites fled areas next to those with blacks, but the 1920 census shows no empty houses. Another is that the quality of white tenants in such areas suffered, whereas the succeeding blacks were more respectable. But there were professionals in both white and black groups, and equal numbers operated their homes as rooming houses.
A final common explanation is that blacks paid more by crowding in. The black tenants may well have paid more, but they were not materially more crowded, with 316 tenants recorded in the 1925 state census, a modest increase over the 292 white tenants in 1920.
Whatever the explanation, the 1925 census offers a picture of black life. At 12 West 130th Street, the occupants were Joseph Bushnell, a 50-year-old minister;, his wife, Effie; their five children, and three lodgers: Thelma Hatcher, a teacher, Charles Hamlet, a bellman, and his wife, Iva. All were American-born.
In 46 West 130th Street, occupied by a machinist, Allen Abramson, and his wife, Mary, and several roomers, most of the occupants had come to this country from St. Kitts, St. Thomas or the Barbados since 1905. The youngest Astor Row inhabitant recorded in 1925 was Marion Walton at 32 West 130th Street, 106 days old, daughter of Wilbert Walton, a West Indian electrician who had been in America since 1919.
Astor Row was pretty much forgotten by 1978, when the second edition of the AIA Guide to New York City, by Norval White and Elliot Willensky, mourned the "restrained beauty which has been tarnished by years of economic distress," especially their fragile wooden porches, many of which were collapsing or had been removed.
IN 1981 the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the houses landmarks, but they continued their slide until 1990, when the New York Landmarks Conservancy began of one of the city's most unusual restoration projects.
Although the 28 houses are now mostly privately owned, some by occupants, some by investors, the Conservancy has collected $2.16 million for facade and interior repairs to 17 buildings. Of this money $375,000 is for low-interest loans, but the rest is outright grant money, about $100,000 per house.
Some are being restored by owner-occupants, some are being rebuilt into co-ops, and there's one "where we're still not sure who the homeowner is," says Peg Breen, president of the Conservancy. Later financing will cover other buildings, but the exterior work on most of the houses will be finished by 1995.
The project began in 1992, and now scaffolds and carpenters and other tradespeople dot Astor Row. The porch woodwork, originally painted in three different color combinations, is being repainted in a single uniform scheme of olive, white and gray.
The renovation has not been without problems, however. The Conservancy is prudently waiting to move ahead on houses that are still unoccupied. And it had a dispute with two homeowners over delays and financing.
Not many years ago there was something almost romantic for students of architecture discovering this ignored, tumble-down row. But this same romance was killing Astor Row, and in this case the drama of the steady reclamation is just as exciting.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The house at 26 West 130th Street, part of Astor Row, in 1939. The houses, many almost derelict, are being restored today by the New York Landmarks Conservancy. The project encompasses the buildings from 8 to 62 on the block just west of Fifth Avenue. (Office for Metropolitan History; Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Disaster Recovery;
A Business Whose Clients Hope Never to Use It

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, Exchange Resources opened a center in Minneapolis where financial traders could go if their workplaces were hit by a fire, flood or other disaster. The center had 440 seats, complete with desktop computers, Reuters and Quotron machines -- tools of the trader's trade.
"It was the field of dreams, except we built it and nobody came," recalled Kenneth Israel, the company's founder. 
 Then Mr. Israel got a little celestial help: Hurricane Andrew in Florida, an earthquake in San Francisco, a Con Edison failure in New York, all threw into sharp relief the specter of millions of sales dollars going down the drain with flood waters or ashes.
Today, client subscriptions to seats at the Minneapolis center and at a larger one Exchange Resources has opened at Telehouse in Staten Island are bringing in $35 million a year. In the last two months Mr. Israel has opened two more centers, one at 33 Whitehall Street and another on the top floor of Salomon Inc.'s data processing center in Rutherford, N.J.
"There is just a major appetite for this kind of backup these days," Mr. Israel said.
There sure is. Over the last decade the disaster-recovery industry has grown to about 30 companies operating 112 facilities with combined revenues of $471 million, according to Contingency Planning Research, a consulting firm in Jericho, L.I. The centers are lifesavers, not only to companies struck by disaster, but also to owners of high-tech buildings like Telehouse at which they rent their space.
For now, three leaders -- Sungard Recovery Services, Comdisco and International Business Machines -- account for about 75 percent of the disaster-recovery business, with I.B.M. alone having about 42 percent.
"Going into this business certainly wasn't a bad decision to make," said John E. Nevola, site manager for I.B.M.'s disaster-recovery center at Sterling Forest, N.Y.
Among the several reasons behind the boom are that publicized disasters like the World Trade Center bombing last year have highlighted the need for places that companies can turn to in emergencies and that companies increasingly rely on computers and telecommunications for everyday transactions.
"Disaster recovery used to focus simply on preserving data," said Tari Schreider, a partner in Contingency Planning. "Now it is on business continuity as a whole."
That change has vastly widened the disaster-recovery industry's customer base.
"It's not just traders or catalogue-sales companies," said Robert W. Richards, general manager of an AT&T division that runs a disaster-recovery center in Rochelle Park, N.J. "It's hospitals, it's leasing companies, even shipping companies. If a ship can't go to sea until you've checked it out, you can't have your computers and phones down."
Disaster-recovery centers fall into several categories. "Cold sites" are empty spaces that can accommodate shipped-in computers. "Hot sites" have large computers and generic workstations. And specialized hot sites duplicate the electronically intricate work stations that commodities traders use. Most centers are all-purpose hot sites that back up business systems, not individuals. They serve companies that, unlike traders, will not lose millions of dollars if they are off-line for a short time.
"MOST people need to be up and running in 24 hours, not in 20 minutes," said William J. Beaumont, senior vice president of marketing for Sungard, which opened the first commercial hot site in Philadelphia in 1978 and now has six huge disaster-recovery centers and 10 smaller regional ones.
The disaster-recovery business is not cheap to enter. The centers must provide many expensive computers, elaborate security and fortress-like buildings. Their electricity and maintenance costs are huge. And competition is forcing most of them to deeply discount their rates, making it ever harder to recoup their costs.
And locating a center can be a logistical nightmare. Its building must have ample space and wiring for computers, backup generators and fiberoptics cables. It should be within commuting distance of its clients' workforces, yet distant enough to keep clear of whatever has felled the clients' offices.
Such sites are getting easier to find. The recession has left a lot of high-tech space available. So has technological progress: Electronic equipment that used to take up huge floors now fits in half the space.
That's one reason Salomon rented space to Exchange Resources.
"We originally figured we'd need the entire Rutherford building for ourselves," said Robert J. Cassiliano, a senior operating officer at Salomon. "But the power of the computer shifted to the desktop, and this building became an underutilized asset."
Technology vendors are turning to disaster recovery to leverage their own underutilized real estate. The AT&T center in Rochelle Park is in space left vacant when switching equipment got smaller. I.B.M. derives about $200 million in annual revenues from its 16 disaster-recovery centers, all in spaces that became available as the company's staff and equipment shrank.
All of the disaster-recovery centers command hefty subscription prices. Clients can pay anywhere from a few hundred dollars a month for simple computer file backup to hundreds of thousands of dollars a year for a setup in which not only their data, but their entire operation -- their trading floor, say, or catalog selling house -- is duplicated and ready to run at a moment's notice. And that just covers the right to use the backup. Clients pay a hefty per diem fee if they do use the center, although most centers will let them run free tests of their systems.
Most centers will sell the same computer access or seat to several clients, on the principle that they are unlikely to have an emergency at the same time. A client who insists on exclusive access to its backup can pay hundreds of thousands of dollars.
NOT surprisingly, some companies balk at what amounts to an expensive insurance policy. Most, citing fear of sabotage, will not discuss their contingency plans on the record.
But several say they have arranged with their own suppliers and customers -- or even, in a few cases, with competitors -- to back each other up.
Others have set up reciprocal arrangements internally. For example, Salomon's Rutherford building and its Manhattan offices serve as backup for each other. Still others have asked their real estate departments to keep up-to-the-minute accounts of empty internal space.
"Between our power plants, warehouses and offices, we have dozens of places that can be hooked up with phones in an emergency," said Domenick Lorenzon, senior real estate representative for Consolidated Edison. "We do more to back up our data systems, but this setup works to relocate an accounting department."
But few companies find it cost-effective to handle rent and maintenance for huge, high-tech spaces that, in best-case scenario, will never be used. There are exceptions. The investment banking firm Allen & Company, for example, is building its own disaster-recovery center at the International Design Center building in Long Island City, Queens.
Far more typical is U.S. Trust. The big bank has an intricate contingency plan for sending people in critical functions in a disaster-hit building to space occupied by employees doing less critical tasks in another building nearby.
But it still pays a commercial recovery center over $250,000 a year to back up its computer systems.
"It's just too tremendous an expense to set up a separate data center that you don't need on a daily basis," said Vincent J. Leuzzi, U.S. Trust's vice president of data security and contingency planning.
Another problem when companies maintain their own centers, the commercial purveyors are quick to note, is that corporate America, like nature, abhors a vaccuum.
"Growing firms tend to gobble up space that was supposed to be reserved for disaster recovery," noted Robert D. Felch, president of Chubb Services Corporation, which runs a disaster-recovery center for Wall Street traders at Metrotech in Brooklyn.
Actually, Chubb and several other recovery centers get double use from the space, too. Some rent it out for seminars, training and special projects.
Why is that less risky? "We won't let anyone modify the space," Mr. Felch said. "And the contract says they must vacate in case of emergency."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Builders Seek to Turn Economies Into Extra Space

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
BUILDERS in Connecticut are responding to home buyers whose mantra for the 90's is value. Gas fireplaces and radiant-heat ceiling panels are selling briskly. Vinyl siding has shed its bourgeois image and steel framing is emerging as an alternative to lumber's unstable prices and scarcity.
Builders say that most buyers, sometimes surprised to learn that what looks like wood siding is vinyl and what appears to be a real fireplace is a gas-burning fake, accept them readily as a trade-off for more square footage and better-equipped kitchens and bathrooms. 
 In addition, developers who once offered a choice of three models -- take 'em or leave 'em -- will customize generously and in some cases custom build. In terms of style, split-levels and ranches are noticeably absent. "People want two-story houses," said Ralph Lee Smith, publications editor for the National Association of Home Builders in Upper Marlboro, Md.
Demographically, empty-nesters and young families in the $100,000-to-$300,000 market are most interested in houses requiring minimum maintenance, while purists and those who can afford it continue to insist on natural materials.
"I advise against synthetics," said John P. Franzen, a Southport architect. "A house with a masonry chimney and wood or brick siding will hold its value. But a $375,000 house can cost almost $100,000 less built of synthetics."
Over the last two decades, when mercury and lead were removed from paint for environmental reasons, mildewing and a weakened ability of paint to adhere to wood siding resulted. Homeowners resorted to covering the wood with vinyl, and builders of new houses found vinyl easy and cheap to install in 100-square-foot sheets that require no painting.
But it is not trouble-free. In a fire it gives off toxic fumes, and after a decade or two it can become porous and lose color. "We are test-marketing something called Siding Paint," said Carl Minchew, chief chemist at the Benjamin Moore paint company in New Jersey, "that is designed for use on weathered vinyl, and we have developed paints containing agents that retard mildew."
Carl Kuehner, a third-generation New Canaan builder, has constructed vinyl-sided houses in Darien and New Canaan for as much as $700,000. "It insures a maintenance-free life style," he said, "for people who would rather be on the golf course." And he has installed gas fireplaces not only in homes but also in office buildings, "to give that corner office a certain cachet," he said. "You just click it on with a remote control," Mr. Kuehner added.
CHRIS NELSON, whose Nelson Construction Company in Farmington is building 68 vinyl-sided homes on a 29-acre site, will sell them for $110,000 to $210,000 in sizes of 1,300 to 2,020 square feet. He uses detailed wood trim, gas fireplaces and will customize.
"We have five models and two to three elevations for each, so there are 15 house styles," he said. "Computers give us the flexibility to move interior walls, shift configurations, then run the plan through the computer and have the printouts, specific to the buyer, out in the field within hours." Customizing with hand-drawn blueprints sometimes took weeks.
In Madison, Robert Dowler and his son Chris are building 40 vinyl-sided houses with gas fireplaces on a 30-acre site, with each house custom-designed for the topography and the buyer's requirements. Don Miner, the resident designer, tailors the house to the buyer's specifications and life style. Homes of 1,600 to 3,000 square feet start at around $260,000 and go up to whatever the customer's tastes and pocketbook dictate.
In high-priced Stamford, the Vaneck Brothers, longtime local builders, are offering four vinyl-sided models of 1,800 to 2,200 square feet with two to four bedrooms for $260,000 to around $290,000. But there is no customizing, there are no basements and the condominiumized lots are very small.
"The gas fireplaces," said Nicholas Vaneck, "do not require chimneys. They are sealed behind a glass front and vented through the wall with a metal cap on the outside of the house. Fifty percent of our buyers are empty-nesters, not interested in hauling firewood."
Masonry chimneys add from $2,000 to $6,000 to the cost of a house, so it is not surprising that nationwide sales of gas fireplaces increased by 30 percent in 1993 over 1992, to more than 600,000 units, and a higher figure is anticipated for 1994 by the Hearth Products Association of Arlington, Va.
Vent-free gas fireplaces, in which the flame is open to the room, are prohibited in some states, including New York, and some municipal building inspectors in Connecticut will not approve them.
Sales of both vent-free and vented gas fireplaces at Novicky's Fireside in Brookfield account for 60 percent of total sales of gas and wood-burning fireplaces, said Bobbi Novicky, the owner.
"Fears of the vent-free type are unfounded," she said. "They work like a gas burner on a countertop range, producing no carbon monoxide. We recommend that a window be open slightly because they use room air, but if the oxygen level goes down to 17 parts per million the fireplace shuts off automatically."
Vented fireplaces automatically shut down when too high a temperature is reached or the sealed glass front, which creates a combustion chamber, is removed.
Town Glen, a vinyl-sided apartment complex in Stamford, vents its gas fireplaces up a stacked flue through the roof.
"WE prefer gas because wood logs attract insects," said Chuck Berman, head of Avalon Properties of New Canaan, the developer, "and in an urban setting it's difficult to find space to store them." The one- and two-bedroom units rent from $1,000 to $1,700.
Steel framing is a learning experience for carpenters, but "it will be installed in 35,000 houses by the end of this year," said James Prindle, project manager of the American Iron and Steel Institute in Washington, "double last year's figure."
"By 1997 we expect to have 25 percent of the market," he said.
Half of the output is in prefabricated housing as studs -- the vertical wall supports -- structural walls, floor joists and roof truss packages. Steel siding and steel roofing sheets can be textured to look like stucco, shingles and various other traditional materials. "Every stud is a dollar cheaper than its wood counterpart," said Mr. Prindle, "and they are all straight and usable. About 20 percent of wood studs are returned for defects."
Warming up from the ceiling down is the business of the Solid State Heating Company in Old Saybrook, where radiant-heat ceiling panels are made. They require no furnace, ducts or flues or maintenance and are silent and nonallergenic. Operated from thermostats at every light switch "they warm all objects in their path, including the floor," said Richard Watson, president of the company, "rather than warming air and blowing it through the house."
They have been used successfully at Heritage Village in Southbury by the builder K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., and by local contractors. Studies by the National Association of Home Builders show that they save 33 to 52 percent over heat pumps and baseboard units, and they are competitive with natural gas.
"We call them Enerjoy People Heaters," said Mr. Watson.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Water Eyes Private Suppliers

BYLINE: By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
COMMUNITIES trying to make a strong stand for home rule are having trouble keeping their private water utilities alive.
New Federal standards have opened the way for acquisitions by the Suffolk County Water Authority, which supplies 80 percent of the water in the county. 
"Outside areas that we don't control will be experiencing great difficulties with the new guidelines," the chairman of the authority, Michael A. LoGrande, said.
Increases stemming from the new standards imposed by the Environmental Protection Agency are costing the authority $4 million this year. Twenty-five wells were tested under the Safe Drinking Water Act, and 25 will be added every other year at a cost of $4 million each time, according to Mr. LoGrande, who added:
"We know the tests will be O.K., but still we have to do them. Most of the tests don't even affect us. They are for mining substances found in Southern states such as the Carolinas. But they are Federal mandates and have to be complied with across the board."
Under New York State guidelines the authority also tests its 415 wells for 120 additional substances.
The authority says benefits from takeovers include lower rates than private companies because the authority is exempt from property and income taxes, issues tax-exempt bonds, does not have to show a profit and spreads costs over its base of 320,000 customers.
At a new $5 million laboratory in Hauppauge, 18 chemists have been added to the nine-member staff. "We now test over 40,000 samples per year," an operations supervisor, Herman Miller, said. "We monitor wells, some daily, if there is a potential problem. In private labs it can take up to a week for results. We have them the next day. We have people on duty 24 hours a day for emergencies, and we do our own maintenance."
The average customer pays $1.25 per 1,000 gallons of water. Forty percent of the revenues go to construction costs like laying mains. The remaining 60 percent is for operations and management.
"We only operate in eight of Suffolk's 10 towns," Mr. LoGrande said. Riverhead and Shelter Island run their own water utilities. "Fifteen or 20 years down the road we may integrate Riverhead," he said. "But right now they are doing a good job. Shelter Island just didn't work out."
The eight towns in the authority each also have two or three independent districts. The authority manages the districts, which are charged for water and taxed for capital expenses. Most districts are self-contained and pump their own water.
In the Town of Huntington the districts include Dix Hills, Greenlawn and South Huntington. Babylon has East Farmingdale, Islip has Brentwood, and Brookhaven has Stony Brook and some communities on Fire Island.
On the East End, Hampton Bays and Greenport are the only two independent districts.
"Most of those districts, like Greenlawn, are doing a fine job," Mr. LoGrande said. "Their water quality is fine. So we have never offered to buy them."
Offers have been made to purchase some districts, but in some instances like East Farmingdale, which has low rates, the communities did not want to give up their autonomy, Mr. LoGrande said.
Smithtown and St. James own their water utilities, but buy water from the authority. Both districts voted down acquisition by the authority last year. A takeover would have raised their annual rates, from $1.20 to $1.21 per 1,000 gallons, or $4 a year per homeowner.
Opponents of the takeover in Smithtown contend that the Town Board had not obtained an independent evaluation of the district to negotiate a counteroffer to the authority's proposal for $4.45 million.
The rejection occurred near an election, but Supervisor Patrick Vecchio said he did not know why the proposal failed. "I was in favor," Mr. Vecchio said. "I think one entity is better. Most people polled want less government, not more. Here was an incident where they could get less. But they turned it down."
In St. James, which Mr. Vecchio called a homey community, voters "just did not want to give it up," he added.
St. James is among the districts feeling the effects of rising costs imposed by the county authority. The 9,000 residents face an estimated 24 percent increase in rates next year. Smithtown, which has a water surplus, is not being affected.
The Town of Shelter Island also opted for home rule, when the West Neck Water Company, which has 52 customers, was put up for sale in the summer. The town, rather than let the county authority acquire the utility, is hoping to buy it. It is placing a proposition on the ballot in November to establish a town water district for those 52 houses, said Supervisor Hoot Sherman. The other 90 percent of the residents have wells.
The 52 homeowners hooked up to the 40-year-old West Neck utility would be the only people bearing the $25,000 cost of its wells. They now pay $125 a year, and the cost would rise, to $350.
It would have been cheaper to join with the county authority because of the new testing and regulations, Mr. Sherman said. "But we don't want the S.C.W.A. and all the things that go with it, the pressure to down zone and the pressure for development," he said.
In many attempts to purchase utilities, Mr. LoGrande said, his authority is "buying headaches." He cited the 495-customer Swan Lake Water Company in Patchogue and the 1,000-customer Sun Hill in Centereach and Selden.
Two years ago, after years of unsuccessful talks, the authority started condemnations against the utilities, saying that they did not meet quality standards. "In many of these cases," Mr. LoGrande said, "you have poor families with high rates and poor water."
In 1992, after a public outcry over rate increases, the authority made its largest purchase, spending $17.5 million for the Shorewood Water Corporation in Shoreham-Wading River. The rates for the 5,300 customers were lowered 40 percent, from $4.44 per 1,000 gallons to $2.50.
On Fire Island the rate would be higher than the average $1.25, to cover the logistics of servicing a barrier island, Mr. Miller said. Seeking alternatives to higher rates, four of the 17 communities on the island -- the Pines, Cherry Grove, Kismet and Ocean Bay Park -- have approached the county authority.
Ocean Bay Park residents, who pay $7 per 1,000 gallons of water and an annual service charge of $225, turned down the proposal. The president of the board of the Ocean Bay Park Water Corporation, Bruce Martin, said the authority did not propose sufficient savings to induce the residents to give up control. "People on Fire Island do like to keep home rule when they can," he added.
But Elizabeth Mahoney, a member of the Held family that has owned the 45-year-old Kismet Water Company that serves 180 houses, said a purchase by the authority had been negotiated.
"It's hard to run a mom-and-pop operation without the knowledge and education now required," Ms. Mahoney said. "And it's hard economically. Last year our well-casing started to be compromised. There's no financing for a small water company, and the family just doesn't have the money to put up any more."
The Pines and Cherry Grove districts, which are managed by Brookhaven, have not made a decision. But the financial burdens are growing, according to Clern LaFountaine, Commissioner of the Fire Island Pines Water District.
Bids recently opened for a $4 million to $6 million project to deal with asbestos in the water mains in the Pines. New backflow valves are being installed, and along with seven other Fire Island communities the Pines has to treat its pipes for lead corrosion control, at an estimated cost of $15,000.
"Between the Federal, state and county health regulations, the small purveyor of water is the targeted species," Mr. LaFountaine said. "They can't keep it up."
Mr. LoGrande said although his authority was buying companies, hewas most concerned about the 50,000 homeowners with private wells, like those in Head of the Harbor and Nissequogue in Smithtown. The laws are written just for public suppliers, he said, adding:
"We've already hooked up 250 people who have shallow wells. We ask that people test their water at least twice a year. Our goal is to make sure all people have pure drinking water."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
A Strong Jobs Reports, but Inflation Alarms Stay Silent
 The financial markets were jittery all week about -- what else? -- inflation. One day the Dow dropped 45 points for no other discernible reason, and the 30-year Treasury bond yield flirted with an unheard-of 8 percent, as most eyes were focused on the unemployment report looming on Friday. When it appeared, it was -- in Labor Secretary Robert Reich's words -- "steady as you go." Unemployment did fall to 5.9 percent, the lowest level in four years, but the 239,000 added payroll jobs were lower than expected. So the markets decided, yet again, that inflation wasn't pounding on the door, Treasury yields eased a bit, and the Dow rose 21 points. Of course, the latest tension in Iraq had a clear effect, lifting oil stocks (on speculation of a supply disruption) and the dollar (a traditional haven when nations draw their swords).
 
Whose Economy Is It, Anyway?
Wait a second. What, exactly, does a strong economy look like? As in a house of mirrors, it depends on where you stand. The jobs data give a far-off, brute-force sort of picture, but last week the Census Bureau gave another snapshot, showing a few more warts. This economy's dirty secret, Census figures show, is that it's "in danger of splitting into a two-tiered society," in Labor Secretary Reich's words. Because while the rich got car phones, the family in the middle lost $300 (in real dollars) last year. On top of that, more than a million Americans slid into statistical poverty. "This," Mr. Reich said, "is not anyone's idea of progress."
 
Interactive? No, Thanks
So there's all this money pouring into enabling a technology-besotted public to shop at home, say, or order movies -- "interactive" services, they're called. But did anyone ask that public if it was interested? Actually, yes -- and the companies pouring that money may not like the answers. In a poll out last week, people showed scant interest in interactive services -- far less than in plucking out information. One big reason seems to be that people have a nagging fear that with all that computing power loose in the land, marketers will latch onto any information they can and bombard armchair shoppers with sales pitches. When privacy safeguards were mentioned, the interest doubled. But will shoppers' privacy ever be intact again?
 
See the Movie, Buy the Shrimp
It's a familiar scene: a 7-year-old, after seeing "The Lion King" 42 times, spirals into tears because the Nala doll -- Simba's pal -- is sold out everywhere. On such grief is a multi-zillion-dollar industry built: if you've seen the movie, kids, badger Mom or Dad to buy every movie tie-in doodad in sight. Adult movies, of course, are above such merchandising silliness -- at least they used to be. "Forrest Gump" has already defied gravity by hitting No. 5 on history's blockbuster list -- without a space alien or animated critter in sight. And now -- are you ready for this? -- there's everything from Gump T-shirts to table-tennis sets to Bubba Gump Shrimp. Hundreds of millions of dollars' worth. So brace yourself: next summer there'll be a dozen movies starring floating feathers.
 
Did That Quiz Turn a Profit?
City schools are a huge problem in this country, and -- in sheer dollars -- they're also a huge business. They're not run like businesses, though -- with trained business people calling the shots -- and some people say that's where the problem lies. Like the people in Hartford, which has Connecticut's largest school system, and one of its most troubled. So last week Hartford acted on that theory, taking the radical step of hiring a private company called Education Alternatives to run its schools -- the first whole system turned over to private hands. There's something unsettling about the idea, of course -- the whole notion of treating those young minds as so many widgets -- but Hartford clearly decided that the schools' current sad state was even more unsettling.
 
Flash! Something Worked!
Occasionally, just occasionally, some grand Government plan actually works. So as titillating as it is to recount horror stories, let's pause for a moment over one that appears to be a success. Seven years ago, with the semiconductor industry battered by Japan, the Government -- urged on by chip makers -- set up a federally financed consortium called Sematech to give the industry a lift. Over the years, Washington has invested $690 million, with Sematech members -- like I.B.M., Motorola and National Semiconductor -- matching that. And lo and behold, America leads the world again -- so last week Sematech told Washington that chip makers would soon go solo, weaning themselves from Federal financing by 1997.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Seal of Approval for South Africa
Ending apartheid was only a start. South Africa badly needs rebuilding after years as a global outcast, but it could borrow cash to do so only at loan-shark rates. For even with all the investment capital sloshing around the globe, South Africa lacked one vital ticket to the party: the blessing of a top credit-rating agency. But last week -- as Nelson Mandela visited the United States in search of investment -- it finally got it, as Moody's declared South Africa an investment-grade sort of place. Standard & Poor's still held back, saying it wanted more time, but it indicated that it could come around soon. Moody's rating, though, might get the money moving.
 
Giving Russia Some Time
One of the world's biggest, most important question marks is whether Russia can make the giant leap to a market economy. To do so, it argues, it must have some breathing room before having to pay back its huge debts. World governments have already postponed interest payments repeatedly, and last week it got another much-needed break: foreign banks made a deal to give Russia a five-year grace period during which it need not pay interest or principal on $26 billion in loans. The breakthrough came when Russia was granted "sovereign immunity" from having funds seized abroad if it defaults. But it still has to pay all the money back.
 
COMPANIES
 
McHospital
Who needs a national health care system when we've got Columbia/HCA Healthcare? At this rate, there'll be as many Columbia/ HCA hospitals across the landscape as there are McDonald's. The company's already the nation's biggest for-profit hospital chain, but why stop there? Why indeed. Last week, Columbia heard that Healthtrust, No. 2 in the industry, was thinking of merging with a rival, and Columbia jumped in and merged with Healthtrust itself -- to create a giant with 311 hospitals in 31 states. The idea is that with shorter patient stays and more home care, a hospital chain must hammer away at efficiency. The merged company will still account for just 4 percent of the $350 billion spent in the nation's hospitals annually. But the day is young.
 
Have a Coors -- After Work
Loyal employees should certainly be encouraged to use their employers' products. Editors should read their own newspapers, toothpaste packers should be politically correct at the sink. But enough, sometimes, is enough -- which is what Coors decided. It used to let workers at its Colorado headquarters drink Coors at lunch and during breaks -- the last big brewer to allow on-the-job drinking. But tomorrow that policy ends. In March, it seems, a Coors worker died in a car accident after he left work, reportedly with too much alcohol in his blood, but Coors said the drinking policy had been under review since "well before the accident."
 
Remember Us? We Pay the Bills
Many people have unkind things to say about Philip Morris, but arts organizations aren't among them. For years, the company has been one of nation's biggest backers of the arts -- giving millions a year to museums, dance groups, you name it -- and asked nothing in return. But Philip Morris has a little problem -- New York City's proposed anti-smoking bill -- so it was time to ask a few favors. Its executives have been calling arts groups asking them to put in a good word with the City Council. Not to lobby, mind you -- just to gently remind officials of Philip Morris's good works. And though arts-group officials may have been tempted to hang up in an air-purifying huff, little voices said, "Remember the money." As one official put it, "It's a very tricky situation." The City Council got a lot of calls.
 
Watch Kidder Shrink
General Electric doesn't like surprises, and it does like investments to pay off. Kidder, Peabody has failed on both counts. It took a beating in the bond market, and the Joseph Jett scandal was probably the last straw. So last week the G.E. executives who waded in to straighten things up cut Kidder down to size -- the size G.E. wants, that is. That means a 10 percent cut in staff -- 550 jobs -- plus $100 million in cost cuts and the sale of $30 billion in assets. In other words, a far smaller firm. Most notable, perhaps, is the scrapping of plans to move Kidder uptown to G.E. headquarters. G.E. may be about to banish the errant firm from its tidy corporate family. Nobody's denying it.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Savers Suffer At Most Banks

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
ONCE again, the American economy is showing surprising strength, with the unemployment rate down to 5.9 percent. Wall Street thinks it is all but inevitable that the Federal Reserve will be pushing short-term interest rates up again.
Again? If your money is in bank money market accounts -- you remember, the accounts that were introduced a decade ago as the alternative to money market funds -- you may not have noticed anything happening on the interest rate front. 
 When the Federal Reserve tightens, it pushes up the rate that banks pay on loans from other banks. This year, it has tightened five times, raising that rate by 1.75 percentage points. But the banks have seen no reason to pay depositors anything like that increase. Bank Rate Monitor reports the average bank was paying 2.3 percent on money market accounts just before the first tightening, and now is paying 2.5 percent.
Unsurprisingly, banks have been less hesitant to raise the rates they charge on loans. Meanwhile, the average yield on money market funds, which compete directly with the banks, has gone from 2.7 percent to 4.3 percent.
What's going on here? In past cycles, notes Bob Heady of Bank Rate Monitor, banks have pushed up rates more slowly than the market, but never this slowly. At IBC/Donoghue, which tracks money market funds, Ralph Norton, an analyst, says it is "a mystery to me" why banks have decided to not compete with money market funds for available savings.
The issue is not one that bankers are itching to discuss. Calls to several big banks Friday produced a series of responses that the only official who could discuss such things was unavailable.
Federal Reserve data show that bank savings account balances -- including the money market accounts -- have declined very slowly even while their rates lagged the competition. Many savers don't bother to check rates, and others have tied up money to meet minimum deposit requirements to get "free" checking. The banks, having found that they don't need to pay up for this type of deposit, are only too happy not to do so. When certificates of deposit are up for renewal, customers are more likely to call around, and thus there is more competition in those rates. The low rate for one-year C.D.'s was 3.1 percent. Now it is up to 4.6 percent.
But there is something else to be seen from these numbers. As Merrill Lynch strategist Chuck Clough notes, banks are not exactly falling all over themselves to find money to make more loans. Loan demand is up, but it is far from overwhelming.
For savers, the answer is obvious. If you want to stay in a bank, consider certificates of deposit, which often count against minimum balance requirements. Or move to a money market fund.
That behavior may have already begun. While the total balance of bank and savings institutions savings accounts has dropped only 3 percent since February, the pace has started to pick up in the last few weeks. As Abe Lincoln said, you can't fool all of the people all of the time.

LENGTH: 1502 words

HEADLINE: Pushing for the Free Trade Pact From 1,500 Feet Down

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: GREEN RIVER, Wyo.

 BODY:
FIFTEEN hundred feet under the sagebrush of the southwestern Wyoming desert here lie the world's biggest soda ash mines. One mine alone has 2,400 miles of tunnels, nearly five times the combined length of the streets of Manhattan.
So plentiful are the deposits that geologists estimate they could supply the entire world for 2,300 years at current rates of consumption. Soda ash is similar to baking soda and serves as the raw material for glass, toothpaste, powdered soaps and laundry detergents. 
 This mother lode has turned the United States into the world's lowest-cost producer, allowing it to claim nearly one third of the world market. And if the House and Senate approve a new global free trade agreement at the end of November, it will mean even more jobs in the soda ash industry, which had sales of $734 million last year. That makes the industry an unusually clear winner from a highly complicated pact.
The losers will be the foreign producers of soda ash. The low production costs here have prompted other countries to raise steep tariffs to protect their less efficient chemical factories that make synthetic soda ash. Desperate European multinationals have even sued American producers, including one of their own mines here, accusing them of dumping soda ash at unfairly low prices in the European market.
"It's like calling in an air strike on your own position," said Dennis Kostick, a soda ash geologist at the United States Bureau of Mines.
The soda ash industry offers a mirror image of the dilemma that usually confronts Americans when they think about trade as a choice between job losses and lower prices for consumers.
The traditional dilemma is best seen in the American clothing industry, which has much higher labor costs for sewing than its foreign competitors. Lowering trade barriers in the apparel industry at home and abroad means cheaper clothing for American consumers. But it also means throwing thousands of Americans out of work.
Soda ash is a different case. Since foreign soda ash is much more expensive, the United States imports virtually none and is unlikely to do so regardless of trade agreements. For this industry, then, a global free trade agreement will only mean more overseas sales, more jobs here and more economic activity that the Government can tax.
Other American industries hoping for big gains in exports from lower tariffs include producers of paper, pharmaceuticals, beer, processed foods, construction equipment and farm equipment.
If the pact is approved and other countries lower their barriers, miners here are ready to step up production, said John V. Corra, the manager of the FMC Corporation's mine here, as he drove with a visitor through miles of 9-foot-high, 16-foot-wide corridors, all the while keeping an eye on the rough ceiling from which foot-long stalactites hung like Vermont icicles.
The curving walls of the corridor still bear the inch-wide grooves where giant boring machines sliced through the rocks. These machines have two sets of 8-foot-wide rotating blades, so that they resemble a pair of huge electric shavers clamped together. Smaller blades also tear at the ceiling and floor to produce a smooth, oval-shaped corridor.
As the blades chew through the ore, the crumbled rock falls on the front of a conveyor belt that carries the ore back through the middle of the 110-ton machine and dumps it out the back on a shuttle car. The shuttle car then carries the ore down a few passages to one of the mine's big conveyor belts, which extend for 20 miles and carry the ore to an immense freight elevator that hauls up 22 tons of ore in each car.
Tariffs for soda ash would be among 198,000 tariffs around the world that the 123-nation trade pact would reduce. The pact would also extend the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to farming and a few service industries, like accounting.
With the failure of President Clinton's health care overhaul, the trade pact has emerged as the Administration's top legislative priority for the rest of this year. But the bill putting the pact's provisions into American law faces an uncertain future because of election-year politics and because Senator Ernest C. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the Commerce Committee, has forced an eight-week delay in the Senate vote. Mr. Hollings's home state is a big producer of textiles and clothing, but he attributes his opposition to a general skepticism of free trade.
The dollars involved in the soda ash industry here are not large by trade standards: by one Government estimate, the trade pact's lower tariffs would mean an extra $80 million a year in American soda ash exports, representing an increase of about one third, and 300 to 400 more mining jobs here.
But such gains add up quickly. Administration economists predict that annual American economic output could be $100 billion larger within a decade if the trade bill passes. But opponents contend that the gains would be no more than $2 billion a year.
So economically important and politically powerful is the soda ash industry here that one of the state's two Republican senators, Malcolm Wallop, flew from his ranch in Wyoming to Geneva and back last December just to spend a day lobbying for lower European tariffs on the substance.
BECAUSE of a fluke of geology, the United States is the only country with huge reserves of soda ash that can be readily mined.
Soda ash ore, known as trona, is formed when sodium is combined with carbon dioxide and water in fairly precise ratios. Geologists believe that the deposits here formed 50 million years ago as continental drift pushed up mountain ranges around a large lake. The lake gradually dried out and the plant matter in it died and decayed, producing large quantities of carbon dioxide. At roughly the same time, numerous volcanic eruptions in northwestern Wyoming blanketed the region in sodium-rich ash, while the lake bed itself held some sodium-rich rocks.
The only other big veins of soda ash ore lie in a remote area of Turkey and in China near the Mongolian border. Neither is being mined because there are no nearby railroads or highways to ship the ash.
Industry executives once hoped that the trade pact's benefits for American soda ash would be even more substantial than they turned out to be. But the final pact is the sum of many compromises over seven years of negotiations.
The pact calls for all countries to limit their soda ash tariffs to 5.5 percent, but does not eliminate them entirely, as the United States had sought. This will force the European Union to cut its 10 percent tariff nearly in half.
"The reduction in tariffs," said William L. Breunig, the soda ash marketing director at FMC, "will make the market open to us and increase exports."
 
Industry at Odds With Itself
WASHINGTON -- THE soda ash industry holds a certain distinction in international trade circles: its corporations abroad have tangled with their subsidiaries here, even accusing one in a lawsuit of dumping goods at unfairly low prices in the parent's home market.
While rare, if unheard of, in other industries, similar suits could become increasingly common in the next few years as ever more companies set up operations around the globe and more countries enact anti-dumping laws. The reason: such laws effectively require a domestic producer suffering from low-priced foreign competition to sue all producers in another country or none.
Sometimes that may mean a company must sue its own subsidiary. Solvay S. A. of Belgium blames low-priced shipments from the United States for ruining the profitability of its synthetic soda ash factories in Europe. So it formed a coalition of European companies that filed anti-dumping complaints with the European Union in Brussels. The action seeks steep tariffs on all soda ash from the United States -- even though the Europeans own mines in southwestern Wyoming that account for a third of American production.
Solvay says its huge American mining operations have stopped shipping to Europe but it must sue them because of legal technicalities.
The European companies filed their case in late 1992, and a decision is due later this year or early next year. If the European Union decides to impose tariffs, the global free trade pact now before Congress is unlikely to prove any help to American producers.
The Clinton Administration insisted during the final days of negotiations last December in Geneva that the pact not put many restrictions on anti-dumping claims, which the American steel industry has used often against foreign rivals.
The final pact does call for several highly technical changes in the rules for anti-dumping cases.
A few soda ash executives, including William L. Breunig of the FMC Corporation, contend that the new rules will help Americans defend themselves by making the European anti-dumping process less secretive. But many others are less optimistic.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUNTS POINT/LONGWOOD;
Revival Stirs in Hunts Point

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, Duane Reade, the drugstore chain based in New York City, opened its second outlet in the Bronx, on Southern Boulevard in Hunts Point.
The opening would have drawn little attention in Manhattan, where the chain operates all but 6 of its 50 stores. But to many in Hunts Point, one of the city's poorest neighborhoods, the occasion signaled renewed confidence in the blocklong commercial strip between East 163d Street and Westchester Avenue. 
 The drugstore's arrival, along with its 40 jobs, comes at a time when vacancies on the 121-store strip are almost nil and the city's Economic Development Corporation is completing $900,000 worth of improvements on the sidewalks.
"This section of the South Bronx is a strong retail area," said Clay B. Lifflander, president of the Economic Development Corporation. "And, certainly, having a major chain like Duane Reade there is testimony to the area's business strength."
The strength follows the development of new houses in the area. As more and more people have moved in, the number of retail services has not climbed proportionately. And while residents living south and west of the strip are more likely to head to the Hub on 149th Street, Southern Boulevard draws many customers from the store-starved north.
Duane Reade had been considering the location for the last eight months, said Gary Charbonneau, a vice president at the drugstore chain, and thought that the promise of an untapped market outweighed concerns over safety.
The Southern Boulevard Chamber of Commerce now estimates the strip's occupancy rate at 97 percent. Tina Mateo, the chamber's director, calls it a significant improvement over three years ago when the poor economy and high rents combined to hold occupancy to about 80 percent.
"Businesses move in and out," she said. "But the turnover has been a lot less."
As business picked up in recent years, the chamber of commerce and the local community board began looking for funds to improve the street's infrastructure. The Economic Development Corporation began work on the street in the spring and expects to have most of the $900,000 project finished by Thanksgiving and the start of the holiday shopping season.
Many of the improvements are cosmetic: trees are being planted and bricks are being placed on the edge of sidewalks. But one change will seek to remedy what the chamber of commerce found was the commercial strip's biggest obstacle: fear of shopping here after dark. Ms. Mateo said 22 lampposts will be added to the 16 already there.
"Except in the summer, this area was dark at 4 P.M.," Ms. Mateo said. "Everybody went home. Nobody wants to go to a dark place and shop." But the lighting met city standards, so the chamber is paying for the new lampposts' annual maintenance of $2,000, she said.
Dr. Henry Blum, an optometrist who opened his shop in 1945, said he has seen the area go from middle class to a symbol of urban decay. But now, even when his Upper East Side neighbors shake their heads over his South Bronx location, he says he is optimistic. "They still have an image of when Jimmy Carter was here surrounded by burned-out buildings," he says. "It's not like that anymore." NORIMITSU ONISHI

GRAPHIC: Photo: On a commercial strip along Southern Boulevard, business is booming. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)
