HEADLINE: What Does Russia Want?

BYLINE: By Grigory A. Yavlinsky; Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an economist, is leader of a democratic opposition party in the Duma, the lower house of Parliament. This was translated from the Russian by Antonina W. Bouis.

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
An increasingly disquieting feature of Russian politics is President Boris Yeltsin's ambiguous attitude toward integration with the former Soviet republics.
Big unanswered questions hover in the air. With which members of the Commonwealth of Independent States -- if any -- should Russia integrate? How? On what basis? With what goals? And with what consequences for Russia, those republics and the rest of the world? 
 The United States and others may well conclude that a neo-imperialist Russia, catering to an outdated notion of its vital interests, is trying to re-create the defunct Soviet empire through military, political and economic integration. For this conclusion, blame Russia's chaotic foreign policy and vague priorities, as well as the influence of both Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the hard-line nationalist, and the Communists in the country's populist leadership.
When Americans raise objections, Moscow explains them away by arguing that the U.S. really does not want today's situation in Russia and the entire post-Soviet region to improve -- that it has an interest in doing everything possible to preserve instability.
To prevent confusion about its intentions, Russia must base its policies toward the former Soviet empire -- the "near abroad" -- on explicitly formulated, intelligible principles that reflect moral absolutes.
If Russia truly wants to remain democratic, these should be the principles: the states that appeared after the collapse of the Soviet Union must remain politically independent; integration must be voluntary, without any pressure from Russia; economic union should be the basic form of integration -- and in Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova the only form.
Why would this approach be practical? First, because neither Russia nor any other post-Soviet country can hope to join the European Community, much less NATO, in the near future. Russia and its neighbors need their own markets, which would provide the sole basis for economic growth in the next 5 to 10 years.
Second, because economic integration would result in greater social stability throughout the post-Soviet region.
An economic union would have to have three main features. First, a customs union. This would guarantee free trade and neutralize monopolies in these countries.
Then, a payments union. This would promote the convertibility of the currencies and, with help from the central banks, establish and support exchange rates. Of course, this assumes the coordination of fiscal and budgetary policies. A payments union would lead to greater stability of the currency systems and, consequently, to the growth of trade while significantly diminishing the risk of loss through wildly fluctuating exchange rates.
Finally, harmonized economic legislation. This would facilitate a single set of rules and simplify the movement of capital among the several countries.
If an economic union is formed, Russia would significantly slow the decline in production and reduce by 30 percent inflation and the growth of unemployment. An increase in sales in Commonwealth of Independent States markets would allow Russian enterprises to pay for their own restructuring, enabling them to enter world markets eventually with competitive products. Russia could temporarily provide gas and oil at a discount to such countries as Ukraine and Belarus. It would cost $2 billion to $3 billion a year -- a relatively small price to pay for a significant expansion of markets for Russia's industry and agriculture.
What most worries the democratic opposition in Russia is the absence of a clear stand among the country's leaders against military and political integration with Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova -- the only approach that can truly calm the fears among members of the Commonwealth of Independent States and make talk of neo-imperialism unfounded. (It would also prevent the potential danger of political schism between the western and eastern parts of Ukraine.)
Besides, a clearly expressed desire to avoid political and military union with the western countries of the former Soviet Union would weaken the pressure from Eastern European countries for early admission to NATO.
Russia has no need for a military union with Ukraine, Belarus or Moldova: no one is threatening it from the West. What it needs first and foremost is cooperation with Ukraine on reducing nuclear arms.
The economic scenario I propose might well persuade the U.S. to reduce its financial aid to Russia (including aid through international financial institutions) and to increase aid proportionately to other former Soviet countries. In particular, money could go to Ukraine or Belarus (on condition of faster market reforms) to support their balance of trade with Russia.
Any support that opened markets for Russia is more beneficial than direct aid. It would stimulate production in Russia. This would let the Russians work instead of receiving handouts. And it would support 25 million Russians living in the near-abroad.
Is economic integration without political integration possible? Yes. But Russia must understand that it must refrain from any political union with Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova whatsoever -- even if these states invite it -- because there would be only two possible outcomes: failure or neo-imperialism.
In view of the discomforting neo-imperialist thinking that is arising in Russia, formation of an economic bloc is the only reasonable counterweight.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The World: Cardoso, the Global Salesman;
Brazil Thinks Big, Again

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: BRASILIA

 BODY:
FOR only the second time since 1960, Brazil held presidential elections last week. But voting in the hemisphere's second largest democracy -- which brought to power Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a former Foreign Minister and Finance Minister with big plans -- failed to draw any television crews from the hemisphere's largest democracy, the United States. Without a military coup to grab headlines or a nuclear bomb to inspire fear, Brazil is huge in just about everything but the amount of outside interest it generates.
It has always been thus, it seems. Regardless of the global aspirations its leaders proclaimed and the country's obvious potential in resources, Brazil long failed to find the right political structure or, when it did, the right person to lead it from the third world to the world stage. First there were two decades of clunky military rule, then a transition to direct voting leading to the election of a youthful, smooth-talker who proved too smooth -- that is to say corrupt -- followed finally by his replacement with a safe but lackluster caretaker. 
 With these unsatisfactory experiences behind them, many Brazilians now figure they have learned a thing or two and are pointing not only to Mr. Cardoso's election but to Brazil's swift opening to foreign imports and investment as evidence the country just may at last be headed for the big time.
 
Insular No More
 On the economic side, Brazil has abandoned decades of insular protectionism, slashing import tariffs to an average level of 14 percent. Responding speedily, foreign traders, largely Americans, have increased imports to Brazil by 50 percent in two years. With other free market changes cutting inflation and encouraging growth, foreign investment has doubled in two years.
"American businessmen are faster than American journalists," said Brazil's Ambassador to the United States, Paulo Tarso Flecha de Lima.
On the political side, Brazil will have a cosmopolitan salesman as leader when Mr. Cardoso takes office next year.
The 63-year-old President-elect (who handily defeated the leftist Luis Inacia Lula da Silva) speaks fluent English, French and Spanish, and was Brazil's Foreign Minister -- the first to rise to the presidency. He also has visited 34 countries, and he is the first Brazilian president in memory to have lived overseas -- in Chile, France and the United States.
The contrast with the past is striking. From 1964 to 1985, Brazil was run by nationalistic generals (under whose rule Mr. Cardoso, a former professor, was exiled, imprisoned and blacklisted), and one military president's world experience was limited to service as a military attache in Uruguay. Itamar Franco, Brazil's current president, who is completing the term of the suave Fernando Collor de Mello, whom Parliament forced out 1992 in a huge corruption scandal, does not like to fly in airplanes, speaks only Portuguese and routinely cancels foreign trips on short notice. Two weeks ago, he canceled a trip to New York to address the United Nations General Assembly. In fact, although the United States is Brazil's largest foreign investor and trading partner, he has never visited the United States.
Other factors have prolonged Brazil's insularity. Defaults on foreign debt payments soured international relations until a restructuring was finally agreed upon last April. Brazil has also been on the defensive on social and environmental issues -- killings of street youths, invasions of Indian lands and the destruction of the Amazon rain forest.
But Brazilian diplomats assert that while the country makes headway on social and environmental issues, economic issues are likely to loom of greater importance to the outside world, as they have with China. Indeed, Brazil is one of 10 "big emerging markets" identified as targets for trade and investment by the United States Commerce Department.
 
More Assertive
 "In Asia, China is in that category," said Jeffrey E. Garten, United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. "In this hemisphere, we think it is Brazil."
Other nations are coming to similar conclusions. In the last year, nine British ministers have traveled here. Peter W. Heap, the British Ambassador, said: "Each has arrived skeptical or hesitant. Each has gone away dumbfounded or spellbound."
With a World Cup soccer victory last July restoring Brazilians' self-esteem and a new economic plan -- Mr. Cardoso's -- restoring credibility to their currency, Brazilians are more assertive in foreign affairs.
At home, Brazil positions itself, like an industrial queen bee, in the middle of a South American free trade zone that echoes the North American Free Trade Agreement among Canada, Mexico and the United States. Starting Jan. 1, virtually all trade will be duty-free between Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay. Last month, Chile and Bolivia started talks on association. Next week, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela are to start talks.
In international forums, Brazil increasingly speaks up. At the United Nations last week, Foreign Minister Celso Amorim announced that Brazil wants a seat on an expanded Security Council.
Of course, the bubble could burst if the new leadership fails to meet the buoyed expectations of the Brazilian masses -- say, if the nation's economic growth, forecast at a robust 5 percent annually for the next few years, fails to narrow the huge disparities in income between the relatively few well-off and the majority who are wrenchingly poor.
But then, Brazilians have been disappointed before.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet;
Dialogue That Lingers: 'Hi, Mom.' 'Hi, Pop.' 'Hi, David.' 'Hi, Rick.'

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
WHAT is the original definition of an adventure in the world of television? Being pushed out of a helicopter by an assassin, only to be saved by a sky-diving sidekick? Nah. Attempting vehicular homicide on your ex-husband, and framing his other ex-wife for it? Nope. An adventure, in the root television meaning of the word, is Harriet Nelson getting Ozzie to fix the broken kitchen door.
 Or maybe it's Ozzie and Harriet deciding that David, their teen-age son, is old enough to have a key to the house. Or refereeing when David complains that his kid brother Rick's rock music keeps him from studying symphony records. That was how Ozzie and his co-writers, Don Nelson, Bill Davenport and Ben Gershman, defined adventure.
 
 Harriet, she of the sweetly hoarse voice and sunny smile, died last week at the age of 85, leaving David Nelson, now 57, the sole member of the family that sought to teach the country about families. For 14 years, from 1952 to 1966, "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" was broadcast by ABC-TV, becoming television's longest-running situation comedy and an epic tribute to family tribulations, as they were then understood.
 Alex McNeil, a lawyer and television historian in Boston, argues that "they never had an adventure." One could argue that we've just suffered from adventure inflation since then. Meet the Nelsons, and decide. FELICITY BARRINGER
 In the show's early years, the advertisements for kitchen appliances or hospital-tested antacids were melded into the leitmotif of family life. This 1952 episode, titled "The Pancake Mix," begins with Harriet on the telephone to the drugstore, saying, "Say, would you please include a couple of large bottles of Listerine with our order? Yes, please. It's just wonderful for keeping those colds away."
 Then the announcer took over:
 Listerine Antiseptic, Listerine toothpaste and Pro-phy-lac-tic toothbrushes present America's favorite family comedy, "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet." So settle back in your easy chairs and enjoy another delightful half-hour with all the Nelsons.
 Ozzie Nelson, of course, plays the part of the head of the Nelson household, Ozzie. And here's his lovely wife, Harriet Nelson, who keeps the family on an even keel. Hello, Harriet. The smiling young teen-ager we now see is David Nelson, older of the two Nelson boys and played by David Nelson. And here we have the youngest of the Nelsons, the little guy with the twinkle in his eye, Ricky Nelson, played by Ricky Nelson.
 Ozzie and the boys are at breakfast. Harriet is at the stove.
 HARRIET: And there's a couple more pancakes here, if you guys are ready.
 DAVID: They sure do taste good, Mom.
 RICK: Yeah, they sure do, Mom.
 OZZIE: Would you pass me the syrup, please, Rick?
 DAVID: Boy, nobody can make pancakes like Mom.
 RICK: Nobody can eat like Pop.
 OZZIE: Just a second, young fellow. Think you're doing pretty well yourself for such a little guy.
 HARRIET: I'll keep making them as long as you guys keep eating them.
 DAVID: They sure are good, Mom.
 HARRIET: That's what I like to hear. What's the verdict from dear old Dad?
 OZZIE: Well, evidently you haven't been counting or you'd know that dear old Dad took on about five pounds of pancakes this morning. I'll take another one right now.
 RICK: Can I have a couple more, Mom?
 HARRIET: Yes, you bet you can. Help yourself. You know I really hate to admit this, but I can't take all the credit for these pancakes this morning.
 OZZIE: Well, all we did was eat them.
 HARRIET: Well, what I mean is I didn't exactly make these myself. They came already prepared.
 DAVID: Oh?
 OZZIE: Is that something new?
 HARRIET: Well this is the first time I've tried to make them this way. You don't have to mix any pancake batter. It's already mixed for you. . . .
 RICK: What's this about money?
 OZZIE: Where?
 RICK: Right here on the box.
 OZZIE (reading): "If you are not absolutely satisfied that Hasty-Tasty makes the finest pancakes that you've ever eaten, then return the unused portion and we will cheerfully give you double your money back."
 DAVID: Double your money back?
 RICK: Oh boy, we're rich, Pop! (With a twinkle in his eye) Lucky we didn't like them, huh?
 OZZIE: Now, wait a second. Not so fast.
 Rick calculates that returning the 47-cent box would net him 94 cents. A few scenes later, Ozzie lectures Harriet about the virtues of holding people to their word, saying he heard someone actually returned a box of Hasty-Tasty pancake mix.
 OZZIE: Oh, hi, Rick. I was just telling your mother, somebody'd come into the grocery store down there and demanded double his money back, didn't like the pancakes. I'd just said I'd like to meet the man and shake him by the hand.
 RICK: Honest, Pop?
 OZZIE: Well, sure.
 RICK: Put 'er there, ol' buddy.
 OZZIE: You mean you were the guy?
 RICK: Sure, I keep telling you. I don't mess around, boy.
 The dramatic conflict in another episode, also from 1952, was constructed around two chairs delivered to the Nelsons by mistake. Ozzie calls the store.
 OZZIE: Oh, hello. My name is Nelson. . . . A couple of large living room chairs were delivered to our house when there was nobody home. That is, only our boys were home. They let the men in. . . .
 HARRIET: Get to the point, dear.
 CLERK: Now, what's this about the chairs, please?
 OZZIE: Aahh, well, they were delivered to our house, but we didn't order them. . . .
 CLERK: What was the name again, please?
 OZZIE: Nelson. Ozzie Nelson.
 CLERK: Oh thank you Mr. Nelson. . . .
 OZZIE: Just one thing, though. The name on the receipt will be David, David Nelson. They were sent to Ozzie Nelson but David signed for them.
 CLERK: I see. Is that R -- Robert?
OZZIE: R?
 CLERK: Did you say they were ordered by R. Z. Nelson?
 OZZIE: No, no, no, no, no. They were ordered by Ozzie Nelson. Not R. Z. Aaaaah, like in gargle.
 CLERK: I'm terribly sorry. . . . The chairs were ordered by this Mr. Gargie Nelson?
 OZZIE: They were not ordered by Gargie. . . . In the first place, there's nobody in the world named Gargie Nelson. Miss, let's assume for the moment that there is such a person as Gargie Nelson. He did not order the chairs.
 CLERK: That's what you said. They were ordered by David Nelson.
 OZZIE: No, no, no, no. David is the boy who signed for them.
 CLERK: I see. That David was at Gargie Nelson's house at the time the chairs arrived.
 OZZIE: That's right. David is my son. I'm Gargie. Now, at your convenience would you please stop by and pick up the two chairs?

HEADLINE: PENTAGON MOVING A FORCE OF 4,000 TO GUARD KUWAIT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The United States ordered 4,000 Army troops to Kuwait today as Iraqi forces massed near the Kuwaiti border.
The Pentagon announced the move as intelligence reports indicated that Iraq's forces near Kuwait had grown to about 50,000 troops, some of whom have moved within 12 miles of the border. 
 Lieut. Gen. Jack Sheehan of the Marines, who is director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the Iraqi forces gathering near Kuwait included about 14,000 elite Republican Guard soldiers and presented a clear threat to Kuwait.
The American military deployments ordered on Friday and today are both a message to Baghdad not to attack and a hedge in case an attack does occur. To make clear what the stakes are, President Clinton, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Defense Secretary William J. Perry and General Sheehan all bluntly warned Iraq against attacking.
"I want to make it clear one more time," Mr. Clinton said. "It would be a grave error for Iraq to repeat the mistakes of the past or to misjudge either American will or American power."
The United Nations Security Council also put Baghdad on notice that Kuwait would be defended.
In addition to the 4,000-member Army task force of the 24th Mechanized Division from Fort Stewart, Ga., the Pentagon is sending two Patriot anti-missile batteries to Saudi Arabia.
American officials said that other units had been put on alert and that additional military deployments might be ordered soon. The units ordered to be ready to deploy include the remainder of the 24th Mechanized Division, an armored unit that fought in the Persian Gulf war, a wing of Air Force combat planes, and the First Marine Expeditionary Force at Camp Pendleton, Calif.
American officials said Mr. Perry and Gen. John M. D. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, would be stopping at the United States Central Command Headquarters in Tampa, Fla., while returning from Haiti, to review the situation in the gulf and decide what additional deployments were needed.
The Central Command, which is led by Gen. Binford Peay of the Army, who commanded the 101st Airborne Division in the Persian Gulf war, has responsibility for American military operations in the Middle East. Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to Washington, also visited the command's headquarters today to consult with American military officials.
Some American officials said the Iraqi moves were probably no more than a bluff on the part of President Saddam Hussein, aimed at coercing the Security Council to lift economic sanctions. By this view, Iraq's intention is to demonstrate that it still has the military ability to stir up trouble if the sanctions are not removed. The United Nations commission overseeing the disarmament of Iraq is scheduled to report to the Security Council on Monday, putting the issue of removing the sanctions squarely on the table.
While some officials said Iraq was posturing or planning a small provocative move, others said they were reluctant to interpret Mr. Hussein's intentions. One worry is that Mr. Hussein may have concluded that the United States is tied down in Haiti, reluctant to involve itself in another military confrontation in the gulf and therefore believes that this is the time to strike. Officials well recall how top members of the Bush Administration believed that Mr. Hussein was posturing before his invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
"He could be bluffing, but we have to assume the worst," a senior Administration official said. "We just have to play it as it comes and be ready for anything."
In a closed session of the Security Council, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States delegate to the United Nations, warned that if Iraq continued its military preparations, it could amass a force of 60,000 men and 1,000 tanks within striking distance of Kuwait.
The Iraqi troops south of Basra or heading there include forces from the Hammurabi division, the Nida division and the Adnan division, all Republican Guard units that represent the most capable and loyal troops in the Iraqi Army.
Adding to the Clinton Administration's anxieties is the fact that the United States now has a comparatively tiny military presence in the gulf region -- about 12,000 troops. Moreover, it currently has only two ships in the region that are able to launch cruise missiles. And while the United States has about 80 planes in Saudi Arabia, it only has about two dozen F-16 and F-15E planes able to drop bombs. No A-10 antitank planes or F-117 "stealth" fighters are there.
Because the American ability to defend Kuwait is so limited, the Pentagon did not promise today that it could stop an Iraqi attack if one were launched right away. Rather, Pentagon officials spoke in terms of "punishing" the Iraqis if they crossed the Kuwait border. The officials today issued a pointed warning that an Iraqi attack on Kuwait would prompt an American cruise missile attack against Baghdad.
"We are clearly in a position right now that if Saddam Hussein does something, we can punish those forces," General Sheehan told reporters. "We clearly have the capacity to go to downtown Baghdad. And as I said before, that's one of the lessons I hope Saddam learned the last time we did this."
General Sheehan said that when additional naval reinforcements arrived, the United States would have about 200 cruise missiles in the region. The 4,000 Army troops that are being sent will use tanks and other military equipment stored in Kuwait.
Administration officials said Iraq's apparent efforts to precipitate a crisis were likely to backfire at the United Nations. Instead of setting a date for lifting the sanctions, the Security Council is likely to deliver a firm rebuff, American officials said.
To win support in the Security Council, Ms. Albright showed five spy satellite photos. An American official said the photographs showed a T-72 tank and units from the Hammurabi division, which escaped the allied attack during the Persian Gulf war, near the Kuwaiti border.
After the Council meeting, the British representative, Sir David Hannay, issued a statement on behalf of the Council, reaffirming the United Nations' commitment "to the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Kuwait."
The Council also urged the United Nations observer mission in Kuwait to report any violations of the border and expressed concern over Iraq's threat to prevent United Nations monitoring of its military sites if the Council did not ease the economic sanctions on Iraq.
The sanctions imposed on Iraq include a ban on oil exports and other bans on other types of trade. An exception is made for imports of food, medicine and relief supplies. The ban is enforced by a naval blockade, and no air traffic is allowed in or out of Iraq.
In an effort to underscore the Administration's resolve, President Clinton and top officials tried to speak with a command voice.
Mr. Christopher, who left today for a trip to the Middle East, added, "Current Iraqi troop movements and recent statements by Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council must not be allowed to intimidate either Iraq's neighbors or the United Nations Security Council."
Iraqi officials have insisted that their actions are peaceful. "Iraq is a sovereign state," said Nizar Hamdoon, the Iraqi delegate to the United Nations. "It has all the rights to move its troops within its territories and borders."
But Iraqi diplomats gave similar assurances before Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
The Administration took the first steps to strengthen its military force in the Persian Gulf region on Friday. Acting on the recommendations of General Peay, the White House ordered the aircraft carrier George Washington to sail to the Red Sea, along with other warships.
It also ordered an amphibious force of 2,000 Marines to the northern Persian Gulf. It dispatched huge floating warehouses full of tanks and weapons to sail from Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean to the gulf.

HEADLINE: Iraq Threatens to End U.N. Role If Oil Export Ban Is Not Lifted

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Iraq said today that it did not want "war or military confrontation" with the United States, but it threatened to end its cooperation with the United Nations if a crippling ban on its oil exports was not lifted.
"We are not seeking war or military confrontation at all," said the Government newspaper al-Jumhouriya in a front-page editorial. "But we need to put an end to the suffering of our people by lifting the sanctions through any means." 
 Fighting with the United States would "aggravate the suffering of the Iraqi people," the newspaper said. "But if America chose to commit a new military aggression, then we will be obliged to defend ourselves."
Iraq issued the statement as the United States and Britain moved military forces into position to counter any possible threat by Iraqi troops, who have been moving toward the border in recent days. An official spokesman for the Ministry of Culture and Information neither confirmed nor denied the reports of an Iraqi military buildup in the south.
The newspaper report said the United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990 had led to "widespread poverty, rampant crime, immorality and are causing the society to disintegrate."
Spelling out for the first time what action Iraq might take if the oil embargo were not lifted, the newspaper said, "The process to save the Iraqi people may start by reconsidering cooperation with the United Nations and canceling all that has been agreed on or implemented."
This apparently meant that Iraq would not allow the monitoring system of its arms industry already installed by the United Nations to go ahead and would not abide by cease-fire resolutions that prevented Iraq from rearming itself. The economic sanctions were imposed at the end of the Persian Gulf war.
In Baghdad there were few signs of a country preparing itself for war although there was some hurried buying of staple foods, but no new price rises.
"If sanctions remain, there will be starvation," said Jaleel Abdulnabi, a shopkeeper.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
Clinton and Allies Rediscover Their Voice in Writing Epitaph for Congress

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
With Republicans unabashedly claiming credit for tying Congress up in knots, Democrats acted almost like mute bystanders -- until now.
For months, Democrats seemed to have lost their voice as Republicans rolled over them in Congress. As long as Democrats, who control both chambers, were trying to reach legislative accommodation with the Republicans, they could not afford to trash them. Moreover, the party seemed stunned into silence by predictions of big Republican gains in November and of a Democratic President who seemed to be a political untouchable. 
 But as members of the 103d Congress headed home today to campaign, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the departing majority leader, picked up the themes that President Clinton voiced on Friday.
"Change is never easy or achieved without resistance and opposition," Mr. Mitchell said on the Senate floor, hailing enactment of President Clinton's deficit-reduction program and economic growth plan as "by far the most important action" of the 103d Congress.
For some, the Democrats' new-found voice appeared like water in the desert.
"Out here in the hinterlands," said Mark McKinnon, a Democratic campaign consultant based in Austin, Tex., "we feel that the Republicans have been finger-painting all over us for months, and it's high time we threw some paint back in their faces. We're delighted."
When asked if this would be enough to get the Democrats back on track, Mr. McKinnon demurred. "In politics," he said, "doing something is always better than doing nothing."
As the Democrats try to overcome weeks of sour news about Congress's inability to act and its basement-level approval ratings, the centerpiece of their message is that change is always difficult but that they have the courage to try to bring it about.
Their thrust will be to draw a distinction between the parties, portraying themselves, as President Clinton did in his 1992 campaign, as the agents of change and casting the Republicans as throwbacks to an era when the rich got richer. The Republican's "Contract with America" reinforces those differences, the Democrats say, and they intend to use the contract against Republican candidates as the campaign season moves into its final weeks. Hundreds of Republican incumbents and candidates signed the contract on Sept. 27, promising tax cuts, more military spending and a balanced-budget amendment in the first 100 days of the next Congress if Republicans won a majority in the House.
President Clinton, for instance, said at a news conference on Friday, "The message I have to say is, what is the direction you want?"
Democrats, the President said, are fighting for the future of ordinary people by passing bills like family leave and making college loans more available, while Republicans, he continued, are offering nothing more than Reaganomics, higher deficits and cuts in Medicare.
The message was reiterated throughout the day on Friday. At a breakfast with reporters, the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, boasted of the Administration's record. And finally, after being pummeled on the House and Senate floors for the last several weeks by the increasingly bold Republican minority, Democratic leaders pointedly blamed Republicans for foiling their best-laid plans.
The Democrats admittedly had been doing nothing. Stymied on Capitol Hill, they lashed out at the news media and looked increasingly ineffective as the Republicans staged a filibuster frenzy that choked off several Democratic initiatives.
But all that changed, Democratic officials said, when more than 350 Republicans running for Congress gathered outside the Capitol 11 days ago and signed the Contract with America.
Examining the contract, the forlorn Democrats suddenly sounded as if they had found the Hope Diamond.
"There is not a night that I don't thank God for the contract," said Paul Begala, a Democratic consultant and political adviser to President Clinton. "It is the greatest gift to the Democratic Party since Medicare."
Tony Coelho, the former Democratic congressman who is taking over the helm of the Democratic National Committee after this fall's elections, said: "That was our break. We think we can win on it."
Democrats are casting the contract as a retread of Reaganomics, the mere mention of which makes focus groups blanch, Mr. Coelho said.
"People immediately understand what Reaganomics means -- tax benefits for the wealthy, deficit increases and cuts in programs for seniors and veterans," he said. "It doesn't take any coaching. They gave us a vehicle we do not have to educate people on."
Mr. Coelho said the contract, put together by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, and Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster who worked for Ross Perot's independent Presidential bid in 1992, was intended to appeal to Perot voters but will backfire.
"It has given us something to go to our base with and get our base voter, who was not motivated before, to come out," he said, noting that the contract provided a clear difference between the parties -- a distinction the Democrats had been unable to draw on their own. "Our base voter is now motivated, and I think it will make the difference. This is the beginning of the campaign. We are engaged."
The party plans to begin a television advertising campaign next week taking aim at the contract, one that all Democrats can use.
Still, they must overcome the message that Republicans have been hammering home, virtually unchallenged, since the summer: that Republicans have been saving the country from bad Democratic legislation.
Despite their minority status, the Republicans have virtually controlled the legislative agenda since they stalled the crime bill in July. The President responded by excoriating the Republicans, a tactic that got him nowhere. Only by meeting some Republican demands, including those of freshmen, did he eventually win over enough votes to pass the crime bill -- and in the process, set a pattern that emboldened the minority.
Mike Casey, a spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, explained the party's delayed response to Republican attacks by saying the Democrats had been committed to governing, not politics.
"Call us crazy," he said, "but we were actually trying to accomplish some things, and that was given a higher priority than trying to out-napalm Newt Gingrich." But now that the Republicans have "thrown sand in the engine and brought everything to a halt," he said, "they need to be held accountable for their obstructionist actions."
Some skittish Democrats worry that the party's counteroffensive is too little too late. Others are more optimistic, suggesting that the Republicans may have overreached.
"No question, the Republicans had the upper hand," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster. "But now, individual Democrats can go home and say, 'I'm as mad as you are.' "
The end of the legislative session has provided as much of an opening for the Democrats to get organized as the contract has.
"Two or three weeks ago, people were in a panic," said a Democratic operative, speaking on condition of anonymity, referring to Democratic candidates. "Now they're thinking: 'Hey, all is not lost. There's the contract. And we're going home.' "
While incumbents were still in Washington, they would naturally be linked with Congress and national issues -- and with President Clinton. But once home, they believe, they will fare better by running on local issues, and they are determined not to let Republicans "nationalize" their campaigns.
Mr. Begala said the challenge would now be to link the Contract with America with what the Republicans have been doing in Congress.
"They were talking about obstructionism in the service of a cause," he said. "That cause was protecting privilege and power and hurting people. The Republicans gloat about killing health care, but a million people have lost their health care in the last year. This whole idea flows into the Reaganomics of the contract. We will use it."
Until the contract came along, Mr. Coelho said, "Democratic voters were disgusted with Democrats and sitting at home, and Republicans were feeling fabulous and aggressive and ready to go. Now, Democrats are fighting, and Democrats are going to be turned on. This will be an interesting and engaging four weeks."

HEADLINE: A Consumer Watchdog Is Eliminated

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J.

 BODY:
Iris E. Greene, a nurse's aide, desperately needed help several years ago after she had paid usurious interest rates -- $3,300 in installments for $2,800 worth of furniture -- at a store here, and still had it repossessed for having missed a few payments following a heart attack. "I cried as they carried it away," Ms. Greene recalled.
A state agency, the Department of the Public Advocate, stepped in. The department, New Jersey's chief consumer advocate, convinced the State Attorney General to go to court on Ms. Greene's behalf and, last March, a judge ruled in her favor. 
 But the Public Advocate was unable to press for new state regulations that would protect all New Jersey consumers against similar losses, because the agency itself fell victim to changing priorities in New Jersey and the nation.
To help cope with budget problems in 1991 and 1992, Democratic leaders in Trenton decided to eliminate the agency's consumer protection programs, which had handled everything from AIDS discrimination to furniture-store scams. Then, in July, the state's Republican leaders eliminated the Public Advocate entirely.
Consumer advocates and civil libertarians mourn the agency's demise, saying that New Jersey, which had been an early pioneer in consumer protection, was now following a pack of other state and local governments in abandoning support for consumer programs.
The fiscal realities of the 1990's have been a prime reason for the cutbacks. But consumer leaders contend that the programs have also been targeted for elimination by conservative politicians, whose free-market philosophy has no place for a public agency that represents the special interests of consumers.
"The Public Advocate was the crown jewel of consumer and taxpayer protection in state governments," said Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate. "Imagine destroying a tiny government department whose sole function was to make the rest of the bureaucracy more responsive, more efficient and more fair. It's pretty sad."
But the New Jersey officials who eliminated the Public Advocate say that the reorganization will serve consumers and taxpayers.
"In our view, nothing that was done rises to the level of undercutting or eroding the rights of consumers in this state," said Carl Golden, a spokesman for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. "The rationale for abolishing the agency, apart from saving a million or two a year, was the feeling on the part of the Governor, and the Legislature agreed, that its functions could be carried out within existing agencies."
Across the region and the nation, consumer-protection agencies have not weathered the recession well. Connecticut's Consumer Protection Department has had its budget reduced by one-third since 1991, to $8 million this year. The New York Consumer Protection Board had five lawyers practicing consumer law four years ago, but now has only two.
"There is no question that all around the country there has been a retrenchment of governmental consumer-protection services," said Richard M. Kessel, the New York board's executive director.
The Alaska Attorney General closed its seven consumer-protection offices. Consumer-protection agencies have also been closed in recent years in Boston, Cleveland, Dallas, Syracuse and dozens of other cities and counties. In New Jersey, county offices have closed in Sussex and Morris, and budgets have been slashed in Camden and Bergen.
"We used to mediate consumer complaints, but now we tell people to get an attorney or go to Small Claims Court," said Patricia M. Tuck, Camden's director of consumer affairs. In 1990, her agency had a staff of nine including five investigators; today it is just Ms. Tuck, her secretary and a college intern.
The loss of New Jersey's Public Advocate is considered a stunning defeat for the consumer movement, because the agency had much more independence and authority than comparable agencies in other states.
Wilfredo Caraballo, who served as Public Advocate from 1990 to 1992, says that the agency was eliminated principally because of its success in pursuing civil rights cases, including ones that forced suburbs to include low-income housing in new developments and others that forced school districts to consider consolidation to achieve racial balance.
"Some legislators didn't like it that we won cases," Mr. Caraballo said. "But by winning, we were vindicating people's rights."
But State Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Republican from Englewood Cliffs who sponsored the Whitman plan, argues that a nuisance has been eliminated.
"The Public Advocate would sue other branches of government for the sake of suing," Mr. Cardinale said. "And they would frequently win because the courts were of the same philosophical bent."
Gov. Brendan T. Byrne created the Public Advocate 20 years ago in the aftermath of Watergate and investigations of political corruption in New Jersey. The agency subsumed the existing office of Public Defender, which represented poor defendants in criminal trials. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the Republican-led Legislature eliminated the Public Advocate on the grounds that a cabinet-level agency was unnecessary and too litigious.
But the dismemberment of the Public Advocate's seven divisions clearly diminished consumers' voice in state government, many consumer advocates say. Under the reorganization, only the Office of Public Defender, which is mandated by law, escaped major alteration.
The division of public interest advocacy and the division of citizen complaints, which had already lost their funding under Gov. Jim Florio, were entirely eliminated in July.
The division of public interest advocacy, which was essentially the nation's first and only state-supported public interest law firm, once had the authority to sue just about anyone in the state, including the governor. In more than 2,000 lawsuits over 20 years, the division won both friends and enemies by seeking to enforce state and Federal laws governing things like consumer fraud, exclusionary zoning in the suburbs, racial integration in city schools and discriminatory beach fees that shore communities charged nonresidents.
Some other divisions were shifted to other agencies, but with their budgets and missions greatly reduced. For example, the rate council division was once the official advocate for utility consumers. A new division was created to represent residential, commercial and industrial customers. Called the ratepayer advocate, it has a new mandate: to try to accommodate the needs of utilities and use litigation as a last resort.
The state privatized two other divisions of the Public Advocate, spinning them off as a Federally funded nonprofit organization with no state support other than some office space in Trenton. The divisions were developmental disabilities, which represents people with physical and learning disabilities, and mental health advocacy, which represents patients in mental hospitals.
The new organization, called New Jersey Protection and Advocacy, will continue to press for systemwide improvements in special education and mental health programs, but it has sharply curtailed its advocacy services for individual clients, said Sarah H. Mitchell, the director of the new organization.
The division of inmate advocacy, which had acted as an ombudsman for inmates, has been restricted to completing a half-dozen class-action lawsuits that primarily deal with overcrowded conditions in county jails and state prisons.
Susan Remis Silver, director of the division, said that phasing out her agency was shortsighted and not cost-effective. "The reason my office was created was to prevent riots," she said.

HEADLINE: Can Olympic Torch Ignite Atlanta Reconstruction?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 8

 BODY:
First a quixotic pipe dream, then an exhilarating but distant reality, the 1996 Summer Olympic Games have suddenly become a juggernaut transforming the look and feel of Atlanta.
But as the pieces come together for the $1.6 billion Olympiad, the largest extravaganza any American city has ever staged, it remains unclear whether the games will produce anything resembling the inner-city revitalization that many here envisioned when Atlanta was awarded the games four years ago. 
 The approval last week of a $50 million, 60-acre Centennial Park that will be the heart of a 100-acre public space for the games is only the most recent sign that fund raising and construction are largely on track for the games' scheduled opening on July 19, 1996. The Atlanta Olympics are expected to draw 2 million people, generate $5 billion in economic activity and be twice the size of the 1984 games in Los Angeles.
"We've divided the pie, we've made virtually all the deals, and you can already feel the anticipation that this is going to happen, this is going to be great," said Billy Payne, president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games. "People realize, my goodness, we are transforming our community."
But in a city where former Mayor Maynard Jackson used to talk about the "twin peaks of Atlanta's Mount Olympus" -- the first a successful staging of the games, the second an extensive revitalization program -- the second peak remains largely speculative and the subject of mounting anxiety as opening day draws ever closer.
City officials say that winning the right to stage the Olympics set off inflated expectations, but that Olympics development is already making Atlanta a better place.
"Anybody who believes the Olympics is an anti-poverty program is not being realistic," said Mayor Bill Campbell. "But anyone with any sense at all will see that the life of virtually everyone in Atlanta will be enhanced tremendously by hosting the games."
But some critics say the development is too little, too late and often of the wrong kind.
"I think we've lost a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," said the Rev. Timothy McDonald, co-chairman of the Atlanta Olympic Conscience Coalition, which has advocated more housing and development in inner-city neighborhoods. "When it comes to the poor," he added, the corporate and civic forces behind the games "know how to get silent in seven different languages."
Officials of the local Olympic committee say that there is little margin for error in either time or dollars, but that Olympic plans are proceeding roughly on schedule. An auditor's report this summer said the committee would at least break even on the games. Construction is well under way at the $169 million Olympic Village, which will eventually become student housing at the Georgia Institute of Technology, and a new $170 million stadium, which will become a new home for the Atlanta Braves baseball team.
And though Peachtree Street will never be confused with the Ramblas, the grand promenade that was part of Barcelona's dazzling backdrop for the 1992 games, Atlanta will now have the just-approved Centennial Park as a much-needed gathering place for the '96 games.
It will be built by bulldozing a ragged area dominated by small shops and light industrial buildings. In addition, the adjacent area will include a 14-acre amusement park developed by the Coca-Cola Company and a 20-acre privately developed "global village" called '96 Expo.
The road to the games is certain to be bumpy, even without considering the logistical and traffic nightmare of staging events in the July Georgia heat. Over the next month the Olympic committee will begin negotiating with the city over millions of dollars of Olympics-related public services. Olympic organizers have pledged that the games will be staged with privately raised money. But city officials and the Olympic committee are likely to have differing views on what city services should be covered by the committee and how much those costs should be offset by new revenue like increased sales or hotel taxes.
John A. Lucas, a professor and expert on the Olympics at Pennsylvania State University, said he doubts whether Atlanta can become the only Olympiad other than Los Angeles to come up with enough private financing to meet all the costs of staging the games.
"I think they're going to pull off a very excellent Olympics games, but they're going to do it by a gnat's tooth, by a whisker," Professor Lucas said. "In my opinion they will lose money rather than make money. The Olympics is not a money-making venture."
For now, most signs are positive for projects and fund-raising directly tied to putting on the Olympic events. But the outlook is less certain for using the games to revitalize Atlanta. City officials are scrambling to capitalize on the games without using any of the money being raised by the Olympic committee.
Amid concerns that Atlanta would not even repair decrepit streets and sewer systems in time for the games, the city this summer passed a $149.9 million bond referendum. More than $17 million will go toward a goal of $65 million (the rest to come from other sources) for street and thoroughfare improvements downtown and in neighborhoods nearby.
But so far only $37 million of the $65 million has been raised. An earlier financing proposal, to levy a surcharge on tickets, meals, parking and hotels for a $100 million Olympic Legacy Trust Fund for housing and other local needs, went nowhere. The site for Centennial Park has virtually no permanent residents, but small businesses and two homeless shelters will be displaced.
Critics say the park will chiefly benefit the games and Coca-Cola, the corporate giant whose environs will undergo a massive dose of urban renewal. They say the city's ability to come up with $50 million for the park, while other projects languish, reflects the city's real priorities.
"We've done amazing things in this community, and will continue to do so, but not for the people I serve," said Anita Beaty, co-chairwoman of the Olympic Conscience Coalition.
But others see advantages even for the poor. There is a $42 million facelift for the Techwood/Clark Howell Homes housing project near Georgia Tech. Habitat for Humanity is planning to build 100 houses. In the Summerhill neighborhood, near the Olympic stadium, redevelopment plans call for 300 new housing units.
The Olympic Committee is awarding about a third of its contracts to minority concerns. And city officials say their street and parks projects will provide the underpinning for neighborhood revitalization in the future. In addition, the Olympic designation helped provide momentum for former President Jimmy Carter's Atlanta Project to aid inner-city neighborhoods.
Feelings are mixed, but even in the frayed neighborhoods near the Olympic sites, people tend to be more supportive than not of the coming extravaganza.
"You know, even when Christ was here, not everybody liked him either," said the Rev. John H. Pullin, who lives in the Peoplestown neighborhood near the stadium.
Indeed, the city's Olympic-related development, once derided as a bust, is finally coming together. But the question asked here is how much will get done in the time remaining.
"The date on the tip of everyone's tongue is July 1996, but the real date is January 1995, because if you haven't begun by 1995, you cannot possibly meet a July 1996 deadline," said Clara Axam, president of the Corporation for Olympic Development, which coordinates Olympics building projects. "There's a real sense of urgency for getting things tied down, started and completed."

HEADLINE: 4 Are Indicted in Scheme Using Tribe to Obtain U.S. Equipment

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SISSETON, S.D., Oct. 8

 BODY:
To Russell Hawkins, the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991 was the beginning of a bonanza.
When the war ended, the Government had a large amount of heavy equipment it no longer needed. Mr. Hawkins, who had been the chairman of the Sisseton-Wahpeton Sioux Tribe for nearly a decade, learned that he could use the tribe's name to get much of the equipment free. 
 In the next two years, prosecutors say, people connected to Mr. Hawkins received $63 million in Government equipment, including earth movers, all in the name of helping the unemployed among the 9,200-member tribe.
But now four men and one company have been indicted in the transactions, and a Federal investigation is continuing. Records show the lion's share of proceeds went to Mr. Hawkins's non-Indian business associates. The tribe never saw millions of dollars' worth of gear ordered in its name. And it sold other equipment worth millions for a small fraction of its worth.
All the while, the Bureau of Indian Affairs watched and did nothing until this February, records show. Although it is the agency's job to make sure that Indian tribes run their affairs legally, its officials either ignored the equipment sales or actively participated, records show.
"What they did by turning a blind eye to it was that they sanctioned it," said Andrew Laverdure, a top agency administrator in Sisseton at the time. "They were aware because we told them about it."
The chain of events being investigated began in 1990, when Mr. Hawkins hired Roger Raether to obtain surplus food and clothing for tribal members. When Mr. Raether discovered that the tribe had no money to pay for shipping the material to the Lake Traverse Reservation, Mr. Hawkins suggested obtaining and reselling Government equipment to raise money, court records show Mr. Raether said.
Thus Dakota Machinery Exchange was born.
Two non-Indians, Francis Oseby and Donald Jerke, both of Sioux Falls, S.D., and a tribe member, Warren Barse, formed the company in April 1991, on the same day the tribe's lawyer wrote to Mr. Hawkins saying the plans were legal.
The plan was for Mr. Raether and Mr. Oseby to look for surplus equipment and the tribe to obtain it. The company was then expected to buy it from the tribe, paying pennies on the dollar for equipment worth millions.
For example, the company paid the tribe just $500 for a semi-tractor worth more than $68,000. The truck was among $10 million in Government equipment seized from the company in a raid earlier this year.
In the summer of 1993, the last of several Federal investigations of the scheme began bearing fruit when the Seminole Tribe of Florida began to try similar equipment deals and Mr. Raether obtained a 300-ton crane for them from a naval yard in San Diego. Mr. Hawkins signed documents for the Seminoles selling the crane to Dakota Machinery Exchange for $34,000, and Mr. Jerke began trying to sell it for $450,000.
The Federal Government's property management agency, the General Services Administration, became suspicious, and after an investigation Mr. Raether and Mr. Jerke were charged with conspiracy and with lying to the agency about the crane, which it recovered before it left California. Mr. Oseby was charged with conspiracy and with bribery and the company was indicted on charges of receiving illegally converted tribal property. A Bureau of Indian Affairs official, Charles Hacker, was charged with bribe-taking.
All have pleaded innocent. They are to go on trial in March. Mr. Hawkins has not been charged.

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Chief Warns Bankers on Risky Loan Practices

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
With banks suddenly flush with extra capital, Federal regulators warned yesterday that the days of easy money and risky loans may be returning, just a few short years after excessive real-estate lending brought the banking system to its knees.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave a stern lecture on prudent lending yesterday to members of the American Bankers Association, who had gathered for their annual convention in New York. 
 "Competition among banks and their nonbank counterparts has never been greater," Mr. Greenspan said. "We have been seeing for some months now that the result of that competition in the form of easing of the price and nonprice terms for credit for business loans.'
He said it remained an "open question" whether the current loan standards were adequate. "There are enough questions to be raised about industry loan practices to give a central banker and supervisor pause," he said.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, echoed Mr. Greenspan's concern in his speech to the convention at the New York Hilton. "We found signs that some banks have eased their underwriting standards over the last several quarters."
In a tone measured to warn bankers without raising alarm, Mr. Ludwig called the situation "a yellow caution light signaling all of us to remain alert to avoid a repeat of mistakes made in the recent past.
The banking industry traditionally oscillates between periods of lax lending standards and periods of contraction as many of the earlier loans turn bad.
Many bankers and industry experts have been warning in recent months that the sloppy lending practices of the past are coming back faster than expected. In particular, bankers have worried that key conditions, like how much collateral is required of business borrowers, have been relaxed too far.
Mr. Greenspan, in fact, alluded to "anecdotal evidence that credit standards have weakened," but he noted that "these banker anecdotes, of course, are always referring to the competitor down the street."
Mr. Greenspan also strongly criticized the way that banks were setting interest rates on business loans.
"The highest-quality borrowers are being charged loan rates that are higher than actual loss experience indicates," he said. "Meanwhile the riskiest borrowers are not being charged sufficiently high rates to cover their significantly higher risk of default."
He said that most banks currently had a single interest rate for each type and length of business loan.
Mr. Greenspan described dire consequences if banks did not start taking risk into account in loan pricing. Their competitors will steal the banks' highest-quality customers, he said, leaving them with only the riskiest loans. Both finance companies and investment banks actively pursue midsize business customers.
For the future, Mr. Greenspan called for a radical restructuring of the way money for business loans is raised. Now, of course, most banks use their own deposits to finance loans.
Mr. Greenspan called for banks to take groups of loans they have made and to sell them to investors as securities, much as they do now for home mortgages. This would allow banks to protect themselves from the potential default of borrowers while still allowing them to profit from fees earned for making and processing the loans. "The overall effect would be to reduce bank risk," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
If the Owners Impose the 'Imps,' Are They Facing an Implosion?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
So baseball won't fill October with playoff and World Series games. But it will fill the legal calendar with more cases than a legal groupie can keep up with. The members of the Montreal Expos won't receive post-season shares, but the lawyers from the owners' law firm, Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, will share in whatever wealth baseball has left.
Having hung together through nearly two months of a players strike, the club owners face a legal wilderness of decisions that history says they will mess up: 
 *Do they impose their 45-day freeze on player transactions after the union refuses to go along with it?
*If they impose the freeze, do they unilaterally suspend the provision in the expired basic agreement that provides for triple damages if clubs are caught colluding again?
*Do they declare an impasse in their negotiations for a new labor agreement with the players?
*If they declare an impasse, do they implement their coveted salary cap?
*If they want to declare an impasse and implement their coveted salary cap, do they first make another proposal, changing the economics to conform to the revenues from the strike-shattered season?
*Do they appeal to the United States Supreme Court last week's decision of the Florida State Supreme Court striking down nearly all of baseball's antitrust exemption?
Having survived, at least for this session, the scariest Congressional challenge yet to their exemption, the owners have to decide whether or not to risk losing it all before a high court. They may be on safer ground letting the state decision stand.
The other legal headaches stem from the owners' inability to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement with the players. If they engage in any of the imps -- impose, impasse, implement -- they will find themselves defending their acts against a union challenge before the National Labor Relations Board.
If they suspend the anticollusion provision and are found to have done so improperly, they could wind up bankrupt. The Basic Agreement prohibits clubs from acting in concert, and if the owners decide as a group that they're not going to peruse free agents until they want to, they could be found guilty of collusion.
A high-ranking executive of one club said the clubs have been told they face no exposure or threat of economic damage from impasse, implementation or imposition because the basic agreement has expired and players are on strike.
"We wonder if that's accurate," the wary executive said. "Having been through bad legal advice, we wonder."
Recent baseball history is filled with bad legal advice. The owners' lawyers, one specifically, told them not to worry about Peter Seitz's 1975 arbitration ruling that created free agency. It would be overturned in court, they were assured. It wasn't.
The owners guilty of collusion against free agents after the 1985 season? The lawyers laughed at the suggestion. Two additional cases and $280 million in damages later, the owners weren't laughing.
"I wish they would implement this," said a lawyer who represents players, referring to the suspension of the anticollusion provision. "They would hoist themselves on their own petard."
Another lawyer, a person not in baseball but one who follows its inner workings carefully, suggested the owners never think through their actions and the ramifications of their actions.
"They haven't war-gamed it," the lawyer said. "What do you do when you get the troops to a certain point?"
In this case, after the owners declare impasse, implement and impose, they may implode.

 
 
When Does Free Agency Start?
 Eligible players can begin filing for free agency Saturday. Or can they?
Because there is no World Series, the free-agency filing period should run Oct. 15 to Oct. 29. But the clubs want to delay that period until Nov. 16 to Nov. 30.
The Players Association may protest the change and advise players to wait for the later period, but just in case players file in October, the clubs want to be safe from collusion charges. That's why they want to suspend the triple-damage anticollusion provision.
Among the potential victims of any new collusion -- players who are eligible for free agency -- are Paul O'Neill of the Yankees, John Franco and Dwight Gooden of the Mets, Bo Jackson of California, Darren Jackson of the Chicago White Sox, Danny Jackson of Philadelphia, Dave Winfield of Cleveland, Kirk Gibson and Mickey Tettleton of Detroit, Jay Buhner of Seattle, Kevin Brown of Texas, Jeff Blauser of Atlanta, Mark Grace of the Chicago Cubs, Kevin Mitchell of Cincinnati, Brett Butler and Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles, Larry Walker of Montreal, John Kruk and Fernando Valenzuela of Philadelphia, Andy Van Slyke of Pittsburgh, Gregg Jefferies and Bob Tewksbury of St. Louis and Darryl Strawberry and Bill Swift of San Francisco.

 
 
The Difference a Day Makes
 The abbreviated season will be remembered, among other things, as the season Tony Gwynn will never know if he would have batted .400. Brother Chris, though, will remember it as the season he could have become a free agent if only the players had walked out Aug. 13 instead of the day before.
The Los Angeles Dodgers reserve outfielder has five years and 171 days of major league service, one day short of the six years needed for free agency. Fourteen other players could have reached six years if the season had been played to completion. Among the others are Jim Abbott and Randy Velarde of the Yankees, Jack McDowell of the White Sox, Kenny Rogers of Texas, Erik Hanson of Cincinnati and Marvin Freeman of Colorado.
In all previous strikes, players gained service credit in the final settlements. If this strike has a final settlement, those players could gain a delayed free agency.

 
 
Hard to Find a Job
 Remember Steve Ontiveros?
Because their clubs want to remove them from their 40-man rosters by outrighting them to the minor leagues, a sizable group of name players will become free agents this week after exercising their rights and refusing the assignments. The list includes Rob Dibble, Rich (Goose) Gossage, Steve Farr, Roger McDowell, Jim Gott, Tom Browning, Bud Black, Tony Fernandez, Chris Sabo and Willie McGee.
The reason the players should remember Steve Ontiveros is he became a free agent that way a year ago, leaving the Seattle Mariners but not finding a job until Oakland signed him on the last day of last January. Now the 33-year-old journeyman pitcher is the earned run average champion of the American League, finishing the aborted season at 2.65 after pitching only 1 1/3 innings over the 114 innings he needed to qualify for the official standings. He also is eligible to be a free agent.
 
Awards or Bonuses?
 The decision to give post-season awards this year can be debated, but perhaps the best indication that the Baseball Writers Association made the right decision is that some club officials don't think the awards should be given. John Schuerholz, for one, has said it's "blasphemous" to talk about individual honors.
Schuerholz, the general manager of the Atlanta Braves, said last week that because no teams were named champions, individual players shouldn't be honored. But it was the decision of major league baseball not to designate division leaders as champions, and it is the baseball writers' decision to give its annual awards. They are different organizations with different responsibilities.
Not to doubt the sincerity of Schuerholz's view, but he does have a vested interest in one award. When -- not if -- Greg Maddux wins the National League Cy Young award for the third consecutive year, the Braves will have to pay him $750,000 in bonuses -- $250,000 for winning the award and $500,000 for winning it a second time during the life of his five-year contract.
That economic issue aside, Schuerholz said no post-season awards should be given because the season was devastated. But the season was terrific while it lasted; no one can deny that. It featured some outstanding individual performances, and it is some of those performances the baseball writers' awards will recognize.
If Frank Thomas is named the American League's most valuable player, he will earn a $100,000 bonus. The National League award would bring Jeff Bagwell $50,000. Jimmy Key would get $150,000 for being named the A.L. Cy Young winner.
The clubs have only themselves to blame for the extra expense. A year ago, the baseball writers, concerned about the appearance of a possible conflict of interest, asked the clubs to stop basing bonuses on their awards. No one replied to the letters sent to the acting commissioner, the league presidents and the clubs.

 BODY:

Mr. Blinder, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has generally criticized European Governments for allowing unemployment to remain high; he has not specifically criticized Germany for maintaining high interest rates.

HEADLINE: Oct. 2-8: Threat to Kuwait;
Iraq Moves Its Troops Toward the Brink Again; Clinton Responds Quickly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

 BODY:
More than three years after the United States and its allies tried to deliver a knockout blow to Iraq, Saddam Hussein's armored legions re-emerged last week as a threat to Kuwait.
 The crisis developed when Iraq sent forces toward Kuwait's border, including units from an elite Republican Guard division that escaped destruction during the Persian Gulf war. Madeleine K. Albright, the United States delegate to the United Nations, told the Security Council that if the buildup continued, Iraq might soon have some 60,000 troops and 1,000 tanks poised to attack Kuwait.
 
 The largest question concerned Saddam Hussein's intentions. As he did when Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990,, he seems to think military force (or at least the threat of it) is the way to achieve economic and political goals (or at least concessions). In this case, Iraq seems to be saying it will cause trouble unless s the Security Council lifts the economic sanctions under which Iraq has staggered since it was driven out of Kuwait in 1991.
 American officials said they thought Iraq was bluffing. But they were taking no chances. The Clinton Administration dispatched to the area an aircraft carrier, two ships with cruise missiles, 2,000 Marines, and ships carrying tanks and enough war materiel for 15,000 troops. MICHAEL R. GORDON

HEADLINE: Gridlock's Political Price

 BODY:
Polls and pundits alike predict a mid-term Democratic defeat so catastrophic that the Republicans could end up controlling not only the Senate but also (for the first time since 1954) the House of Representatives. The polls are preliminary and the pundits fallible, and when we all wake up on Nov. 9 the Democrats, though shaken, may still have slim majorities. But if things do turn out badly, it will be partly because Bill Clinton and the Democrats have failed to persuade the American people that they can govern as a party.
This failure of governance is rarely mentioned in the litany of causes for the Democrats' discontent. The most common suspects are: a nagging, nationwide sense of economic discomfort. The elusive but present ghost known as the "character issue," raised anew by Whitewater. Doubts about the President's managerial skills and his bumbling White House staff. A generally sour national mood and the growing rebellion against incumbency, more damaging to Democrats simply because there are more of them than there are Republicans. 
 But the fact that these assembled Democrats could not manufacture a satisfying product in Mr. Clinton's first two years may be more important than the other reasons combined.
Mr. Clinton, it should be recalled, rode to the White House on the premise that a Democratic President and Congress could get things done. There were flaws in this premise. The Democrats themselves have never been models of unity. Nor could Mr. Clinton claim a numerical mandate; nearly 60 percent of the electorate voted for somebody else. Nevertheless, Americans were invited to expect the end of gridlock. That was Mr. Clinton's single most powerful argument against the gathering ineptitude of the Bush Administration and the seductive togetherness offered by Ross Perot.
The President and his party did not deliver. Again, there are any number of explanations, all plausible, none satisfactory. First, he expended huge amounts of his political capital on a few matters of great moment: successes like the budget agreement and the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, failures like health care reform in 1994. That made orphans of lots of other worthy legislative enterprises. Second, though an instinctive compromiser, he did a surprisingly poor job of involving the opposition in his legislative program, not least health care.
Third, the Republicans, never really invited to the clambake, threw sand everywhere. Make no mistake: the Republicans cannot possibly run as the party of creative and helpful suggestions on the basis of Representative Newt Gingrich's jerry-built "contract" with the voters, which is little more than the voodoo economics of the Reagan 80's. The Republicans must shoulder the additional burden imposed upon them by Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, whose ugly behavior in the waning days of Congress helped kill campaign finance and lobbying reform.
But Republicans cannot be held responsible for whatever harm the Democrats suffer in November because their participation was never part of the original promise. If the voters are sour, and they are, it has more to do with Mr. Clinton's failure to consolidate the majority they handed him and the failure of the party to unify itself.
Democrats helped defeat his health care initiative. A Democrat, Ernest Hollings of South Carolina, at one point in his career an offbeat candidate for the Presidency, opposed the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The churlish behavior of Tom Foley, the House leader, did much to cancel Mr. Clinton's pledge to end Washington's culture of influence-peddling. Western Democrats joined with regional Republicans to sabotage many of Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's most promising environmental initiatives. The final proof of the Democrats' own gridlock-feeding disunity was their inability to rally all their troops for the two critical cloture votes on the lobbying bill.
In the end, it was difficult for a self-professed "New Democrat" to deliver when so many old Democrats stood in his way. This must surely have been a painful surprise for a hopeful fellow like Bill Clinton. But his dilemma is no worse than the voters', who have before them equally unappetizing bunches of Foley Democrats and Gingrich Republicans. This is a gloomy prospect, promising not just gridlock but rising public frustration at the majority party's inability to govern even when it has the keys to the Capitol and the White House.

HEADLINE: The Smoking Bill Struggle

 BODY:
Last March City Council Speaker Peter Vallone introduced a bill that, by putting sweeping new restrictions on smoking in public places, would go a long way toward insuring fresher, cleaner air for New Yorkers. But as the Smoke-Free Air Act plods toward enactment -- presumably by the end of the year -- the controversy surrounding it gets more contentious by the minute.
The original version of the bill required employers of all sizes to restrict smoking to enclosed, specially ventilated rooms, with a limit of one room to each floor of a building. Smoking was to be restricted to separate rooms in pool halls and separate sections of outdoor cafes, and banned in Shea and Yankee Stadiums except in separately ventilated rooms. Nightclubs and bars not attached to public areas in restaurants or hotels were exempted, as were restaurants seating fewer than 50 people. That last exemption was removed, however, after the vast majority of speakers at the Council Health Committee's first public hearing on the bill, in June, clamored for even stronger legislation. 
 Then the tobacco industry started doing what it does so well: heavy leaning. A never-ending stream of faxes, letters, phone calls, meeting requests to City Council members and full-page newspaper advertisements resulted in a bill that is, if not quite a shadow of its former self, getting perilously close to becoming one. The current version allows smoking in private offices, even those without separate ventilation, an unfortunate provision that would allow circulation of smoky air to other parts of the workplace. This version also permits smoking in the concourse areas of stadiums and offers restaurants a loophole by allowing smoking in the bar area.
On Sept. 25, the day before the bill's second public hearing, came a really big show of muscle: Philip Morris's threat (ingenuously described as "an option we would consider") to move its headquarters out of New York if the bill passed as it stood. After that, came the arm-twisting.
Philip Morris has, to its considerable credit, been a lavish and unintrusive supporter of America's cultural institutions for nearly 40 years. Last week, however, it demanded quid pro quo by asking city art groups it had aided to put in a good word for it with Peter Vallone. Many did, saying that while they were taking no position on the bill they wanted to go on record about Philip Morris's generosity to the city -- and, however reluctantly, adding their weight to the tobacco company's.
Between now and a third hearing and a third version of the bill -- probably next month -- the arm-twisting will doubtless continue. Mr. Vallone needs and deserves public support to maintain a strong bill whose exceptions do not go beyond minor loopholes now being discussed. Should the outcome be a bill that puts the tobacco industry's economic clout ahead of New Yorkers' health, then that industry, and Philip Morris in particular, can congratulate itself on its power to undermine public health policy for millions of Americans.
