HEADLINE: CONGRESS CALLS IT QUITS: FINAL HOURS;
Rancor Leaves Its Mark on 103d Congress

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The 103d Congress quit for the elections today, leaving behind a bitterly disputed record of legislation passed, defeated and put off.
As it closed its books, the Senate overcame the 28th Republican filibuster in two years and voted to protect millions of acres of California desert. Some senators who had already returned to their states to campaign had to fly back to the capital to vote, and Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois arrived at the Capitol by cab to vote on the bill after escaping from a garage that had a broken electronic door opener. [Page 28.] 
 That frantic footnote sent President Clinton the first significant environmental bill of this Congress. Mr. Clinton and Congressional Democrats looked back over 21 months that began with high hopes that a new President and more than 100 new members could solve dozens of problems they said had been ignored in 12 Republican years. But they were dogged by defeats on health care, campaign finance and long frustrating delays on many issues.
But in writing their epitaph for the 103d Congress, Democrats have suddenly rediscovered their voice, after standing by almost mutely for months as Republicans ran roughshod over the Administration's bills. [Page 26.]
In the session's final day, Democrats found several points of pride, arguing that accomplishments in trade, education, crime and deficit reduction had earned this Congress a respected place in history.
In listing accomplishments, Republicans agreed with Democrats only on trade -- an issue both sides managed to leave unfinished until Congress returns after the elections to vote on the global trade agreement. Last year's vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement was indeed one of only a handful of truly bipartisan lawmaking efforts, repeatedly praised by Republican leaders like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the minority whip, as the kind of Democratic leadership they wanted to encourage.
Today Mr. Dole ridiculed what he called "photo-op bipartisanship," which he said took place instead of real consultation.
Democrats were also keenly aware of the session's failures. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the departing majority leader, told the Senate today of his unhappiness with the failure of health care and campaign finance legislation. "The disappointments of recent months are real," he said, but "we made a significant difference in the economic direction for the better -- more jobs, lower inflation, declining deficits -- than the country has seen for a dozen years."
Representative Pat Williams, a Montana Democrat who managed one of the many health insurance bills, described the Congress this way:"Fast start, slow finish, too much rancor."
On education, Democrats always had significant Republican help, especially in the Senate. But the Republican Party does not praise measures like shifting aid for poor children away from rich suburbs, easing the loan terms of college students and establishing national educational goals, perhaps because they were handled by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the most prominent incumbent they hope to defeat.
Where Democrats claimed this summer's $30 billion crime bill as an accomplishment, providing more money for police, prisons and crime prevention, Republicans scoffed, calling it too soft. Mr. Dole said the legislation was filled with pork-barrel projects, calling it "big pig."
The deficit issue remains perhaps the sharpest division of all. Fourteen months after it passed without a single Republican vote, Democrats say it has spurred economic growth and confidence; Republicans continue to blast it as no more than a tax increase.
Generally, Republicans saw Congressional success only where the Democrats saw failure, most of all on national health insurance.
On that issue and many others, the Republicans were remarkably unified, while the Democrats, with solid-looking majorities, were really too shaky to let them push more than one measure at a time.
That made the variety of bills passed in 1993 a legislative tour de force. But it also made 1994, with its yearlong focus on health care, seem even more a failure, with attention significantly diverted from that defeat and others only by passage of the crime bill.
Indeed, the Democrats' most famous victory, the August 1993 vote to pass the budget measure that reduced the deficit by raising taxes and cutting spending, sowed the seeds of their most grievous defeat. The need to concentrate on the budget slowed health care, let its opponents define the issue and left the 1994 record flat.
Whatever historians may say, there was no doubt that this Congress disappointed the voters.
In January 1993, a New York Times/CBS News Poll showed that most Americans expected the Government to work better now that one party controlled the White House and Congress and about half believed that more than 100 new members would help Congress improve. By last month, only 19 percent said Congress had accomplished more than it does in a typical two-year period.
Republicans counted on that disappointment to lead voters to punish the Democrats next month. When they voted to kill measures they had once supported, like greater regulation of lobbyists, Democrats charged them with no motive beyond what Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, called "dissent for the sake of legislative destruction."
But some Republicans, like Senator John McCain of Arizona, warned that the public mood imperiled incumbents, regardless of party, and that trying to stall measures like the bill that would have imposed some limits onlobbyists was bad policy and bad politics.
Republicans were careful to say they opposed the lobbying bill because it might hurt grass-roots lobbyists, not the Gucci-shod, K Street professionals who stood outside the Senate chamber and cheered Thursday's vote to prolong the filibuster.
But on other issues, Republicans have veered between claiming credit for obstruction and denying they were dragging their feet. As Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon said about killing health care legislation, "We've got to make sure our fingerprints are not on it."
But more often they take credit. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas said proudly Friday that this Congress would "be remembered most as the Congress that, at the critical moment, when we were going down the wrong road at 100 miles an hour headed toward socialized medicine, we had a few members who were willing to stand up and say 'no.' "
Today Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the deputy Republican leader, complained of attacks on his party's "principled opposition." In a national radio speech, Mr. Simpson said, "The President and some in the media have tried to characterize my party as a bunch of Cro-Magnons standing in the mouth of a musty cave with our clubs, using arcane legislative procedures to disrupt the greatest and loftiest ideas for an ever expanding Federal role in our daily lives."
And blocking legislation has not been the exclusive hobby of Republicans. Votes on issues like term limits and giving the President line-item veto authority have been blocked by Democrats.
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate's senior Democrat, cheerfully takes credit for leading the fight against a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget. "I consider the Senate's defeat of the balanced budget amendment earlier this year to be one of the Senate's finest moments," he said.
With disdain equal to Mr. Gramm's for the President's health care plan, Mr. Byrd said, "There is no greater threat to our system of checks and balances and separation of powers than that amendment."
But in few areas was obstructionism more of a success than in dealing with Congress's ways of doing its own business. Sometimes the obstructionism was along party lines, as when House Republicans sought rule changes to give them more influence and Democrats scorned them.
Sometimes, as with campaign finance, it combined partisanship with the differences between the two Houses and the general reluctance of incumbents to see any flaws in the system that had proven its worth by electing them.
Sometimes Democrats waited so long to settle their own differences, as on campaign finance and lobbying legislation, that Republicans found it easy to force a pre-adjournment deadlock.
But reform was the one set of issues that brought the 110 freshmen of both parties together in the House. They accomplished very little, though the House voted on Friday to make itself subject, as a matter of its rules, to the Federal law on employment discrimination, workplace safety and similar matters. An effort to do more, by legislation, died in the Senate.
Even so, the House resolution did less than some freshmen expected. Representative Karan English, Democrat of Arizona, complained that just before the vote, the resolution had somehow mysteriously lost a provision barring members from using frequent flier mileage earned on official trips for personal vacations.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A headline yesterday in some copies about passage of the California Desert Protection Act misstated the margin of the Senate vote that ended a filibuster of the bill. The motion to end debate was backed by 68 Senators, eight more than needed, not one.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Congress went home for the November elections yesterday. Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, walked down the Capitol steps. (Stephen R. Brown for The New York Times) (pg. 1)
 
Chart: "HIGHLIGHTS: The 103d Congress: What Was Accomplished, and What Wasn't"
 
WHAT CONGRESS DID
 
1993
 
Family and Medical Leave -- Congress gave President Clinton his first legislative victory when it passed the family leave bill to guarantee workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for medical emergencies and births.
 
Voter Registration -- After a Republican filibuster was broken in the Senate, Congress passed a bill directing states to provide voter registration forms in motor vehicle offices, military recruiting stations and welfare offices.
 
Budget Deficit -- By the narrowest of margins, Congress approved the President's plan to reduce the budget deficit by $496 billion and raise individual and corporate income taxes, gasoline taxes and Medicare and Social Security taxes by about $220 billion over five years.
 
Nafta -- Legislation was approved that put the North American Free Trade Agreement into effect staring Jan. 1, 1994, gradually abolishing nearly all trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada.
 
National Service -- Congress passed a law intended to encourage volunteerism. It provides for a living allowance and up to $10,000 in education grants to people who do community service before, during or after college or trade school.
 
Civil Servants -- Legislation was approved that lifted many restrictions on political activity by Federal employees.
 
Supercollider -- Despite the President's support for the program, Congress voted to scrap the $11 billion Superconducting Supercollider project.
 
Space Station -- After a close call in the House, Congress decided to continue financing a scaled-down version of the space station project.
 
Gun Control -- Congress passed a bill providing a five-day waiting period for the purchase of handguns.
 
Abortion -- Congress again approved an amendment restricting Federal payments for abortions, although in a slightly modified form. It allows the use of Federal money for abortions in cases of rape and incest as well as when the life of the woman is in danger.
 
Student Loans -- Congress approved a new loan program that enables students to borrow directly from the Government, instead of from banks, and gives them five repayment options.
 
1994
 
Abortion Clinic Access -- Congress passed a law making it a crime to interfere "by force or threat of force or by physical obstruction" with anyone who is seeking or performing an abortion or other reproductive health services.
 
Education -- Congress acted on several fronts. It passed legislation aimed at raising education achievement levels by establishing national education goals for all students and schools. It approved money for a program focusing on job skills that helps students who are not going to college make a smooth transition from high school to the workplace. It reauthorized the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, providing money to help students in impoverished districts, to train teachers and to reduce school violence.
 
Crime -- After a tortuous legislative process, Congress passed a $30.2 billion anti-crime package providing for 100,000 new police officers, expanding the death penalty to cover more than 50 Federal crimes, banning the sale and possession of 19 types of assault weapons and authorizing $6.9 billion for prevention programs.
 
Independent Counsel -- Congress reinstated the independent counsel law, which allows a special prosecutor from outside the Government to be appointed by a three-judge panel of Federal judges to investigate accusations of crimes by high Government officials.
 
Banking -- Congress approved a bill that would eliminate the remaining barriers to interstate banking in a dozen states and a requirement that banks operate separate subsidiaries in each state.
 
California Desert Protection -- Congress passed a compromise bill to protect millions of acres of desert in California, creating the largest wilderness area outside Alaska.
 
WHAT CONGRESS DIDN'T DO
 
Health Care Reform -- After President Clinton promised to fight for universal health insurance coverage, Congress spent a year debating his plans and less complicated alternatives. Republicans and the health insurance industry were intense in their opposition, while Democrats found it hard to settle differences among themselves, and the effort was abandoned last month.
 
Superfund -- Congress gave up trying to rewrite the Superfund law, which provides for cleaning up toxic waste dumps.
 
Campaign Finance -- An effort to overhaul the way election campaigns for Congress are financed failed, a victim of Republican opposition to public financing and Democratic differences over how to deal with political action committees.
 
Clean Water Act -- The nation's most important water quality law has been up for review since 1992, but Congress has not acted on it. The law will not be re-examined until next year.
 
Public-Land Mining -- In the face of resistance by the mining industry, Congress dropped efforts to pass a measure that for the first time would have imposed fees for mining hard-rock minerals like gold and copper on Federal land.
 
Lobbying Reform -- Congress failed to pass a bill that would have tightened financial disclosure requirements for lobbyists and prohibited lobbyists from providing gifts, meals, entertainment or travel to members of Congress and their staffs.
 
Telecommunications -- An effort to rewrite the nation's telecommunications laws and permit open competition between telephone and cable television companies collapsed amid feuding between rival industry groups.
 
Safe Drinking Water -- A bill that would have revised the Federal standards for purity of municipal water supplies died when negotiators from the House and Senate failed to reach a compromise.
 
Economic Stimulus -- Using a filibuster, Senate Republicans defeated the President's plan to stimulate the economy.
 
Grazing Fees -- Unable to break a filibuster by Western senators, Congress abandoned efforts to pass legislation to increase grazing fees and make other changes involving Federal range land, leaving it to the Administration to make the changes by regulation.
 
Balanced Budget Amendment -- The Senate rejected a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, killing the proposal for this year.
 
Strikes -- Senate Republicans, using the threat of a filibuster, blocked passage of a bill that would have made it illegal for employers to hire permanent replacements for workers striking over wages and benefits.
 
WHAT CONGRESS PUT OFF
 
GATT -- The trade bill, or General Agreement on Trades and Tariffs, became entangled in election-year politics. Congress decided to postpone until after the elections a vote on the legislation, which would allow the United States to participate in a new worldwide trade agreement that would reduce tariffs over 10 years. (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Managed Care Changing Practice of Psychotherapy

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

 BODY:
Managed-care companies have several names for what's ailing people who spend years in psychotherapy that the companies consider unproductive: They call it the New Yorker syndrome or the Woody Allen syndrome. And they intend to eradicate it.
But who determines whether psychiatric treatment is productive or merely high-cost self-improvement? This question has led to pitched battles between the companies and psychotherapists, particularly in the New York region, where more than 20 percent of the nation's therapists work. The battle is seen as a testing ground for the efforts of managed-care companies to scrutinize more closely medical spending in New York, where managed care has been slow to take hold. 
 Many therapists say managed-care companies, intent on cutting costs, are undermining the quality of care by calling the shots on treatment without ever seeing a patient. These companies, they say, favor doctors who charge the lowest fees, driving some practitioners from the profession.
"This industry is destroying the field," said Dr. Karen Shore, a psychologist and co-chairwoman of the Coalition of Mental Health Professionals and Consumers, a Long Island-based national group that opposes managed care for mental health. "Nobody wants their kid to be a psychologist anymore."
Managed-care companies and their advocates, who include some psychiatrists, counter that therapists are chiefly unhappy about the loss of income. Insurance plans have never been very generous with mental health care, but managed care is even more parsimonious.
In the New York area, typical therapy fees range from $150 to $300 an hour for a psychiatrist and from $40 to $150 an hour for a social worker; managed-care companies generally pay only 55 to 60 percent of that. One doctor said he was getting $80 a visit from managed-care companies but usually charged twice that; another was asked to settle for $40.
Supporters of managed care say many practitioners would rather keep people in talk therapy for years than try drug therapy that has increasingly proven effective. For years, these doctors had authority to continue treatment that shows no signs of working, the companies say.
"There's a lot of resistance against managed care among psychiatrists because they don't want to be part of a system where they have to conform to what the company's rules are," said Dr. Terry Golash, medical director for Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield, who has both supervised managed-care reviewers and been subject to their scrutiny in his private practice. "A lot of doctors don't like to call and ask for permission."
Dr. Ian Shaffer, executive vice president and chief medical officer of Value Behavioral Health, the country's largest managed-care company, argued that patients can suffer when their doctors' decisions go unchallenged.
But therapists say patients suffer when their professional judgements are challenged by sometimes unqualified employees of managed-care companies who press them for confidential information. Psychiatrists also complain that they are increasingly limited to dispensing pills as therapy is conducted more and more by licensed social workers or psychiatric nurses who charge lower fees. Psychologists say they, too, are being shunned, and many are leaving private practice for diagnostic and consulting work in schools and businesses.
Most managed mental health care companies report that they deny a very small number of requests for treatment. Value Behavioral Health, for example, has an outright denial rate of less than 1 percent. But reviewers and providers commonly negotiate agreements that provide less treatment than the therapists originally requested, Dr. Golash said.
 
Reducing Costs, But Also Incomes
 A more telling measure of how much treatment is being denied -- or provided more efficiently, depending on your point of view -- is the amount of money that managed-care companies save businesses in outlays for mental health care, with the companies typically reporting cost savings of somewhere between 30 and 50 percent.
Those savings translate into tens of thousands of dollars in lost income for New York psychiatrists, whose annual incomes generally range from $80,000 to $200,000 (some make far more), and social workers with master's degrees, who make upward of $50,000. Depending on how many patients they have in managed care, they say their income has been cut by 5 to 25 percent.
New York doctors were among the last holdouts against managed care, which took hold in the area only recently but has made the most dramatic local inroads in the mental health field. Like many private companies, New York City signed its employees up for managed care -- for mental health services only -- several months ago.
Across the country, in areas where managed care has been around longer, therapists said they were losing even more money, as much as 50 percent in California and Florida, forcing some to take early retirement or look for a second career.
But Dr. Shaffer said New York therapists have been particularly vocal about the changes brought on by managed care because of the popularity of psychoanalysis. He said many New York patients were not mentally ill but were in therapy for self-improvement. And health insurance, he said, should not have to pay for that, any more than it should be paying for continuing education.
The emphasis on cutting mental health costs in particular is generally attributed to increases in the money employers spend on the treatment of mental illness and substance abuse -- $22 billion in 1993, up 57 percent in five years.
 
One Way to Test A Growing Industry
 Opponents of managed care, however, insist that psychiatric services are being used as a local testing ground for the managed-care industry. "It's seen as a way of testing the waters, to see how managed care plays" in New York, said Dr. Golash of Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield.
As a result of managed care, psychiatrists say their medical practices have changed drastically because now they primarily treat acutely ill patients.
"By the time they're approved, they're in an emergency situation so you have to work them in and see them immediately," said Dr. Robert Campbell, medical director of Gracie Square Hospital in Manhattan.
Doctors said as much as 25 percent of their day is now spent talking with reviewers about how many sessions and what kind of treatment is warranted. And a few are joining group psychiatric practices because some managed-care companies require that doctors be on 24-hour call.
Several doctors told of troubling excesses by managed-care companies, like patients' being denied benefits because they were well enough to work, or cut off because they became so ill they lost their jobs.
"The reviewer will tell you the patient's been in therapy with you for over a year, so it's chronic care and we don't pay for chronic care," said Dr. Frederick Mendelsohn, who is in private practice in Manhattan.
But others wondered whether some colleagues had begun to exaggerate the menace of managed care as something of a siege mentality has taken hold of their profession.
 
Approach Raises Privacy Concerns
 What seems clear, however, is that the growth of managed mental health care has changed the way many therapists do business.
One therapist said he and others had recently stopped taking notes during sessions because they feared being asked to turn them over to managed-care company reviewers, whom they do not trust to maintain confidentiality. Another said he now routinely warns patients in their first session that he can no longer guarantee confidentiality because of managed care.
A third, Dr. Edward Gordon, a Putnam County psychiatrist, said, "I had one patient who had applied for life insurance and they wrote me for information, and she hadn't mentioned me on the form."
Several therapists said they spent an enormous amount of time trying to stay a step ahead of the reviewers, even tape-recording conversations with them to protect themselves from lawsuits. And skirmishes between practitioners and reviewers often turn personal, they said.
 
Does It Work? What Patients Say
 About a dozen patients referred for interviews by their therapists complained about the difficulty in finding the right doctor among the limited choices offered by some managed-care companies. They worried that managed-care companies could not maintain confidential ity, expressing concern that their most intimate secrets were giving some clerk a good laugh or, worse, were being stored on computer disks that frequently change hands, when managed-care companies are bought and sold. And, they said, the process of proving their need for treatment was often demeaning.
A Manhattan textile designer who was widowed, lost her job and was later diagnosed with bipolar disorder said she was devastated when she found that her therapist had described her on forms for a managed-care company as disheveled, incompetent and belligerent.
"I came back from hell so they can put on a piece of paper that I'm disheveled?" she said, adding that the incident diminished her faith in her doctor at a time when she counted on him for support.
"I told him, 'I thought you were on my side,' and he said, 'I am, but I have to put that down or you won't get the money,' " she said. "But who is going to look at those forms? There's no bigger prejudice in our society than against people having psychiatric trouble. I'm frightened."
On the other hand, most of these same patients said they eventually received the help they needed and, in one case, persuaded a managed-care company to allow them to choose a doctor who was not on the company's list. And they complained as much about their therapists as about managed-care companies.
A Manhattan woman who suffers from chronic depression complained bitterly that after a managed-care company refused to reimburse her for continued treatment with a "world-renowned therapist," she was then denied a second weekly session with her new therapist.
But after two years in treatment, she said, "I stopped in the spring because it was wasting my time."
 
Learning to Work With the System
 Despite therapists' overwhelming opposition to managed mental health care, some acknowledge that they cannot defeat the system, and medical schools have recently begun teaching psychiatrists-in-training how to work with managed-care companies.
But many say they still hope to help overhaul the young managed-care industry and are lobbying on both the state and Federal levels for legislation that would require a licensing process for reviewers and a better appeals mechanism, make managed-care companies subject to state insurance laws and allow any willing provider into their managed-care group.
At the American Psychiatric Association in Washington, a toll-free number for complaints about managed care is logging a significant number of calls from doctors who are irate because they have been denied admission to managed-care groups.
"We have started getting a lot of calls from New York," said Sajini Thomas, the health economist in charge of the number. "Especially about being excluded."

The company, Value Behavioral Health, is the largest managed-care company for mental health; it is not the country's largest managed-care company.

HEADLINE: Comeback for Adjustable Mortgages

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
NEIL KLAR of Armonk, N.Y., had never gambled on interest rates before; he had always taken out fixed-rate 30-year mortgages, the safe, conservative, plain-vanilla loans that have been the financial foundation of the American housing industry for most of the last 50 years.
After studying some numbers crunched by a mortgage broker, however, Mr. Klar recently decided to switch to a mortgage with a rate that adjusts every year --also known as an A.R.M. -- for the new home he is having built in nearby Katonah. 
 "When I looked at where the market was and my current expenses, an A.R.M. made sense," said Mr. Klar, the president of Spot Quotations and Data Inc., better known as SQAD, a company based in Elmsford, N.Y., that supplies information on television and radio advertising costs.
After being wildly popular when interest rates soared in the 80's then becoming less so when rates plunged in the early 90's, A.R.M.'s -- many of them with newfangled terms, conversions to or from fixed rates and links to exotic indices -- are again attracting home buyers.
Though most borrowers still take out fixed-rate loans, the market share for A.R.M.'s, according to the Federal Housing Finance Board, has more than doubled, from 21 percent in February to 43 percent in August, the highest level since June 1989, when it was 47 percent.
"Sixty-five percent of my loans are now A.R.M.'s, and a year ago it was probably 25 percent," said Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a mortgage broker in Manhattan.
The steep increase in interest rates since February has been the primary impetus behind the growth. When interest rates rise, fixed-rate mortgages become more costly, and some borrowers may have trouble affording or qualifying for them. A.R.M.'s, which have lower initial rates, currently as low as 4 percent, require smaller monthly payments than fixed-rate mortgages.
Of course, if rates rise, A.R.M. payments can become higher than those for a fixed-rate mortgage. Which type of mortgage costs less over the long term? Depending on interest rates and how long a borrower keeps the loan, A.R.M.'s can become more costly in as little as three years or as many as 10, or never.
"Most of our moderate-income buyers, including young, first-time purchasers, favor adjustable-rate mortgages with low initial rates," said JoAnne Kennedy, co-founder of Hunt Kennedy Inc., a real estate broker in Manhattan. "When young people buy a New York apartment, they do not anticipate staying long-term. A.R.M.'s work best for these people because they reap the savings upfront."
"BIG apartment buyers, typically families, purchase for the long term," she added. "So their preferred mortgages are 15- or 30-year fixed-rate loans."
A.R.M.'s have also attracted attention because their rates have not been rising as much as those of fixed-rates. In the last year, the national average interest rate on a one-year A.R.M. rose 1.56 percentage points, to 5.69 percent as of Sept. 30, compared with 2.28 points, to 8.91 percent, for 30-year fixed-rate loans, according to HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J.
More important, perhaps, the spread between the lowest A.R.M. introductory rates and the average fixed-rate loan has expanded to an unusually wide 4.5 percentage points. The spread hasn't been that large since October 1987, when it was about 5 percentage points, in part because of price wars among lenders. (Not surprisingly, A.R.M.'s held 60 percent of the mortgage market that month.)
"The spread is significant because it is what gives the customer a reason to look at an adjustable-rate product," said Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates. "There has got to be enough of a difference so that you don't lose the savings of an A.R.M. in the first year."
He added that A.R.M.'s were also in vogue because lenders, many of whom have been hurt by the diminishing demand for mortgages, particularly refinancings, are again aggressively marketing A.R.M.'s as a better deal than fixed-rate home loans, even though fixed-rates remain lower than at any time during the 1980's; the low point for fixed-rate loans that decade was 9.09 percent, in March 1987.
Mr. Gumbinger noted that Federal regulators had cautioned lenders about making loans at rates that could lead to substantial losses if rates rose sharply; such a pattern occurred with many banks and thrifts in the 80's. Indeed, the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision, which oversees savings and loan institutions, last spring described the practice of offering unusually low teaser rates as "unsafe and unsound."
"A lot of the growth in A.R.M.'s is because of marketing prowess, not consumer demand," Mr. Gumbinger said.
Lenders, though, say that borrowers are taking out A.R.M.'s because they are more financially sophisticated. In particular, they say, borrowers are seriously weighing how long they intend to stay in their new home -- the average mortgage lasts for only seven years -- and calculating the difference in accumulated interest between an A.R.M. and a fixed-rate loan.
"For a young couple with no kids, seven years is a very long time," Ms. Scott said. "They could get transferred, decide they want to move to the country, improve their income so much they want a better house or apartment, or decide they want kids and need more space. What are the chances that none of those things are going to happen?"
Though much depends on the particulars of individual loans, the future direction of interest rates and whether a mortgage is refinanced, borrowers today who plan to sell their home or refinance in three to five years are likely to fare better with a one-year A.R.M. This is largely because of the low initial rates and the caps on interest-rate increases -- two percentage points a year and six over the life of the loan -- that keep the rate from rising too high or too quickly. (A.R.M.'s generally also have conversion clauses that, for a $250 fee, allow the loan to be converted into a fixed-rate, generally .5 to .625 percentage points above the going rate for fixed-rate mortgages.)
Those who plan to own their home longer can also save on accumulated interest with a one-year A.R.M., but only if rates decline or do not rise substantially. Such has been the case with many borrowers who took out A.R.M.'s in the mid-and late 1980s.
LONG-TERM borrowers can also come out ahead if they get a mortgage with a deeply discounted initial rate. Mr. Klar, for example, is closing on a $450,000 A.R.M. for a five-bedroom colonial on two and a half acres. The first-year rate is 4.25 percent -- substantially less than the average rate on a one-year A.R.M. of 5.71 percent -- and the rate cannot climb more than 2 percentage points a year and no more than 6 over the life of the 30-year loan.
Mr. Klar will pay $18,187 in interest during the first year of the A.R.M. compared with $38,152 for a comparable fixed-rate mortgage at 8.875 percent. His monthly payments during the first year will be $2,121 ($3,000 with local property taxes included.). A comparable fixed-rate loan would cost $3,392 a month, taxes excluded.
"Loans that low may not be available to Joe Six-Pack," Mr. Gumbinger said. "For most people, four or five years is probably the break-even point."
Because his starting rate was so low, Mr. Klar will continue to save on accrued interest until sometime between the ninth and 10th year of the loan, even if his rate rises to the capped maximum, 10.25 percent, by the fourth year. His loan, though, also cost him a high 2.75 points, or $12,375. A point is a fee paid to the lender equal to 1 percent of the mortgage.
"Whether I will be in the home 30 years is questionable," Mr. Klar said.
Though rates on most A.R.M.'s adjust annually, some change monthly, every 90 days or every 180 days. Rates, usually, can rise no more than one percentage point at a time and five or six percentage points over the life of the loan.
Some of these loans, six-month A.R.M.'s generally, may be linked to the London interbank offered rate, known as Libor, which is slightly less volatile than the usual standard for the one-year A.R.M., the one-year Treasury security, or a more comparable gauge, the six-month Treasury bill.
Other mortgages, monthly A.R.M.'s usually, may be linked to the 11th District Federal Home Loan Bank's cost of funds index, or COFI, which is less volatile than a one-year or monthly Treasury bill. Less volatility doesn't mean that the rate won't increase as much -- just not as quickly.
"You are less likely to get a spike in rates," Mr. Gumbinger said.
Brian Perkis, a Manhattan bank auditor, recently took out a $68,000 monthly A.R.M. tied to COFI for a one-bedroom co-op apartment he bought on Sutton Place for $85,000. His initial rate for the first three-month introductory period is 4.85 percent, which is unusually high for a single-family or condominium mortgage but not for a co-op share loan. He paid 1.5 points.
After three months, Mr. Perkis's rate will jump to the COFI rate -- currently 3.94 percent -- plus a margin, or lender's profit, of 2.25 percent. No cap exists on monthly adjustments; the lifetime cap is 11.35 percent, or 6.5 percentage points above the starting rate.
"I CHOSE to have a higher cap and a lower margin," he said. "I also was able to purchase at a very low rate, and I'm not planning on holding the loan for more than three to five years. By then, I'll probably be out of the city."
Mr. Perkis's starting monthly payments will be $384; the highest they can go is $655. "Which is still pretty reasonable," he said.
Borrowers, however, should be wary of loans that have rates that change less than annually but have minimum payments that change only once a year. A rapid rise in rates and the subsequent lag in higher minimum payments could lead to negative amortization, a high-risk situation in which none of the monthly payments reduces the amount of principal owed. (Only when real estate prices are appreciating rapidly or when interest rates are falling are the risks inherent in negative amortization reduced or eliminated.)
Mr. Perkis, for example, has an option on his COFI mortgage of making the same minimum payment each month throughout the year (and risking negative amortization), or making a payment that includes the rate adjustment or making an even higher payment that would effectively be prepaying principal.
"It places the onus on the consumer to be diligent," Mr. Gumbinger said.
Besides one-year A.R.M.'s and A.R.M.'s that adjust more frequently, several new types of adjustable-rate mortgages, known as hybrids, also exist. These loans, often called 3-1's, 5-1's, 7-1's or 10-1's, have fixed rates for 3, 5, 7 and 10 years, respectively, and then adjust annually. They usually have an initial interest rate that is 0.375 of a percentage point to 0.5 of a percentage point less than that on a 30-year fixed-rate loan. Some also have conversion clauses.
"If someone calls up and they say that they want a 30-year loan but they are only going to be in their home for 10 years, we will tell them about a 10-1," said Bruce R. Lublin, president of Homerica Mortgage Corporation, a mortgage broker and banker with offices in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Westport, Conn. "It will cost them half a point less than a 30-year fixed."
Walter Buchleigtner of North Stamford, Conn., recently took out a $250,000 3-1 loan starting at 6.375 percent, with no points, from People's Bank in Bridgeport for a three-bedroom condominium unit that he and his wife are buying on Long Island Sound in Stamford; they are downsizing from a four-bedroom house now that their twin boys are in college. A comparable fixed-rate loan would have been 9 percent.
Mr. Buchleigtner, who owns a marketing company, said that a 3-1 loan made sense in his situation because he planned to pay off the mortgage in three years and buy a retirement home out of the region.
Though many who plan to stay in an area or a home for only three years choose to rent, Mr. Buchleigtner said that he had decided to buy because his monthly payments were only $1,240. The monthly payments on a comparable 30-year fixed-rate loan would be $1,599.
"Paying $1,240 a month sounded so good," he said. "We looked at the rentals there, and they were going for twice what a mortgage payment is. The rate was also so good. I shopped the mortgage market and I had people quoting me a full point higher."
Similar to the hybrids are the "two-step" mortgages, also known as "balloon-reset mortgages" or 5-25's and 7-23's. With these loans, the rate is fixed for five or seven years, adjusts once and then remains fixed.
The starting rate is .375 to .50 of a percentage point lower than a comparable fixed-rate mortgage. The adjustment, however, is generally to a level that is above the market rate rather than a rate linked to the one-year Treasury security plus a margin of 2.25 to 2.75 percentage points. A hypothetical adjustment: the 10-year Treasury security, which is currently 7.54 percent, plus a margin of 2.5 percentage points. There is, usually an adjustment cap of 5 or 6 percentage points.
The appeal of these old-fashioned two-step loans is fading, though, especially with the advent of 5-1 and 7-1 hybrids.
"That's the product that market is abuzz about," Mr. Gumbinger said. "The percentage of A.R.M.s being reported is distorted because it includes hybrids with a fixed rate. Easily half of them are hybrids."

HEADLINE: Hispanic Population Outnumbers Blacks in Four Major Cities as Demographics Shift

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
The Hispanic population now outnumbers blacks in four of the nation's 10 largest cities and is poised to overtake blacks in the biggest, New York, as immigration has surged, Hispanic birth rates have outpaced those of other groups, and non-Hispanic whites and middle-class blacks move to the suburbs.
The four cities -- Los Angeles, Houston, Phoenix and San Antonio -- are all in the Southwest or West. But Census Bureau figures show that the shift has been moving farther and farther beyond that region and could be reflected in the nation as a whole within 15 years -- earlier than some previous projections. The 1990 Census found that nationally, there were 22.3 million Hispanic people, a 53 percent increase since 1980. There were 29.9 million blacks, a 13 percent increase from 1980. 
 "You have a pretty impressive potential for growth," said Jorge de Pinal, chief of the Census Bureau's Ethnic and Hispanic Statistics Branch.
The Hispanic population was already in the majority in Miami, El Paso, Tex., and Santa Ana, Calif.
Analysts say the rise in the Hispanic population could have enormous political, social and economic implications, further stoking debates over policies ranging from immigration quotas to whether English should be the nation's sole official language. The shift could also affect the alliances that Hispanic and black groups have built up over the years to fight for civil rights and to lobby for services for their disproportionately poor constituents. Some of those alliances have fragmented in the last few years as these groups competed for the same Congressional or legislative seats or for jobs and other benefits in a weak economy.
Dr. Marvin Dunn, professor of community psychology at Florida International University in Miami, said there was "an intense competition for political office" in that city, "with a sense among blacks that we are losing ground to the Latinization of the community and are becoming marginalized."
"I think it transcends the experience with Cubans" in Miami, he added. "I think it's happening nationwide."
In places like Compton, Calif., where blacks dominate politics in a largely immigrant Hispanic community, said Dr. David Hayes-Bautista, director of the Center of Latino Health at the University of California at Los Angeles, "some of the things black councilmen say about the Latino population sound like the kinds of things Southern whites would have said about blacks in the 50's: 'We were here first. We're being pushed out. These are our jobs; how dare you take them away?' "
Despite differences in social, economic and political characteristics, Hispanic and black groups share many common goals, he said, "and at the grass-roots level I don't see the level of animosity I sometimes see from the politicians."
While nearly two in three Hispanic residents of the United States were born in this country, about half the nation's Hispanic people say they still speak Spanish at home and do not speak English well. Because so many are young or are recent immigrants, Hispanic people still constitute a disproportionately small share of the electorate.
From 1980 to 1990, the Census Bureau recorded that the Hispanic population had surpassed that of blacks in areas including San Francisco and Pasadena, Calif.; Homestead, Kissimmee and Lake Worth, Fla.; Arlington, Va.; Las Vegas, Nev.; Lynn, Mass.; Providence, R.I.; Rockville, Md.; Waukegan, Ill.; Central Islip and Long Beach on Long Island; Yonkers in Westchester County; Paterson and Woodbridge, N.J., and Danbury and Waterbury, Conn.
The Hispanic population was nearly as large as the black population in Beacon and Ogdensburg in upstate New York, in Edison, South Plainfield, Summit and West Orange in New Jersey, and in Bridgeport, Conn.
In many of those cities, though, non-Hispanic whites still outnumber the Hispanic and black populations.
In New York City, blacks made up 25.6 percent of the population in 1990 and Hispanic people 23.8 percent. By now, the Hispanic population may be larger than the black population, given the vast disparity in growth rates. In the 1980's, the number of black New Yorkers increased by 9 percent, while the Hispanic population increased by 27 percent.
In the early 1990's, said Dr. Joseph J. Salvo, who heads the population division of the New York City Planning Department, the emigration of blacks from the West Indies decreased somewhat, while the influx of Hispanic immigrants from the Dominican Republican intensified.
California and Texas still account for a majority of the nation's Hispanic population. More than six in 10 Hispanic citizens nationwide identify themselves as Mexican, about one in 10 as Puerto Rican and about one in 20 as Cuban. Increasingly, though, the Hispanic population is becoming more varied, with growing numbers from the Dominican Republic, Colombia, Ecuador and elsewhere.
Arguably, in the latest phase of the nation's metamorphosis, the ascendancy of Hispanic residents of the United States represents their re-emergence as the dominant minority in America after more than 400 years, decades before English colonists landed at Jamestown, Va.
Hispanic people can be of any race, although a vast majority identify themselves as white. The 1990 Census found that Hispanic people made up 9 percent of the nation's population and blacks 12 percent of the population.
Representatives from both groups are typically lumped together as "minorities" by non-Hispanic whites, but their interests sometimes diverge.
"There are problem areas," said Hugh P. Price, president of the National Urban League, a predominantly black advocacy and social service organization. "In some Los Angeles neighborhoods there has been a redistribution of jobs, of control over certain institutions. Some of the tension on the margin is to be expected as communities change. And, in the broader sense, in an environment of scarce economic resources there's a natural jockeying. But I don't think there's any kind of eruption brewing."
Representative Jose E. Serrano, the Bronx Democrat who is chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, suggested that the changes represent a challenge. "There's always the potential for conflict, but more and more there's a need for coalition because at the bottom of these two communities are basic similar needs," he said.
Dennis Rivera, head of Local 1199 of the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, in New York, agreed that blacks and Hispanic people often share the same goals regarding housing, education and employment opportunities, he also acknowledged that ethnic and racial succession can breed conflict.
"In New York City people tend to live closer together, but in Los Angeles and Florida there are strong differences between the groups," he said. "They're different, in part, because the Hispanic community in Florida -- many of them Cubans -- is far more conservative than the African-American community."
The shift in the 1980's was calculated for The New York Times by Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge of Queens College of the City University of New York.
Nearly 9 in 10 Hispanic people live in 10 of the nation's 50 states. New Mexico has the highest proportion -- about 40 percent -- although the proportion of Hispanic people in some New Mexico cities has been declining because of the influx of non-Hispanic whites from California and other states.

HEADLINE: In 25-Year Fight, the Hudson Starts to Mend

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WHEN evaluating a 198-mile stretch of the Hudson River from Manhattan north to Hudson Falls, environmentalists like John Cronin take pride in gains that have been made over a quarter of a century.
As the head of the Garrison-based Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, he cites reduced pollution and generally healthier fish populations as proof that the river has begun to mend. 
 "I'm optimistic about the future, because that's my nature," said Mr. Cronin, who is the riverkeeper for the 4,000-member environmental organization. "But I'm worried, too."
While he recognizes the gains, Mr. Cronin -- who patrols the river by boat to watch for polluters -- also describes the Hudson as "sometimes beleaguered," citing increased levels of industrial contaminants like PCB's in some places, deteriorating bulwarks along the riverfront and political setbacks.
"Progress notwithstanding," Mr. Cronin said, "there are still sources of environmental abuse, although maybe they are not as obvious as a raw-sewage pipe."
Of particular concern to environmentalists are waterfronts like that of Hastings-on-Hudson, where 40 acres of prime real estate have been "rendered almost worthless" by past industrial pollution, Mr. Cronin said.
The Anaconda Company of Great Falls, Mont., which manufactured wire and steel on the Hastings waterfront until 1970, left behind a dilapidated factory building, and a nearby structure formerly used by a defunct carting concern is still bulging with solid waste. Also, the state has estimated that the cost for cleaning up pockets of underground PCB pollution there could run as high as $15 million.
"A lot of things cross my desk," Mr. Cronin said. "Hastings is one of those stories that depress you."
The village has joined the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund as a plaintiff in a lawsuit against Harbor at Hastings Associates and other limited partnerships, which are development companies that own the former Anaconda site. Also named in the suit is the Atlantic Richfield Company, a Los Angeles-based oil company, which acquired the Anaconda Company in 1977. The Mobil Oil Corporation of Fairfax, Va., which owns another waterfront parcel in Hastings, and Chevron Chemical Corporation, a former owner of that property, are also named as defendants.
The suit is pending in United States District Court in White Plains and seeks a cleanup of the site under the Federal Resource, Conservation and Recovery Act.
Environmentalists also look at problems downriver in New York City, where floating debris mars the river surface and bacteria from overflowing sewers continue to be a problem.
They also cite as problems the waterfront in Dobbs Ferry, just north of Hastings, where model homes from an abandoned residential-housing development are tumbling into Wicker's Creek, a secondary waterway leading into the river and the site of an old Indian campground. That property was the subject of a successful lawsuit filed by the Riverkeeper Fund in District Court in White Plains.
In Croton-on-Hudson, an apartment complex along the river has been abandoned by its developer. And across the river in Nyack, a waterfront condominium development that Mr. Cronin said "became a big pink wall separating the community from the river" remains unfinished and not fully occupied. He termed it "another failed real estate project."
The problem of polychlorinated biphenyls, too, continues to vex state officials and environmentalists. In Hudson Falls, 60 miles upriver from Albany, a rotting door in a turn-of-the-century stone mill has given out, apparently releasing a stockpile of the toxic substance, which was used by General Electric in manufacturing electrical capacitors until the late 1970's.
PCB's have been implicated as carcinogens by the Federal Government, and a growing body of evidence suggests that they may also have other ill effects on humans.
Fish living in PCB-infested water carry the substance in their flesh, and the State Department of Health in April warned people not to eat more than half a pound of fish a week taken from any freshwater body in the state, including the Hudson River and New York Harbor. The advisory also said that women of childbearing age and children younger than 15 should not eat fish taken from any contaminated body of water.
The problems notwithstanding, Langdon Marsh, Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, recently described the river as "on a recovery road."
"The Hudson, to a large extent, has been brought back from the brink of disaster," the Commissioner said.
He cited water-quality improvements -- achieved through investments in sewage-treatment plants -- under the Federal Clean Water Act of 1972 and the state's standards for industrial discharge. And he called attention to the "healthy numbers of striped bass that we're seeing in the river these days."
PCB's, unlike many other sources of pollution, are particularly troublesome to scientists because they are difficult to get rid of.
"They tend to stick around," said Ron Sloan, a research scientist with the fish and wildlife division of the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
DDT, which was used as an insect spray in the 1950's, and chlordane, used on turf to control pests, have been phased out, and the residual problems associated with their use have dissipated, scientists say.
"But PCB's are unfortunately very persistent and will continue to be with us for years to come," Mr. Sloan said.
Officials had been recording diminishing levels of PCB's in fish until 1992, when a three-fold increase occurred in some places. Brown bullhead fish, which measured 5.3 parts per million of PCB's until then, started showing 18 parts per million that year, and the level in black crappies jumped to 31.5 parts per million from 7.1.
Anything over 2 parts per million in fish is considered a health hazard, the state says.
General Electric, which discharged PCB's into the river from 1952 through the late 1970's from its plants on the eastern shore of the river in Hudson Falls and Fort Edward, signed an agreement in 1977 to halt discharges and study the impact of the contaminant.
When the problem at Allen's Mill was discovered, General Electric initiated a removal plan, and to date almost 50 tons of PCB's have been removed from the site, which is downstream from two of the company's plants.
In all, since 1990 the company has spent $45 million on correcting the PCB problem in the Hudson Falls-Fort Edwards area, which has been designated a hazardous waste site, said David C. Warshaw, a General Electric spokesman.
Bridget Barclay, environmental director for the Poughkeepsie-based Hudson River Sloop Clearwater organization, said that although there appear to be no new sources of PCB's, the river was "still paying the price." She accused General Electric of "doing too little and taking too long" to correct the problem.
Mr. Warshaw disagreed, saying that his company had responded quickly to the problems. "We saw the levels of PCB's shooting up, and we tracked it down to Allen's Mill," he said. He and M. Peter Lanahan, General Electric's manager for its Hudson River Project, said that in addition to removing PCB's from the mill, the company was sealing rock fissures, where it had found PCB leakage.
While General Electric continues, under state and Federal orders, to clean up the PCB's in Allen's Mill, there remains the highly charged question about what to do with PCB's that have settled in sediment along the river bottom.
Commissioner Marsh said the state was studying the feasibility of dredging sections of the river bottom.
But General Electric objects to dredging, contending that PCB's in the sediment are not absorbed by fish and in many places the levels of the contaminant "have dropped to nothing."
General Electric also maintains that there are many varieties of PCB's in sediments, and that regulatory agencies fail to distinguish which varieties pose a danger.
Responding to public concern about the health hazards of PCB's, Mr. Warshaw said studies of General Electric workers indicated that the risks had been overrated. He said that the company's workers have not had health problems as a result of working with PCB's.
Ms. Barclay said, however, that other medical evidence suggested that PCB's and other chemicals with the ability to mimic natural hormones were causing cancer in adults and adverse health and reproductive effects in the offspring of both humans and wildlife.
Both Commissioner Marsh and Ms. Barclay said that dredging may prove to be an effective way to remove the chemicals buried in the river bottom. They also said new dredging methods would prevent the sediments from being stirred up, which could cause the PCB's to travel downstream.
"Hudson Falls needs to be cleaned up to stop that faucet and remove PCB's," Ms. Barclay said. "But our organization also advocates dredging. We have hired a consultant to evaluate the new methodologies for destroying PCB's."
Also of concern to many environmentalists like Mr. Cronin -- who called the Hudson River the "birthplace of the modern environmental movement" -- is the potential for a conservative backlash in Washington.
One indicator of the backlash occurred last month when, property-rights advocates in the House of Representatives blocked a measure that would have given the Hudson River Valley national recognition and up to $10 million in funds over 10 years.
The bill was part of a larger measure creating 10 American Heritage areas in the country that would become what Representative Maurice Hinchey, a Democrat from Saugerties, N.Y., called "educational laboratories" for the future. The money was for capital projects aimed at increasing tourism and enhancing economic development, among other things.
"One of our biggest obstacles is government," Mr. Cronin said. "The Hudson River has been a bellwether of what's going to happen environmentally in the country in terms of environmental law, hazardous waste cleanup, fish and habitat protection and the type of activism that takes place."
Mr. Cronin and Ms. Barclay cited efforts in Croton and Ossining as examples of successful attempts to preserve the river. In those communities and others, funds from the Greenway Council, a state agency, are being used to develop waterfront areas and provide better access for the community.
Croton and Ossining are receiving $25,000 each as part of the voluntary program to create local Greenway model communities, said David S. Sampson, executive director of the agency.
Richard F. Herbek, Croton's Village Manager, said the village would develop a boat-launching ramp along its waterfront "as part of a movement to reclaim the river." It was also working with Ossining to rebuild the Croton River Bridge to add a walkway.
In another waterfront-restoration effort, Yonkers plans to use $15.5 million in county funds and $750,000 from a combination of city, state and Federal funds to renovate its historic pier.
Mr. Sampson described the Yonkers plan as potentially "a great before-and-after success story" on the river.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard F. Herbek, Croton-on-Hudson Village Manager, sits beside Croton River near confluence with the Hudson River. Village plans a boat-launching ramp to help reclaim the Hudson. Inset: former Anaconda plant in Hastings-on-Hudson. (Photographs by Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Back From the Mommy Track

BYLINE: By DEBORAH L. JACOBS; Deborah L. Jacobs, an independent journalist based in New York, specializes in legal and business topics.

 BODY:
JACQUELINE ENGEL IRWIN quit her job as a marketing director at Citibank in 1980 to raise her two daughters. Eight years later, after running her own consulting firm and starting an after-school center, she returned to corporate life in a position for which she felt overqualified. Ms. Irwin, now 52, has spent the last six years at the Nynex Corporation in New York, retracing her steps up the corporate ladder. In terms of salary and responsibilities, she figures she is no further along than when she stepped off the fast track 14 years ago.
Kitty Knecht began paving the road back to the fast track on the day that she announced her second pregnancy. A market researcher at the Quaker Oats Company in Chicago, she received a commitment from management to let her come back part time -- three days a week -- after her maternity leave. When she was ready for a full-time schedule two years later in 1991, she negotiated a promotion as a condition for the increased work load. But Ms. Knecht, who has a Ph.D. in psychology, still landed in what looked like a dead-end job. She said she sensed a need "to prove that I would travel, that I could stand the pace, that I could be productive and that I wasn't going to get pregnant again." Ms. Knecht, now 41, has since earned another promotion. 
 Celeste Robb-Nicholson, a Boston physician with four children, worked four days a week for six years -- first at Brigham and Women's Hospital and more recently at Massachusetts General. Both hospitals offered her tremendous flexibility, she said. But when Dr. Robb-Nicholson, 44, switched last year to a full-time schedule, she found that she would not earn as much as peers who had consistently worked full time.
Ms. Irwin, Ms. Knecht and Dr. Robb-Nicholson were part of the first great wave of women to enter business and the professions during the 1970's. A decade later, with careers well under way, many women in this group cut back or took a break for child-care reasons. Now, some of them are leading a new wave of the 90's: women working their way back from the sidelines and the mommy track.
The experiences of Ms. Irwin and the others reflect those of many women making the return trip. For all the talk by companies about accommodating work and family needs, not much has really changed, employment experts say.
"The traditional managerial career path of a continued uninterrupted climb up the corporate ladder is still held in high regard," said Joy Schneer, associate professor of management at Rider University's College of Business Administration in Lawrenceville, N.J. "If you violate that, there are repercussions."
Patricia Caputo, who worked up until the day her daughter was born and returned 12 weeks later, puts it bluntly: "You either make the decision to stick it out on the fast track or you drop out and you don't get back on. There's a big talent pool out there, and you're easily replaced." Ms. Caputo was promoted to senior business unit manager at the consumer pharmaceuticals division of the Ciba-Geigy Corporation in Woodbridge, N.J., soon after returning in 1992. Now 39 and pregnant again, she is not sure she would have received the promotion if she had taken even a few more months off.
Many of the women who chose to scale back have experienced painful trade-offs. Women like Ms. Irwin, who measure their time off in years, have had to pay their dues all over again. And, to a lesser degree, so have women like Ms. Knecht and Dr. Robb-Nicholson, even though they cut back only slightly.
The stories of these women may not surprise people who expect that taking a break will have opportunity costs. All's fair in work and family, they argue: Women who choose to step off the fast track should not complain when peers who kept moving outpace them. Besides, the argument continues, working parents with the financial flexibility to take time off are a privileged group.
But many women who try to pick up where they left off say the dues they must pay go beyond catching up on seniority and honing rusty skills. Often, they say, there is a petty and punitive edge: People who take time off risk being treated virtually as beginners, or, even worse, as dilettantes, no matter how broad their experience. Even women who keep careers afloat by cutting just one day a week may forever lag behind in salary, title and responsibilities.
Surprising or not, the early reports from those who came back could have profound implications for American companies, employment experts say. Discouraged by the news from the front, more women may forgo taking a break, risking early burnout. And more of those who do take a break may decide not to try a comeback, causing business to suffer a "brain drain" of experienced female professionals.
Such a loss would add to the costs already associated with the glass ceiling, the pervasive, often subtle, barriers to advancement that hold back many women from top positions. Such barriers are keeping the economy from growing to its full potential, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said late last month at a hearing of the Government's Glass Ceiling Commission.
No one knows just how many women drop out for child-care reasons -- or how many try to get back in. The one hard fact is that women constitute an ever-growing percentage of American workers, up from 44.7 percent in 1973 to 57.9 percent last year.
Many women now re-entering the job market have adjusted their expectations before. They came of age professionally believing the myth of superwoman, that high-octane executive who juggled career and family without breaking a sweat. One by one, women reluctantly confessed that they could not live up to this model.
TO be sure, some businesses have made it easier for them by becoming more flexible about schedules, permitting employees to work part time, telecommute or share jobs with other working parents.
But these opportunities, which are still relatively rare, are often reserved for women who "were already the high performers, the very valued employees," said Kathleen Christensen, an environmental psychology professor in the graduate program of the City University of New York who has tracked workplace and family trends. "Companies have been allowing it largely because they don't want to lose this person and because they want them back on the fast track."
Victoria Brooks, a vice president at J. P. Morgan & Company, for example, worked four days a week for seven years when her children were young, and is now back full time, heading the company's global training program. Resuming a full-time schedule "happened pretty easily," said Ms. Brooks, 48. She attributes her smooth transition two years ago to the fact that she had a 17-year track record with the company.
But for many women, the road is much rougher. Although Ms. Irwin had an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago, 12 years of experience in managerial jobs at major corporations and had run a lucrative business of her own, a headhunter prepared her for a comedown when she started job hunting again in 1988. She should expect to earn no more than she made at her last corporate post eight years earlier, he said. As a vice president in charge of marketing at Citibank, Ms. Irwin's 1980 salary had been $60,000.
Ms. Irwin re-entered the work force at a lower level, as a marketing specialist for Nynex. Ultimately, she was able to get a promotion and make several lateral job changes.
Today she is staff director of market planning in the company's New York offices. Her current salary, she said, is less than her 1980 salary adjusted for inflation. Large companies "have molds," Ms. Irwin said. "It is very hard for them to deal with someone who is out of the mold."
Ms. Knecht has tried to work within the mold at Quaker Oats. By promising management that she would come back full time eventually, she framed her request for part-time work "as an investment the company was going to make in me that they were going to be paid back for," she said. To help her prospects for promotion after she returned, she "volunteered for some high-profile good works," like leading the United Way drive in her department and serving on a benefits design team.
The strategy worked: two years later, Ms. Knecht got a promotion to her current position as director of Quaker's convenience foods division. Like Ms. Irwin, though, she thinks she would be further along and making more money had there been no interruption.
A RECENT study by Professor Schneer of Rider University of the career paths of M.B.A.'s suggests that women executives who take time off and later go back to work permanently sacrifice career advancement and earning potential. In her study, with Frieda Reitman, professor emeritus at Pace University's Lubin School of Business in Pleasantville, N.Y., Ms. Schneer compared 128 women who had never had a gap in their employment with 63 who had taken time off and gone back to work full time by 1987.
The researchers were dealing with women who had relatively brief interruptions -- an average of 8.8 months. After adjusting for differences like years of experience, the study found that women who took a break earned 17 percent less in 1993 than women who didn't. Sixty percent of the women without a gap in employment had reached upper-middle management or higher; for those with a gap, only 44 percent reached that level.
Both groups were equally satisfied with their careers, however. Ms. Schneer speculates that women adjusted their goals so that they were happy with less.
Although Dr. Robb-Nicholson finds her career fulfilling, she is not happy with the dollars-and-cents trade-off that is a legacy of her years on a four-day week.
Part-time work has become more acceptable, she said, but it still has different connotations to different people. While young women professionals feel encouraged by the growing number of part-time opportunities, older colleagues may label part-time professionals as dabblers. "The uncertainty of returning," Dr. Robb-Nicholson said, is "what will your act have meant to whomever it is you are trying to get a job with?"
Bettina B. Plevan, a partner at the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn in New York, returned to work within two weeks after her second child was born nearly 20 years ago and stayed on the fast track throughout her career. Ms. Plevan now makes hiring and promotion decisions about women lawyers who have opted for reduced work schedules.
While it is not impossible for someone who worked part time to become a partner at the firm, "it's difficult to maintain the degree of interest and dedication to the job the more time you're away from the office," Ms. Plevan said. People who put families first are making "a legitimate choice," she added. But "for a period of time at least, maybe forever, the job is secondary."
Joan Faier, a New York lawyer, gave up her job at Random House in 1989 shortly before her second child was born. Now, Ms. Faier, who is 42 and married to Andrew Tannen, an executive at a large public relations firm, is ready to go back to full-time employment.
SHE is preparing "to do a big push" this fall, writing letters to companies where her skills might fit in, following up on contacts she made through Georgetown University -- her law school alma mater -- and attending professional seminars. She plans to discuss the five-year gap in her professional life, emphasizing her maturity and experience and inviting interviewers to discuss her time off. "I think that the approach of bringing this issue out in the open is valuable," said Ms. Faier, who specializes in communications law. "I don't want anybody to think that I'm somehow less dedicated."
Some women who have dropped out are avoiding the issue altogether by starting their own businesses. Given the recent spate of corporate downsizings, a growing number of women opt for self-employment, said Professor Christensen of City University. And once they discover the rewards, most do not want to return to corporate life.
From a company perspective, "these are lost assets," Ms. Christensen said.
Carol Guthrie of Darien, Conn., is among the women who are defining their own fast tracks outside the corporate world. Ms. Guthrie, who has an M.B.A. from Columbia, quit her job as an account executive at Grey Advertising in 1985, shortly before her second child was born. Two years later, she started the Connecticut Landscape, a design company she runs from the porch overlooking her garden. Annual revenues are $200,000 and growing. Ms. Guthrie, now 43, cannot imagine working for someone else again.
"If I had wanted to go back into advertising and do account management," she said, the decision to stay at home would have hurt. Instead, "it has freed me to do something for which I was suited."
 
Some Tips For the Return
 WOMEN who have made the return trip to full-time employment recommend the following steps to help get a career back on track:
* Maintain contacts with people with whom you have worked before.
* Become involved in volunteer activities in your community.
* Network through parents at your children's school.
* Start your own business.
* Read professional journals to keep current.
* Join, or rejoin, professional associations.
* Get in touch with the alumni office of your college or professional school.
* Take classes to acquire new skills.
* Look for companies that are hospitable to women: those with significant numbers of women in upper management; those with part-time or flex-time work arrangements; smaller companies and start-ups.
* Consider part-time employment or temporary jobs in your field that could lead to full-time positions.
