HEADLINE: Hannah's Neurotic Sister? That Was Ages Ago

BYLINE: By ELLEN PALL 

 BODY:
WHEN FIRST GLIMPSED IN "Bullets Over Broadway," the new Woody Allen comedy, Dianne Wiest is hurling a script down the magnificent staircase of her sumptuous New York apartment.
"Don't you remember who I am?" she thunders as she sweeps into view, her imposing form dripping with the furbelows of high 1920's fashion, her face a seven-layer cake of makeup. She asks the question in a voice an octave lower than the sweet, girlish one film audiences may recall from Ms. Wiest's portrayal of Holly, Mia Farrow's floundering, desperately insecure sibling in Mr. Allen's 1986 "Hannah and Her Sisters." Then she answers herself in a roar: "I'm Helen Sinclair!" She might as well be saying "I'm Zeus!" 
 It's a good thing that poor, neurotic Holly, a perpetual failure of a would-be actress, lived in a different age than Helen, the slightly over-the-hill Broadway legend Ms. Wiest plays in "Bullets Over Broadway," which was shown last weekend at the New York Film Festival and opens commercially on Oct. 21. Helen would eat Holly for breakfast (or, since breakfast probably isn't a meal in the grande dame's repertory, spear Holly on a toothpick and drown her in a dry martini).
As for the woman who gave life to these disparate thespians, Ms. Wiest, sipping mochaccino by the window of a cafe near her home on the Upper West Side, was neither formidable nor nerve-racked but sunny, sympathetic, as close to serene as any sensible Manhattanite gets. At 46, she is less angular and more fair than of old. (Her formerly dark hair is streaked honey blond.) Her smile is sweet, her assessment of her accomplishments sedulously modest. Helen Sinclair would more likely sit on her than notice her. But the feeling is not mutual.
From the time she saw the script, Ms. Wiest says, she "couldn't wait" to play Helen. (Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, called her "wonderfully funny" in the part.) "There's something so disgusting and so inviting about this character," she said. "This empty, cavernous, shallow, egomaniacal alcoholic!" Diving into the role, she thought, was "like having a bath in chocolate."
Mr. Allen, a friend of Ms. Wiest since he cast her in a small role in his 1985 film "The Purple Rose of Cairo," wrote the part expressly for her at her request. (Mr. Allen co-wrote "Bullets Over Broadway" with Douglas McGrath, a playwright and columnist who writes the satirical Flapjack File for The New Republic.) The movie tells the story of David Shayne (played by John Cusack), a young Prohibition-era playwright hungry for his first Broadway hit. So hungry is he, in fact, that to get the money to mount the show, he agrees to cast a rich gangster's girlfriend (Jennifer Tilly) in a supporting role. Helen Sinclair, a bit long in the tooth but still enough the great lady of the stage that David soon falls in love with her, is cast in the play's leading role as a spurned wife. (It is the insulting unglamorousness of this character that initially causes her to throw the script down the stairs.)
For Ms. Wiest, the outsize, self-centered, flamboyant Helen is a bit of a departure, for the actress has had, in some ways, a curious career. A highly respected and successful veteran of the New York stage, she started out in theater playing Shakespeare and Shaw, then got raves for her comic performance in Tina Howe's "Art of Dining" at the Public Theater in 1979. Since then, she has played leading roles -- often tragic -- in many Broadway and Off Broadway productions, including Desdemona to James Earl Jones's Othello and Maggie to Frank Langella's Quentin in Arthur Miller's "After the Fall." Over the summer Sidney Lumet directed her as a haunted survivor of the Holocaust in the premiere of Cynthia Ozick's play "Blue Light" at the Bay Street Theater Festival in Sag Harbor, on Long Island.
Yet in film, she is seldom offered anything but comedy. She sees the fact as a legacy of her flighty role in "Hannah" in 1986. Though it won her the Academy Award for best supporting actress, it also, seemingly, doomed her to be cast by Hollywood as a ditzy comedian. And, since she was already 37 when "Hannah" was released, that has meant mainly moms: high-strung moms ("Parenthood"), dizzy moms ("Cookie"), sweet moms ("Edward Scissorhands") and surrogate moms ("The Scout," Michael Ritchie's comedy, released 10 days ago, in which she plays a motherly psychiatrist).
So the powerful, egocentric, childless Helen was a particularly exhilarating gift to Ms. Wiest from Mr. Allen. Yet, as sometimes happens with gifts, at first she had trouble figuring out how to wear it. She had acted a grande dame before, but on stage and in a very serious drama, "In the Summer House" at Lincoln Center last year. And she was, according to Frank Rich, writing in The New York Times,"priceless" as a struggling Polish emigre actress Off Broadway in Janusz Glowacki's comedy "Hunting Cockroaches." But she didn't know how to play a grande dame in a comedy.
After the first day's shooting of "Bullets Over Broadway," "Woody came over to me and said, 'It's no good,' " she remembered. "So I went and saw the dailies, and I was just awful. I thought, 'This might be one of the more gigantic cases of miscasting.' " She promptly returned to Mr. Allen and suggested that he consider letting her leave the movie. The director was unperturbed.
Remembering the initial misfire, Mr. Allen said: "This character was so unlike who she is in life, so different than anything she's played. But she's a tremendously gifted actress. She can play comedy or Lady Macbeth or Arthur Miller. It really just becomes a problem of exploring with her a little bit. And very quickly, she got it."

THE CHIEF KEY TO "GETTING it" proved to be Helen Sinclair's voice. The character shapes her words as if shaping words were a thrilling, sensual activity. Angered, she barks, snarls, growls; when she purrs, it's the purr of a tiger.
"Certain actors and actresses need some kind of thing to play," said Mr. Allen of the throaty vocal style that seemed to free Ms. Wiest to be Helen. "Often, it's the costume: Put them in their pirate costume and suddenly they start mincing and flouncing. Other people, it's the voice -- they play it as a Hungarian, or an English actress. With her it helped to play in a more -- I don't know what -- a more pretentious voice." As
 
 
the production went on, whenever Mr. Allen said "voice" to Ms. Wiest, she knew she had gone off track. She would drop her pitch and become Helen once again.
But how did she come up with Helen's diction, which makes the words "full of life," for example, sound like "fool of lllife"?
"That's probably my stage voice," the actress said, a little abashed. "Which I would never think of using in film -- you can't take a stage performance and put it on film. It's like trying to paint in marble."
Yet for Helen Sinclair, stagiest of actresses and larger than life in her own living room, theater techniques designed to project 500 seats back seemed just right.
"It's really no different than Hedda Gabler," Ms. Wiest said of her own performance, "but the lines are different."
In the film Ms. Wiest was deliberately made to look older to emphasize the difference in age between Helen and David Shayne (Mr. Cusack is 28). But though she enjoyed filming her love scenes with Mr. Cusack ("He's a very good kisser"), she also found doing them unsettling. The difference in their ages, she feels, would have passed unnoticed had their genders been reversed. "But it's strange to be the woman," she said. "To be older, with everything in her life ebbing, to go after the young playwright -- it's very sad. Or it could be sad." She laughed and raised her eyebrows. "But I had a very good time."
As for Mr. Cusack, he didn't find the love scenes strange at all. "When you French kiss your mother and then she cuts your throat," as happened with him and Anjelica Huston in "The Grifters," he said, "that's strange. This was so harmless, really. Dianne is a beautiful woman. I mean, she's not 75."
Ms. Wiest was born in Kansas City, Mo., and grew up in an Army family in half a dozen towns in the United States and Germany. Her parents had met in Algiers during World War II, when her father was a reconnaissance pilot and her mother, a Scot, was a surgical nurse with the British nursing corps. After the war, they settled in America, where Ms. Wiest and her two younger brothers were born; her father eventually became a psychiatric social worker for the Army.

HER PERIPATETIC CHILDhood hardened her to at least one useful end, she believes: it made it relatively easy for her to jump into a production, reveal herself intimately, then leave. She was also helped by ballet, which she studied as a teen-ager at the School of American Ballet here, during the time the family lived at West Point, north of New York City.
"One of the reasons I found the courage and confidence to act was what ballet had given to me," she said. "I felt, O.K., I had been out there and people had been looking at me. Now I had to open my mouth."
She dropped ballet at 16 but took up acting in high school productions. She studied acting at the University of Maryland, left to join a touring Shakespearean troupe, spent four years at the Arena Stage in Washington, then appeared in several productions at the New York Public Theater. Her performance in "The Art of Dining" brought her her first broad recognition. But while her stage career flourished, her sporadic, mostly small film roles received little attention until Mr. Allen added her to his band of regulars. After "The Purple Rose of Cairo" came "Hannah and Her Sisters," then "Radio Days," in which she had a small part as a woman desperate to marry, and a major dramatic role as a troubled married woman in Mr. Allen's serious chamber piece "September."
Then Mr. Allen made seven movies without Ms. Wiest.
"Was it seven?" gasped the actress. "Yeah, I had children, that's what happened. And I'm one of these women who has failed utterly at combining family and career." Though Mr. Allen continued to call and offer roles now and then, "I had to stop and just be with them," she said.
Ms. Wiest, who has never married, is the mother of two daughters, Emily, now 7, and Lily, 3. Both are adopted. When the subject of her girls comes up, the actress's face leaves the realm of sunny and heads toward celestial. "It's just the most incredible love," she said. "Everything else sort of pales."
Having children has changed her in several ways, says John Tillinger, a friend who has directed her on stage in Lanford Wilson's "Serenading Louie" and in "After the Fall." When they first met, he said, "she was very much the actress."
"She traveled," he said. "She worked. That was the job."
But her priorities have changed. "Now she is very much a mother," he said. "When you adopt it's a real, conscious decision. This is something she did on her own, something very brave. That has deepened her."
Another longtime friend, the screenwriter and playwright Steve Tesich, calls the actress a "clean soul," one who can be hurt easily when she or others fail to live up to her high standards. "She is not a street-smart person," he said. "She's not sarcastic. She hasn't got that cool, jaded quality. She has no armor plating."
Mr. Tesich added that it would be wrong to claim that having children has brought out her warmth, which was already there. The difference, he said, is that she "now has two living, wonderful children who can receive all of it."
Since her daughters came, Ms. Wiest said, her ambition is "almost gone."
"No, I can't say almost gone. I love to work," she corrected herself a moment later. "And I do have to make a living."
Hence the movie moms. Yet even when she speaks of the "bitter taste" left in her mouth by playing such slight, familiar supporting roles on screen, she doesn't sound very upset.
"I can have that bitter taste all the way to the bank and not believe I've been paid like this," she said. "And that frees me to be with my kids and do all the Off Broadway I want."
Will Helen Sinclair change all that? Will Hollywood directors finally see (and cast) a new, powerful Dianne Wiest, one who can carry a movie rather than simply adorn it? If the role does mark an epoch in Ms. Wiest's career, she seems to be the last one to know.
"God, that would be so nice!" she exclaimed wistfully, clearly startled by the very notion. But she doubts it.
"Woody is really the only one who's taken any kind of chance with me at all," she said. "I can't imagine people in Hollywood are going to see this and say, 'Oh, yeah, let her play the ax murderer.' "
In any case, "I feel very, very lucky in terms of career," she said.
And what new projects is she involved in now?
"Nothing. Putting the kids in school."
And the future?
"No prospects." She gave a tranquil smile that made this sound like the optimal state for a very lucky actress.

HEADLINE: The New World Disorder

BYLINE: By Francis Fukuyama; Francis Fukuyama is a member of the research staff of the Rand Corporation in Washington and the author of "The End of History and the Last Man."

 BODY:

CIVIL WARS
From L.A. to Bosnia.
By Hans Magnus Enzensberger.
144 pp. New York:
The New Press. $18. 
PROVOCATIVE and widely read when they appeared in Germany, the three essays making up this slim volume by one of that country's leading poets, dramatists and philosophers all relate broadly to current problems of ethnicity, immigration and violence. The first essay in "Civil Wars," itself entitled "Civil War," argues that the highly organized and goal-directed wars of industrialized nation-states have now been replaced by "molecular civil war." In Hans Magnus Enzensberger's phrase, "violence has freed itself from ideology," and thence from any sort of heroism or higher purpose. We are wrong to think that the fighting in Bosnia or Afghanistan is over issues like ethnic identity or Islamic fundamentalism. Nor does the extreme nationalist right in Germany have a meaningful agenda; conversations with German skinheads show them to be absolutely devoid of ideas, even fascist ones.
The very goallessness of the new violence gives it a nihilistic character: in a strange abnegation of self, the perpetrators are willing to bring destruction equally on themselves and the things they hold dear. Thus the German skinhead is willing to attack a fellow German as much as a foreigner, while the gang member in Los Angeles burns down the community center built for his benefit. The reaction of the comfortable part of society (as well as of the wealthy West as a whole) to all of this is to wall itself up behind security gates while the "molecular" violence metastasizes.
Like virtually all other European writers and intellectuals today, Mr. Enzensberger is unrelievedly gloomy about our present situation. Based on his own arguments, however, it is hard to understand how the changes he portrays make the world as a whole worse. Forget the fact that he ignores the large parts of Asia and Latin America that, far from sinking into anomic violence, are closing the gap between themselves and the wealthy West and joining the global village. Would we really be better off if violence were the preoccupation not of disorganized gangs at the margins of society but rather of disciplined states with well-defined and conflicting purposes, ready to commit huge amounts of money and all of their technological resources to achieve them? The latter situation, in effect, describes the cold war world we have just left behind. Mr. Enzensberger notes that wars between states had many positive consequences -- the promotion of constitutionalism, spreading enfranchisement, the abolition of serfdom -- while today's violence is purely destructive. This is all true enough, but it constitutes a strange sort of nostalgia to see the good side of conflicts that included Verdun and Nagasaki. The very incoherence of the new civil wars makes them self-limiting and therefore, at least to outsiders, less destructive.
"Europe in Ruins," the middle essay of "Civil Wars," similarly contains good news wrapped in bad. Its ostensible purpose is to remind Europeans that only a few decades separate them from conditions no different from the chaos they now read about in the third world. Mr. Enzensberger pictures the years 1944-48 through the eyes of a number of firsthand British and American observers. These accounts of a time when many Europeans thought that their civilization had met its demise, both physically and morally, re-create a sense of the sheer enormity of what had taken place, as well as of the nervous forms of denial and self-justification prevalent among Germans and Nazi collaborators in France, Italy and elsewhere.
The conflict that led to these horrors, however, was pre-eminently that sort of purposive, ideological war carried out by large industrialized states that Mr. Enzensberger argues is disappearing. World War II displayed many grotesque pathologies, but it does not advance our understanding to compare it to the social breakdown of contemporary Liberia or Afghanistan.
In spite of the apparent anarchy at the war's end, Europe retained a high degree of orderliness. Mr. Enzensberger himself describes the incredible energy with which Germans, Italians and Frenchmen went about the business of adaptation and reconstruction in the face of defeat and occupation. He admits, almost despite himself, that the deadly ideology that drove the war has disappeared: the Germans have become peaceful, democratic, a "nation of shopkeepers" succumbing to the primacy of economics over politics. "Europe in Ruins" should remind Western Europeans not of their closeness to the carnage of contemporary Bosnia, as its author intends, but of their distance from it.
THE final essay, "The Great Migration," can best be described as a thoughtful and highly nuanced discussion of the German debate over immigration and asylum. Mr. Enzensberger has a clear-eyed understanding of the hypocrisies and contradictions on both sides. He has no patience for right-wing Germans who argue that Germany is not a nation of immigration, or that it is a lifeboat unable to hold more passengers. More than most other nations, he argues, Germany is the product of continual population shifts and changes, to which Germans have adapted in the past. On the other hand, he dislikes the moral posturing of those on the left who want Germany to solve the third world's problems, and questions whether it is realistic for Germany to become a truly "multicultural" society. What this means concretely for German policy toward refugees and immigrants is not spelled out.
Given that the post-cold war world presented in this book is in many respects much better than its predecessor, the question remains why its author and other Europeans like him are so pessimistic. Mr. Enzensberger himself hints at a possible explanation when he acknowledges that the apparent disorderliness of the world of the 1990's is in many respects a news media artifact. He notes that Bosnias and Rwandas have been occurring with grim regularity throughout history -- indeed, they proceed out of deep-seated and universal human drives -- but we are only now being made vividly aware of them. The author draws from this the sensible conclusion that both our universalistic moral concerns and our desire to intervene to fix the world's problems have to be tempered with a sense of limits, since there is no end to the outrages brought to our living rooms by modern communications.
There are many gaps in Mr. Enzensberger's argument, the most glaring of which is the lack of any account of how "molecular civil war" arises and spreads. Granted that it reflects deep human urges, why has it emerged in Monrovia or Mogadishu and not Seoul or Santiago? While the parallels between gangs in Los Angeles and the third world are intriguing, the author surely does not mean to argue, like Robert D. Kaplan in The Atlantic Monthly earlier this year, that Europe and the United States are about to disintegrate into Somali-style warlordism. Despite its failure to come to closure on this and other issues it raises, "Civil Wars" remains consistently interesting and full of small but striking insights on the changes taking place since the end of Communism.

HEADLINE: Shore Merchants Breathing Sighs of Relief After Rise in Summer Business

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY 

DATELINE: MARGATE CITY

 BODY:
THE magnificent homes with manicured lawns along Ventnor Boulevard, as well as the private toll bridge that charges 50 cents to get both in and out of this bedroom community of Atlantic City, tells one immediately that it is not a typical Jersey Shore town. What is typical, though, is the kind of summer Margate had this year. It was good.
Beach tag revenues were up about $1,000 -- from $163,000 in 1993 to $164,000 this summer, said Thomas D. Hiltner, the City Clerk. And most businesses, including Robert Hammerschlag's Deli Express, report doing a great business. But business, they say, is seldom really bad here. 
 Linda Mysliwy Conlin, director of the state's division of travel and tourism, summed up what is known so far about the shore tourism economy of 1994. "When the official figures are in, and we do not expect them for several months, I think that they will show that 1994 was a very good year at the shore, approaching the summer of 1993," she said.
According to recent interviews with residents, merchants and local officials, what Mrs. Conlin and others had predicted in June could be the best summer on record in years turned out to be exactly that for some, but not others.
"August was one of the most phenomenal months we have had since 1985, almost like the old days," said Jeanne DiPaola, executive director of the Southern Ocean County Chamber of Commerce. "There were more people staying from Saturday to Saturday, instead of just long weekends, and rentals were up 8 to 10 percent."
The chamber takes in Long Beach Island, the barrier island between Barnegat Light State Park and Holgate.
Marion Larsen, whose husband, John, is the captain of Miss Barnegat Light, a party fishing boat, said that July was 15 percent below the same period in 1993 while August was 60 percent higher -- an overall increase of 45 percent for the summer of 1994. The total number of passenger fares for both months was 7,000, she said.
The success varies, not only from county to county but from town to town. For example, just several miles north of Barnegat Light, in the same county, the story was different. Bob Bennett, owner of Casino Pier and Water Park in Seaside Heights, said that revenues were down about 4 percent from 1993.
More than two million people visited the amusement pier's rides, eateries and other attractions, Mr. Bennett said, "but some mornings you could not even see the ocean from the beach because of the fog." He explained that ocean water temperatures that seldom left the 60's, several rainy weekend days, as well as some afternoon thunderstorms reduced admissions at the Water Park, but generally not at the amusement pier.
"In 1993 we had perfect weather and business was up 10 to 15 perent over 1992, so we have never really slipped," Mr. Bennett said. "My feeling is that the economy is still not what it should be and that some people were cautious about spending their money."
Nor were there any records broken in Monmouth County. At the Sandy Hook unit of Gateway National Recreation Area, Bruce Lane, the supervising park ranger, said that while summer admissions had not yet been tallied, attendance was good -- about one million visitors -- "but a little lower than last year."
July was the busiest month, he said, and "by August people seemed to pretty much have their fill of the beach and did not come back."
In Belmar, beach tag revenues were down about $100,000, representing about 28,000 fewer people than in 1993, according to figures provided by Marie Newbery, the principal account clerk for the borough. Although the the 247,000 beach tags sold last summer in Belmar were down from the 283,000 sold in 1993, the figure was about 14,000 more than 1992.
Mrs. Newbery said that in addition to cool water temperatures and a few stormy weekends, the borough's beach season started a week later this year.
There were 50 beach closings along the coast due to higher than normal bacteria counts. Dave Rosenblatt, a spokesman for the state's Department of Environmental Protection, said that Atlantic City had 27 of the closings, 22 of which occurred in just one day, July 19. Seaside Heights had 7 and Cape May, 4. Others occurred in Long Branch, Spring Lake and areas where, Mr. Rosenblatt said, large volumes of contaminated stormwater runoff temporarily entered the bathing beaches after heavy, prolonged rains.
Mr. Rosenblatt and others said that while the 50 closings were more than the 1992 and 1993, which saw 27 and 34, respectively, they were nowhere near the 784 closings during 1988, the shore's worst year ever for the economy and environment.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE MILITARY BUILDUP;
AT LEAST 36,000 U.S. TROOPS GOING TO GULF IN RESPONSE TO CONTINUED IRAQI BUILDUP

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced tonight that it is sending at least 36,000 troops and some of its most potent warplanes to the Persian Gulf to counter a large and continuing buildup of Iraqi troops near the Kuwaiti border.
But American officials said that if the Iraqis continue their military preparations at the current rate, they could be in a position to launch a major invasion of Kuwait in a matter of days, well before the vast majority of the ground troops could arrive. 
 President Clinton approved the additional troop deployments, a substantial increase over what had been announced Saturday, after conferring with his top national security aides today.
A senior Pentagon official said Mr. Clinton had ordered the 18,000-member 1st Marine Expeditionary Force to the Persian Gulf. He also ordered the 16,000 troops from the Army's 24th Mechanized Division to head out.
Senior Pentagon officials said that additional Army divisions had been told to prepare to go to Kuwait and that the American deployment could double yet again, to about 70,000 troops or so. Some Pentagon officials expect the American deployment to grow well beyond 36,000 troops if the Iraqis continue to menace Kuwait. But the final decision to send more divisions has not been made.
The United States already has 2,000 Marines on ships in the northern Persian Gulf.
The Administration is also sending 51 additional combat planes, including A-10 tank-attack planes and F-16 fighter jets, bringing the number of warplanes in the region to about 200.
The deployments are the latest indication of how seriously the Administration takes the Iraqi military threat.
Today's deployment represented a major stepping up of American military preparations. On Saturday, Pentagon officials said that only 4,000 Army troops from the 24th Mechanized Division were being ordered to Kuwait.
The Pentagon's hope is that by dispatching troops and warplanes suited to attacking Iraqi ground forces, it will deter an Iraqi action. In effect, the United States is in a race to put sufficient forces in the region to mount a credible defense.
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, for his part, appeared to have his own strategy. Military officials said the Iraqi forces, which first began moving toward Kuwait on Oct. 2, were estimated tonight to be about 70,000 and still growing.
American intelligence showed that two Republican Guard divisions, the Hammurabi and the Al Nida, had been deployed within a few miles of Kuwait. The Iraqi divisions, each with about 10,000 troops, took up their positions late last week and have ammunition and food for 15 days, the intelligence sources said.
American officials also say divisions from Iraq's III Corps near Basra are also on alert. In addition, three additional Iraqi divisions may be preparing to join the force north of Kuwait, including the Adnan, a Republican Guard division.
In Kuwait, United Nations officials said several hundred Iraqi civilians had put up tents along the border, possibly to stage an anti-Kuwait demonstration. Iraq has staged such demonstrations in the past, describing the protesters as farmers who had been forced off their lands along the border.
But a senior Kuwaiti official said at a news conference this evening that the Iraqis were soldiers.
"These are not stateless people," the official said. "These are Iraqi soldiers dressed in civilian clothes, put there by Iraq to embarrass Kuwait."
President Clinton cut short his visit to Camp David today to discuss the situation in the gulf with Defense Secretary William J. Perry; Vice President Al Gore; Gen. John M. D. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser.
The stark warnings today by Administration officials and the display of military force were intended to make clear that the Administration would fight to protect Kuwait and to discourage President Saddam Hussein from miscalculating American intent. Three and a half years ago, an American-led coalition drove Iraqi troops out of Kuwait.
"All in all, this is a formidable military force," the Defense Secretary asserted on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
Pentagon officials said that additional deployments were under consideration. The air deployments ordered today did not include F-117 stealth fighters, whose strikes knocked out Iraqi command posts and communications in downtown Baghdad during the Persian Gulf war, or B-52's, which pounded Iraqi forces during that conflict. But Pentagon officials said they are considering sending such planes.
American officials still hope Iraq is bluffing. But they also acknowledge that it is possible that Mr. Hussein believes the Administration is distracted by Haiti and other trouble spots, and that Iraq's economic situation is so dire that this is the moment to force a crisis or even launch a military strike.
By this analysis, Iraq's intent would be to negotiate a new settlement that would lead to the lifting of economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations.
Administration officials said Iraq has several military options: it could make a small raid to occupy disputed areas of the border, like Kuwaiti-held territory near the port at Umm Qasr, and dare American military forces to respond, or it could sit tight, maintaining military pressure on Kuwait.
Or Iraq could launch a major attack. Baghdad has not made all of the necessary logistical preparations for a major invasion, Administration officials said, but they noted that Iraqi forces could be in a position to strike by Tuesday or Wednesday.
The Persian Gulf is 7,000 miles from the United States, and the American buildup will take time. The 4,000 Army troops, from the 24th Mechanized Division at Fort Stewart, began deploying Saturday night. But it will take several days for all the troops to fly to Kuwait and get the tanks and other weapons that are stored there.
Even with American air power, the troops there would be in peril if Iraq attacked soon. But by attacking the American unit, Iraq would be commiting itself to war with the United States.
Recognizing the vulnerability of the initial American deployments, top Administration officials went out of their way today to publicize the new air deployments and to threaten punishing missile and air attacks against Baghdad if Iraqi forces attacked Kuwait.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, for instance, said today that Iraq would pay a "horrendous price" if it invaded Kuwait a second time.
And on Saturday, Lieut. Gen. John J. Sheehan of the Marines, the chief operations officer for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the United States would fire sea-launched cruise missiles at Baghdad and other targets deep in Iraq if Iraqi troops crossed into Kuwait.
It will also take some time to get a heavier ground force in place. The 18,000 marines will fly to Saudi Arabia and get their equipment at the port of Al Jubail. More than 300 Marines left today for Diego Garcia to help prepare the equipment that is to be carried to Saudi Arabia on ships from that island in the Indian Ocean. But the ships are about seven sailing days from Saudi Arabia and are not expected to leave until Monday.
President Clinton spoke by telephone today with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who agreed on the need to act quickly to deter any Iraqi attack, a senior Clinton Administration official said.
The immediate issue for Iraq is to lift the economic sanctions, which have been in place since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Iraq insists that it has complied with the conditions set by the United Nations that could clear the way for the lifting of sanctions: destroying its weapons of mass destruction.
But the United States contends that Iraq has not complied. The Central Intelligence Agency, for example, says Iraq has hidden Scud missiles, and Administration officials say Iraq has not turned over crucial information to the United Nations, including data on its weapons suppliers.
Some nations, like France and Russia, which would like to resume trade with Iraq, have been more sympathetic to the Iraqi position. But that was before Baghdad began its latest saber-rattling. One senior State Department official said France and Russia indicated to the United States this weekend that they would back American efforts to continue the sanctions.
Among the air units being sent to the gulf are 24 A-10 tank-attack planes and 18 F-16 fighters from Pope Air Force Base, N.C.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS;
For Voters, Hope Gives Way To Anger, Fear and Cynicism

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 8

 BODY:
This colonial city is so sedate that the biggest contretemps is how to retrieve the bench on Chippewa Square, on which Tom Hanks sat in the movie "Forrest Gump" and which has now been replaced by a dumpster. But get them talking about politics, and residents here are no less irritable, dispirited or cynical than the rest of America.
Mannered they may be, but they are also angry. 
 "I've thought of moving to another country," said F. W. Daily, a 74-year-old anesthesiologist who has lived here for 35 years. "I'm considering Costa Rica for my wife and me. If I live another 10 years, it's going to be economically unfeasible to live in this country. These politicians think they're a law unto themselves."
Sherri Lawless, a 38-year-old city employee, said that she voted for President Clinton in 1992 but that he had let her down like other politicians. "I had to take my bumper sticker off my car," she said. "It just reached a point where it was difficult to be supportive."
It is a bitterness that came up time and again in dozens of interviews around the country this week, from a corn and hog farm in Sigourney, Iowa; to an automobile factory in Ypsilanti, Mich.; to a boat yard in Yarmouth, Me.; to a grocery store in a depressed section of Oakland, Calif. People are as discouraged about politics as they have ever been. And they are scared about their futures.
This is by no means the first time that polling and interviews have uncovered an unsettled electorate. What is different this season is how nasty and ugly the mood has become. The disillusionment that helped elect Mr. Clinton in the first place has only deepened -- to the point where people say they do not expect that their leaders can make things right again. The cynicism has frozen into something of a political tundra that would take a great wave of heat and light to thaw.
"The hope and the expectations of 1992 have given way to the fear and cynicism of 1994," said Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster. "It is really surly and mean."
What is also striking, as well as perplexing, is that unlike in the past, the antagonism is not fueled so much by personal anxieties over the economy; many people interviewed said they were not particularly pressed financially. And they did not talk much about specific issues or Congressional votes. Instead, they expressed a general unease about their futures and a feeling that they were not getting ahead. They also spoke of a broader sense that the country was losing its moral roots and that the ever-corrupt politicians could do nothing about it. Again and again they cited politicians they did not trust, from Dan Rostenkowski to Oliver L. North to Bill Clinton.
"It's scary," said Douglas C. Ray, 50, a worker at the General Motors plant in Ypsilanti and an independent. "The nation as a whole is losing all respect for the political process. We'll leave ourselves open to some demagogue. They'll say they tried the democratic process and it doesn't work."
Karen Meryash, 41, a medical marketing manager in Oakland, Calif., stopped while grocery shopping with her two baby daughters to register her frustration. "People have been voting and voting and voting for a change and haven't seen a difference," said Ms. Meryash, a Democrat. "There's a sense that the system is broken."
This deep disgust with Government is what may be leading voters to threaten to turn on Congressional leaders like the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, both Democrats. Maybe that is why so many incumbents who measure such things say their popularity ratings are stuck at record lows.
In Savannah, Dr. Daily, a Republican, was one of several people who spoke seriously of leaving the country. J. Everett Graves, 53, a retired firefighter in Richmond and an independent, said he, too, was thinking of moving to Costa Rica because of a lower crime rate and more favorable tax laws. "I'm looking for a place that will allow you the freedom to raise your child as you see fit, to live in relative safety and at least be free to protect yourself and your property."
Voters said they were discouraged, though not surprised, that a Congress and a President elected on a wave of reform in 1992 could not bring themselves to pass even a mild campaign finance measure this year. And some looked with disdain at how even the special interests have eagerly fed off the cynicism. More than one remarked that Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat, lost his party's primary, in part because interest groups like the National Rifle Association spent large sums to tar him as an out-of-touch incumbent who is too fond of the President.
"The guy basically voted his conscience," said Everett Toney, a shipping company official, as he leaned on a parking meter after work in downtown Savannah. "Now he's out of office just because he did the right thing." He added, "I've actually gotten to the point where I've considered not participating, not voting, this year."
The hostility was also captured in a recent focus group of independent voters assembled in Denver by Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster. "What do you think of when I say the word Congress?" he asked a dozen participants from assorted demographic backgrounds.
As Mr. Luntz went around the table, the only responses offered were ones that would depress incumbents who are returning home for recess this weekend: "inept," "same old, same old," "crooks," "overpaid," "great power," "over-impressed with themselves," "out to lunch" and "glorified people who like to have two places to live."
Adding to the insult, in the interviews around the country this week, most people were stumped when asked to identify any politician they admired. "Admire?" asked Ronnie Thompson, a 48-year-old restaurant manager in Savannah who is a Republican. After jangling the change in his pocket, he laughed when he finally came up with an answer, "People that stand out in my mind are ones that I dislike."
But Mr. Toney, 47, who said he usually voted for Democrats, did not laugh at the question. "It's sad," he said. "These are our leaders. We should have admiration for them. But the only people I've looked up to were my school teachers; they're really in the trenches."
Pamela Snelling, a 39-year-old bank officer in this coastal city, put down her newspaper long enough to offer her view of a typical politician. "They're on an ego trip," she said. "They sit around playing power games with each other."
Republicans, of course, groused about the star of their commercials this campaign season: Mr. Clinton. Democrats, by the same token, groused about what Mr. Hart, the Democratic pollster, called the "red-light group -- Republicans who stop everything." But beyond the obvious partisan divides, people in both parties, young and old, wealthy and struggling, black and white, agreed that the problems had become so ingrained that not even a new President or Congress could solve them.
People said they were disgusted by what they saw as the escalating sniping on both sides that left Congress unable to pass several major bills before the election.
"People have lost a lot of respect for other people," said Peggy Yates, 61, a Democrat who is a first-grade teacher in Sigourney, Iowa. "There seems to be a constant partisanship and a constant bickering all the time -- they're just always at each other." Her husband, Don, a 62-year-old farmer, agreed, saying, "They ought to be more disciplined."
Johanna Lockhart, an official with an investment company in Houston, said any hope for the nation did not rest with politicians. "If there could be a gentle revolution in this country from the voters who just say, 'It's the old, we're mad as hell and we're not going to take this any more,' " Ms. Lockhart, 50 and an independent, said over a sandwich on a park bench. "But it's got to come from the voters. Congress isn't going to do it. They're not going to set term limits on themselves. And they're not going to restrict the amount of money they can take in for their campaigns."
The lack of faith in leadership comes as people say they worry about crime and their economic well being. Even those with jobs and steady incomes are generally apprehensive.
"Our safety is in jeopardy each time we walk the streets," Helen Neuner, 75, explained as she toted a bag of produce from a gourmet grocery in Miami Beach. "I don't think they're putting enough money into the fight for crime." The retired nurse said she was so worried that she was thinking of breaking her Democratic tradition and voting Republican in November.
As he was walking the beat at an outdoor shopping mall nearby on Biscayne Bay, Peter Romero, a 34-year-old police officer, said he had to moonlight as a security guard 10 to 20 hours a week to support his family. "It's scary down the line," this Republican said, noting that he has a year-old son. "What can happen is not having the money there for him, for education."
Douglas P. Keen, 24, a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, said he intended to continue voting for Democrats. But he also sounded worried about his security. "A healthy economy right now does not mean a healthy economy in 20 years," he said.
Cradling his cappuccino at an outdoor cafe here, Jim Routon, a physician, shook his head as he explained how politicians had lost their souls. "When you're young, you look up to your father -- that's your whole world," said Mr. Routon, 53, a Republican. "Then you find your father is really a sleaze bag. He's been running around and lying. You lose your stability. That's the way I feel."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Pataki Stresses Efficiency and Leadership

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, contends that New York State has an anemic economy, crime-ridden streets, a meddlesome government and property taxes that are driving its residents away.
In making that bleak diagnosis during a two-hour interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times on Friday, Mr. Pataki advocated sweeping away 12 years of Democratic policies under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that he said had engendered high taxes, crushing welfare costs and burdensome regulations. 
 Beyond his prescriptions for deep tax cuts and the death penalty, Mr. Pataki outlined his vision for a government that would be smaller and more efficient without being less humane.
But he also argued that the race is as much about effectiveness as ideas. He should be elected, he said, because he has the energy and leadership skills to push new policies through a divided Legislature and tame a bloated bureaucracy. Three terms in office, he declared, have clearly demonstrated that Mr. Cuomo does not.
Of the Governor, Mr. Pataki said: "He says he didn't do enough good things in the first three terms. He's right. But that's no reason to say that there's going to be a fourth term."
In that comment and at several other points, Mr. Pataki was responding directly to remarks by Mr. Cuomo in an interview with The Times on Sept. 26. Both candidates were invited for open-ended sessions; Mr. Cuomo appeared for 5 hours and 15 minutes, while Mr. Pataki stayed 2 hours.
Like Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Pataki brought along several aides who occasionally slipped him hand-scribbled notes. And, like the Governor, Mr. Pataki dominated the session, showing a command of issues ranging from civil rights law to taxes, mixing folksy anecdotes with feisty retorts and providing detailed explanations of many of his positions.
On the stump he can appear wooden and constrained, but in the interview he was enthusiastic and animated, on several occasions shouting, "Aha!" He tartly corrected a questioner who referred to Peekskill, his birthplace, as a town instead of a city.
And he cast barbed asides at Mr. Cuomo, referring to the Governor's interview at The Times as a "filibuster" and, when accused of sidestepping a question, saying, "You mean Mario Cuomo didn't dodge any questions?"
Having been campaigning in a close race on often hazily defined pledges to reduce taxes and crime, Mr. Pataki broke some new ground in the interview when he was pushed to explain how he would pay for his proposal to cut $5.6 billion in income taxes.
For the first time in the campaign, he said he would seek to reduce the soaring cost of Medicaid, the health-care program for the poor that will cost the state $5.9 billion this year, by cutting nonessential services, though he provided few details. "It's absurd somebody can get a hair transplant paid for by Medicaid," he said. He also said he would consider imposing time limits on welfare for able-bodied, childless adults if other means of controlling welfare spending failed.
Under repeated questioning, Mr. Pataki steadfastly defended his economic projections as conservative, saying his tax cuts could be financed through normal revenue growth and painless belt-tightening -- assumptions that many independent economists have questioned.
"I believe we can do it without cutting services in a way that people are going to look and say, 'My God, I've lost this service,' " he said.
When asked whether he would postpone tax cuts if confronted with a budget deficit, as one of his models, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, has said she may do, he bluntly replied, "No." He was confident, he said, that tax cuts would have a "supply-side impact" and create jobs.
But Mr. Pataki hedged when asked whether he would exempt one of his priority areas, education, from a spending cap he has promised to impose on most of the budget. "It depends on our success in other areas," he said. "We want to provide more support for the schools so that they can start taking the burden off the property taxpayer."
Mr. Pataki said his political patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, would not play a special role in his administration. "What I owe him is what I owe every New Yorker," Mr. Pataki said somewhat snappishly of the man who shepherded his nomination through the State Republican Convention in May. "I'll listen to him. When I agree with him, I'll do what I think is right. When I disagree with him, I'm going to tell him."
As for his opponent, Mr. Pataki and his aides revisited a longstanding complaint that Mr. Cuomo has used state resources to abet his re-election effort. They cited flights on state aircraft to what they called campaign destinations and the use of the state budget office to critique Mr. Pataki's tax-cut plan. The Pataki campaign has also criticized Mr. Cuomo for bringing aides on the public payroll to his interview at The Times last month.
Throughout the interview on Friday, Mr. Pataki scattered words of praise for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican who has thus far declined to endorse anyone in the race for governor. Mr. Pataki said the Mayor had proved effective in cutting spending, fighting crime and improving New York City's quality of life. He said he would support Mr. Giuliani's efforts to gain greater control over the city school budget.
But he would not pledge to increase the city's share of state school aid, as Mr. Giuliani and mayors before him have sought, saying he would first evaluate the total aid package to the city, which includes welfare and transportation funds. "You want to take one particular element and say, 'Is this fair?' " he said. "You can't."
Mr. Pataki defended capital punishment, the issue on which his differences with Mr. Cuomo are perhaps sharpest, as a deterrent to crime and also a reasonable form of justice. Citing the World Trade Center bombers, he said a terrorist who kills "has forfeited his right to live, and we, as a society, have the right to take that person's life."
He said Mr. Cuomo's proposal for sentences of life without parole for three-time felons would be a "perverse incentive" for murder without capital punishment. Two-time felons, he contended, would be more likely to kill a police officer rather than face capture and life behind bars. "You have to couple three-strikes-and-you're-in with the death penalty," he said.
Mr. Pataki, who once opposed abortion and is now accused by the Cuomo campaign of being "multiple choice" on the issue, described the evolution of his views by saying he weighed the competing rights of a woman and an unborn fetus. "I think the right of the woman prevails and that's why I would protect the woman's right to choose, period," he said.
He said he had repeatedly voted against Medicaid financing of abortions for poor women because he wanted the program to include mandatory family counseling. But he said that if elected governor, he would not try to restrict Medicaid funds for abortion, even if the Legislature blocked his counseling proposal.
Mr. Pataki explained his opposition to legislation that would extend civil rights protections to homosexuals on legal, not moral, grounds. He said employers would have difficulty defending themselves against accusations of discrimination because there are no reliable statistics showing the percentage of homosexuals in the general population. And he said the bill might have the unintended effect of forcing employers to lay off workers who have concealed their homosexuality to protect the jobs of others who are openly homosexual.
Asked about his credentials for being governor, Mr. Pataki said his three years as Mayor of Peekskill had given him a better understanding of local government than Mr. Cuomo had when he was elected. Asked what legacy he would like to leave if ekected governor, he said, "I want my four kids to stay in New York."

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 559 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Pataki Offers a Vision for New York

 BODY:
Senator Pataki was asked to sum up what qualifies him to be governor.
Q. You were the Mayor of a small town --
A. City. 
 Q. Excuse me, city -- a small city, a minority member of the Assembly and then, most recently, a junior member of the majority in the Senate. What is it about all of that experience that qualifies you to be the Governor?
A. . . . I have experience in the state government, and I know the state government and I know it well. And I know where the problems are and how we can change things in the state government.
I have experience in local government, which Mario Cuomo didn't have before he went into the Governor's office, and I think that's one of the reasons why we have seen things like the cost shifts and the mandates imposed on local government, because he hasn't been there on the other side trying to balance a budget and trying to deal with impositions coming from other levels of government.
I've been a lawyer in the private sector and run a small business, so I think I have the experience in the state government, in local government, in the private sector and, more importantly, I have the ideas that I believe are necessary to move this state forward so that when we're talking four years from now New York State is not at the top of the list with an overwhelming, disproportionate number of job losses, but that we're up at the top of the list in creating jobs and opportunity and confidence in the future. . . .
Q. What would you like your legacy to be?
A. Specifically, it would be someone who turned around this state's economy to where we started to create jobs and opportunity and we're No. 1 in job creation instead of No. 1 in job losses; where we lowered the tax burden on the people of this state so they could afford to stay in their homes and afford to do business here in New York; where we restored safety to the streets, and the schools and the homes so that people in the communities didn't feel that they were under an unfair risk of being victims of violent crime; where we have schools that instead of being, I think it's 46th or 47th in the dropout rate, where we were again No. 1 in educational excellence.
If there's one thing this thing comes down to: I'm a New Yorker. I grew up in Peekskill. This state gave me the best this state has to offer: a great public education, the chance to go to a fine college, the chance to work for one of the best firms down on Wall Street, and that's what this state has represented for generations of people from around the country and from around the world. They come here for hope and opportunity and the chance to build a better life for themselves and for their children and their families.
If there's any legacy that I want to leave behind, it's I want my four kids to stay in New York, to go to school in New York, to get a job in New York, to get married and have children and a family in New York. And I want to be able to visit them here in New York instead of going down to North Carolina or Atlanta and visiting them there because that's where they thought the opportunity was.
And people want -- people, I think, in this city and state, have a tremendous commitment to New York and believe it's a special place. And it is a special place. But we can make it a better place for everyone again, I truly believe that.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:
PATAKI STRESSES LEADERSHIP AND CHANGE
State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, contends that New York State has an anemic economy, crime-ridden streets, a meddlesome government and property taxes that are driving its residents away.
 In making that bleak diagnosis during a two-hour interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, Mr. Pataki advocated sweeping away 12 years of Democratic policies under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that he said had engendered high taxes, crushing welfare costs and burdensome regulations. A1. 
 The deadlines for registering to vote in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for the Nov. 8 general election are approaching. B6.
Senator Pataki addressed the congregation of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and spoke of the need for jobs, health care and economic revitalization in the Harlem community. B6.
 
DOCTOR USES DRUGS FOR ABORTIONS
The so-called abortion pill from France, RU-486, is still illegal in this country, but an alternative drug treatment has become available for $500 in New York. Richard Hausknecht, a gynecologist and longtime abortion-rights crusader, says he has used two drugs already on the market -- but approved for other purposes -- to perform more than 100 abortions without
surgery. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
WOMAN IS RAPED AND MAN IS BEATEN
A couple's evening out ended violently near an abandoned Brooklyn pier when three men beat the man and raped the woman and then stole their car, the police said.
 The couple had just parked near the pier, on the border of Williamsburg and Greenpoint, when they were attacked by three men who appeared to be in their 20's. B6.
 
DO VOTERS CARE WHO ENDORSES WHOM?
Given all the hullabaloo, you'd think the outcome of New York's race for governor depended on political endorsements. When former Mayor David N. Dinkins finally announced his support for Governor Cuomo last week, after months of delicate negotiations, he got the royal treatment.
 And what will Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani decide? Will he cross the divide and endorse a Democrat? Will he support Senator Pataki, a fellow Republican? Or will he, as most political insiders anticipate, hedge his bets and endorse Mr. Pataki unenthusiastically as he winks at Mr. Cuomo?
 The speculation is fevered -- among politicians and the press, anyway. But what about the voters? Metro Matters, B6.
 
KELLY, IN HAITI, SEES BARRIERS TO REFORM
The Haitian police made an effort to clean up the station house before Raymond W. Kelly arrived the other day. But the former New York City Police Commissioner says reforming the Haitian police force is going to take a lot longer and will be a lot more difficult. A8.
 
REGION
 
A FINAL REPORT ON EROSION PLAN
 The final report on a $400 million plan to protect the vulnerable coastal areas of Long Island, New York City and Westchester County was released by Governor Cuomo, but funding remained in doubt.
 The plan stresses the need to protect the public in heavily populated shoreline areas and to retain major recreational areas. To make repairs and prevent future storm damage, the task force called for spending $400 million over five years. It said $119 million had already been appropriated for emergency repairs to barrier beaches. The rest depends on legislative action in Washington and Albany, and in some cases, at the local level. B2.
 
ARREST IS ISSUE IN PENNSYLVANIA RACE
 The arrest of Reginald McFadden of Philadelphia, who was charged with raping and robbing a woman in South Nyack, N.Y., and robbing and fatally stabbing another woman, in Floral Park, L.I., has become a big issue in the governor's race in Pennsylvania, where crime was already the major issue.
 Lieut. Gov. Mark S. Singel, the Democratic candidate, had, as chairman of the state Board of Pardons, recommended the pardoning of Mr. McFadden, a convicted killer serving a life sentence. A15.

Companies
 
Executives of Apple Computer and I.B.M. are close to agreeing on a common personal computer standard, industry executives familiar with the discussions said. The intensified talks -- involving Apple's chairman, Michael H. Spindler, and an I.B.M. vice president, James A. Cannavino -- came after rumors that I.B.M. or Motorola might be considering an investment in, or outright purchase of Apple. [Page D1.]
 

The vision behind the merger of Columbia/HCA Healthcare and Healthtrust is simple and alluring. The bigger the network, the easier it is to drive down costs and provide every health service that patients might need. The pivotal word is network. [D1.]
 
The Economy
 
Despite a drag from rising interest rates, pockets of strength are keeping the United States economy buoyant, raising the possibility that a predicted slowdown might not occur until well into next year. The most recent in a parade of bullish statistics are last week's reports of a drop in the unemployment rate to its lowest level in four years and a sharp rise in industrial production. [D1.]
 
The baseball strike could cost as much as $280 million in merchandise sales, and many retailers are postponing orders for goods, uncertain whether play will resume in the spring. [D1.]
 
International
 
Should Persian Gulf tension erupt into fighting, oil analysts do not expect shortages but do think that prices will rise, perhaps sharply. If Kuwait lost its ability to produce the two million barrels a day it now pumps, other oil nations in the Gulf Cooperation Council could compensate for the losses. [D1.]
With the victory of Fernando Henrique Cardoso in Brazil, diplomats and foreign executives predict that Brazil, Latin America's largest economy, will become a powerful magnet for investment and exports. [D3.]

Random House's goal at the Frankfurt Book Fair has been to make Gen. Colin L. Powell, retired Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as exciting an international prospect as possible, so it will not have to earn back the $6.5 million advance on his autobiography exclusively from American sales. The general hopes to finish the book in the spring. [D1.]

Electronic experimentation by daily newspapers is in full swing across the country, the Newspaper Association of America says. William Glaberson: Press Notes. [D5.]

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: LABOR;
Bitter Strike in Indiana Echoes in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MARION, Ind., Oct. 8

 BODY:
A dot in a sea of pancake-flat farmland, this northern Indiana factory town has handed Senator Edward M. Kennedy an unexpected opportunity to try to tip the balance in the tightest campaign of his 32-year Senate career.
Mr. Kennedy's Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, is an entrepreneur who boasts of having created 10,000 jobs at 60 companies. But here, workers at an Ampad stationery factory that Mr. Romney and fellow investors bought in July went on strike in September. Management has shed 41 of 265 blue-collar jobs, cut wages, tripled some workers' health insurance payments, abolished most of their seniority rights and junked the prior management's union contract, which had two years to run. 
 The Romney campaign does not deny that cutbacks were made at the factory, but it says management has done all those things so the company can survive and grow. It further says its representation of the number of jobs created takes account of a few losses at companies Mr. Romney has had to reorganize.
Still, the workers' accusations of callous ownership plays neatly into the themes being used by Senator Kennedy, a strong supporter of labor from a heavily unionized state who also happens to be the chairman of the Senate Human Resources and Labor Committee. To make the issue vivid, a group of five people from Marion who are either on strike or have been laid off went to Massachusetts this week to air their gripes. And since late last month, Mr. Kennedy has been flooding local television with 30-second commercials featuring anguished employees in Marion.
"I'd like him to show me where these 10,000 jobs that he created are," a worker asks in one commercial.
Another says, "I'd like to say to the people of Massachusetts: 'If you think it can't happen to you, think again. We thought it wouldn't happen here, either.' "
The campaign's new focus on labor's woes illuminates issues reaching far beyond Marion, a town of 40,000 about 65 miles northeast of Indianapolis.
By most accounts, Mr. Romney, whose investments include large holdings in Staples, the office supply chain; the Duane Reade drug store chain in New York, and Totes, the maker of boots and umbrellas, has a knack for building businesses.
Among his big investors are leading universities, including Yale, Princeton, Stanford and Notre Dame, which have entrusted him with $300 million of their endowment funds. But in making those endowments grow, Mr. Romney and his 11 partners have become masters of the brutal job economy of the 1990's, resisting unions and holding the costs of labor close to the bone.
Long before the news of the strike, unions chose to overlook Senator Kennedy's one noteworthy break with them, his vote in support of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which they contend will drive jobs to Mexico from the United States. "He's probably working people's biggest supporter in the Senate," said Candace Johnson, a spokeswoman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Losing him would be another important setback in labor's long-waning fortunes, and the strike has raised their hopes that he can hold on to office.
On State Road 18, on the fringe of town and across the road from a vast General Motors automobile body stamping plant, sits the Ampad Corporation, where the factory has all but closed. Ampad's principal owner is Bain Capital Inc., a Boston-based investment company whose founder and chief executive is Mr. Romney, now on leave.
In the five weeks since the strike began, not one member of the United Paperworkers Local 154 has been willing to cross a picket line at the plant, which makes file folders, index cards, legal pads and while-you-were-out pads. The workers are getting by on $60 in strike benefits a week.
"We're effectively shut down," said Charles Hanson 3d, the chairman of Ampad, from his headquarters in Dallas.
Those on the picket line are indifferent to the political implications of their strike. "They don't care about us, Democrats or Republicans, both of them," said Cindy Smith, 42, a file folder packer whose pay dropped from $9.97 to $7.88 an hour. "If Romney cared, he would come straighten us out. If Kennedy cared, he'd come find out what's happening."
Randy Johnson, 40, Local 154's top officer at the plant, said, "We kind of look at each other and say, 'What have we done?' " In July Mr. Johnson was demoted from slitting machine operator, at $10.04 an hour, to file folder packer, at $2.16 less.
When it was discovered that Mr. Romney was one of Ampad's owners, a Kennedy film production crew came out to interview workers. And now one picketer's sign proclaims, "Romney Union busters not welcome in union country." Another's says, "Romney creates jobs in Massachusetts, loses jobs in Marion."
"I don't know nothing about Ted Kennedy," said Jerry Rayburn, 25, who puts glue bindings on scratch pads and whose pay dropped by $1.83 from $9.71 an hour. "All I care about is going after Mitt Romney so we can get back to work. We're not asking for a penny more. We just want what we had."
The extent of the pay cuts is a much disputed issue. Mr. Hanson says the average worker earns $10.50 an hour -- 6 cents less than at the time of the takeover. But the union contends that workers lost 97 cents an hour.
Employees here say their problems began on July 5, when they received a memorandum telling them that Smith Corona, the company that had owned the plant, had sold it to Ampad.
At a meeting with Ampad management that day, they were presented with new wage schedules, work rules and management prerogatives, including the right to consider ability along with seniority in assigning jobs and promotions.
The shifts were altered, and many workers were told to work 12 hours each on Saturdays and Sundays and eight hours each on two other days. Workers' monthly cost of family health insurance would climb to $44, from $15, and deductibles, the amount workers pay before the insurance kicks in, would be raised.
The takeover, they were told, was a purchase of assets -- buildings, machinery, inventories, customer lists -- and the union contract was not among them. But since all the workers were union members, the company has recognized the union, as the law requires. Management and the union have been negotiating a new contract since July 20, but there has been little progress, prompting the strike.
Mr. Hanson says the changes have worked at other Ampad plants since Mr. Romney and his partners bought the company from the Mead Corporation two years ago, and since then Ampad's profits from the other three factories have grown and employment, too, from 728 jobs to 850. "People of entrepreneurial bent took it over and made it successful," he said.
Perhaps, say some workers, but the main beneficiaries of the success are Mr. Romney and his investors. Robin Dollar, a 31-year-old warehouse worker whose $9.62-an-hour wage was cut by 65 cents an hour after the company was sold, said, "I think somebody just wanted to make money at our expense."
In Massachusetts, the two campaigns put these issues in predictable lights. "Here you have a company that finds a way to keep a factory alive," said Charles Manning, an adviser to Mr. Romney, "and a union that says, 'We don't care if what you've done works.' "
Rick Gureghian, the Senator's spokesman, said, "Here's Kennedy standing up for working people, and here's Romney treating people like disposable commodities."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate for the Senate whose investment company owns the Ampad plant in Marion, Ind., where workers struck over pay cuts. (Associated Press); The striking workers at the Ampad plant in Marion, Ind., have given Senator Edward M. Kennedy ammunition in his difficult re-election race against Mitt Romney, an entrepreneur whose business strategy at the Ampad stationery factory has led to a bitter strike. (Mary Ann Carter for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: No Shortage Of Oil Seen If Gulf Erupts

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
Should the suddenly tense Persian Gulf erupt into fighting, energy analysts say they do not expect any shortages of oil but do think prices will rise, perhaps sharply.
Even if Kuwait lost its ability to produce the two million barrels a day of oil that it currently pumps, others in the Gulf Cooperation Council of which it is a part could pick up the slack, Mehdi Verzi, an oil analyst at Kleinwort Benson in London, said yesterday. "There is enough capacity within the gulf area to counter a big drop in production in Kuwait," he said. 
 Yet it is virtually certain that fighting would nudge up prices. "If we had another war, there would be at least a short-term upward push in prices, just as we had in 1990," said Marion Stewart, an energy economist at National Economic Research Associates in White Plains. In the worst case, crude oil prices could reach as high as $25 a barrel this week from last week's close of less than $19, Mr. Stewart said.
Crude oil prices reached their highest levels in two months during trading on Friday, reacting to the news that Iraqi forces had neared the border of Kuwait. But, after reaching $18.70 a barrel, crude oil for November delivery closed up only a cent, at $18.26, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
In trading this morning in Singapore, crude oil was up 27 cents a barrel.
Gary Ross, the chief executive of the PIRA Energy Group in New York, said the markets settled down in part because of the perception that Saddam Hussein did not have much room to maneuver -- and thus little room to wreak havoc with the oil markets.
"Iraq is very frustrated, and Saddam seems to be thinking that through intimidation he will get us to ease up on sanctions," which have reduced Iraqi oil output to 500,000 barrels a day from three million, he said. "Part of his problem is that he has no leverage, so maybe he is trying to get leverage through this bluster."
Because the international oil markets have been relatively calm recently, several analysts said, even a war might have only limited impact on prices.
Mr. Verzi said yesterday that even if there was fighting in Kuwait, the markets could remain stable for a number of reasons, including the fact that heating oil inventories in the United States were 10 percent higher than they were at this time last year, when the country faced its coldest winter in 25 years.
Also, Mr. Verzi said, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries "has actually been a stable element in the market in the past year," producing a steady 24.5 million to 25 million barrels a day.
Of the 7.2 million barrels a day of crude oil imported by the United States in the second quarter of the year, only 300,000 barrels came from Kuwait, Mr. Ross of PIRA Energy said.
Yet if the oil experts are notably sanguine about the short term, they note that increasing worldwide demand for oil just as OPEC is producing near its capacity is likely to lead to "a period where producers will be in the driver's seat again," Mr. Stewart the economist said.
If the immediate situation is not quickly resolved, analysts expect to see increasing participation in the oil markets by unsophisticated speculators who will place bets in some trading arenas that are rarely touched by professionals.
Don Fishbach of Fishbach Management and Research, a Cincinnati consulting service to options traders, said small investors on Friday were actively trading in options that were untouched by institutional investors. One of the options based on the American Stock Exchange oil index, which reflects prices of 16 large oil companies, traded 1,290 contracts, compared with an average daily volume of 15, Mr. Fishbach said.
"Institutions don't play these things because they won't plunge into illiquid markets," he said. "So this to me is speculative money."
As the speculators increasingly place bets this week on oil and international politics, analysts are largely convinced that it will be money ill spent on a situation with little immediate impact on supply.
"If Saddam was really going to invade Kuwait, he already would have done so, presumably," Mr. Ross said. "What does all this mean to oil? Not a hell of a lot."
Steven Hanke, professor of applied economics at Johns Hopkins University, said he was concerned that political and economic prognosticators might have become too complacent about the West's ability to quickly defeat Iraq in a conflict.
"Everyone is thinking that we can pop Saddam and get it over in a couple hours," he said. "I think reality is that if we get involved in something over there, it will be a much more drawn-out affair than last time just because we're not prepared."
Mr. Hanke is of the opinion that President Clinton will seize the political opportunity "to get in there and bloody Saddam's nose" in order to appear strong and Presidential going into the Congressional elections.
