HEADLINE: Clintons Should Address Health Care One Issue at a Time, Expert Suggest

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Health policy experts, including many who advised Bill Clinton over the last two years, say he and Congress should set their sights lower, worry less about the goal of universal health insurance and try to make modest improvements in the nation's health care system next year.
They say two issues are likely to dominate the health policy agenda of the next Congress: proposals to curb the growth of Medicare and Medicaid, and proposals to give states more freedom to pursue their own health care plans. 
 These issues are only pieces of the national health care debate, but they are big pieces. Medicare and Medicaid account for the bulk of Federal health spending, costs that are rising fast. And with the collapse of President Clinton's health care plan and of all efforts to guarantee health insurance at the Federal level, states are clamoring for more authority to tax and regulate the health benefits provided by companies operating within their borders. Large multistate corporations, whose health plans are now generally exempt from such state regulation, say they will resist efforts to give states more flexibility under Federal law.
Regardless of the results of the Nov. 8 elections, and regardless of what Mr. Clinton might propose, the national debate over health care will continue simply because 39 million Americans still lack coverage and health costs are still rising much faster than other consumer prices.
But Drew E. Altman, president of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, which studies health policy, said, "For health reform to succeed in the next Congress, it must be simpler, less scary, less bureaucratic -- a more incremental plan, in bite-size chunks." One area with obvious political appeal is legislation to assure health care for children.
Mr. Altman predicted that "there will be a huge debate about caps and cuts in Medicare and Medicaid, driven by a desire for reduction of the Federal budget deficit, not by a desire to pay for expanded coverage." And "while states can do very significant health care reform," he said, "there are real limits to what they can do without getting exemptions from Federal laws" like the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, known as Erisa.
One purpose of that law, passed in 1974, was to establish a comprehensive, uniform Federal system to regulate pension and health plans so they would not be subject to conflicting state requirements. But now Minnesota, Oregon, Washington, Maryland and other states say they need exemptions from Erisa so they can carry out ambitious plans to expand insurance coverage and control health costs.
"State flexibility will be a big issue next year," said Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota. "In Congress, you'll see a major effort to permit greater state flexibility."
Mr. Wellstone wants to let states try Canadian-style "single payer" programs of health care financed with taxes. Several states want to require all employers to buy or provide a standard package of health benefits for employees.
Surveying the wreckage of health care legislation on Capitol Hill, many experts said future proposals must rely less on Federal authority and more on market forces already revolutionizing the delivery of health care in the United States.
As a Presidential candidate in 1992 and for a while after his inauguration, Mr. Clinton supported the idea of "managed competition," which combines market forces with Government regulation in the hope that doctors and hospitals will compete for business on the basis of price and quality.
The originators of that idea, far from being distraught over the rejection of the Clinton plan, feel partly vindicated. "Our horse didn't cross the finish line," said Alain C. Enthoven, a professor at Stanford University who is the intellectual father of managed competition. "But our horse was the last one in the running."
Many elements of managed competition were incorporated in the bill drafted by a bipartisan group of senators who called themselves the mainstream coalition. The bill would have given small businesses an opportunity to buy health insurance through regional purchasing cooperatives, and it would have subsidized premiums for low-income people.
Health policy experts say they do not know if President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, have learned what they say are the appropriate lessons from the demise of health care legislation this year.
"I noticed that Hillary Clinton has been meeting with groups that strongly supported her position on health care," Professor Enthoven said. "She ought to be talking to the groups that opposed her. Instead of huddling down with her faithful few, she ought to reach out to those that defeated the Administration and find some common ground with them. She ought to meet with Senators Dole and Chafee and Moynihan and Kerrey of Nebraska and say, 'How can we work out a broadly supported bipartisan plan that will accomplish what the mainstream coalition wanted?' "
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas is the Republican leader. Senator John H. Chafee, a moderate Republican from Rhode Island, led the mainstream coalition. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, and Senator Bob Kerrey, also a Democrat, frequently criticized the Clinton plan as grandiose and unrealistic.
Over and over, experts on health policy and politics offer the same advice to the President and Mrs. Clinton: if they continue the fight for health care legislation next year, they should start in the center of the political spectrum and build coalitions outward from there.
Lynn M. Etheredge, a health economist who was a consultant to Mrs. Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, said: "The mainstream proposal is an excellent starting point. It would make life better for the average American. It provides a potential basis for bipartisan agreement. By contrast, if you start on the left wing, you polarize the debate."
Mr. Etheredge, an architect of managed competition, worked this year for Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, in trying to devise a compromise on health care.
The next Congress is widely expected to be more conservative than the Congress that just adjourned. If health care legislation is to have any chance of success, it will have to be very different from what President and Mrs. Clinton proposed last year. Mr. Etheredge said he did not know if the Clintons would be willing to accept such changes.
"They are likely to think that their plan was right and the strategy for selling it was wrong," Mr. Etheredge said. "But they designed an Edsel. If you can't convince the public to buy it, you ought to realize that you have the wrong product."
Even the mainstream coalition bill may prove too liberal and expensive, with too many new taxes and too much Federal regulation, to suit the next Congress. Gloomy Democrats conjure up a vision of what they call "triple negative health care reform" -- Congress might do nothing to expand coverage, might impose strict limits on spending for Medicare and Medicaid and might hold back states trying to adopt comprehensive health programs.
State Representative John F. Cosgrove of Florida, a Democrat who is chairman of the Insurance Committee in the Florida House of Representatives, was depressed after hearing Congressional aides, at a conference of state legislators here in late September, describe their low expectations for Federal action.
"It is indefensible and obnoxious for Congress to refuse to deal with these problems at the national level and not to let us do it at the state level," Mr. Cosgrove said. "I hear only gridlock and grunts in Washington, no positive policy proposals as to how they intend to cover 39 million uninsured Americans."

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE KUWAITIS;
As Going Gets Tough, Kuwaitis Go Out to Eat

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, Oct. 9

 BODY:
With thousands of Iraqi troops just north of the border, Kuwaiti reservists being mobilized and American soldiers on the way, many Kuwaitis are responding to the pressure by turning to one of the most beloved activities in the emirate -- eating.
Restaurants, fast-food outlets, ice cream parlors, pastry shops and candy stores are packed with jittery Kuwaitis, who hope there will be no replay of the 1990 invasion, when Iraqi soldiers sliced through meager defenses and rolled into Kuwait City. 
 In the ubiquitous American franchises, like Pizza Hut, Kentucky Fried Chicken, Baskin-Robbins and McDonald's, the fare that was adopted with such gusto after the liberation is being snapped up as people discuss the latest news.
"We are not that scared," Haytham al-Shaya said as she garnished a half-pound of hamburger meat with ketchup and mustard at a Fuddruckers restaurant, part of a Texas-based chain. "The United Nations is here and the allied forces will protect us, but still we are human. We are nervous, so we come and eat."
To the north, in Saddam Hussein's Iraq, food rations have been cut in half and there are lines for bread and cooking oil. Inflation is rendering the Iraqi dinar worthless, and many on fixed incomes have trouble buying enough for their families. Food has become a daily concern.
But Kuwait, whose oil wealth and small population give it one of the highest per-capita incomes in the world, has no such worries. Obesity has been steadily on the rise since the end of the Persian Gulf war, and Health Ministry officials say that at least half of the population is overweight.
The life-style in the emirate, where most Kuwaitis spend their days ensconced in air-conditioned offices, homes, shopping malls and gas-guzzling American luxury sedans, does not help. The country shuts down from 1 to 4 in the afternoon, and most Kuwaitis go home, eat a large meal and then sleep before returning to work.
Many Kuwaitis have servants, relieving them from much of the housework. And, as in the United States, many people spend evenings channel-surfing through dozens of programs offered by home satellite dishes. Since alcohol is banned, social gatherings, at least in public, often center on food.
But it may not be just the life-style that leads some Kuwaitis to eat too much. A Danish study published this year estimated that a quarter of the adult population suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder, with those who remained here during the Iraqi occupation the worst affected. Excessive eating, many say, has become the most common way to cope with the problem.
Wassimya al-Mutaa, the owner of The Forgotten Woman's Fashion Shop, dropped two lumps of sugar into her coffee as she sat at a table surrounded by racks of roomy dresses and baggy pantsuits. By the door is a large wicker basket full of candy.
"Kuwaitis have been under more stress ever since the invasion," she said, "and the way they respond is to eat. Whenever we go out, even to go shopping, we stop for ice cream and cake. When I get my largest sizes in, they sell out immediately. People are getting bigger and bigger, and many of my largest customers are teen-agers, who watch television and eat junk food all day. I am a big woman, but these girls make me look tiny."
In the last few months, several health clubs and weight-loss clinics have opened. Dr. Mohammed Rable sat at his desk in his clinic at the Dar al-Shifa Hospital and read the label on a bottle of diet pills handed to him by a patient, Sharifa al-Attar. Mrs. Attar, 40, a mother of four, said she had steadily been gaining weight and now hoped to take it off.
"If these make you feel better, you can take them," the doctor said, "but you will still have to begin to diet and get some exercise. They won't solve your problem."
Mrs. Attar replied: "I know. I can spend whole days without moving."
The doctor, who sees patients until 10 P.M., does a brisk business, but he despairs of the habits of Kuwaitis, who he says often lack self-control.
"People don't like the weather, so they don't go out," he said. "They eat fatty meats, full cream and rich desserts. They don't get exercise, and for recreation they eat."
Mia Ponzo, 33, a native of Syracuse, N.Y., who married a Kuwaiti, says she has put on 70 pounds in the 10 years she has been here. Now, she and her friends have formed a group to meet weekly and bring their weight down.
But as a guest turned to leave, she took a tray of chocolates from a table.
"If you are worried about your weight," she said, "just eat the chocolate-covered dates."

HEADLINE: Study Says Military Bases Survive Plan to Shut Them

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
After three rounds of closing military bases, and with the biggest round still to come, more than one-third of the installations that were supposed to close have managed to stay open in some way, a new study by a business group says.
The operations that survive at 26 major bases that have been ordered shut since 1988 could cost the Government more than $15 billion in the next five years, says an analysis conducted by Business Executives for National Security, a private Washington-based organization that seeks to reduce spending and eliminate waste at the Pentagon. 
 The study, whose results are to be made public on Monday, says the Pentagon has allowed bases to stay open by unnecessarily transferring Defense Department offices and other Federal agencies, as well as reserve military units. In some cases the special commissions that recommended the closings approved the changes in plans.
The study also faults local officials, many of whom fought closings in the first place, for embracing a continued Federal presence rather than trying to rely entirely on commercial projects.
The findings, the most extensive to date on the status of the major military closings, raise questions about the savings the Pentagon has said it expects. The Defense Department has estimated that when all the closings are complete, toward the end of the decade, savings will amount to $4.6 billion a year. Defense Secretary William J. Perry is relying heavily on this money to pay troops, to train them and to modernize weapons in the future.
Three special commissions, established by a law that sought to sidestep the political and bureaucratic tangles that normally arise when military bases are closed, met in 1988, 1991 and 1993. The commissions listed about 70 major installations to close and the recommendations were approved by Congress.
Since 1990, the Pentagon has reduced its forces by about 30 percent, but the number of bases has dropped by only about 15 percent, which means the military is paying for many more installations than it needs, military officials have said.
Yet, Pentagon officials, who say it takes five to six years to shut down a base completely, challenge the new study. They say some bases listed as open in the report are closed or are going to close soon. They also said nine bases were closed in just the last two weeks.
"No one expected the restructuring of one of the world's largest organizations to be easy, quick or smooth," said Joshua Gotbaum, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Economic Security. "But anyone who thinks we're not doing it is just plain wrong."
Carswell Air Force Base in Fort Worth, for example, was ordered closed in 1991. Two years later, a commission approved a Pentagon plan to consolidate several Navy and Air Force reserve units at Carswell. But the study says that after the Government spent $200 million to build hangars and housing, it has failed to bring as many aircraft to the base as had been intended. And the base costs $197 million a year to operate.
In addition, Carswell's hospital was promised to the Bureau of Prisons, so the Pentagon may have to build a new medical center at the base. Closing Carswell would have saved $156 million by 1997, the study says.
But Mr. Gotbaum said the Carswell consolidation had saved money by allowing the closing of three smaller naval air stations and that more changes were under way.
Lawmakers and Pentagon officials have predicted that the 1995 round of decisions, the last one that has been scheduled to date, could identify more bases to close than the previous three combined. The military has an overall goal of shutting down 15 percent of all military installations.
The 74-page report, a copy of which was made available to The New York Times, also criticized the Pentagon's plan to assign 13 new Pentagon accounting offices to bases that are closing. The report said the decision would reduce projected savings by $385 million. Mr. Gotbaum, however, said the Defense Department conducted a detailed cost analysis and found that those bases were the cheapest sites for the centers.
The independent base-closing commissions have won broad acclaim for tackling a difficult political issue in a nonpartisan way, exactly what Congress intended when it wrote the law establishing the panels. Just last week, the Senate approved the appointment of Alan J. Dixon, a former Democratic Senator from Illinois, as chairman of the 1995 panel.
But there has been less scrutiny for what happens to bases after the commission's recommendations are adopted. An earlier law, written in 1949, gives the Pentagon and other Federal agencies first dibs on using any portion of a base slated to close. Advocates for the homeless can then request parts of an installation to use as shelters. Only after that do local officials get the opportunity to develop bases into civilian airports, commercial offices or other uses.
This year President Clinton issued new interim rules intended to speed the transfer of military property to communities and help create more jobs in those areas. But some experts said the transition to commercial use from military base was slow and checkered with pitfalls. "My impression is that examples of successful conversions are few and far between," said Wayne Glass, a senior analyst with the Congressional Budget Office.
Independent experts who have reviewed the business organization's report quarrel with some of its specific examples, but praise the effort to assess the total savings achieved in the closings.
"We have continued to tell the Defense Department they should reveal to the taxpayers the full costs to the Government," said Donna Heivilin, director of defense management and NASA issues for the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress.
"This kind of information needs to be exposed and public needs to know about it," said Ms. Heivilin, who is the author of an accounting office report on the status of installations in the 1988 and 1991 rounds that will be issued later this month.

HEADLINE: Holding the Slowdown at Bay

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Despite the drag from rising interest rates, pockets of strength are keeping the American economy buoyant, raising the possibility that a widely predicted slowdown might not occur until well into next year.
While most forecasters say that economic growth is slowing, a parade of bullish statistics suggests otherwise, the latest being last week's reports of a drop in the unemployment rate to its lowest level in four years and a sharp rise in industrial production. Numerous stories from Corporate America reinforce the impression left by the data. 
 "The momentum is definitely in a positive direction," said Timothy McKenna, director of investor relations at the Union Camp Corporation, a major supplier of linerboard used in making cardboard shipping boxes. The demand for these boxes is so great across America that linerboard prices have risen to $420 a ton from $285 last fall. They had dropped steadily since 1989, and these are the first increases since then.
Wall Street has greeted the bullish statistics with the expectation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again to force slower economic growth, and thus reduce the risk of a sharp rise in inflation. But what the central bank might actually do is not known -- and probably not yet decided.
The pockets of economic strength -- including automobiles, home construction, bank lending, disposable income and exports -- first showed themselves last year, while interest rates were low. Falling rates for auto loans and mortgages, for example, produced booms in auto and truck sales and in home construction that continue today.
The lower rates also led to a wave of mortgage refinancings, which suddenly freed $100 billion a year in mortgage payments for other spending or to pay off new loans -- just as banks became aggressive lenders again. This lending, to business and consumers, continues to grow week after week, so much so that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, in a speech on Saturday warned that some of the loans were riskier than they should be.
Another pillar of economic strength has been the rising income of American workers -- not from big raises but from record levels of overtime pay and from the salaries going to the five million jobholders who have been added to the nation's work force since early last year. And with more jobs has come more public confidence.
"Early in the current recovery, optimism would rise and then fall back again because of an underlying sense of uncertainty," said Richard D. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Surveys. "That really has changed. There is a sense that the expansion is durable and the people we survey are less fearful of losing their jobs and more willing to spend."
Vehicle sales and home construction are the two most important pockets of strength. They are huge industries that reach out to tens of thousands of suppliers. For example, Phelps Dodge Industries, whose products include wiring and truck wheels, is operating its American plants at full capacity and employment is back at the 1989 level of 5,000, after having fallen to 4,500.
Similarly, TRW Inc.'s booming automotive business, particularly airbags, is offsetting declines in its military and space operations. "Five years ago we did not make airbags," James Christy, a vice president, said.
With home construction and home sales well above last year's levels, appliance manufacturers like General Electric and Whirlpool are prospering, and so are retailers like Pier 1, a nationwide home furnishings chain. Sales are particularly good in Western states benefiting from the migration of people and companies from California, said Clark Johnson, Pier 1's chairman.
Like the building of the railroads in the 19th century, but on a much lesser scale, all the construction activity involved in the migration generates activity that makes the economy expand. But clothing sales, a small operation at Pier 1's 640 stores, are way down this year.
"When people are in a big-ticket buying frenzy, purchasing homes and cars, that takes a lot of firepower and other things tend to take second place," Mr. Johnson said.
Weak clothing sales, not only at Pier 1 but at retailers everywhere, are offsetting the pockets of strength. Rising interest rates are a more significant problem. They appear to be gradually dampening demand for new housing, autos and trucks. Rates on 30-year mortgages and 5-year car loans are nearly two percentage points higher than they were last October. While vehicle sales and home construction are still very strong, in August and September they fell below the peak rates reached late last spring -- supporting the view of 50 prominent forecasters surveyed monthly by Blue Chip Indicators that economic growth is slowing.
Vehicle sales, which reached an annual rate of 16.3 million in March, declined to 15.3 million last month. And spending on home construction, after rising to a peak of $197.5 billion, at an annual rate, in May, from $173 billion in the summer of 1993, fell back to $191 billion by last August.
"The family housing market in terms of actual construction is clearly moving down," said David F. Seiders, chief economist of the National Association of Home Builders.
Auto executives are more optimistic. They say car and truck sales will rise again this fall. But a fourth of the car sales are, in fact, leases, usually for two years at low monthly payments. The payments are low because the industry assumes that at the end of the two years, the vehicles can be sold as used cars for 70 percent of their value when they were new.
"Right now the used-car market is extremely strong," said Tom Webb, chief economist at the National Association of Automobile Dealers. "But the industry is gambling on the future."
Exports, on the other hand, seem to have a bright future, particularly machinery sales abroad. With the dollar weak, exports have slowly risen to more than $40 billion a month. That has certainly helped companies like the Bison Gear and Engineering Company in St. Charles, Ill. It makes gears for motors that go mostly into restaurant dishwashers, rotisseries and other commercial kitchen equipment. Sales are up 35 percent in the last year, to $35 million, and the staff has grown to 175 from 150, said Ronald D. Bullock, the chief executive.
"We had been working people on overtime and we did not want to burn them out," he said.
Exports now represent 5 percent of Bison's sales revenue, up from zero three years ago. Fast-food chains like McDonald's, opening outlets in Europe, have turned to American companies for equipment, finding them to be lower-priced than Japanese and Belgian suppliers, Mr. Bullock said. Aside from the weak dollar, Bison's growing efficiency makes this possible, he said.
Feeding the auto and housing booms are the rising amounts of money now available to many households. The average hourly wage has not kept up with inflation for most workers, but overtime pay is at record levels. And the addition of five million jobs since January 1993 has meant five million new salaries, including 239,000 in September, when the unemployment rate fell to 5.9 percent from 6.1 percent.
This money has sharply increased the total income of the American population. What Government statisticians call disposable income -- the earnings people have left after taxes -- rose by 5.6 percent for the year ended in August, to $5 trillion, compared with a 4.1 percent rise in August 1993.
Mortgage refinancing and bank loans supplement this income. "I know folks who refinanced two or three times, going from a 30-year mortgage at 12 percent to a 15-year mortgage at 7 percent and still saving $300 a month," said Leland M. Stenehjem Jr., president of the First International Bank and Trust Company in Fargo, N.D.
The total saving of $100 billion a year, by some estimates, was diverted to spending or to financing personal loans and credit card spending. And banks, having spent the early 1990's investing heavily in Treasury securities, found they could make more money by switching back to aggressive lending. Bank loans have been rising ever since.
But two problems might be on the horizon. One involves households with variable rate mortgages -- 25 percent of all mortgage holders. With interest rates up, their mortgage payments will rise as annual adjustments are made. And the rise will offset some of the $100 billion gained from the refinancing.
The aggressive bank lending, particularly to support credit card debt, is another area of incipient concern.
"Consumer delinquencies are the lowest they have been in 20 years," said James Chessen, chief economist at the American Bankers Association. "But I think that by the end of this year, we will see these delinquencies rise again, because of the volume of credit and the willingness to make loans that a year ago were considered too risky."

HEADLINE: Pataki Takes His Campaign Message to Harlem Church

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
For State Senator George E. Pataki, the campaign trail led yesterday to Harlem, where he addressed a Baptist congregation and spoke of the need for jobs, health care and economic revitalization in the community beyond the church's doors.
Members of the Abyssinian Baptist Church said they were not surprised that the visit of a gubernatorial candidate coincided with the approach of Election Day. 
 But in a season of political discontent, in which many black voters say they feel taken for granted by the Democratic Party, Mr. Pataki's message was politely received. And several at the church said the fact that the Republican bothered to come at all was significant and made him worthy of consideration, if not, ultimately, their support.
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, Abyssinian's pastor, has yet to endorse either Mr. Pataki or Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Though he plans to meet with Mr. Cuomo sometime this week, he has in the past called the Governor "arrogant." And yesterday he said the incumbent had not visited the church in his 12 years in office.
"If our votes are so important, if we carry the margin of victory, then those who want our vote ought to respect us enough to come and talk to us," Mr. Butts said to resounding applause, moments before he introduced Mr. Pataki.
Mr. Pataki, who attended the morning service with his wife, Libby, had come with prepared notes. But when he finally addressed the church, he put the notes aside.
Mr. Pataki spoke of the common desire by all New Yorkers to have access to quality education, good health care and a decent place to live. Though he offered few specifics, Mr. Pataki said that as Governor he would work to insure Harlem residents had a chance at those dreams.
Every parent has the same aspirations for a child, he said: "that that child can get a decent education; that that child can get adequate health care." He continued, "And yet in Harlem right now we have a health-care crisis, we have an explosion in infant death. Unacceptable."
Mr. Pataki also spoke of the need to help the economy, saying he would support opening a community-based bank in Harlem to foster redevelopment.
He ended his short address by quoting a verse from the gospel of Matthew. "By their fruits ye shall know them," he said. "I pledge to you, you will know me by my actions, and those actions will bear fruit."
Among those who listened to Mr. Pataki's message at the church was the Rev. Al Sharpton, the church's guest speaker, who used his moments at the pulpit to warn Democrats and Republicans alike that black votes are promised to no one.
"We too often keep loyalty to people who are not showing loyalty to us," Mr. Sharpton said. He added, "There's a peculiar political marriage between the Democratic Party and the black community. And we have been abandoned wives."
But Mr. Sharpton, who formed his own Freedom Party this year partly because he believes mainstream parties have not served blacks well, cautioned that just because some blacks were disenchanted with the Democratic Party did not mean they would automatically throw their support to the Republicans.
"We hope both sides will court us," said Mr. Sharpton, who said he wants to hear more specifics from the gubernatorial candidates before giving his support. "Democrats take us for granted. But Republicans should not take us for fools."
Blacks are a core constituency for Mr. Cuomo, and a large black turnout is considered critical if he is to win a fourth term. But some who have always voted for Mr. Cuomo said yesterday that for the first time in their lives, they are on the fence.
Naomi Henry, 62, said the Democratic voting tradition began in her family in the 1930's, with the election of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the beginning of his New Deal.
But Democrats, from Washington to Albany, have not upheld their end of the bargain, she said. Mr. Cuomo has done nothing to help Harlem, she said, adding that she was angered by his lukewarm support for Mayor David N. Dinkins's re-election bid last year. The trouble is, she does not know if she can trust the other parties to be any better.
"I really feel we're being used by all of them," she said outside the church on West 138th Street. "We only see them at this time. It's funny. Our vote means so much today, but not the rest of the year."
James L. Hudson also had many complaints about Mr. Cuomo, He even voted for Lenora Fulani in the Democratic primary, "not because I thought she would win," Mr. Hudson said, "but because I wanted Cuomo to know it wasn't so easy."
But come Nov. 8, he will vote again for Mr. Cuomo, because the Governor dared to ask for one more term and of all the candidates, Mr. Hudson knows him best.
"I'll hold my nose," he said. "It'll be the most painful vote I ever gave to anybody."

HEADLINE: For Brazil, New Praise and Potential

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 6

 BODY:
With Fernando Henrique Cardoso's decisive victory in Brazil's presidential elections, foreign diplomats and business leaders predict that Latin America's largest economy will become a powerful magnet for foreign investment and exports.
"You can't put a limit on the possibilities," the United States Ambassador, Melvyn Levitsky, said here, citing Mr. Cardoso's pledges to allow foreign investment in oil, telecommunications, mining and public works. "There are going to be many, many more opportunities for U.S. companies to invest in Brazil and to export to Brazil." 
 Down the street, Ambassador Peter W. Heap of Britain, noted a stream of visiting British executives: "In the next week, I will be seeing here the chairman of British American Tobacco, the chairman of SmithKline Beecham, the pharmaceutical company. The chief executive of Jaguar cars is coming to open showrooms in Sao Paulo and Rio for the first time."
At the French Embassy, the talk was of last week's announcement by Renault to build a factory in Brazil next year capable of manufacturing 100,000 cars a year. And at the German Embassy, the talk was of plans by Volkswagen and Ford to join Brazil's multibillion-dollar rush to expand the country's automobile production.
Five years ago similar praise was heard here when Brazilians elected Fernando Collor de Mello, a more outspoken free-market advocate than Mr. Cardoso. But today's mushrooming of concrete investment plans reflects fundamental differences between the two men and the economic moments.
Mr. Cardoso, 63, a veteran senator from Sao Paulo, the business heartland, will take office on Jan. 1 with a three-party coalition that will have a loose congressional majority. As Finance Minister until last April, Mr. Cardoso started Brazil on the Real Plan, a currency change that has proved to be a successful first step in a long battle against inflation.
Mr. Collor, a former governor of Alagoas state, Brazil's poorest, was elected at age 39 with virtually no formal party support. But he was forced to resign in 1992 after the Brazilian news media and Congress turned against him amid accusations of corruption.
But Mr. Collor's legacy to Brazil was a national course correction, away from controls to free markets.
In the last two years, Brazil's imports have jumped 50 percent, to $30 billion; new foreign investment has doubled, to $23 billion, and foreign reserves have almost doubled, to $43 billion. With the adoption of the new currency on July 1, monthly inflation plummeted, from 45 percent in June to 1.5 percent in September, the lowest since 1973.
"Whoever tries to make decisions against the market is going to fail," Mr. Cardoso said after the election on Monday. He called for foreign joint ventures in Brazilian oil exploration and foreign participation in hydroelectric projects.
The big question now is whether Mr. Cardoso will be able to marshal congressional support to continue the inflation fight. Such support will be needed to change the constitution to allow foreign investment in mining, oil and telecommunications, reorganize the bankrupt social welfare system, shut down bankrupt state banks and transfer health and education responsibilities to states.
"If Brazil can prove successful in stabilizing and restructuring its economy, some investors are predicting that growth in the region could approach Asian proportions," William R. Rhodes, a vice chairman of Citibank, said last week.
Mr. Cardoso's backers think he will have the power to execute the changes. Mr. Cardoso was elected with a near majority in Congress, and with centrists leading runoff races for most state governorships.
Reflecting a new consensus for stability, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, the main left-wing presidential candidate, said before the elections: "I am convinced that independently of who wins the election, we all have to make a great effort so that inflation never returns to this country."
For the moment, Brazilians are cautiously discarding the inflationary habits of 20 years. With monthly inflation forecast at about 2 percent through the end of the year, Brazilians now pay with cash instead of checks drawn on interest-bearing accounts. In a signal to markets, the Government is lowering telephone, gasoline and postal rates.
"We are betting that inflation will not come back," said Roberto Civita, president of Abril, Brazil's largest publishing group.
Indeed, even if Mr. Cardoso's anti-inflation plan lumbers forward unevenly, there seems to be no stopping investment into an economy that is repeating last year's growth rate of 5 percent. Despite 1993 inflation in four digits, Brazil's top 500 private companies had average growth in profits of 11.6 percent -- the highest increase in 15 years.
Even without constitutional changes, Government officials are exploiting loopholes to open up the economy. Telebras, the state phone company, adopted rules in August that allow partnerships with private companies to install lines, switchboards, cellular and fiber optic systems. Telesp, the Sao Paulo telephone company, is preparing bids for 500,000 new lines. With each line expected to cost $2,000, installation contracts could be $1 billion. Other state companies are following suit, with contracts expected to add up to a further $1 billion.
Officials are abolishing paper work for imports and are allowing more foreign banks and insurance companies to open agencies.
"Over the next two months, we are going to get rid of the bureaucratic garbage surrounding imports," Ailton Barcelos Fernandes, executive secretary of the Trade Ministry, said here. "Brazil's trade opening is absolutely irreversible. We want to import more." He predicted that trade would increase about 14 percent this year, to $72 billion. Government officials saw that increasing to $120 billion in 1996.
Brazil's imports from the United States, growing almost twice as fast as those from any other region, are expected to rise by 25 to 35 percent this year. The United States Commerce Department is expanding its staff in Sao Paulo and opening offices in the industrial cities of Belo Horizonte and Porto Alegre.
"If the reforms are continued, if inflation is kept under control, there is a very big chance that looking back from the end of this century, Brazil could be the big success story," Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The election of Fernando Henrique Cardoso as Brazil's President has generated praise for the country's potential as a magnet for foreign investment. Mr. Cardoso spoke at a news conference in Brasilia last week. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Bettman On Move, But Are The Talks?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Toronto is not No. 1 on Gary Bettman's itinerary of favorite spots to visit right now. But with little time left to reach an agreement before Saturday, the National Hockey League commissioner will be there today to receive a new proposal from union negotiators.
Bettman would have preferred the bargaining session to have taken place in New York for two reasons: One, Canadian fans seem to be angrier about the absence of hockey during what is supposed to be the hockey season than their counterparts south of the border; two, Bettman has a board of governors meeting scheduled for tomorrow, which means he would have to return to New York and have less time to negotiate if he finds something worth talking about. 
 One person with ties to management said yesterday that the owners expect the union to present a proposal that addresses a lot of issues but doesn't come anywhere near what they feel they need. When Bob Goodenow, the union leader, was asked if the proposal would be more comprehensive than the core issues the two sides have been debating, he said, "We're looking at a lot of issues."
It's possible that Bettman will look for something in the union's move that he can use to justify opening the season Saturday, his designated Opening Night II, even without an agreement.
Bettman announced Sept. 30 that he was postponing the start of the season for two weeks. After meeting with the owners tomorrow, he conceivably could announce that the season will open Saturday night, giving himself and Goodenow a period of, say, 30 or 60 days to reach an agreement. If they fail, his plan could call for a lockout of the players at that time.
Throughout recent negotiations, the two sides have focused on a payroll tax that the owners say would create a needed revenue-sharing pool for low-revenue teams and that the players say would induce the highest-spending teams to reduce their payrolls closer to the league average.
Last week the league added to its proposal a tax on gate receipts that the union has proposed. "Gate sharing is a revolutionary concept in this sport," said Jeffrey Pash, the league's general counsel.
Since last Wednesday, the union has been working on its new proposal, and it could include ideas on rookies salaries, salary arbitration and free agency, issues that also have to be resolved but that have been nudged to the background while the concept of a payroll tax is thrashed out.
Player members of the union's negotiating committee met with Goodenow in Toronto yesterday to go over the proposal. One person close to the union said some players are "more hawkish" than Goodenow, a circumstance that could make it difficult for Goodenow to formulate the kind of proposal that could lead to progress in the talks.
The union's proposal may reflect what appears to be the league's reduction in the amount of money it wants to create for low-revenue teams. In earlier proposals, the league set a $30 million figure, but its latest proposal lowered that figure to $20 million.
"What happened to this being driven by the needs of small-market teams?" the person who talked about hawkish players asked. "Bettman cares about revenue sharing, but most of the owners don't."
The teams considered most in economic need are Winnipeg, Quebec, Edmonton and Hartford, the teams that perhaps not so coincidentally joined the N.H.L. in 1979 as refugees from the World Hockey Association.
The players believe revenue sharing is a cover for what they perceive as the owners' effort to lower salaries. But league officials deny that is their goal.
"We deny flatly, unequivocally, without equivocation, without qualification, that our goal is to have teams reduce their payrolls," Pash said. "It is false. It has never been a part of our proposal. We have offered from the very start of these discussions to guarantee to them a percentage of revenue or absolute dollars that they will receive as a floor what they receive now.
"We're not looking for payrolls to be reduced. We're talking about how money is going to be allocated."
But the teams, Pash said, would like to slow the escalation of salaries. To this point, he added, the players' proposal wouldn't achieve that goal.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Once, a Penny Saved; Now, a Dollar Charged

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:
A PIECE OF THE ACTION
How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class
By Joseph Nocera
464 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25.
"Over the past two decades, we've been participating in nothing less than a money revolution," writes Joseph Nocera, a business and financial journalist, in his entertaining but uncritical cultural history, "A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class." 
 "Money revolution" is "not a term I use lightly," he continues. "When one recalls what the financial life of the middle class was like 20 years ago -- when thrift was the highest value, when the daily movement of the Dow Jones average had almost no relevance to our lives, when few of us knew what a mutual fund was, much less the distinction between, say, a growth fund and a balanced fund -- it's hard not to conclude that the change has, indeed, been revolutionary."
How did the change come about that has permitted the middle class to spend and invest in a way that once only the wealthy could do? Mr. Nocera traces the change to three major financial innovations: the widespread acceptance of the credit card, which democratized debt; the rise of the mutual fund, which democratized investment, and the coming of the discount brokerage house, which democratized investment strategy.
What spurred these innovations, Mr. Nocera reasons, was a shift in the financial ethos of the average American caused by the great inflation of the late 1970's and early 1980's. The resulting decline in the value of money wiped away the lesson taught by the Great Depression of saving now and spending later, and replaced it with the practice of spending now and paying later, with cheaper dollars. A climate of thrift gave way to one of extravagance.
This shift, along with the arrival of credit cards, mutual funds and discount brokers, built up a pressure that eventually blew away the legal barriers that once separated such entities as banks and brokerage houses, savings accounts and money-market funds. Once these barriers fell, the middle class rushed in to stay.
Mr. Nocera recounts how all this happened in what he aptly describes as a melding of history with journalism. What makes his narrative tick along so effectively, though, is his close-up portraits of figures like Charles Merrill, who dreamed of selling stocks to everyone but failed because he disliked mutual funds; Dee Ward Hock, who evolved the Visa card and made it work; Edward Crosby (Ned) Johnson of Fidelity Management and Research, who thought up the idea of a money-market fund with check-writing privileges, and Charles Schwab, who pioneered the discount brokerage.
The result is particularly absorbing because it describes a series of events that most readers will find as familiar as mashed potatoes, yet it places them in a larger context that is well known only to those who follow the financial pages closely. One minor flaw in the book is, paradoxically, that it tends to get bogged down in good but beside-the-point drama, like the story of Ted and Nina Wang, two Hong Kong stock speculators who immediately after Black Monday, 1987, owed Charles Schwab & Company $84 million in unpaid margin calls. Nina Wang bargained the settlement down to $67 million. Her husband was shortly thereafter kidnapped for a $60 million ransom, $30 million of which is said to have been paid by his wife, yet he was never seen again.
Not that "A Piece of the Action" doesn't elaborate the thesis summed up in its subtitle, "How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class." It does, complete with statistics on the rise of credit-card debt and the huge number of people who stayed in the stock market even after the 1987 crash. Moreover, Mr. Nocera holds that the money revolution he describes is "a force for good" because we "have tools and resources at our disposal that were formerly unavailable to us, and we have been handed possibilities for making money that had always been out of our reach."
The trouble is that he fails to resolve that part of his thesis that involves the spectacular piling up of debt as a consequence of a lingering inflation psychology. Fittingly enough, he cites John Kenneth Galbraith and Alfred L. Malabre Jr. as twin Cassandras decrying economies built on debt, Mr. Galbraith in his 1958 book, "The Affluent Society," and Mr. Malabre in "Beyond Our Means: How America's Long Years of Debt, Deficits and Reckless Borrowing Now Threaten to Overwhelm Us," published three decades later.
Yet he never explores the deeper messages of these books. He states that debt primes the economy but fails to acknowledge that spending money one doesn't have also risks pushing the act of saving it into a future burdened with endless interest payments. The paradigm of his book may well be one Andrew Kahr, a brilliant analyst of the credit-card market, whose ideal customer would take 44 years and $4,950 in interest to pay off a $1,000 loan.
What "A Piece of the Action" never acknowledges is that if marketers like Mr. Kahr had their way, instead of rising into the money class, most of us would sink into the un-money class. As the old song puts it, we'd keep getting another day older and deeper in debt, and we'd owe our souls to the company store.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph Nocera (Fred Woodward/Simon & Schuster)

HEADLINE: IN PERFORMANCE;
CLASSICAL MUSIC

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
From Comedy to Cuteness
In a Storybook Setting
New York State Theater
The New York City Opera has an economical property in Lotfi Mansouri's production of "Il Barbiere di Siviglia." The single set, by Desmond Heeley, uses reversible elements so that outdoor scenes give way to indoor ones with quick efficiency. But it has its troublesome aspects. The costumes, blindingly bright and occasionally garish, contribute to the storybook quality that Mr. Mansouri seems to have been after, and Christian Smith's stage direction pushes beyond the bounds of comic opera and well into the territory of late-19th-century operetta. Comedy defers to cuteness, and cuteness quickly grows cloying. 
 The singers on Thursday evening seemed more than happy to ham their way through "Barbiere." This was a familiar approach for Erie Mills, whose portrayal of Rosina was from a generic operetta mold. Still, her soprano is compact and well-projected, and she sang "Una voce poco fa" with considerable charm.
Charles Workman, the Almaviva, began tenuously, but he overcame his initial intonation problems, and in the second act his voice blossomed nicely. Louis Otey's Figaro was suitably virtuosic, but inconsistent. Most of the time he sang with great agility, but he occasionally slurred Rossini's florid lines, negating a principal attraction of the style.
Joseph McKee was a suitably creaky Bartolo, and Carla Wood, a mezzo-soprano in her first season at the house, made a good impression with Berta's second-act showpiece.
Joseph Colaneri conducted without much fire, but William Barto Jones provided some amusingly busy harpsichord flourishes, and there were some lovely guitar accompaniments played by Frederic Hand. ALLAN KOZINN

LENGTH: 472 words

HEADLINE: British Labor's New Look

 BODY:
Tony Blair's promising debut as leader of the Labor Party signals an important turn in British politics. Since the rise of Margaret Thatcher 15 years ago, Labor, Britain's ruling party for most of the 1960's and 70's, has seemed fusty and often irrelevant. Now a revitalized Labor is storming back, with updated policies, a strong lead in the polls and a telegenic young leader. This sharpening of political competition is healthy for British democracy and, hence, welcome to Americans as well.
Mr. Blair benefits from groundwork done by his recent predecessors. Neil Kinnock began revising obsolete policies favoring unilateral disarmament and state ownership. The late John Smith healed internal wounds and reconnected the party with followers who had been alienated by the cultural radicalism of recent decades. But it falls to Mr. Blair, who took over in July, to complete the process of generational and philosophical renewal. 
 At last week's party conference, the new leader got to work. While he has been vague about details -- leading some to call him "Tony Blur" -- his intention to shift the party's emphasis from class enmity and state ownership to social cooperation and humane progressivism is plain. He failed to get the party to drop the traditional call for nationalization from its platform, but came tantalizingly close.
As Bill Clinton knows, New Democrats are not always easy winners. But repositioned Labor is well placed to win back centrist voters whose defection to minor parties like the Liberals and Social Democrats (now merged) helped Margaret Thatcher win huge Conservative parliamentary majorities with only a minority of the popular vote.
Britons still think far more in class terms than Americans do. Labor is, by definition, a party built around the working class. But the suburbanized workers of today's service economy have different interests than their coal-mining and factory-laboring grandparents. They care about well-run and adequately financed social services, decent education and keeping up with Continental living standards rather than state ownership, unilateral disarmament and sympathy with Soviet Russia.
On issues of special interest to the U.S., Tony Blair's Labor is more eager for a Northern Ireland settlement, more enthusiastic about the European Union and more favorable to a comprehensive test ban treaty than John Major's Conservatives.
America's traditionally warm relations with Britain do not depend on which party holds power in London. But the celebrated special relationship forged in World War II is now based more on nostalgia than contemporary reality. Even this, our closest diplomatic bond, needs constant attention and renewal. By modernizing the British political debate, a revitalized Labor Party can significantly contribute to that effort.

HEADLINE: Essay;
To Counter Saddam's Ploy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The first foreign-policy blunder made by Bill Clinton, soon after his election, was about Saddam Hussein. The President-elect told Tom Friedman of The New York Times that as a good Baptist he believed in conversion, and that perhaps the dictator could be dealt with if he acceded to U.N. arms-destruction and human-rights requirements.
Some of us turned purple. That was contrary to the hard-line American position to use sanctions to force the tyrant from power. President Bush had sent an unambiguous message to Baghdad: get rid of Saddam or forget about pumping oil. Clinton's remark offered Saddam room to maneuver. 
 President Clinton found a way out of that gaffe by professing to foresee no way that Saddam could obey the U.N. resolution's requirements and remain in power. Then Clinton exhibited toughness in putting a missile into the window of Saddam's spy chief as retaliation for the plot to assassinate former President Bush.
The hard-line policy has evidently been working. Two weeks ago, the cash-strapped Saddam had to stop subsidizing food prices, which then doubled, causing internal unrest. If he cannot show some promise of ending sanctions, he will be deposed.
That is why the dictator has been appearing to comply with the U.N. inspectors searching for mass-destruction weapons factories. This week, inspector Rolf Ekeus will tell the U.N. that a monitoring system is finally in operation, and Iraq's Tariq Aziz will demand that the U.N. stop starving Iraqi babies (though the Republican Guard is well fed).
Saddam will have support in the Security Council. Russian intelligence chief Yevgeny Primakov is Saddam's longtime ally; Russia will support the lifting of sanctions, if only to make possible the repayment of $6 billion owed Moscow by Iraq. France's Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, is salivating at the prospect of his nation's resuming business with its best oil source.
France or Russia care little that Saddam continues to try to strangle Iraq's Kurdish minority and starve its Shias, or will surely circumvent arms inspections at the first opportunity; what does cause them to hesitate is Saddam's continued claim of ownership of Kuwait.
Now we come to Saddam's reason for the well-publicized movement of Iraqi troops -- including the Hammurabi division of the Republican Guard spared by the shortsighted men in the Oval Office on March 26, 1991 -- to the Kuwaiti border.
The reason may be that Saddam has observed Clinton in Bosnia, Haiti and North Korea and thinks it may be possible to snatch a couple of islands and make a face-saving deal with a State Department feeling the pressure to out-Carter Jimmy Carter. That's a misreading of geopolitics, but Saddam has been wrong before.
The more likely reason is to create a favorable basis for negotiation of an end to sanctions. He now has the world's attention. Here is his stick-and-carrot strategy:
First, the stick: If sanctions are not lifted now, he will threaten to throw out the U.N. inspectors and begin re-arming. He thinks the world will not make war on him for that; indeed many U.S. editorialists will agree with Moscow and Paris that Saddam was the poor victim of demonizing American hard-liners.
Second, the carrot: If sanctions are lifted to allow his oil to flow, then not only will he allow the inspectors to stay, but he will refrain from once again taking over Iraq's 19th province, which calls itself Kuwait.
Not so stupid. By creating a threat, Saddam makes possible his grand concession: If we will let bygones be bygones, he will not make war. Paris may even extract "recognition" of Kuwait and claim a diplomatic triumph, deserving of instant trade relations.
Here is what Clinton's response should be:
If Saddam moves on Kuwait, that will trigger a fight to the finish: destruction of his forces, a parade in Baghdad, establishment of Kurdistan, war crimes trials, free elections.
If he refrains from invasion but throws out inspectors not only will sanctions be tightened but the U.S. and its allies will "inspect" by national means and will regularly bomb suspected nuclear, germ and chemwar sites.
Hope for Iraqis: If Saddam is overthrown, sanctions will be lifted. Sometimes the only conversion possible is in a baptism of fire.
