SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 4787 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Pataki on the Record: Excerpts From a Talk On Campaign Issues

 BODY:
State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor of New York, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times for two hours on Friday to discuss issues in the gubernatorial race and his goals if elected. Here are excerpts from the session.
 
FISCAL MATTERS
 
Taxing and Spending
[Senator Pataki was asked how he will be able to reconcile his campaign promises to cut taxes and control spending while also increasing aid to education and improving other state services.] 
PATAKI First of all, let me say: We are going to control spending because we have to control spending. And it's not something that's unique to government or unique to the state government. Look what Mayor Giuliani has done right here in the last year. He had a $2 billion-plus budget gap. And he didn't raise taxes. He's done it by controlling spending. And he's done it by things like by cutting positions in the central Board of Education. We have outlined a large number of different areas where significant savings can be made.
 Our tax cut plan hinges on two things:
 One is we're anticipating an increase in the revenue of the state. We're anticipating a lower increase than has traditionally or historically been the case, even during Mario Cuomo's two terms.
 And the second is we are going to keep spending below the rate of inflation -- spending increases. That still allows for significant spending increases. It just doesn't allow for the hemorrhaging of money as we saw in Albany this year. This year, state spending in Albany, I think, is up 9.9 percent. It's up over $5 billion. More than three times the rate of inflation. And I don't think there's anybody in this state saying, "Isn't that a wonderful thing that we're finally going to solve New York's problems by having the state government spend a lot more." . . .
 And Mario Cuomo says, well, you can't control spending. You can't cut taxes. You have to. It's being done all around us, not just in New York City. The last three years Westchester County has kept its spending increase to less than 1 percent -- in the last three years. And yet they've had the higher Medicaid costs and the higher social-service costs and mandates imposed by the state government. But they've done it.
 Q. He says you can't cut spending or cut taxes to the degree that you want to.
 A. In other words, he's saying we can't keep spending increases below the rate of inflation. That's his record. He hasn't been able to keep spending increases below the rate of inflation. . . .
 The cumulative record of Mario Cuomo, in his 12 years in office, is that spending has increased at more than twice the rate of inflation. And this year it increased at more than three times the rate of inflation. So I think when he says he can't keep the spending increase below the rate of inflation, I think he's right. He can't.
 But we can and we will because we're going to impose discipline. . . .
 
Welfare Costs
 [Mr. Pataki said he would look at how to make government more efficient.]
 PATAKI . . . Let me just give you one major area where significant cost-savings can be achieved and where Mario Cuomo has failed miserably and you haven't taken him to task on it. And that is the Home Relief population of welfare. The Home Relief population of welfare is a nonfederally-mandated program. It's a program where the states can voluntarily decide: Do we have the program or do we not have the program? We have unending permanent Home Relief benefits. I don't know what other states do, but it's a handful, and none of the surrounding state have that. Home Relief in this state has gone up, under Mario Cuomo, by close to 100 percent. The population is now almost 400,000 people

 	 	 		. . .	 	 [The Senator also said that when Mario M. Cuomo became Governor, 34 percent of the Home Relief population was in workfare programs but that now only 14 percent are.]
 PATAKI Workfare saves money. Take a look at what happened in Westchester County. Their Home Relief costs are down more than 25 percent. I was saying 20 percent. It's more than 25 and closer to 30 percent because they have put in place a successful workfare program. It's not like reinventing the wheel. It's not like we have to, at the state level, come up with some creative concept that hasn't been considered before. It works. It's working right above this city government.
 And yet Mario Cuomo yesterday says, or whenever he sat down for his filibuster, says you've got two alternatives: private-sector jobs, and in private-sector jobs we are doing horribly, or public-sector jobs. No. You have community service. You have workfare, which is precisely what has happened up there. And you're not creating a new bureaucracy. You're not hiring someone on Home Relief at $18,000 a year to become a public employee. You are requiring them, week in and week out, to show up for public service work.
 Q. So, Senator, would you put the entire Home Relief population on workfare

 	 	 		. . .	 	 A. Absolutely.
 Q. Would you eliminate education programs, job training programs
 A. No. And in fact the Westchester program incorporates that. It incorporates job training. It incorporates education. And it has been extremely successful. And there are a number of ways that this works. One is that it reduces the number of people who are living or employed someplace else, so that you have a reduction in the number of people because the ineligibles don't show up. They're not there. Two, you create a sense of self-worth and dignity in the person who is receiving workfare. And I think this is an incredibly important part of this program -- is it's not simply to reduce fraud and save money. It's to create the sense of self-worth and pride that comes from going out and being a working, contributing member of society. . . .
 I was sitting in my Senate office in downtown Peekskill a year or so ago and a man comes in to interview me. He's a student at Mercy College. And he starts asking me about my thoughts on the Senate, and I tell him my ideas. And, as often happens, I start asking him about his life and what he's doing. He was a heroin addict on welfare in the Bronx. And he had decided that if he didn't straighten his life out he was going to die. So what he did is, he said, I have to get out of the neighborhood. Moved to Peekskill. Got off drugs. Was living in Peekskill, off drugs but on welfare. Just sitting home doing nothing.
 Westchester put in place its pride-in-work program. He had to show up. And all of a sudden he realized he had some ability. He had some skills. And when he came in to interview me, he was doing public service work for the city of Peekskill at the Water Department in a job that didn't displace a public employee. And the unions were supportive of the program because they were talked to and it was made clear that the work that would be done would not displace public employees but would be work that otherwise would have never been gotten to. . . .
 When he was interviewing me he was still on public service, he was doing public service work for the city through the county program and he was a student -- I think he was a sophomore at Mercy College, getting A's and B's -- and this person's going to make something of his life. So it's not simply the saving of money, which is obviously very important, but it's also the changing of approaches and attitudes to life. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Will Cuts Be Painful?
 Q. You're offering people a $6 billion tax cut, we just want to hear you say what is going to be the cost of that on the other side.
 A. The cost of that on the other side is that we are going to keep the rate of spending increase at the state level to less than the rate of increase of inflation over the four-year period. And I don't think that is something that in any way is going to impose hardship on the people of this state. In fact, I think it's going to be a huge relief to the people of this state that we are finally controlling spending, we are finally cutting taxes.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Job Creation
 [The Senator was asked how he explains the strong job growth in New York in the mid-1980's.]
 PATAKI We lagged the national average. We have been 47th in the country in job growth since Mario Cuomo's been Governor for 12 years. And Mario Cuomo says, "Oh, it's Ronald Reagan's fault, it's George Bush's fault, it's the Japanese's fault. And yet, look what I did in the middle 80's." What you did in the middle 80's was, when there was a national boom, you lagged that national boom. We created jobs at a slower rate than the rest of the country. When the recession hit, we lost jobs at a faster rate than the rest of the country.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Why? Is it because we don't have people? Is it because we don't have capital? Is it because people aren't willing to work here? They don't have the commitment or the risk taking or the entrepreneurial spirit? Of course not. We have the most talented people in this country right here in this state. But they're being killed by overtaxation, overregulation, things like raids on the workers compensation fund.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Aid to New York City
 Q. Senator, while we're talking about school aid, what should New York City's percentage of school aid be?
 A. Well, first of all, let me say that the Mayor should have control over the education system in this city, and it's something the Mayor has wanted. He's right. He's responsible. He's the one who's accountable. He's the one who has to balance the budget and provide the budget, he should be given that authority.
 I know the argument. It's like 34.5 percent of the aid and 37 percent of the students under the formula. But you can't look at it simply under that formula, you have to look at all the different aid packages, the transportation-aid package, it's the Medicaid assistance package, and the city should be treated fairly. The success of the city is critical, absolutely critical to the success of the state.
 Q. Is it treated fairly now in terms of education aid?
 A. I don't think any local government is being treated fairly, whether it's in Medicaid or education. . . .
 It has been the pattern of this administration to have wonderful programs that you can announce, but they have to be paid for by the county government or the city government so that it's the local politician who has to raise the tax and get yelled at.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Limits on Medicaid
 [Senator Pataki was asked whether he would limit some of the services that the state now provides under Medicaid.] PATAKI I think, personally, it's absurd that somebody can get a hair transplant paid for by Medicaid. It makes no sense. And I think that's the case: that you can't. And I do not want to see us dramatically cut the benefits available to Medicaid recipients, particularly the A.F.D.C. population. We don't want to hurt kids and we don't want to hurt mothers caring for children. But there are things like: There is no reason why the taxpayer should fund hair transplants for somebody on Medicaid. . . .
 Q. How much is spent on hair transplants?
 A. I have no idea. I mean, let me make an absolute confession. We are not going to pay for the $5.6 billion in tax cuts by eliminating hair transplants from Medicaid. I know that's a pretty dramatic concession for me to make. But I think it's more emblematic than financial in its implications.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Q. And if your projections don't work out, how would you then confront that situation? Would you do like the Legislature and the Governor did in the 90's and postpone the tax cuts?
 A. No. . . .
 We are going to enact this tax cut plan. It is going to happen. And if you look at the numbers -- in the fourth year, the total cost of the tax cut package is a little over $5.6 billion. . . .
 What I'm going to look to do next year is see if we can avoid increasing spending at all. It's what Governor Weld did his first year in Massachusetts, he had no increase in spending. Governor Whitman, her first year in office had no increase in spending. Mayor Giuliani, his first year in office had no increase in spending. This projection is sound even with an increase in spending of 2.7 percent a year.
 I'll tell you, absolutely honestly, I believe we can make the savings, change the system, put in place the cost-containment measures and improve the efficiencies of government to the point where we don't have to increase spending at that point. So I think it is a sound and conservative plan.
 
CRIME AND PUNISHMENT
 
The Death Penalty
 Q. Why is the death penalty a greater deterrent than life without parole, and under what circumstances do you envision yourself commuting a death sentence as governor?
 [The Senator began by talking about Governor Cuomo's "three strikes and you're in" proposal -- which would sentence three-time violent offenders to life in prison without parole -- and what it would mean to someone who has already served two sentences as a violent felon.]
 PATAKI You're out there committing another violent felony. You're holding up the cabdriver or holding up the shop. You know that if you're caught again, you're gone -- life without parole. Never out on the street again. If you kill that person, if you kill the shopkeeper, you're less likely to get caught. You have no witness, you have nobody to testify against you. And if by some chance you do get caught, it's the same penalty -- life without parole. You are creating a perverse incentive for a violent felon to kill if you have life without parole without the death penalty.
 Think for a minute -- a police officer wanders into a bodega, somebody's holding up the storekeeper, he's already served two violent felonies. The police officer wanders in -- what's going on? He surrenders -- life without parole. He kills the police officer, he has a chance of getting away, and if he gets caught -- life without parole. . . . So if we have "three strikes, you're in" without the death penalty for someone who has already served those two violent felonies and would kill, we are creating a perverse incentive. It's the law of unintended consequences where someone who is violent, who is a criminal, has an incentive to kill.
 So I believe that you can't -- you have to couple "three strikes and you're in" with the death penalty.
 Now you ask, what makes you think the death penalty is a deterrent or should be a part of the criminal justice system? Let me give you two broad philosophical reasons: One -- there are two -- one is deterrence, and one is justice.
 Deterrence: I happen to think that there -- and I firmly believe that -- that there are rational circumstances where -- and it's not the case of somebody is high on drugs or a mental patient or someone who in the heat of passion commits a murder -- but there are rational killers who make a determination that, and do an analysis and say, I'm going to kill someone. And the death penalty is a factor. . . .
 And the second part is I truly believe that the death penalty is a part of a fair system of justice. We have the bombing in the World Trade Center, I think a terrorist who commits that act, the system of justice, has forfeited his right to live and we as a society have the right to take that person's life. . . .
 [Senator Pataki was asked if there are circumstances under which he would commute a death sentence.]
 PATAKI I think it's conceivable. You never say that it's, under no circumstances is it possible. You'd have to take a look, that's something that is sui generis. I don't mean to sound like Mario Cuomo, but it's unique, to the circumstances.
Drug Offenders [The Senator was asked about Governor Cuomo's belief that many people in state prisons should be in other kind of programs, particularly nonviolent drug offenders.]
 PATAKI I think to say that someone who is a predicate felon who's been convicted of a second felony doesn't belong in jail, is wrong. A predicate felon, someone who has been convicted of two felonies, belongs in jail. . . .
 You get arrested, you get tried, you get convicted. What happens is you don't serve one day. Not one day. You are out on the street the same day. And you can check with any criminal justice expert in this city. When you plead to your drug felony conviction for selling drugs, you do not get one day in this city. And check with any judge, district attorney, defense attorney. That's what happens. They're out on the street the same day. What message does this send to the community? What message does this send to the kid convicted of a drug felony -- zero time. . . .
 I think that the first time we have to do something to save that kid, to save that person who has been convicted of the felony of selling drugs. And instead of just saying you're back out on the street corner, we have to do things like have structured correctional programs where that person is required to do things as a penalty for having been convicted. And it's a way to avoid that second felony conviction. . . .
Gun Control
 Q. There's been some confusion about your votes on banning assault weapons. Can you explain what your position is?
 A. We should ban assault weapons. It doesn't make any sense to me that someone could have an AK-47 or an Uzi or a Street Sweeper that serves no valid self-defense purpose and serves no valid sporting purpose and just poses an undue risk to the people of this state. . . .
 Q. Senator, are you receiving any campaign funding from the N.R.A.?
 A. Have we gotten any? I don't think so. I don't know. We'll have to go back and take a look at that. We're doing very well at raising money. I'll tell you that much.
 [The Senator was asked what he thinks about the National Rifle Association. At first he said he did not "want to start categorizing other groups, whether they're groups I agree with or disagree with." He was then pressed further on the question. ]
 PATAKI I believe in freedom of speech. I would have voted for the Federal crime bill. Do they have a right to say that they didn't like it? Absolutely they had that right. Do I agree with them on that? No. . . .
 [He was asked whether private citizens should be allowed to have weapons.]
 PATAKI Do I think people should have the right to have a gun in their home if they choose to do it and it's permitted and legal? Yes.
 Q. Is it a good thing for private citizens to own guns?
 A. That's their personal decision.
 Q. Do you own any guns?
 A. No. Actually, I have wired to the wall my grandfather's old shotgun. And it would pose a far greater threat to me, if I ever tried to use it, than to anybody else. I am not -- I do not own guns. But I think it's a person's personal decision, under the law, whether or not they choose to do that. And I'm not going to say to someone that they should or they shouldn't. It's their personal decision.
 
SOCIAL ISSUES
 
Abortion
 Q.Do you or do you not support Medicaid funding for abortion?
 A. Abortion comes down to three issues right now in the State Legislature. The whole question of choice -- I am pro-choice. Regardless of what happens with Roe v. Wade, I don't think politicians in Washington or Albany should tell my wife what she can or cannot do. Period.
 With Medicaid funding, I will continue Medicaid funding. I want to make a change in the system. And the change that I would make is to have an educational component when someone comes in for a Medicaid-funded abortion. I don't support our present system because I want to make that change. But we are not going to deny Medicaid funding, and we are not going to put any legal impediments to abortion in this state.
 Q. What is the educational component?
 A. Right now, if someone comes in for a Medicaid-funded abortion, I believe they should be counseled. They should be counseled in a way so that they can avoid a future unwanted pregnancy. . . .
 Q. Does this represent an evolving position in that you were previously opposed to Medicaid funding, period, but now you're for it with this component?
 A. The position and my position on abortion has evolved. It hasn't evolved in the last year. In 1990, we had the first pro-choice platform of any Republican state party in the country. And it's a position that I feel very strongly about. It is the woman's decision. . . .
 Q. Explain to us your evolution on this issue because it has changed. . . . What accounted for the change?
 A. Well, to me it's not an easy issue. I am not someone who doesn't reflect on the whole question of abortion. And I think most people do. It is a tough decision not just for politicians, it is a very tough personal decision for people.
 And what you're doing is you're weighing rights and, ultimately, I believe that the most important right here involved is the right of the woman to control her body and to control her decision. . . .
 [Mr. Pataki was reminded that he voted against Medicaid financing of abortion as a legislator and was asked if, as governor, he would veto a bill containing the financing.]
 A. No. I will try to make the change to get that educational component in there. I believe we should because I have not heard -- if I don't I will continue Medicaid funding, but I have yet to hear anyone say why it's a bad thing to have this where the provider is given a curriculum provided by the health department to say, "We don't want you to get pregnant again unless you choose to and here are various ways that you could choose to avoid it." And I have never heard anybody say that that's a bad thing and yet it's not the law, so I'm optimistic that we can get it, but if we can't get it we're not going to discontinue Medicaid funding.
Gay Rights [The Senator was asked about gay rights legislation. He said he voted for a bias crime bill whose protections would include homosexuals and would sign it if it reached his desk as governor. He said he supported a vote before the full Senate on a second piece of legislation that would provide broader civil-rights protection to homosexuals in a variety of areas including employment; he went on to discuss two reservations about the bill.] PATAKI One is a practical question -- and here I'm being a lawyer -- is that when a person is a member of a protected class and files a claim, the employer has the ability in defense to use statistical proof. If 12 percent of the work force are minorities and 14 percent of the employees in that company are minorities, then there's a presumption that there is no discrimination and the employer can defend itself that way. You don't have that in the question of sexual orientation because you don't have the statistics. It is largely a private matter, so that the employer is hard pressed to defend the case.
 [A bit later he described his second reservation about providing broader protections.]
 PATAKI You have two people, both of them homosexual. One of them openly states his sexual orientation, all of a sudden becomes a member of the protected class. The other does not. The other, out of a sense of privacy or for whatever reason, doesn't do it. The employer has to cut a job. One of those two jobs. The employer will cut the job of the person who's not the member of the protected class because you are then protecting yourself against a lawsuit. So instead of having equal rights, it becomes a special right as a member of the protected class.
 
THE CAMPAIGN
 
Senator D'Amato
 Q. Talk to us for a second about Senator D'Amato. He's played a crucial role in your campaign. What would his role be in a Pataki administration?
 A. His role would be that of the U.S. Senator, along with the other U.S. Senator. And that would be his role. It's kind of ironic. In 1990 The Daily News writes an editorial blasting D'Amato because the Republican Party ran someone, to be polite, less than qualified as an opponent to Mario Cuomo. They said, "This is a disservice to the people of this state. They deserve a debate on the issues and an intelligent choice and where was Senator D'Amato. He's so influential in the party. He should have helped get a candidate who could raise the issues."
 And now all of a sudden a year ago, he says -- and he didn't say, "Pataki, you're the guy" -- I went down and made the case and said I want to run, I think I have the ideas and the record to beat Mario Cuomo and he said, "Well, it sounds plausible to me." . . .
So I just went out and earned the support and earned the nomination, and Senator D'Amato was very helpful after he went through that whole process and said you're the one who can win. And he helped me with it. What I owe him is what I owe every New Yorker. I'll listen to him. When I agree with him, I'll do what I think is right. When I disagree with him, I'm going to tell him I disagree with him and I'm going to do what I think is in the best ----
 Q. Senator, when have you disagreed?
 A. On the crime bill, on abortion, on environmental issues. I mean, I'm pro-choice, he's pro-life. He runs on the Right-to-Life line. The Right-to-Life line is an opponent of mine, and in fact I had a conservative primary and the conservative primary was on the social issues of someone who was pro-life and against the bias crime bill and was bashing me on that. I would have voted for the Susan Molinari improved crime bill. He didn't. . . .
 Q. Has the Senator raised funds for you?
 A. Yes, he has. We have raised a great deal of money from all different sources, and he has been helping me.
 Q. Are you satisfied or comfortable with the outcome of the ethics inquiry into the way Senator D'Amato ran his office?
 A. You know, I've never even -- I've read about it in The New York Times and . . . I'm not about to tell Congress or Washington how they should run their committees or their operations. I have a very clear idea as to how we should change -- change Albany -- talking about changing the committee structures, talking about changing the budget process, talking about opening up the government in Albany, and my goal is to be the best governor I can be for the people of this state. And I'm going to do everything in my power if I'm given the right to be the governor.
 Q. Should D'Amato be an issue in your campaign? Are you saying he should not, is that the message you're trying to send?
 A. I don't think so at all. I think people who know me know that I've stood up to my own party leadership in Westchester County.
 Q. Most people in New York don't know you.
 A. And we're doing our best to get them to know me, working night and day. The people in Westchester know I stood up to my own party leadership to run for office. Anybody who's covered Albany knows that I stood up to my own party leadership in the State Senate to do what I had told the people of this state I would do, which was fight to lower the cost of government and restructure government and impose budgets that didn't control spending and move toward tax cuts.
 And I did that against the wishes of my party's leadership and I will give Senator D'Amato and Senator Moynihan or Senator Castro or whoever is there the courtesy of listening to their ideas, but I will do what I believe is right for the people of this state, period.
Media Coverage
 [Mr. Pataki and his aides began criticizing news coverage of the campaign, particularly what has been written about Mr. Cuomo's use of state planes. The Republican candidate said that "with respect to the Governor, he's gotten away with much more than he should have."] PATAKI Let me say, when I was -- you were hammering me: Pataki, release your tax returns, release your tax returns. We went back, released them all, including when I was in the private sector.
 Mario Cuomo has never released his tax returns when he was Secretary of State. He was a full-time state employee, never released his returns. That's wrong. And he's gotten away with it.
 I got hammered on my real-estate transactions even though [a Times reporter] found out they were legal, because we laid out every single piece of property I've ever bought or sold. The Governor's never done it.
 Laid out a net worth statement. The Governor won't do it. . . .
 After I got a little bit of a hammering there to disclose and did, the issue seems to have lost attention. And I don't know why the fact that the Governor hasn't matched our level of disclosure isn't still something under consideration.

GRAPHIC: Photo: State Senator George E. Pataki during his two-hour interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times. The Republican gubernatorial candidate said New York's economy was suffering under the weight of high taxes and big government. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Pataki on the Record: Excerpts From a Talk On Campaign Issues

 BODY:
State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor of New York, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times for two hours on Friday to discuss issues in the gubernatorial race and his goals if elected. Here are excerpts from the session.
FISCAL MATTERS Taxing and Spending [Senator Pataki was asked how he will be able to reconcile his campaign promises to cut taxes and control spending while also increasing aid to education and improving other state services.] 
PATAKI First of all, let me say: We are going to control spending because we have to control spending. And it's not something that's unique to government or unique to the state government. Look what Mayor Giuliani has done right here in the last year. He had a $2 billion-plus budget gap. And he didn't raise taxes. He's done it by controlling spending. And he's done it by things like by cutting positions in the central Board of Education. We have outlined a large number of different areas where significant savings can be made.
 Our tax cut plan hinges on two things:
 One is we're anticipating an increase in the revenue of the state. We're anticipating a lower increase than has traditionally or historically been the case, even during Mario Cuomo's two terms.
 And the second is we are going to keep spending below the rate of inflation -- spending increases. That still allows for significant spending increases. It just doesn't allow for the hemorrhaging of money as we saw in Albany this year. This year, state spending in Albany, I think, is up 9.9 percent. It's up over $5 billion. More than three times the rate of inflation. And I don't think there's anybody in this state saying, "Isn't that a wonderful thing that we're finally going to solve New York's problems by having the state government spend a lot more." . . .
 And Mario Cuomo says, well, you can't control spending. You can't cut taxes. You have to. It's being done all around us, not just in New York City. The last three years Westchester County has kept its spending increase to less than 1 percent -- in the last three years. And yet they've had the higher Medicaid costs and the higher social-service costs and mandates imposed by the state government. But they've done it.
 Q. He says you can't cut spending or cut taxes to the degree that you want to.
 A. In other words, he's saying we can't keep spending increases below the rate of inflation. That's his record. He hasn't been able to keep spending increases below the rate of inflation. . . .
 The cumulative record of Mario Cuomo, in his 12 years in office, is that spending has increased at more than twice the rate of inflation. And this year it increased at more than three times the rate of inflation. So I think when he says he can't keep the spending increase below the rate of inflation, I think he's right. He can't.
 But we can and we will because we're going to impose discipline. . . .
 
Welfare Costs

 [Mr. Pataki said he would look at how to make government more efficient.]
 PATAKI . . . Let me just give you one major area where significant cost-savings can be achieved and where Mario Cuomo has failed miserably and you haven't taken him to task on it. And that is the Home Relief population of welfare. The Home Relief population of welfare is a nonfederally-mandated program. It's a program where the states can voluntarily decide: Do we have the program or do we not have the program? We have unending permanent Home Relief benefits. I don't know what other states do, but it's a handful, and none of the surrounding state have that. Home Relief in this state has gone up, under Mario Cuomo, by close to 100 percent. The population is now almost 400,000 people. . . .
 [The Senator also said that when Mario M. Cuomo became Governor, 34 percent of the Home Relief population was in workfare programs but that now only 14 percent are.]
 PATAKI Workfare saves money. Take a look at what happened in Westchester County. Their Home Relief costs are down more than 25 percent. I was saying 20 percent. It's more than 25 and closer to 30 percent because they have put in place a successful workfare program. It's not like reinventing the wheel. It's not like we have to, at the state level, come up with some creative concept that hasn't been considered before. It works. It's working right above this city government.
 And yet Mario Cuomo yesterday says, or whenever he sat down for his filibuster, says you've got two alternatives: private-sector jobs, and in private-sector jobs we are doing horribly, or public-sector jobs. No. You have community service. You have workfare, which is precisely what has happened up there. And you're not creating a new bureaucracy. You're not hiring someone on Home Relief at $18,000 a year to become a public employee. You are requiring them, week in and week out, to show up for public service work.
 Q. So, Senator, would you put the entire Home Relief population on workfare ----
 A. Absolutely.
 Q. Would you eliminate education programs, job training programs ----
 A. No. And in fact the Westchester program incorporates that. It incorporates job training. It incorporates education. And it has been extremely successful. And there are a number of ways that this works. One is that it reduces the number of people who are living or employed someplace else, so that you have a reduction in the number of people because the ineligibles don't show up. They're not there. Two, you create a sense of self-worth and dignity in the person who is receiving workfare. And I think this is an incredibly important part of this program -- is it's not simply to reduce fraud and save money. It's to create the sense of self-worth and pride that comes from going out and being a working, contributing member of society. . . .
 I was sitting in my Senate office in downtown Peekskill a year or so ago and a man comes in to interview me. He's a student at Mercy College. And he starts asking me about my thoughts on the Senate, and I tell him my ideas. And, as often happens, I start asking him about his life and what he's doing. He was a heroin addict on welfare in the Bronx. And he had decided that if he didn't straighten his life out he was going to die. So what he did is, he said, I have to get out of the neighborhood. Moved to Peekskill. Got off drugs. Was living in Peekskill, off drugs but on welfare. Just sitting home doing nothing.
 Westchester put in place its pride-in-work program. He had to show up. And all of a sudden he realized he had some ability. He had some skills. And when he came in to interview me, he was doing public service work for the city of Peekskill at the Water Department in a job that didn't displace a public employee. And the unions were supportive of the program because they were talked to and it was made clear that the work that would be done would not displace public employees but would be work that otherwise would have never been gotten to. . . .
 When he was interviewing me he was still on public service, he was doing public service work for the city through the county program and he was a student -- I think he was a sophomore at Mercy College, getting A's and B's -- and this person's going to make something of his life. So it's not simply the saving of money, which is obviously very important, but it's also the changing of approaches and attitudes to life. . . . Will Cuts Be Painful?
 Q. You're offering people a $6 billion tax cut, we just want to hear you say what is going to be the cost of that on the other side.
 A. The cost of that on the other side is that we are going to keep the rate of spending increase at the state level to less than the rate of increase of inflation over the four-year period. And I don't think that is something that in any way is going to impose hardship on the people of this state. In fact, I think it's going to be a huge relief to the people of this state that we are finally controlling spending, we are finally cutting taxes. . . .
 
Job Creation

 [The Senator was asked how he explains the strong job growth in New York in the mid-1980's.]
 PATAKI We lagged the national average. We have been 47th in the country in job growth since Mario Cuomo's been Governor for 12 years. And Mario Cuomo says, "Oh, it's Ronald Reagan's fault, it's George Bush's fault, it's the Japanese's fault. And yet, look what I did in the middle 80's." What you did in the middle 80's was, when there was a national boom, you lagged that national boom. We created jobs at a slower rate than the rest of the country. When the recession hit, we lost jobs at a faster rate than the rest of the country. . . .
 Why? Is it because we don't have people? Is it because we don't have capital? Is it because people aren't willing to work here? They don't have the commitment or the risk taking or the entrepreneurial spirit? Of course not. We have the most talented people in this country right here in this state. But they're being killed by overtaxation, overregulation, things like raids on the workers compensation fund. . . .
 
Aid to New York City
 Q. Senator, while we're talking about school aid, what should New York City's percentage of school aid be?
 A. Well, first of all, let me say that the Mayor should have control over the education system in this city, and it's something the Mayor has wanted. He's right. He's responsible. He's the one who's accountable. He's the one who has to balance the budget and provide the budget, he should be given that authority.
 I know the argument. It's like 34.5 percent of the aid and 37 percent of the students under the formula. But you can't look at it simply under that formula, you have to look at all the different aid packages, the transportation-aid package, it's the Medicaid assistance package, and the city should be treated fairly. The success of the city is critical, absolutely critical to the success of the state.
 Q. Is it treated fairly now in terms of education aid?
 A. I don't think any local government is being treated fairly, whether it's in Medicaid or education. . . .
 It has been the pattern of this administration to have wonderful programs that you can announce, but they have to be paid for by the county government or the city government so that it's the local politician who has to raise the tax and get yelled at. . . .
 
Limits on Medicaid

 [Senator Pataki was asked whether he would limit some of the services that the state now provides under Medicaid.] PATAKI I think, personally, it's absurd that somebody can get a hair transplant paid for by Medicaid. It makes no sense. And I think that's the case: that you can't. And I do not want to see us dramatically cut the benefits available to Medicaid recipients, particularly the A.F.D.C. population. We don't want to hurt kids and we don't want to hurt mothers caring for children. But there are things like: There is no reason why the taxpayer should fund hair transplants for somebody on Medicaid. . . .
 Q. How much is spent on hair transplants?
 A. I have no idea. I mean, let me make an absolute confession. We are not going to pay for the $5.6 billion in tax cuts by eliminating hair transplants from Medicaid. I know that's a pretty dramatic concession for me to make. But I think it's more emblematic than financial in its implications. . . .
 Q. And if your projections don't work out, how would you then confront that situation? Would you do like the Legislature and the Governor did in the 90's and postpone the tax cuts?
 A. No. . . .
 We are going to enact this tax cut plan. It is going to happen. And if you look at the numbers -- in the fourth year, the total cost of the tax cut package is a little over $5.6 billion. . . .
 What I'm going to look to do next year is see if we can avoid increasing spending at all. It's what Governor Weld did his first year in Massachusetts, he had no increase in spending. Governor Whitman, her first year in office had no increase in spending. Mayor Giuliani, his first year in office had no increase in spending. This projection is sound even with an increase in spending of 2.7 percent a year.
 I'll tell you, absolutely honestly, I believe we can make the savings, change the system, put in place the cost-containment measures and improve the efficiencies of government to the point where we don't have to increase spending at that point. So I think it is a sound and conservative plan.
CRIME AND PUNISHMENT The Death Penalty
 Q. Why is the death penalty a greater deterrent than life without parole, and under what circumstances do you envision yourself commuting a death sentence as governor?
 [The Senator began by talking about Governor Cuomo's "three strikes and you're in" proposal -- which would sentence three-time violent offenders to life in prison without parole -- and what it would mean to someone who has already served two sentences as a violent felon.]
 PATAKI You're out there committing another violent felony. You're holding up the cabdriver or holding up the shop. You know that if you're caught again, you're gone -- life without parole. Never out on the street again. If you kill that person, if you kill the shopkeeper, you're less likely to get caught. You have no witness, you have nobody to testify against you. And if by some chance you do get caught, it's the same penalty -- life without parole. You are creating a perverse incentive for a violent felon to kill if you have life without parole without the death penalty.
 Think for a minute -- a police officer wanders into a bodega, somebody's holding up the storekeeper, he's already served two violent felonies. The police officer wanders in -- what's going on? He surrenders -- life without parole. He kills the police officer, he has a chance of getting away, and if he gets caught -- life without parole. . . . So if we have "three strikes, you're in" without the death penalty for someone who has already served those two violent felonies and would kill, we are creating a perverse incentive. It's the law of unintended consequences where someone who is violent, who is a criminal, has an incentive to kill.
 So I believe that you can't -- you have to couple "three strikes and you're in" with the death penalty.
 Now you ask, what makes you think the death penalty is a deterrent or should be a part of the criminal justice system? Let me give you two broad philosophical reasons: One -- there are two -- one is deterrence, and one is justice.
 Deterrence: I happen to think that there -- and I firmly believe that -- that there are rational circumstances where -- and it's not the case of somebody is high on drugs or a mental patient or someone who in the heat of passion commits a murder -- but there are rational killers who make a determination that, and do an analysis and say, I'm going to kill someone. And the death penalty is a factor. . . .
 And the second part is I truly believe that the death penalty is a part of a fair system of justice. We have the bombing in the World Trade Center, I think a terrorist who commits that act, the system of justice, has forfeited his right to live and we as a society have the right to take that person's life. . . .
 [Senator Pataki was asked if there are circumstances under which he would commute a death sentence.]
 PATAKI I think it's conceivable. You never say that it's, under no circumstances is it possible. You'd have to take a look, that's something that is sui generis. I don't mean to sound like Mario Cuomo, but it's unique, to the circumstances.
Drug Offenders [The Senator was asked about Governor Cuomo's belief that many people in state prisons should be in other kind of programs, particularly nonviolent drug offenders.]
 PATAKI I think to say that someone who is a predicate felon who's been convicted of a second felony doesn't belong in jail, is wrong. A predicate felon, someone who has been convicted of two felonies, belongs in jail. . . .
 You get arrested, you get tried, you get convicted. What happens is you don't serve one day. Not one day. You are out on the street the same day. And you can check with any criminal justice expert in this city. When you plead to your drug felony conviction for selling drugs, you do not get one day in this city. And check with any judge, district attorney, defense attorney. That's what happens. They're out on the street the same day. What message does this send to the community? What message does this send to the kid convicted of a drug felony -- zero time. . . .
I think that the first time we have to do something to save that kid, to save that person who has been convicted of the felony of selling drugs. And instead of just saying you're back out on the street corner, we have to do things like have structured correctional programs where that person is required to do things as a penalty for having been convicted. And it's a way to avoid that second felony conviction. . . .
Gun Control
 Q. There's been some confusion about your votes on banning assault weapons. Can you explain what your position is?
 A. We should ban assault weapons. It doesn't make any sense to me that someone could have an AK-47 or an Uzi or a Street Sweeper that serves no valid self-defense purpose and serves no valid sporting purpose and just poses an undue risk to the people of this state. . . .
 Q. Senator, are you receiving any campaign funding from the N.R.A.?
 A. Have we gotten any? I don't think so. I don't know. We'll have to go back and take a look at that. We're doing very well at raising money. I'll tell you that much.
 [The Senator was asked what he thinks about the National Rifle Association. At first he said he did not "want to start categorizing other groups, whether they're groups I agree with or disagree with." He was then pressed further on the question. ]
 PATAKI I believe in freedom of speech. I would have voted for the Federal crime bill. Do they have a right to say that they didn't like it? Absolutely they had that right. Do I agree with them on that? No. . . .
 [He was asked whether private citizens should be allowed to have weapons.]
 PATAKI Do I think people should have the right to have a gun in their home if they choose to do it and it's permitted and legal? Yes.
 Q. Is it a good thing for private citizens to own guns?
 A. That's their personal decision.
 Q. Do you own any guns?
 A. No. Actually, I have wired to the wall my grandfather's old shotgun. And it would pose a far greater threat to me, if I ever tried to use it, than to anybody else. I am not -- I do not own guns. But I think it's a person's personal decision, under the law, whether or not they choose to do that. And I'm not going to say to someone that they should or they shouldn't. It's their personal decision.
SOCIAL ISSUES Abortion
 Q.Do you or do you not support Medicaid funding for abortion?
 A. Abortion comes down to three issues right now in the State Legislature. The whole question of choice -- I am pro-choice. Regardless of what happens with Roe v. Wade, I don't think politicians in Washington or Albany should tell my wife what she can or cannot do. Period.
 With Medicaid funding, I will continue Medicaid funding. I want to make a change in the system. And the change that I would make is to have an educational component when someone comes in for a Medicaid-funded abortion. I don't support our present system because I want to make that change. But we are not going to deny Medicaid funding, and we are not going to put any legal impediments to abortion in this state.
 Q. What is the educational component?
 A. Right now, if someone comes in for a Medicaid-funded abortion, I believe they should be counseled. They should be counseled in a way so that they can avoid a future unwanted pregnancy. . . .
 Q. Does this represent an evolving position in that you were previously opposed to Medicaid funding, period, but now you're for it with this component?
 A. The position and my position on abortion has evolved. It hasn't evolved in the last year. In 1990, we had the first pro-choice platform of any Republican state party in the country. And it's a position that I feel very strongly about. It is the woman's decision. . . .
 Q. Explain to us your evolution on this issue because it has changed. . . . What accounted for the change?
 A. Well, to me it's not an easy issue. I am not someone who doesn't reflect on the whole question of abortion. And I think most people do. It is a tough decision not just for politicians, it is a very tough personal decision for people.
 And what you're doing is you're weighing rights and, ultimately, I believe that the most important right here involved is the right of the woman to control her body and to control her decision. . . .
 [Mr. Pataki was reminded that he voted against Medicaid financing of abortion as a legislator and was asked if, as governor, he would veto a bill containing the financing.]
 A. No. I will try to make the change to get that educational component in there. I believe we should because I have not heard -- if I don't I will continue Medicaid funding, but I have yet to hear anyone say why it's a bad thing to have this where the provider is given a curriculum provided by the health department to say, "We don't want you to get pregnant again unless you choose to and here are various ways that you could choose to avoid it." And I have never heard anybody say that that's a bad thing and yet it's not the law, so I'm optimistic that we can get it, but if we can't get it we're not going to discontinue Medicaid funding.
Gay Rights [The Senator was asked about gay rights legislation. He said he voted for a bias crime bill whose protections would include homosexuals and would sign it if it reached his desk as governor. He said he supported a vote before the full Senate on a second piece of legislation that would provide broader civil-rights protection to homosexuals in a variety of areas including employment; he went on to discuss two reservations about the bill.] PATAKI One is a practical question -- and here I'm being a lawyer -- is that when a person is a member of a protected class and files a claim, the employer has the ability in defense to use statistical proof. If 12 percent of the work force are minorities and 14 percent of the employees in that company are minorities, then there's a presumption that there is no discrimination and the employer can defend itself that way. You don't have that in the question of sexual orientation because you don't have the statistics. It is largely a private matter, so that the employer is hard pressed to defend the case.
 [A bit later he described his second reservation about providing broader protections.]
 PATAKI You have two people, both of them homosexual. One of them openly states his sexual orientation, all of a sudden becomes a member of the protected class. The other does not. The other, out of a sense of privacy or for whatever reason, doesn't do it. The employer has to cut a job. One of those two jobs. The employer will cut the job of the person who's not the member of the protected class because you are then protecting yourself against a lawsuit. So instead of having equal rights, it becomes a special right as a member of the protected class.
THE CAMPAIGN Senator D'Amato
 Q. Talk to us for a second about Senator D'Amato. He's played a crucial role in your campaign. What would his role be in a Pataki administration?
 A. His role would be that of the U.S. Senator, along with the other U.S. Senator. And that would be his role. It's kind of ironic. In 1990 The Daily News writes an editorial blasting D'Amato because the Republican Party ran someone, to be polite, less than qualified as an opponent to Mario Cuomo. They said, "This is a disservice to the people of this state. They deserve a debate on the issues and an intelligent choice and where was Senator D'Amato. He's so influential in the party. He should have helped get a candidate who could raise the issues."
 And now all of a sudden a year ago, he says -- and he didn't say, "Pataki, you're the guy" -- I went down and made the case and said I want to run, I think I have the ideas and the record to beat Mario Cuomo and he said, "Well, it sounds plausible to me." . . .
 So I just went out and earned the support and earned the nomination, and Senator D'Amato was very helpful after he went through that whole process and said you're the one who can win. And he helped me with it. What I owe him is what I owe every New Yorker. I'll listen to him. When I agree with him, I'll do what I think is right. When I disagree with him, I'm going to tell him I disagree with him and I'm going to do what I think is in the best ----
 Q. Senator, when have you disagreed?
 A. On the crime bill, on abortion, on environmental issues. I mean, I'm pro-choice, he's pro-life. He runs on the Right-to-Life line. The Right-to-Life line is an opponent of mine, and in fact I had a conservative primary and the conservative primary was on the social issues of someone who was pro-life and against the bias crime bill and was bashing me on that. I would have voted for the Susan Molinari improved crime bill. He didn't. . . .
 Q. Has the Senator raised funds for you?
 A. Yes, he has. We have raised a great deal of money from all different sources, and he has been helping me.
 Q. Are you satisfied or comfortable with the outcome of the ethics inquiry into the way Senator D'Amato ran his office?
 A. You know, I've never even -- I've read about it in The New York Times and . . . I'm not about to tell Congress or Washington how they should run their committees or their operations. I have a very clear idea as to how we should change -- change Albany -- talking about changing the committee structures, talking about changing the budget process, talking about opening up the government in Albany, and my goal is to be the best governor I can be for the people of this state. And I'm going to do everything in my power if I'm given the right to be the governor.
 Q. Should D'Amato be an issue in your campaign? Are you saying he should not, is that the message you're trying to send?
 A. I don't think so at all. I think people who know me know that I've stood up to my own party leadership in Westchester County.
 Q. Most people in New York don't know you.
 A. And we're doing our best to get them to know me, working night and day. The people in Westchester know I stood up to my own party leadership to run for office. Anybody who's covered Albany knows that I stood up to my own party leadership in the State Senate to do what I had told the people of this state I would do, which was fight to lower the cost of government and restructure government and impose budgets that didn't control spending and move toward tax cuts.
 And I did that against the wishes of my party's leadership and I will give Senator D'Amato and Senator Moynihan or Senator Castro or whoever is there the courtesy of listening to their ideas, but I will do what I believe is right for the people of this state, period.
Media Coverage
 [Mr. Pataki and his aides began criticizing news coverage of the campaign, particularly what has been written about Mr. Cuomo's use of state planes. The Republican candidate said that "with respect to the Governor, he's gotten away with much more than he should have."] PATAKI Let me say, when I was -- you were hammering me: Pataki, release your tax returns, release your tax returns. We went back, released them all, including when I was in the private sector.
 Mario Cuomo has never released his tax returns when he was Secretary of State. He was a full-time state employee, never released his returns. That's wrong. And he's gotten away with it.
 I got hammered on my real-estate transactions even though [a Times reporter] found out they were legal, because we laid out every single piece of property I've ever bought or sold. The Governor's never done it.
 Laid out a net worth statement. The Governor won't do it. . . .
 After I got a little bit of a hammering there to disclose and did, the issue seems to have lost attention. And I don't know why the fact that the Governor hasn't matched our level of disclosure isn't still something under consideration.

GRAPHIC: Photo: State Senator George E. Pataki during his two-hour interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times. The Republican gubernatorial candidate said New York's economy was suffering under the weight of high taxes and big government. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: No Baseball. No Hockey. Lost Sales.

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
The players' strike could cost Major League Baseball up to $280 million in lost merchandise sales, and many retailers are postponing orders for goods because they are uncertain about whether play will resume in the spring.
Whether sales of hockey merchandise will also suffer -- National Hockey League players have been locked out by team owners while negotiations continue -- remains unclear. N.H.L. merchandise has boomed in recent years, particularly in the Sun Belt. If the labor dispute is not resolved, sales could be hurt badly, retailing experts say. 
 But significant damage has been done to baseball clothing and other merchandise.
"It's affecting our planning and buying for next year," said Keith Harmon, a spokesman for Merle Harmon's Fan Fair, a 143-store sporting goods chain headquartered in Elm Grove, Wis. "Orders aren't being placed."
Because some manufacturers need six months' notice to make timely deliveries, Mr. Harmon said, if the strike is not settled shortly "we're reaching the point now that even if we place an order it won't get on shelves."
A spokeswoman for Major League Baseball, Carol Coleman, said the strike, which began on Aug. 12, would cut 10 percent from projected 1994 sales of $2.8 billion, up from $2.5 billion in 1993.
Among the retailers likely to be the hardest hit are those in the home regions of the four division leaders. Of those, the New York Yankees and Chicago White Sox are among the top five teams at the cash register.
In a survey of 30 of the largest sports retailers last month by Sporting Goods Business, a majority of those polled said that the strike was having drastic effects on sales, the editor of the magazine, Andrew Gaffney, said on Friday. Mr. Gaffney added that uncertainty about the resumption of baseball had led several major chains to cut spring orders up to 25 percent.
Sales of baseball goods have declined nearly 50 percent at Sears, Roebuck & Company, the divisional men's sportswear merchandise manager, Tom Pavsek, told an apparel-industry trade newspaper, The Daily News Record, last week.
Hockey merchandise has meanwhile been selling 25 percent ahead of last year's pace and is expected to top $1 billion by season's end in June, according to league officials.
With relatively new franchises in Dallas, Miami, Tampa Bay, Fla., and San Jose and Anaheim, Calif., the league has been building a broader base. Hockey jerseys have become a fashionable choice, even for people who have never been on skates, and the league has reached marketing deals with Nike and Anheuser-Busch and a broadcast contract with Fox Television.
"They are really positioned to grow," said Karen Raugust, executive editor of The Licensing Letter, a trade publication in Brooklyn. N.H.L. merchandise is arriving in stores and is in the pipeline for the holidays, she said, but if the labor impasse turns into "a bitter struggle where the public has little sympathy, like the baseball strike, that could turn people off."
Rick Dudley, chief operating officer of N.H.L. Enterprises, the properties division of the league, said on Friday, "We anticipate the season will get under way and we won't lose out on that momentum."
But few others are that optimistic. The league postponed the scheduled opening on Oct. 1 until next Saturday, to allow time for negotiations, which have made little progress.
One beneficiary of the baseball walkout is the minor leagues. "Their licensing programs got a boost," said Ms. Raugust, adding that even before the strike minor league merchandise was selling strongly above the already powerful level of last year, which was 42 percent above 1992. The 1993 total was $40 million.
Team apparel licensed by an independent minor league, the International Hockey League, is also selling well, retailers said.
All major sports leagues receive average royalties of 9 percent of the wholesale sales of merchandise bearing team names and logos. Those payments go to the respective leagues and are divided equally among the teams. The N.H.L. divides its total among 26 teams and baseball among 28.
Last year the $2.5 billion in retail merchandise sales for baseball produced about $4 million for each team.
Manufacturers of licensed sports apparel are also feeling the pinch, especially those that specialize in "event" items like shirts and hats tied to the World Series.
Larger apparel makers like Logo 7 of Indianapolis and Starter Sportswear of New Haven can generally shrug off the losses, because they make goods involving many sports. So the capacity unexpectedly freed by slacking baseball or hockey orders can be diverted to producing football and basketball merchandise, as well as minor league and college goods, said Pamela Singleton, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company. She follows, among other, the Russell Corporation of Alexander City, Ala., which makes jerseys for baseball players in professional and minor leagues, as well as college and high school teams and the Little League.
The strike has not even led Ms. Singleton to revise her year-end earnings estimate for Russell, which obtains 10 percent of its $1.1 billion in sales from licensed items.

Decline in Hot Dogs
 By The Associated Press
 Companies that make hot dogs and sell them and other snacks at baseball and hockey games have been feeling pain from the labor problems in professional sports.
"This last week should have been terrific," said Bob Schwartz, vice president of sales for the Vienna Sausage Manufacturing Company, which supplies hot dogs to vendors at Chicago White Sox, Cubs and Blackhawks games. "Instead, there's nothing."
The Delaware North Companies of Buffalo, which has concessions at seven major league ball parks and four hockey arenas and whose chairman, Jeremy Jacobs, owns the Boston Bruins, has been particularly hard hit.
"We are a large and a very healthy company, but those kinds of losses are felt by an organization of any size," said Samuel Gifford, a vice president.
Delaware North, whose revenues last year totaled $1.2 billion, had planned for $100 million in sales this year from its baseball concessions at Tiger Stadium in Detroit, Busch Stadium in St. Louis, Jacobs Field in Cleveland, Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati, Milwaukee County Stadium, Comiskey Park in Chicago and the Ballpark in Arlington, Tex.
With the season canceled, Delaware North lost $25 million to $30 million in sales, Mr. Gifford said.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON SENDS MORE PLANES TO MIDEAST, SAYING HE SEES NO SIGN OF IRAQI PULLBACK

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Iraq announced today that it was withdrawing its troops from provocative positions along the Kuwaiti border, but President Clinton told Americans tonight that the United States had seen no evidence so far of a withdrawal and was adding new firepower to its forces in the Persian Gulf region.
In a televised address from the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton announced that he was dispatching hundreds more aircraft, which Administration officials said would bring to about 550 the total of American planes in the region. A total of 356 aircraft ordered to the region today includes F-117 stealth fighters and B-52 bombers, the officials added. 
 Mr. Clinton, declaring that the United States had a duty to insure that Iraq did not again threaten neighboring nations, said, "We will not allow Saddam Hussein to defy the will of the United States and the international community."
In the new confrontation with Iraq, he said: "Our objectives are clear. Our forces are strong and our cause is right." [Transcript of Mr. Clinton's address, page A11.]
The President's announcement was intended first to leave Iraq and its leader, President Hussein, with no doubt about his determination to strike back with overwhelming force if Iraq should mount a new invasion against Kuwait.
But as a 36,000-member American ground force began to make its way to the Persian Gulf, senior advisers said Mr. Clinton had concluded that further military or diplomatic action would be necessary even if Iraq did withdraw its forces from the Kuwaiti frontier.
Among the measures discussed as Mr. Clinton's top national security advisers met throughout the day in the White House was the possibility of asking the United Nations Security Council to create a buffer zone in southern Iraq from which Iraqi ground troops would be excluded.
That would greatly extend the restrictions already imposed on Iraq by the United Nations, which since March 1991 has enforced zones in both southern and northern Iraq where Iraqi military aircraft are prohibited from operating.
The officials said the latest crisis had only underscored the peril to Kuwait that Iraq still represents, 44 months after its forces were driven out of Kuwait by the United States and its allies in the Persian Gulf war.
A senior Administration official said tonight that Mr. Clinton had determined that it was unacceptable to leave Mr. Hussein in a position from which "he can create an international crisis by threatening Kuwait." In dispatching so much military might to the Persian Gulf, the official said, Mr. Clinton was determined both "to deal with the current situation and to prevent it from arising again."
The last American combat troops left Kuwait in December 1991, more than nine months after the gulf war ended. That they are returning in large numbers now raises the prospect that the United States, having committed itself more than three years ago to defending Kuwait, might feel compelled to establish a permanent troop presence on the Arabian peninsula, much as it has maintained forces in South Korea since the end of the Korean War in 1953.
Today, Defense Secretary William J. Perry and other top officials insisted that they had no desire to keep a large number of American troops in Kuwait for a long time. Mr. Perry suggested that the United States might resort to air strikes against Iraq even if Iraqi troops never crossed into Iraq.
But it was far from clear how the United States intended to deter or prevent future advances toward Kuwait by Iraq and its 350,000-man army, short of establishing a permanent new force in the region.
The address tonight was Mr. Clinton's second from the Oval Office in less than a month. He used it in part to call attention to the success of the American military intervention in Haiti, whose military leader, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, announced today that he was stepping down and leaving the country to make room for the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the elected President.
That was what Mr. Clinton sought when he dispatched troops to the Caribbean 21 days ago, and he drew a comparison tonight between his policies in Haiti and in Iraq, saying that diplomacy was sometimes effective only when backed by the threat of military force.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton said the United States still had seen no evidence that Iraqi forces were moving away from the Kuwaiti frontier, despite an announcement this morning from Iraq's Ambassador to the United Nations, Nizar Hamdoon. Administration officials said it would become clearer by daybreak Tuesday whether Mr. Hamdoon's statements were accurate.
But the President expressed considerable skepticism. "Saddam Hussein has shown the world before, with his acts of aggression and his weapons of mass destruction, that he cannot be trusted," he said. Of the Iraqi promise, he added, "We're interested in facts, not promises -- in deeds, not words. And we have not yet seen evidence that Iraq's troops are, in fact, pulling back."
In the meantime, Mr. Clinton said tonight, the 36,000 American troops and hundreds of planes dispatched by the United States would continue on their way. The first planes and troops arrived in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait this morning. Administration officials said a substantial buildup was likely to continue even if Iraqi forces do back away from their provocative positions.
Mr. Clinton, who canceled a political trip to focus on Kuwait, spoke by telephone today to the leaders of Russia, Britain, France, Egypt and Turkey as he sought to build support for possible military action. He spoke on Sunday night with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.
All six foreign leaders expressed support for "quick and vigorous military measures to defend Kuwait," a senior White House official said. The official said the leaders also agreed that Iraq should not be permitted to blackmail the United Nations Security Council into lifting the economic sanctions.
In his speech, Mr. Clinton said the interests at stake were the same as those that prompted President Bush to send 500,000 United States soldiers to the Persian Gulf to expel Iraqi forces from Kuwait in 1991.
Mr. Clinton invoked the names not only of Mr. Bush, but also of Gen. Colin L. Powell and Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the architects of the gulf war victory, in saying that the United States remained committed to defending Kuwait.
While Iraqi forces remain on their own soil for now, Mr. Clinton said, "Because of what happened in 1990, this provocation requires a strong response from the United States and the international community."
Iraq has been seeking to persuade the Security Council to ease the economic sanctions that were imposed after its forces first invaded Kuwait four years ago. In massing its troops on the border yet again, some analysts believe, Iraq may simply be seeking a negotiating tool.
Tonight Mr. Clinton said that "full compliance, not reckless provocation" was the way to get the sanctions lifted. The curbs have imposed substantial hardships on the Iraqi people.
But to address Arab concerns about such suffering, Administration officials said the White House was weighing whether to propose a United Nations resolution that would compel Mr. Hussein to sell $1.6 billion in oil and use the proceeds to buy necessities for his people. The Security Council has already adopted a resolution that would allow Mr. Hussein to sell oil for humanitarian purposes, but he has so far refused to take that step.
Administration officials insisted today that their focus now was to deter Iraq from mounting a new invasion and to defend against such an attack if it should occur.
But they made clear that they were thinking ahead to measures intended either to cripple Iraq's military forces or to insure that they remained far from Kuwait's vulnerable border.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to meet in Kuwait on Wednesday with a number of foreign ministers, including those from the gulf states, and Administration officials said they are likely to discuss such goals.
Mr. Clinton's response to the Iraqi buildup is far more aggressive than that four years ago by President George Bush, who sent only a mild warning to Mr. Hussein. But it is not just hindsight that has pointed Mr. Clinton on a more aggressive course.
With the United States and its allies still united on the need to hold a firm line against Iraq, the President has been able to count on strong statements even from Syria, Egypt and the Arab League, which were reluctant in 1990 to criticize an Arab brother.
Mr. Clinton's hand has also been strengthened by the cache of military equipment that the Bush Administration arranged to leave in Kuwait after the gulf war. And while Mr. Bush did not know whether Saudi Arabia would even allow American forces on its soil until Defense Secretary Dick Cheney won permission from King Fahd, Mr. Clinton has been able to count on the Saudi Government, which allowed dozens of American planes to remain in place at its advanced bases and will now house many of the Air Force planes dispatched in today's substantial reinforcement.
White House officials said tonight that Mr. Clinton had telephoned Mr. Bush to brief him on the steps he was taking. In a speech in Tennessee, the former Presient offered praise for Mr. Clinton's performance while defending his own decision to stop the Persian Gulf war after 100 hours, well short of Baghdad, a step that left Mr. Hussein in power and half of his Republican Guard forces intact.
