HEADLINE: Burning Trash for Energy: Is It an Endangered Industry?

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio

 BODY:
With its towering smokestacks, hungry furnaces and transmission lines vibrating with thousands of kilowatts of electricity, this city's immense garbage incinerator was once considered a safe and economical means for disposing of thousands of tons of trash.
Now Columbus is seriously considering permanently closing the 11-year-old plant and dumping its garbage in a landfill. 
 The most immediate cause of the incinerator's troubles are high concentrations of toxic pollutants, including dioxin, that are pouring from its smokestacks. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency issued an emergency order last month directing Columbus to fix the problem -- at a cost estimated by the city at $65 million -- for environmental equipment to eliminate toxic compounds by 1996, or the Government would close the plant.
Dioxin has been shown to cause cancer and fetal disorders in laboratory animals. Mercury, another toxic byproduct of incineration, causes damage to the nervous system.
The Government's order inspired a debate here about whether the air-pollution problem was a danger to human health. But behind that debate lies the true cause of the incinerator's troubles: legal setbacks, lower energy prices and safety concerns have driven up the costs of burning trash as fuel and pushed down the price of dumping garbage in old-fashioned landfills.
Today a number of cities and counties in the Midwest, East and South are considering closing their incinerators and going back to dumping their garbage in landfills. The current problems appear to be spelling the end of an era that began in the late 1970's, when more than 100 cities and counties decided to build incinerators that would burn trash to produce electricity.
Since 1991, 77 communities have canceled plans to build new plants that would convert waste to energy, according to Governmental Advisory Associates, a research firm based in New York City. Only three new incinerators are under construction this year, and one city, Windham, Conn., has closed its plant.
"The landscape certainly has changed," said Scott Mackin, president of Ogden Projects Inc. in Fairfield, N.J., the nation's largest builder of waste-to-energy incinerators. "Everybody agrees the market is dormant. The question is how long this market will remain dormant in the future."
The company says it has just one new plant on order, the lowest number in its 10-year history.
"Our plant cost more than we expected when it was built, and it was harder to operate than we thought," said Michael D. Long, the executive director of the Solid Waste Authority of Central Ohio, the agency that manages the plant. "Environmental controls are pushing our costs up. Energy prices haven't moved. We've been hit this year by two Supreme Court decisions that went against the industry. Meanwhile, landfill costs went down. Basically, we're into a death spiral."
It is too early to declare the incinerator industry dead, some experts say. They note, for example, that Congress may consider legislation in its next session to allow states to bar shipments of garbage from other states, a proposal that, if approved, may prompt construction of incinerators in New York City, which has averted a trash crisis by shipping garbage to Pennsylvania and Ohio.
A plant proposed for the Brooklyn Navy Yard has attracted significant public opposition, and New York City has put off its decision on whether to build it. City officials say they do not want to build such a plant, but insist that incineration be retained as an option, and they continue to seek a permit for the project.
But elsewhere, the conditions that led cities to build waste-to-energy incinerators in the first place have reversed themselves.
In some ways, the plants are victims of their own success. Today, 17 percent of the nation's trash is burned, compared with 9 percent in 1980, of which waste-to-energy plants accounted for less than 2 percent. That, combined with increased recycling -- estimated to take care of 19 percent of trash -- has meant that pressure on landfills has declined, making dump space less scarce and less expensive.
Incineration has gone through cycles of popularity and disfavor. As recently as 1960, according to the E.P.A., 31 percent of the nation's garbage was burned in conventional incinerators. In the late 1970's, with predictions of steeply rising energy prices and the Government's eagerness to replace leaky landfills, the old idea of burning garbage gained new life, but with the new chore of producing electricity as well.
The waste-to-energy incinerators were the successors to ordinary trash-burning plants that communities built in the 1950's and 60's, the vast majority of which were closed because of heavy air pollution.
In the 1980's the E.P.A. encouraged incineration. At the same time, new landfill regulations called for closing thousands of local dumps because of their potential threat to ground water. This raised fears that the nation would run out of dumping space.
"When you analyzed all the options available to a city, waste-to-energy plants made sense," said Nancy McCann, the urban environmental coordinator for Tampa, Fla., which completed a $115 million plant in 1985. "They provided a long-term solution that is different than finding space for new landfills, which is getting harder and harder in Florida."
But the environmental agency has reversed itself under the Clinton Administration. In early September, for example, the agency proposed new regulations to control dioxin and other air pollutants emitted by municipal incinerators, a decision that will further increase costs.
"My priority is safety first," said the E.P.A. Administrator, Carol M. Browner. "If the effect of putting in place tough standards changes market dynamics, then that's appropriate."
Finding the money to comply with all the environmental regulations will not be easy. Tampa faces $25 million to $40 million in added costs to fit its incinerator with new equipment to control air pollution, Ms. McCann said.
And municipal officials cannot count on as much income from their plants' energy production. In the late 1970's, Federal and state officials predicted that the electricity generated by the plants would produce significant income. But energy prices have declined in real dollars.
Cities and counties had insured that the plants would pay for themselves by drawing up elaborate contracts and regulations that allowed them to control the flow of garbage within their boundaries. The rules enabled communities not only to control prices for garbage disposal, but also to assure them of a steady source of fuel for their new plants.
In May, however, the Supreme Court struck down the contracts that allowed cities to control the flow of garbage to their plants. By ending the incinerators' monopoly on pricing, the decision leaves them more vulnerable to competition from cheaper landfills.
In another ruling in May on a separate case, the Supreme Court ruled that incinerators must treat the tons of ash they generate as hazardous waste because of elevated levels of lead and cadmium. That requires expensive special landfills.
In Columbus, officials and environmentalists differ on whether closing the incinerator is a plus for the environment.
City officials dispute the E.P.A.'s claim that its incinerator spews out more dioxin than any in the country. And they question the E.P.A.'s assessment of the extent of the potential harm to residents.
Mayor Gregory Lashutka also noted that the city built the incinerator in the early 1980's to avoid having to establish a new landfill and to protect farm land and rural areas from unwelcome dumps and unsafe groundwater.
"Without any public debate, priorities have been changed and it's putting at risk our environment and millions of tax dollars," he said.
Even if Columbus saved a few million dollars every year by dumping its trash in a landfill and closing the incinerator, it still has to pay off the $265 million debt for the plant. This could increase the cost of trash disposal for the average family to $220 a year, from $156 this year.
The decision that Columbus will soon make about its incinerator is a lot like garbage itself, said Wyatt Kingseed, the city's finance director. "Any way you look at it," he said, "there are just no attractive solutions."

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: SCENE;
A General Departs, to the Rich and Bitter Sarcasm of the People He Ruled

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The honor guard snapped to attention, more or less -- swords brandished, red-and-blue banners flapping, rifles carefully checked by American troops to be sure they were empty -- as the Commander in Chief of the Haitian Army, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, stepped forward to make his farewell address.
Not a word he said could be heard. 
 "Thief, criminal, murderer!" the thousands of people surrounding the military headquarters shouted, drowning out the public-address system. "Handcuff Cedras. Cedras, your time is up."
In a country where theater plays a big part in politics, where the ostentatious display of brute force confers power, General Cedras's attempt at a dignified show turned into a drama of humiliation. Army officers watched stone-faced from the balcony of the peeling, white French colonial-style headquarters as the general who seized power in a coup three years ago spoke doggedly, if unintelligibly -- his glittering gold-trimmed hat visor low over his eyes, the crowd jubilantly shouting.
"It's only goodbye, don't cry, don't cry," they sang, sarcastically adopting a speeded-up Creole version of "Auld Lang Syne" sung as a folk tradition at funerals here. "Just tell us goodbye, we'll see you in the sky."
Many of the insults were earthy, and some scatalogical. The obscene catcalls and chants reflected the bitterness of a struggle that human rights agencies say has cost about 3,000 lives since the coup that ousted the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Since then, the military leaders have enforced their rule with plainclothes gunmen called attaches who have beaten, robbed, raped and killed in the sprawling shantytowns here and through the countryside.
Early this morning, people who had feared to walk near the government buildings began gathering. They massed around army headquarters in an area near the city center by the National Palace and parks marked by statues of Toussaint L'Ouverture, Henri Christophe and other heroes of the slave revolts that established the first black republic in 1804.
The generals who stepped down today were just the latest in a series of dictators who have bled this country, physically and economically, since its beginnings.
History has left a harsh legacy here. A tiny, light-skinned, French-speaking elite, headed by the wealthy "five families" rules over black, Creole-speaking masses living in the worst poverty in the Western Hemisphere. A predatory state has enforced its will not only with the police and army but also with gunmen known generically as Tontons Macoute, the bogeymen of children's tales.
The last three years of military rule, interrupting the first free and fair elections in modern times, were particularly divisive. Even the economic sanctions intended to put pressure on the military resulted in more profit for rich civilians and the army hierarchy, much of it from smuggling and drug-running. In the mornings, bodies were left in the streets as a warning.
The arrival of the American military three weeks ago began to change that -- at least for now -- and it was American soldiers who orchestrated General Cedras's departure ceremony today.
Olive-drab armored vehicles were parked around the headquarters and a cordon of American military policemen held the crowd back. There was a brief flurry late in the morning, as shots were fired when people surged around General Cedras's departing car, some throwing bottles or rocks. The shots were apparently fired into the air by the general's bodyguards and there were no reports of injuries. American soldiers shouted for everyone to get down, and much of the crowd scattered.
But for the most part, the mood this morning was one of joy rather than vengeance seeking. People danced, carrying an American flag over their heads, and waved the tree branches that are a symbol of President Aristide's political movement. Some climbed into trees to see better. When the United States commander here, Lieut. Gen. Hugh Shelton, appeared wearing his distinctive paratrooper's maroon beret, there were cheers of "Shel-TON."
The Haitian honor guard soon slumped back into its customary lackadaisical posture. The army band was hooted and jeered as it marched off, the drummers and tuba player lurching over a speed bump in the road.
"Aristide, Aristide, down with the army," the crowd chanted and, with a reference to a phrase in the President's 1990 inaugural address -- that there was a "marriage between the army and the people" -- someone remarked, "We have a divorce."

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE U.N.;
Iraq's Attempt to Have Sanctions Lifted Quickly May Have Backfired

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 10

 BODY:
By his show of force near the border with Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq may have harmed his chances of having economic sanctions lifted early.
The Iraqi troop movements were the culmination of a campaign of belligerence aimed as much at the United Nations as at Kuwait. 
 For a week before the troop movements, diplomats and officials were mystified by a spate of angry statements from Baghdad threatening retaliation if the Security Council did not act swiftly to start dismantling the sanctions imposed on Iraq after the Persian Gulf war.
As these statements were being made, a United Nations team of experts was in Iraq for a final inspection of a monitoring system to insure that Baghdad was no longer producing or buying weapons of mass destruction, as demanded under Security Council Resolution 687 of April 1991. The experts' report will be turned over to the Council this week.
Iraq had taken the position that with the monitoring system in place, the Security Council was obliged to ease the sanctions, which prohibit Baghdad from exporting oil. In the Council, there were differences on how to respond.
France and Russia, to whom Iraq owes huge sums, argued that the United Nations should consider a timetable for lifting restrictions after the monitoring system had been tested.
The United States and Britain took a tougher line, saying that President Hussein's intentions had also to be tested -- along with the monitoring system -- for an unspecified time before the Security Council could consider lifting sanctions. The next formal review of Iraqi compliance is not due until mid-November.
China, the fifth permanent member of the Security Council, is generally opposed to all sanctions because of the precedent they set.
But if President Hussein thought he could widen the split and isolate the United States from its European allies, he may have miscalculated badly, diplomats and officials say.
As a result of the troop movements, Iraq's supporters on this issue will have a harder time making Baghdad's case, a Western diplomat said.
"Saddam Hussein has a way of shooting himself in the foot," the diplomat said, adding that most people believed the Iraqi troop movement was no more than posturing. It was accompanied by a verbal attack on the United States on Friday full of bombast and bathos by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz.
But the response from Washington was strong enough for Iraq to announce today that it was withdrawing its troops. President Clinton, however, said that the United States had seen no evidence so far of a withdrawal and it was adding more firepower to its Persian Gulf forces.
Furthermore, in answering Mr. Aziz on Friday, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, again raised a host of other charges against Iraq, including failure to account for Kuwaiti prisoners and return Kuwaiti property.
Iraq, Ms. Albright said, "has sought to evade, ignore and negotiate away its obligations.
"The only approach it has not tried," she added, "is compliance."
In wanting to delay lifting sanctions, the United States has some support from the Special Commission, an independent organization within the United Nations that has put into place an extraordinary array of sophisticated monitoring systems. The commission, working with the International Atomic Energy Agency, organized the destruction of Iraqi weapons after the war.
The head of the commission, Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, said last week after visiting Iraq that the systems were functioning. But experts on the panel are known to want at least six months to prove both the workability of the technology and the good faith of the Iraqi Government.
There are also gaps in documentation turned over to the commission, including information on past purchases and old weapons programs. The commission has a team of 70 to 80 people in Baghdad, from technical experts to helicopter crews authorized to fly them on unannounced searches. Biological, chemical and nuclear weapons programs are prohibited, as are missile systems.
In any event, diplomats say, there is no hope of easing sanctions until Iraq recognizes Kuwait's current borders -- and does so at the highest possible level, the Revolutionary Command Council.
The Iraqis have argued that Baghdad can do this only when the clock has started on an agreed time limit for testing the monitoring systems and Iraq can be reasonably sure there will be no other last-minute demands by the United States.
"Kuwait is Iraq's last card," said Jean-Bernard Merimee, France's representative to the United Nations. "Iraq has to be sure that after the recognition of Kuwait, the Security Council will move to lift sanctions." He added that there was a growing sense that Iraq cannot be cornered indefinitely without the danger of President Hussein becoming even more threatening.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "LEGISLATION: The Resolutions Against Iraq"
 
U.N. REQUIREMENTS
 Section C. of the Security Council Resolution passed on April 3, 1991:
 Requires Iraq to destroy biological, chemical and ballistic missiles with a range more than 150 km and their production facilities.
Requires Iraq to declare locations, amounts and types of all above weapons, agree to urgent on-site inspection by the United Nations special commission on Iraq or the International Atomic Energy Agency and develop a plan for future monitoring and verification of these weapons.
Asks Iraq to fulfill its obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
Requires Iraq to inform the Security Council that it will not commit or support any acts of international terrorism.
Requires that Iraq compensate Kuwait for any losses incurred during its invasion.
 
WHAT IRAQ SAYS
 Tariq Aziz told the General Assembly last Friday that Iraq had complied fully with the section C of the resolution 687 and argued that sanctions be lifted.
 
WHAT THE U.S. SAYS
The U.S. insists that sanctions should not be lifted because Iraq has not given a full accounting of the full capacity of biological and chemical weapons.
It says it doesn't know how long Iraq will comply with the monitoring system.
It says Iraq has failed to account for the oppression of Kurds and Shiit Muslims.
It says Iraq failed to renounce international terrorism.
They have not recognized Kuwait as a sovereign state.
The U.S. says Iraq's current military maneuver suggests that it has not demonstrated acceptance of peace.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: POLITICS;
Aristide Is Now Facing Daunting Job of Restoration

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
As the military rulers in Haiti stepped down, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide spent today trying to decide precisely how he will run the country, whom to name as prime minister and who among a jostling crowd of American politicians will be on the airplane that takes him home.
With his flight to Haiti five days away, the exiled President has neither formally announced who will serve alongside him nor revealed his immediate plans upon returning to power, worrying some White House officials who want assurances of stability for Haiti's future. 
 The White House has been prodding Father Aristide to pick a prime minister with palpably moderate politics, roots among the Haitian elite and a history of working with American Embassy officials -- preferably Robert Malval, a wealthy publisher who was Prime Minister when the President was overthrown in 1991. But Father Aristide is keeping his intentions to himself.
His only political act today was to sign a decree expressing his agreement with the law on amnesty passed on Friday by the Haitian Parliament. The law fell short of the general amnesty sought by the head of the Haitian junta, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, leaving the leaders of the 1991 coup that toppled President Aristide potentially vulnerable to charges of corruption and murder.
The failure to win a complete amnesty was a factor in the general's decision to leave Haiti, United States officials said.
A senior Administration official said that with General Cedras departing for an undisclosed destination, the rest of the military-led government would dissolve this week. He said he thought that cabinet ministers appointed by General Cedras would vacate their offices and that ministers who served under President Aristide would return to work.
"He has a cabinet, and our hope is that they'll be able to go back to work this week," the Administration official said. Some of the 20,000 American troops in Haiti will be "protecting the functioning of the government, protecting the Parliament," he said.
The resistance to Father Aristide among the Haitian military and police remains strong, so strong that United States forces in Haiti are planning to sweep important government buildings for bombs and booby traps before he returns, State Department officials said today.
Still, it has been clear since the arrival of American troops permitted some free expressions of political opinion in Haiti that the overwhelming majority of Haitians -- certainly the 67.5 percent of the electorate who voted for him in 1990 -- will be overjoyed to see him back.
"I am pleased to announce that President Aristide will return home to resume his rightful place this Saturday," President Clinton said in his televised speech tonight. "I also want to caution again, the job in Haiti remains difficult and dangerous. We still have a lot of work ahead of us. But our troops are keeping America's commitment to restore democracy."
It is possible that Secretary of State Warren Christopher will accompany Father Aristide to Haiti on Saturday. But a large number of American supporters of the Haitian President also want very much to be on that plane. They include the Rev. Jesse Jackson, several members of Congress and Randall Robinson, whose hunger strike on Father Aristide's behalf this year is widely credited with focusing Mr. Clinton's attention on the Haitian situation.
From the moment Father Aristide sets foot on Haitian soil after more than three years in exile, he will face the task of building a democratic government in a nation that has never known one. The economic and social foundations of the country are in ruins.
Within days after his return, a trickle and then a flood of financial and material aid is supposed to descend on Haiti. The United States is setting up a jobs program that in theory will put 50,000 Haitians to work by 1995.
Fifteen nations have pledged $77 million in contributions that will wipe out most of Haiti's debts to international financial institutions, allowing new loans to flow in.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
To build Minolta's visibility and market share, a new campaign lets slip a watchdog of copiers.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
GEORGE LOIS was barking.
No, Mr. Lois, the flamboyant chairman and chief executive at Lois/USA in New York, hasn't gone mad. Rather, he woofed to act out a campaign for a new client, the Minolta Corporation, which centers on a dog. 
 Mr. Lois, the initiator since 1949 of what he likes to call "big ideas," was inspired by Minolta's description of the central processing units within its CS-Pro series of copiers as "hidden electronic watchdogs." They guard against paper jams and other malfunctions, and even automatically make telephone calls to dealer service departments.
So Mr. Lois is bringing the watchdogs to life with an actual watchdog. That befits an adman who granted powers of speech to oranges, tomatoes and vodka bottles in a memorable campaign for Wolfschmidt's; urged Braniff airlines customers that "when you got it -- flaunt it," and encouraged rock stars to shout "I want my MTV!"
"The watchdog is a personality, a brand image, fun and dramatic," Mr. Lois said in an interview, switching to English from dogtalk. "It's an icon in the best commercial sense."
The print, broadcast and outdoor campaign begins Thursday. Television commercials depict executives patting and praising their watchdog copiers -- and leaving one a dish filled with dog food.
The watchdog is "a beautiful, elegant, open-faced" German shepherd called Freeway because before his career as an ad star, he was found on one, Mr. Lois said.
"There's not a German shepherd in America we didn't look at," he added, laughing. "People would say, 'I'd like a watchdog with a little bit of a smile.' "
Freeway's appearance is also appropriate because of the intensely competitive nature of the nation's copier market, which is a veritable catfight (just kidding). Dataquest Inc., a consulting company in San Jose, Calif., estimates revenue last year at $7.4 billion, up 8.8 percent from 1992. That figure has risen steadily from 1990, when it totaled $5.9 billion, as American businesses expanded after the recession -- or white-collar workers, laid off from corporate jobs, bought copiers for home offices.
Minolta's 4 percent of the American copier market, according to Dataquest, put the company in a four-way tie for sixth place with Ricoh, Lanier and Konica. The leaders were Xerox, at 32 percent; Canon, 18 percent, and Sharp, 8 percent. Eastman Kodak and Mita, with 7 percent each, tied for fourth.
"Our goal is to be in the top three in the next two to three years," said David Scofield, advertising director for Minolta's business equipment division in Ramsey, N.J., who joined Mr. Lois for the interview.
Did the client ever wonder whether Mr. Lois's idea of a dog would turn out to be a dog of an idea?
"It's a low-interest category," Mr. Scofield said. "You only think of your copier when it isn't working."
To rise in the rankings, he added, "we needed something wild like this. We couldn't do that with blandness."
Still, there is a fine line between a simple ad and a simple-minded ad.
"Advertising should be seemingly outrageous," Mr. Lois said, "but not be nuts."
Mr. Scofield asserted that "the beauty is the simplicity" and the watchdog was "tied totally to the technology."
"There's no better symbol to communicate that," he said.
In defense of Freeway, other copier marketers employ creatures in their ads, too: Konica has a lion and Mita uses dinosaurs.
Minolta plans to spend $2 million on the campaign during the next six months. The television spots will run in 10 local markets like Chicago, Los Angeles and New York. The print ads will run in publications like Business Week, Forbes and Newsweek.
The campaign is the first for Minolta by Lois/USA since the agency was hired in May after a three-month review. The account, with billings estimated at $7 million to $10 million, was consolidated after being previously divided between Bozell New York and Campbell Mithun Esty in New York.
To underscore the breadth of the company's products, the copier campaign also lists Minolta products like cameras, fax machines, digital imaging systems and video camcorders. The ads retain a corporate theme, "Only from the mind of Minolta," that has run since 1983.
"It's a terrific, well-remembered line," Mr. Lois said, "but it needed excitement."
Mr. Lois is the subject of an exhibit through Oct. 21 at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan, the sixth in a series honoring "great visual communicators." As a result, Minolta has already achieved a measure of fame for the copier campaign: he shrewdly included it among his current work on display.

HEADLINE: Oregon, Foiling Forecasters, Thrives as It Protects Owls

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ore., Oct. 5

 BODY:
By now, the timber communities of Oregon were supposed to be ghost towns. There was going to an epidemic of foreclosures, a recession so crippling it would mean "we'll be up to our neck in owls, and every millworker will be out of a job," as President George Bush predicted two years ago while campaigning in the Northwest.
Politicians in both parties agreed. The villain was the northern spotted owl, an endangered bird fond of the same ancient national forests desired by loggers. When restrictions on logging were ordered in 1991 to protect the bird, Michael Burrill spoke for many of his fellow Oregon timber mill owners when he said, "They just created Appalachia in the Northwest." 
 But economic calamity has never looked so good. Three years into a drastic curtailment of logging in Federal forests, Oregon, the top timber-producing state, has posted its lowest unemployment rate in a generation, just over 5 percent.
What was billed as an agonizing choice of jobs versus owls has proved to be neither, thus far. Oregon is still the nation's timber basket, producing more than 5 billion board feet a year. (Ten thousand board feet are used to build the average house.) But instead of using 300-year-old trees from public land to make 2-by-4's, mills are relying on wood from tree farms, most of them belonging to private landowners. And the mills are getting more out of the timber, using parts that used to be discarded.
In the last five years, Oregon lost 15,000 jobs in forest products. But it gained nearly 20,000 jobs in high technology, with companies like Hewlett-Packard, which makes computer parts, expanding considerably in the state. By early next year, for the first time in history, high technology will surpass timber as the leading source of jobs in the Beaver State. And timber workers are being retrained for some of those jobs, particularly in manufacturing.
Instead of spectral monuments to the spotted owl, many parts of the state have reached what economists call full employment -- a jobless level of about 5 percent that the experts say will not cause inflation and where people are usually unemployed by choice. And there are signs of impending labor shortages, according to state economists. In the last year alone, the state's growing economy has added nearly 100,000 jobs -- the exact amount the timber industry said would be lost with the restrictions.
Even the most timber-dependent counties in southern Oregon report rising property values and a net increase in jobs.
But some in the timber industry say the crash is yet to come. Many mills are using trees that should not have been cut because they are too small, said Chris West, a spokesman for the Northwest Forestry Association, an industry group based in Portland.
"The small woodlot market blossomed more than anyone expected," Mr. West said. "But it's going to be short-term."
Asked about the job-loss figure of 100,000, Mr. West said, "We don't think the hammer has hit yet."
As for the loggers and millworkers who have already lost their jobs, most of them did not become minimum-wage hamburger flippers, as predicted. At Lane Community College in Springfield, the nation's largest center for retraining displaced woodworkers, nearly 9 of every 10 people going through the program have found new jobs, at an average wage of $9.02 an hour, about $1 an hour less than the average timber industry wage. They are becoming auto mechanics, accountants, cabinetmakers and health care workers.
"So many people say this is the best thing to ever happen to them," said Jeff Wilson, a former millworker from the town of Mapleton, who is just finishing his retraining program and plans to become a community service worker. "I was brain-dead at the mill, never thought I'd do anything else. Now, it's like the world has opened up."
The big question on retraining, one that President Clinton brought half the Cabinet here to discuss at the timber summit in the spring of 1993, was what a timber worker could be retrained to do. It turned out to be a simple answer, said Patti Lake, who runs the retraining program.
"I'm so sick of the Paul Bunyan stereotype about these people," Ms. Lake said. "They come to us because they know there are better jobs than burger-flipping. They're just people who graduated from high school and went to work in the mill or the woods. Now, they're becoming the accountant who does my taxes or the mechanic who fixes my car."
To be sure, there are pockets of poverty in the smaller, more remote timber towns of Oregon. The aid package promised by President Clinton, $1.2 billion over five years, has only begun to trickle in. Under the President's plan, the timber cut in national forests will be about one-fourth of what it was in the 1980's.
Places like Sweet Home and Oakridge have lost Main Street businesses as the mills have closed. Auctions of heavy equipment used to haul and mill giant trees are common.
But no county in Oregon has an unemployment rate higher than 7.8 percent, and in some rural counties, the rate is about 2 percent, compared with the national rate of 5.9 percent. Also, few people seem to be leaving. During the last period of timber layoffs, from 1981 to 1987, Oregon lost population. Last year, the population grew by 40,000 people.
And as the number of logging jobs has fallen, the average wage here has risen. In 1988, the peak year for timber cutting, wage levels here were 88 percent of the national average. This year, they are 93 percent.
In 1991, Representative Bob Smith, a Republican from the eastern part of the state, said the logging restrictions "will take us to the bottom of a black hole." And that year Representative Peter A. DeFazio, a Democrat who represents the biggest timber-producing district in the nation, in south and western Oregon, sketched a picture of widespread devastation.
But here in Lane County, in Mr. DeFazio's district, the unemployment rate is 4.8 percent. Mr. DeFazio, who still predicts some economic downturn, said he has been pleasantly surprised by some of the positive developments.
"I met a guy my age, a timber worker who was being retrained to become a nurse," he recalled. "A nurse! He said, 'Yeah, it's the fulfillment of a lifetime dream.' "
Springfield, the blue-collar neighbor of Eugene, across the Willamette River, has landed a new Sony Corporation factory, where compact discs will be manufactured. It may employ 1,500 people within five years, at salaries that will start at better than $30,000 a year.
"It wasn't blind, dumb luck that helped us land Sony," said Mayor Bill Morrisette of Springfield. The company wanted a pristine place on the river, he said.
Using some money from President Clinton's forest recovery package, the town offered Sony $8 million in tax abatements and incentives. In return, Sony promised to pay people at least 10 percent above the national average. Today, the factory is rising on farmland just miles from the woods that have been shut down to logging to protect the spotted owl.
"Owls versus jobs was just plain false," Mr. Morrisette said. "What we've got here is quality of life. And as long as we don't screw that up, we'll always be able to attract people and business."
And even though numerous timber mills have closed in Springfield because they could no longer get the big trees, newer, leaner operations like Springfield Forest Products are hiring. The Springfield mill, which was shut in 1989, was retooled to use small-dimension wood from tree farms. When it was owned by Georgia Pacific, the mill relied on old-growth timber from national forests.
The mill now employs 450 people.
"A lot of people were afraid of change," said Scott Slaughter, the personnel manager, a third-generation timber worker. "But I see a real future here."
Ed Whitelaw, a professor of economics at the University of Oregon in Eugene, was one of a handful of economists who predicted that job losses would be minimal and that Oregon, because of its attractive scenery and low property costs, would thrive.
"These 100,000-job-loss figures were just fallacious; they came out of a political agenda," Dr. Whitelaw said. "Yet when I would say this, I was dismissed as an Earth-Firster or something."
Mr. Burrill, who owns a timber mill in Medford, Ore., was asked about his statement that saving the spotted owl would create Appalachia in the Northwest.
"We've had an awful lot of new industry, and that's surprised me," he said. He said people moving to southern Oregon from California are not all retirees, as the stereotype has it.
"They are bringing jobs with them," he said. "Turns out there's a hell of a lot going on."

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: IRAQ;
Kuwait Crisis: Hussein Gambles to Keep Power

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein's latest confrontation with the United States illustrates both the success and the failure of Washington's handling of the Iraqi leader.
The success is that two successive Administrations have managed to maintain crippling global sanctions on Iraq that have created an economic crisis so desperate that President Hussein felt cornered. But instead of recognizing the sovereignty and the borders of Kuwait, a condition set by the United Nations for easing the sanctions, he moved 70,000 troops toward the country that his troops invaded in 1990. 
That troop mobilization highlights the policy failure: three years after the end of the gulf war, Mr. Hussein remains firmly entrenched in power.
The result is that even if statements by Iraq that it is pulling its troops away from Kuwait are true, Mr. Hussein will have proved once again that he can force the United States to send tens of thousands of troops to confront him; if he is not ousted from power, he will prove he is a political survivor as well.
In his 15 years as President, Mr. Hussein has ruled by ruthlessly suppressing all opposition. But his Government does not rule by terror alone. It has survived because it has always been supple enough to respond to the basic physical needs of the people. The philosophy of governing is best expressed in two Arabic words: tarhib (terror) and targhib (enticement).
But in the past year, that delicate structure has crumbled.
"There was only terrorizing," said Amatzia Baram, chairman of the Department of Middle East History at Haifa University. "There was no longer enticement."
Mr. Hussein was forced by the sanctions to allow the United Nations to scrap his weapons of mass destruction, set up an elaborate and humiliating monitoring system of his arms industry and take increasingly tough economic measures. That hurt the Iraqi people, fueled discontent and brought Mr. Hussein to what some Iraqi scholars say was an inevitable decision to take dramatic action.
After retail prices soared last year, Mr. Hussein decided to accept Security Council Resolution 715, which set up the weapons-inspection system; as a result of his compliance, he promised his people, sanctions would "dissipate."
Instead, the sanctions remained in place and prices soared again. Even President Hussein's son Uday used his newspaper Babil to criticize officials who promoted compliance with the United Nations demands, although he never attacked his father by name.
After the Iraqi dinar lost half its value last May, Uday Hussein criticized Iraq's Prime Minister and Finance Minister for their inability to control inflation.
So President Hussein added the portfolio of Prime Minister to his responsibilities as President, Commander in Chief and head of the Baath Party. He also turned the ruling Revolutionary Command Council into an economic body that made decisions on such issues as how much two pounds of sugar should cost.
The economic crisis worsened last month, when the Security Council again decided not to lift the sanctions. On Sept. 25, Mr. Hussein halved monthly food rations, and food prices doubled in one day.
The economic pressure coincided with mounting political pressure. In September last year, there were reports that a bomb had exploded in front of Mr. Hussein's motorcade in Baghdad; last May a car bomb exploded at a place where his motorcade was expected to pass.
Purges and executions followed each incident, and during recent months Mr. Hussein has even purged officials from the Duri clan, a center of his support, and the clan of Izzat Ibrahim, officially his second in command.
Mr. Hussein has answered each setback with more stringent proclamations: He has imposed strict Islamic punishments of amputations of a hand or a foot for thievery, and announced that deserters from the Armed Forces risk losing one or both ears. A repeat deserter may have an X branded on his forehead.
"Iraq has been a sleeper," said Phebe Marr, senior fellow at the National Defense University and a historian who has written extensively on Iraq. "He was running out of time and patience and had to do something to convince his people he was in charge and taking action to get the sanctions lifted. Sooner or later something like this was going to happen."
By mobilizing troops, President Hussein proved once again that he is more a military leader willing to bully than a statesman capable of diplomatic maneuvering.
Mr. Hussein was apparently convinced that even if he complied with United Nations resolutions, the United States would not allow the Security Council to ease sanctions. He ignored repeated advice from France, Turkey and Russia that they would support the lifting of some sanctions if he would fulfill Security Council resolutions and recognize Kuwait and its borders.
Instead he has always said that Iraq's isolation from the sea was a cruel accident of colonial history, and at one point after his invasion of Kuwait he called the tiny nation "a part of Iraq's land" that was "cut off by English scissors."
So it is not surprising that he found it particularly galling after the Gulf War when the United Nations formally redrew the Kuwaiti border to give part of Iraq's only port at Umm Qasr to Kuwait.
"Had Saddam come up with a satisfactory statement on Kuwait, the coalition would have softened further and compelled the United States to confront the sanctions issue," said Ms. Marr. "But he didn't, and my interpretation is that he wasn't close to it yet."
A key to his thinking came on Sept. 27, when he told journalists that he would open for the Iraqi people "all the granaries of the world," a signal that he was poised to take dramatic action. "Tell the people that honor is more important than bread," he urged the journalists.
That was followed on Oct. 4 with an editorial in Al Jumhuriya, the Government-run newspaper, that warned, "The first and second world wars were caused by the imposition of borders on Germany without negotiations or German approval."
Two days later an editorial in the same newspaper said, "When one realizes that death is one's inexorable fate, there remains nothing to deter one from taking the riskiest steps to influence the course of events."
Even if President Hussein withdraws his troops, as his officials today said he had done, his military actions are an unwelcome reminder of the unfinished business of the gulf war.
"By moving his units south, he created excitement that his people will not forget for a while," said Mr. Baram, of Haifa University. "He can pull back and maybe there will be a few weeks of relief. But Saddam is bound to haunt us as long as he is he there. He would rather die than be forgotten."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
L.T.'s Rush Helped Sack Phil Simms

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

 BODY:
BY the time the workout was over, a couple dozen kids were outside the practice field, in the shadow of Giants Stadium, waiting for the quarterback. Like a horde of sleepy buffalo, the other players trudged out the gate, past the kids, into the parking lot, toward the locker room.
Finally, as the quarterback appeared, the notebooks and pens converged in the manner of a ritual circle dance. Dave Brown, who now appears to carry whatever hopes remain for a serious football future in northern New Jersey, smiled, and began to sign. 
 Someone asked Brown about the crushing interception he'd thrown in New Orleans, if he was going to bounce back. "I think I've already showed I could respond in the second half," he said, not yet knowing that this question would dog him for yet another week after the Giants' 27-10 loss to the Minnesota Vikings.
It may have been Lawrence Taylor Night at Giants Stadium last night, but the most important message delivered was that the Giants are getting exactly what they bargained for when they cut Phil Simms. This is Dave Brown's ride, for better or worse, or both.
And you might say that L. T., whose storybook career was all about getting his mitts on quarterbacks, had a hand in what we are watching now.
Phil Simms wasn't expected at halftime of the Giants-Vikings game to applaud the retirement of Taylor's No. 56. The excuse was his analyst's job at ESPN. The speculation was that there was lingering anger toward the Giants. Maybe in the back of Simms's mind, there is also some disgust that Taylor should go out on his own terms, while he could not.
There ought to be. Taylor sure did contribute his share to the current work rules that got Simms canned. He was one of the worst offenders of unity in the players' strike in 1987, even though no one seemed to remember this during the spate of recent tributes.
First Taylor distanced himself from teammates, then he crossed and played with scab replacements, announcing: "The Giants are losing. And I'm losing $60,000 a week."
In the context of the current labor wars, imagine what excoriation Bobby Bonilla and Barry Bonds could expect if they took that attitude next spring.
Maybe that was last night's underlying moral. As great a defensive player as Taylor was, perhaps the greatest of all, there are all sorts of legendary Giants, championship Giants, who never got their jerseys retired. Few got to dictate the terms of their departures.
It is old news now. A couple more victories, it will be forgotten. The acceptance of Dave Brown, out of Westfield, N.J., occurred even before the autumn leaves had a chance to turn, much less fall. George Young and Dan Reeves could not have dreamed that their orchestrated coup would have gone this well this soon when they cut Simms last June.
Brown's not likely to carry these Giants to the Super Bowl, but let's be honest, neither was Simms. The decision to dump the best quarterback in Giant history stemmed from that realization. It was time, the Giants decided, for the man who was younger, stronger and faster.
Simms decided to focus blame on the new National Football League salary cap, but salary caps don't decide which players get cut. General managers do. Coaches do. In Simms's case, the salary cap was less the reason than it was the weapon.
They cut Simms because they decided they could live without him, and because the hard N.F.L. salary cap punishes any team which keeps players who are past their prime or struggling to recapture their health.
That's what happens when players don't collectively fight for their rights, when they throw themselves at one-sided economics espoused by the Gary Bettmans and Bud Seligs, when they trample their own picket line.
"You had to look at L. T. like he was a special case because of what he gave on the field," George Martin, who was the striking Giants' player representative, said yesterday.
Martin admitted that wasn't easy for some of the striking Giants. One of them, a reserve linebacker named Robbie Jones, understood solidarity. "If you follow Lawrence Taylor, you burn in hell," he said.
L. T., who lived on the edge, never did crash, much less burn. That doesn't mean he didn't help cause others to.

HEADLINE: MacNeil to Retire From 'Newshour' In '95 After 20 Years

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
Robert MacNeil said yesterday that he would retire as a co-anchor of the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" next October after 20 years with public television's nightly news program. The program, which is suffering budgetary constraints, is to close down its operation in New York and base itself in Washington.
When Mr. MacNeil steps down, Jim Lehrer is to take over as single anchor of the broadcast, which will then be retitled "The Newshour With Jim Lehrer" and originate solely from WETA in Washington. In a blow to WNET, Channel 13, in New York, the station where it began in 1975, the program and a staff that numbers about 50 will leave that station. 
 Mr. MacNeil said yesterday that he had been planning for almost two years to step down when the program reached its 20th anniversary. The pressures created by a worsening budget shortfall made it logical to consolidate the show in Washington once he retires, he said.
"We needed to make some economies if we're going to survive," Mr. MacNeil said. "The most obvious and dispensable area to cut was the duplication of studios and staffs in two cities."
Mr. MacNeil's departure was reported on Saturday by The Washington Post.
The change is one more indication that the institutions related to public television, faced with increasing competition from cable and other broadcast channels and shrinking sources of revenue, need to cut costs, said Al Vecchione, the president of MacNeil/Lehrer Productions. "The problems of public television in the year 1994 are such that it's time to think about streamlining," he said. "It's getting tougher because it's more and more competitive. Before we start to talk about the need for more money, we have to collectively think about ways to streamline."
For MacNeil/Lehrer Productions, that will mean staff cuts when the "Newshour" moves its base to Washington. Mr. MacNeil said the announcement was being made a year in advance to give staff members in New York time to think about whether to relocate. Thus, some jobs may be eliminated by attrition before the move to Washington. But Mr. Vecchione said some layoffs would undoubtedly be necessary.
The move will also be costly to WNET, as "MacNeil/Lehrer" is probably the most prestigious program to come from the station. "You can't take away the prestige we've already had because of the program," said William F. Baker, the president of WNET. "I want them to do whatever is best for them, but selfishly, of course, I would prefer it to be in New York."
The change also comes at a time when WNET is already faced with continuing budget shortfalls. Channel 13's financial crisis had significant impact on the strategy MacNeil/Lehrer Productions worked out for its future.
"They've been through all these agonizing reappraisals of their finances," Mr. MacNeil said. "They've had cuts and cuts and cuts. Then they came to that tentative decision to close down their studio."
WNET told the "MacNeil/Lehrer" producers in June that the station was so short of money it might have to shut down its studio, forcing the program to find a new place in New York from which to broadcast Mr. MacNeil's portion of the program.
Although Mr. MacNeil said the problem with studio cost was not crucial to the decision to move to Washington, some "MacNeil/Lehrer" staff members criticized Channel 13 for failing to manage its finances more efficiently. "For 15 years they have not changed the way they've done business," said one staff member, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said WNET had finally decided to keep the studio up and running for "MacNeil/Lehrer" at least through June, at an additional cost of $500,000 to the program.
Mr. Baker disputed the $500,000 figure and said Channel 13 "subsidized the program for years." He said the station's financial and labor issues were "phenomenally complex." He also said the loss of "MacNeil/Lehrer" would not necessarily mean the end of the station's studio facilities. But he conceded, "It will make our situation that much more complicated."
Mr. Vecchione said the financial problems of "MacNeil/Lehrer" mirror those of public television as a whole. "The sources of funding are all either down or flat," he said.
"PBS memberships are down," he said, specifically blaming competition from other television for that decrease. "Corporate underwriting was down 16 percent last year and is down again this year."
"MacNeil/Lehrer" has a budget this year of just under $25 million, down from $26 million a year ago. Two years ago, the program had two underwriters, Pepsico and AT&T, each of which donated $6 million. Then AT&T dropped out. "MacNeil/ Lehrer" replaced them with Archer Daniels Midland and New York Life, which, along with Pepsico, each gave $4.4 million.
But Pepsico dropped out last year. Archer Daniels Midland increased its contribution to $6.4 million, but overall the program now takes in only $10.8 million in corporate underwriting, as opposed to $12 million two years ago. The other revenue sources, public television stations and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, have been essentially flat, Mr. Vecchione said.
"The shortfall was going to gradually deepen," Mr. MacNeil said, without the consolidation of the two bases of operations for the program. He added that since the program had gravitated toward more news generated out of Washington, having a single anchor there made a lot of sense.
After Mr. MacNeil leaves, the program will use subanchors for individual stories, Mr. Vecchione said. The overall goal of the consolidation, he said, is to provide for the long-term future of the "Newshour." "We want this program to go on long after all of us have left it," he said.
Mr. MacNeil said he would pursue his other careers, as a writer of fiction and nonfiction and as an independent producer and an anchor of television specials.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
International
 For foreign investors, Russia is too big a business opportunity to avoid, despite the crashing ruble and rising crime. In recent months, American and foreign investment funds and companies have been pouring in money, taking stakes in promising Russian enterprises. They are betting that the nation's industrial core remains badly undervalued and that in the long run big parts of it will prove to be vibrant and profitable. [Page A1.] 
Cosmetics companies are forging ahead in Eastern Europe despite its seemingly small prospects for profits. Estee Lauder, Guerlain and Christian Dior see big potential and are trying to get established with modest initial investments. [D1.]
 
Companies
 A South African company will buy S. D. Warren for $1.6 billion. The purchase of the Scott Paper unit by Sappi Ltd. of Johannesburg would be the largest American investment by a South African company in more than 20 years, executives said. [D1.]
 Ernst & Young dismissed about 240 people involved with its legal work, including 37 of its 65 lawyers. [D2.]
 Sprint is in talks with big cable television operators about collaborating on a nationwide wireless telephone network. [D5.]
 Shares of both Apple Computer and I.B.M. continued to climb on reports that the companies were close to a common hardware standard. [D5.] A company mentioned in speculation on the talks, Motorola, reported a sharp rise in third-quarter earnings. [D5.]
 Panhandle Eastern will buy Associated Natural Gas for $830 million in stock and assumed debt. The deal reflects the new consolidation and integration in the natural gas industry. [D5.]
 R. J. Reynolds Tobacco plans to introduce a cigarette that leaves less of a lingering stale smell. [D5.]
 New drugs from both Biogen and Teva Pharmaceutical seem to be effective in slowing the progression of multiple sclerosis. [C5.]
 
The Economy
 The Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise rates again until the next meeting of its top policy committee on Nov. 15 even as further increases seem increasingly inevitable. Several officials at the central bank say they want to see more data on the economy before deciding when to act again. News Analysis. [D1.]
 Stainless steel is booming as producers find new uses for the metal. Auto makers have increasingly been equipping cars and light trucks with exhaust systems made of stainless steel. [D1.]
 No-haggle selling by car dealers is being investigated by the Justice Department as part of an inquiry into auto pricing. [D1.]
 The incinerator industry is endangered as more towns cancel plans to build plants that convert waste to energy. [A18.]
 
Markets
 Technology and auto issues led stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 23.89 points. [D8.]
 Treasury futures were slightly higher, while the Treasury market was closed in observance of Columbus Day. [D16.]
 Crude oil prices fell sharply after Iraq said it would retreat from the Kuwaiti border. Coffee prices tumbled. [D17.]
 The dollar slipped a bit in thin trading, after the threat of a war in the Persian Gulf faded. [D17.]

 TRW is much more than a credit reporting company. What has attracted investors to TRW is the company's strength in the rapidly growing air bag business. Market Place. [D8.]
 A German shepherd is the star of Lois/USA's new campaign for Minolta copiers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Stainless Steel Widens Appeal

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
The rusted tailpipe may be going the way of the side-vent window. In recent years, auto makers have increasingly been equipping cars and light trucks with rust-resistant exhaust systems made of stainless steel. By the 1996 model year, virtually every car produced in North America is expected to have a stainless steel exhaust system.
Stainless steel is also making its way into household chimney liners, energy-efficient storm windows and a host of other applications in which consumers' demand for durability and quality has overtaken manufacturers' tendency to opt for the cheapest solution. 
 Indeed, finding new uses for corrosion-resistant stainless steel is one reason that producers of the material have found theirs to be an erosion-resistant market, achieving a compound growth rate averaging 4 percent annually for the last 30 years.
And the trend, which is expected to continue into the next century, is expected to lead to record consumption of stainless steel in the United States this year.
"It is hard to find any long-term growth in basic steel, but the underlying demand for stainless steel has been growing faster than economic activity, which is unusual for a metal," said Charles A. Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities.
A record year for stainless steel may seem unremarkable at a time when the entire United States steel industry -- from commodities like carbon steel to specialty alloy grades -- is enjoying its biggest boom in decades.
Yet most steelmakers know that for every boom in the industry comes the inevitable downturn, which is the reason most steel producers have deliberately avoided gearing up production to fulfill the current demand. The consumption of carbon steel, the biggest segment by far, is expected to fall short this year of the United States record of 111 million tons, set in 1973.
But in the stainless steel segment of the industry in the United States, led by the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation, producers are toiling to keep up with record demand for their product. The consumption of stainless steel in the United States is forecast at 2.1 million tons for the entire year -- slightly more than a fifth of the global stainless steel market.
Allegheny Ludlum, based in Pittsburgh, has been consistently profitable since becoming a public company in 1987, after splitting from Allegheny International in a management-led buyout. The other leading stainless steel makers -- Armco Inc. of Parsippany, N.J.; J& L Specialty Steel Inc. of Pittsburgh, and Lukens Inc. of Coatesville, Pa. -- are in various states of revamping and recovery from changes in ownership or money-losing efforts in other, lower-priced types of steel.
Even so, the continued good prospects for stainless steel have prompted positive reports from analysts for at least J& L, whose stock was recently upgraded to a "moderate outperformer" by Goldman, Sachs & Company, and to a "strong buy" by Kidder, Peabody & Company.
Mr. Bradford, the analyst, said he saw plenty of room for continued growth in the United States steel market, as consumers demanded longer-lasting cars, appliances and other products. On a per-capita basis, the consumption in this country is still only about half the level of that in Japan and many European countries, where manufacturers began emphasizing quality and durability in metal goods much earlier.
While the output of stainless steel remains fairly small compared with the overall steel production in the United States, the high prices commanded by stainless steel makes it an important component of producers' financial results. Price varies by grade, but a ton of stainless steel sells for about $2,300 on average, compared with $500 a ton for commodity-grade carbon steel.
"The rule of thumb is that stainless is 1 to 2 percent of industry tonnage, but 10 to 12 percent of the dollars," said Bert Delano, a spokesman for Allegheny Ludlum.
The company, the biggest domestic producer of stainless steel, derives 86 percent of its revenue from the metal, which it produces in nine plants, situated in western Pennsylvania, as well as Claremont, Okla.; New Castle, Ind.; Lockport, N.Y., and Wallingford and Waterbury, Conn.
Allegheny Ludlum had profits of $70.8 million in 1993 on sales of $1.1 billion, and is expected soon to report third-quarter earnings of about $10 million for the period that ended on Sept. 30.
Stainless steel has long been the company's focus. In 1936, for example, the company that would eventually become Allegheny Ludlum persuaded the Ford Motor Company to stamp six "deluxe sedan" bodies from stainless steel, to demonstrate the metal's durability. Fifty-eight years later, four of the cars are still running, their body panels as shiny as ever.
Although there have been no big technological breakthroughs in the manufacture of stainless steel, the makers continue to tinker with the recipe. Stainless steel, which is widely used in cookware, cutlery and chemical plants, is steel that has been made highly resistant to corrosion by being mixed, or alloyed, with chromium. The surface can be highly polished, which also makes it useful as an architectural decoration and for things like elevator doors.
And because it tolerates high temperatures better than ordinary steels, stainless steel is used in pipes and tubes that are widely used in industrial processes. A threshold of about 10 percent chromium is needed to render the metal "stainless" under ordinary conditions, although some alloys contain up to 27 percent chromium for use in especially hostile environments, like factories that use hot, corrosive chemicals.
Most high-grade stainless steel alloys contain nickel as well, which improves its metalworking properties and helps produce the shiny finish. Other metals like molybdenum and niobium are sometimes added to the mix for special applications.
As a result, making stainless steel is a much more complex operation than that which occurs in a standard steel mill. "With flat-rolled carbon steel, three or four grades dominate," said Richard P. Simmons, chairman of Allegheny Ludlum. "We have 300 different melt codes" for stainless steel, he said.
Although the stainless steel production in the United States has been a consistently profitable business, the number of companies has shrunk in response to decades of plant closings and layoffs throughout the domestic steel industry.
"When I became president of Allegheny Ludlum in 1972, I had nine competitors in flat-rolled stainless," Mr. Simmons said. "Now I have three."
Foreign competition has played a role. The largest exporters of stainless steel to the United States, ranked in descending order, are Spain, Japan, Mexico, France, Italy and Korea.
According to data from the Specialty Steel Industry of the United States, a trade association, imports accounted for 26.6 percent of the total market for stainless steel in the first half on 1994. That was up slightly from 25.2 percent for all of 1993 -- but up significantly from 11.9 percent in 1988.
Dire as the import figures may sound, much of the growth in the last few years has been the result of the demand for stainless steel in the United States outrunning the ability of American companies to produce it in sufficient volume. But like their counterparts in the carbon steel industry, stainless steel producers complain that too much of the imported product comes from producers subsidized by their governments to maintain employment levels.
In any case, pressure from imports has forced stainless steel producers to push for greater efficiencies in the mills and cut costs. "I'm producing about one billion pounds of specialty steel this year," Mr. Simmons said. "That is about twice as much as in 1980, and we are doing it with half as many people." Allegheny Ludlum employs about 6,000 people.
Such efficiencies, analysts say, should put United States stainless steel producers in a position to benefit, as more uses are found for the long-lasting metal.
"People are beginning to think in terms of life cycle costs rather than immediate price," said Thomas E. Abrams, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody. "It seems to be sinking into the psyche of American engineers that paying a little more per ton is actually cheaper if the product lasts longer."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Think air bags, not credit reporting, when evaluating TRW.

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:
MENTION the name TRW and for many people what comes to mind is a credit bureau that provides consumer reports to lenders and merchants.
But to investors, TRW Inc. is -- or should be -- much more. More than 50 percent of its revenues come from automotive products, especially the fast-growing air bag business. An additional 35 percent of revenues stems from space and military systems. Only 8 percent of the company's sales is derived from the broad area of information services, which includes not only credit bureaus, but also real estate information and transaction processing systems. 
 "When a company is predominantly in products that are intermediate in the general economy, there are lots of opportunity for misperceiving it," said Wolfgang H. Demisch, an analyst for BT Securities. "TRW is not getting full credit for the technical strength that it, in fact, has. There's probably still some juice in the orange."
Largely because of this strength, TRW achieved an earnings peak for the second quarter and is poised to set a company profits record for the full year, according to many security analysts. Surprising Wall Street with the attractiveness of its margins, profits rose to $1.33 a share in the April-June quarter, from 85 cents a share in the comparable period a year ago. The consensus mean earnings estimate of 15 analysts, according to I/B/E/S International, which tracks estimates, is $4.61 a share this year and $5.48 a share next year, up from net income of $3.39 a share in 1993.
There is little doubt that air bag use is growing and TRW, as the leading producer of safety restraint systems in the world, stands to benefit.
"The primary investment consideration for the stock is air bag profit growth," said Jennifer Pokrywinski, an analyst for Morgan Stanley. "Even outside the occupant-restraint business, TRW should experience increasing content per vehicle from greater penetration of power rack-and-pinion steering in Europe and rising U.S. use of more efficient four-valve cylinders in engines."
The future of TRW's space and military operations -- including spacecraft, communications systems and lasers -- is problematic. The recent consolidation in the military business, like the merger of Northrop and Grumman and the agreement between Martin Marietta and Lockheed to merge, along with declining military procurement could affect the growth of companies like TRW.
"We recommend the purchase," said Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst for Paine Webber. "But TRW has to make sure that they maintain damage control in space and defense."
Even in its credit information service business, where the company is the market leader over two big competitors, Equifax and Trans Union, enticing long-term opportunities exist in Europe and Japan, if not in the United States.
TRW, which is based in Cleveland, suffered bad publicity a few years ago when a data gatherer mistakenly listed tax payments made by consumers in Norwich, Vt., as tax delinquencies. That led to an agreement by the company with the attorneys general of 19 states and the Federal Trade Commission to make broad changes to give the public less costly, faster and more accurate credit reports. While some analysts expect TRW to eventually sell the information unit, such action is unlikely in the immediate future.
With a favorable overall outlook, the stock of TRW closed at $71.625, up 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, not too far below its 52-week high of $77.50, and more than twice its 1991 low of $34.50. At current levels, it is selling at a 1994 price-earnings ratio of about 15.5 and a 1995 price-earnings ratio of about 13.1, both of which are a significant discount to the overall market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
So to get closer to the mark on TRW these days, think air bags, not credit reporting.

HEADLINE: Data on Derivatives Offered

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company, one of the biggest traders in the $14 trillion derivatives market, said yesterday that it would supply daily information on more than 300 derivatives and other securities to help corporations keep track of the value of their holdings of these complex instruments.
Derivatives are contracts whose value is tied to, or derived from, the price of some other asset, such as an interest rate or a currency. 
 The prices of these contracts can swing rapidly and it is difficult to calculate the so-called value at risk in a portfolio, which is a forecast of the most that could be lost in a single day. That is because of the diverse relationships, or correlations, between different markets that can determine a big move in derivatives prices.
Morgan will provide daily information free on 300 types of derivatives, as well as bonds, equities and other securities, and more than 100,000 correlations between them, said the bank, which calls its system Risk Metrics.
"All of this data represents the starting point for working out what your total value at risk is," said Mark Garman, a principal at Financial Engineering Associates. The Berkeley, Calif., firm is one of a number of companies whose software will incorporate the Morgan data.
Morgan's move comes after a year in which many regulators and legislators called for an improvement in the computer systems companies use to value their derivatives holdings.

HEADLINE: Scott Paper Unit Draws $1.6 Billion

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
Sappi Ltd. of Johannesburg and two other investors agreed to buy America's largest maker of glossy paper from the Scott Paper Company for $1.6 billion, the companies said yesterday. Executives said it would be the biggest American investment by a South African company in more than 20 years.
For Sappi, South Africa's leading paper and forest products company, the purchase represents a big leap into the world paper market. Sappi's sales totaled $1.7 billion last year, while the manufacturer it is acquiring, the S. D. Warren Company of Boston, sold $1.2 billion. 
 For Scott Paper, the sale of S. D. Warren is a sizable step in efforts by its chief executive, Albert J. Dunlap, to reduce the size of the company, its debt and the diversity of its interests.
"It was a strategic sale for us, and a strategic buy for them," said Mr. Dunlap, a turnaround specialist who came out of retirement in April to run Scott. "I've always been a great believer in sticking to your core business."
Wall Street viewed the deal quite favorably. Scott's shares jumped $3.25 yesterday, closing at $64.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sappi's core business, while limited to paper products, has expanded substantially in recent years. In 1988, it bought the world's largest producer of dissolving pulp from a British conglomerate, and in 1990 it bought five paper mills in Britain.
Sappi would not have been legally barred from investing in the United States during the period of international economic sanctions, which were aimed mostly at discouraging American investment in South Africa and not the other way around. But executives involved in Sappi's purchase said it would have been difficult as little as two years ago.
"Think of how the press might have looked at a South African company coming in," said John Chalsty, chief executive of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who was born in South Africa and immigrated to the United States in 1954. "At this time, the issue never arose."
Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette is both a new owner and a lender in the sale of Warren. Its investment banking unit, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, bought $125 million in equity, and another DLJ subsidiary provided $375 million in a bridge loan. The UBS Capital Corporation, a private investment arm of Union Bank of Switzerland, is also providing $25 million in equity.
Under the terms of the purchase, which is subject to approval by the South African Reserve Bank and is not expected to be completed before December, Sappi would own about 70 percent of the company; DLJ Merchant Banking Partners would hold 25 percent and UBS Capital would own about 5 percent.
Chemical Bank provided the bulk of the deal's financing, with a guarantee of $1.1 billion, executives said. Because of strict limits on the amount of capital a South African company can remove from that country, Sappi needed an additional $200 million loan from Union Bank of Switzerland to cover its equity investment.
Analysts who follow Scott Paper said that the sale of its glossy paper manufacturer was expected, but that it had been unclear whether Scott could find a buyer for its price tag of $1.6 billion, about equal to Warren's book value. The International Paper Company and the Union Camp Corporation each expressed interest initially, but dropped out because the price was too high for them, analysts said.
"It's interesting to me that the two big sales by paper companies in the past month have each been with foreign buyers," Lawrence Ross, an analyst at Paine Webber, said.
Last week, Reed Elsevier P.L.C. bought the Mead Corporation's on-line information service for $1.5 billion. "Maybe that tells you something about the value of the dollar," Mr. Ross said.
Mr. Ross noted that Scott Paper bought S. D. Warren in 1968 to diversify its holdings at a time when competition from other large rivals in the tissue business was growing. "They never really wanted Warren," he Ross said. "They made the best of it, but it was never really what they wanted."
S. D. Warren produces about 25 percent of the glossy paper -- used in magazines, brochures and catalogues -- sold in the United States. It runs four paper mills, two in Maine, one in Michigan and one in Alabama.
Another analyst said that a complication in the sale arose from the plant in Mobile, Ala., where pulp production will still be owned by Scott, separate from Warren. With a new owner, Warren will have to buy pulp from Scott at a market price.
"It's sort of like selling the sports department of your newspaper while you keep the rest," said the analyst, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Mr. Dunlap said he did not think the split would be problem.
"We worked it out amicably," he said. "This is a very large sale."
Mr. Chalsty of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said he believed the sale was the largest investment ever made in the United States by a South African company, and was certainly the largest in the last 20 years.
