HEADLINE: Fed's Sense of Timing;
Officials See Another Rate Rise Coming, But Will It Be Now or Later in the Year?

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Top Federal Reserve officials say the American economy is growing briskly, making further increases in short-term interest rates almost inevitable in the coming months to try to prevent the economy from overheating and feeding inflation.
But while many bond market analysts worry that the next increase will come this week, there seems to be a growing possibility that the Fed will not raise rates again until the next meeting of its top policy committee on Nov. 15. 
 Several officials at the nation's central bank said in interviews in the last several days that they would like more data on the economy before deciding when to act again. A clear picture of inflation and economic growth may not be available until the Commerce and Labor Departments release key data for September and October later this month and in early November, they said.
The 19-member committee, called the Federal Open Market Committee, is widely believed to have voted at its Sept. 27 meeting to give broad discretion to Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, to raise interest rates again before the November meeting, and he still may. But top central bank officials said that no clear consensus existed at the central bank for immediate action.
The Federal Reserve's decisions affect the interest rates that Americans pay on car loans, adjustable-rate mortgages and credit cards, as well as the returns they receive on bank deposits, money market funds and bond investments. The decisions also have a powerful influence over the economy's rate of growth and the number of jobs that are created each year.
Susan M. Phillips, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said that unemployment figures for September, which the Labor Department issued on Friday, were of limited use in gauging inflation or the economy because they showed little change from the August levels.
The Commerce Department's figures on third-quarter economic activity, scheduled for release on Oct. 28, will provide the best indication of whether the Fed's five interest-rate increases this year have been enough to slow the economy and forestall inflation, she said.
"That's where we're going to have to look to see how much it has been taking" hold, she said.
So far this year, the Federal Reserve has raised its target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 4.75 percent from 3 percent. The central bank has also raised the discount rate, which the Fed charges banks for overnight loans, to 4 percent from 3 percent.
Other top Fed officials also want more information on whether the productivity of American workers is continuing to rise. As long as each worker's output per hour goes up about as fast as wages, then companies' costs per unit of output will stay about the same and inflation will not rise.
Commodity prices have sharply risen this year, though consumer prices have not. Senior Fed officials attribute this apparent paradox to strong productivity. But officials said they wanted to see the Labor Department figures on unit labor costs, a measure of productivity that looks at the cost of labor of producing each dollar of economic output. Those data are due Nov. 9.
In the absence of clear information on the economy, no consensus exists among the central bank's top decision makers on what to do next, said John P. LaWare, another governor of the Federal Reserve Board.
"Obviously, there are shades of opinion and shades of action options," Mr. LaWare said in an interview. "It would be a somewhat diverse picture at the moment."
But while the timing of the next change in interest rates may be somewhat unclear, the direction is not: the next change will be an increase. Fed officials are increasingly certain that the economy is growing faster than most private economists or the Clinton Administration believe.
A survey of economic forecasters issued on Friday found that they predicted that growth for all of this year would be 3.1 percent. The Clinton Administration continues to stand by its estimate in July of 3 percent.
But Fed officials now predict that the final figure will be from 3.25 percent to 3.5 percent, suggesting that the economy has slowed very little since the central bank began raising short-term interest rates in February.
Fed officials want a slower pace, and are unsure that interest rate increases so far are adequate to make this happen. "I'd be quite satisfied, I think personally, if we were able to look at 1995 and see a growth rate of 2 1/2 percent or so," Mr. LaWare said.
For now, at least, some officials see little risk of immediate inflation. "I'm seeing the same number of signs as before -- nothing has changed," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, another governor of the Federal Reserve Board.
Although Fed officials refuse to discuss the subject, they have also historically been reluctant to raise rates a month before national elections.
As for any political pressure on the Fed to raise or lower interest rates the Clinton Administration -- unlike the Bush Administration -- has generally avoided taking strong positions on such policy. The hostility of manufacturers to further interest rate increases, which hurt sales of cars and other goods bought on credit, has been balanced by the enthusiasm of bond traders, who fear that low interest rates will allow inflation to rise again and erode the returns from bond investments.

HEADLINE: A Modest Eastern Europe Attracts Beauty Stores

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
The sparkling brass-rimmed counters, the glistening bottles and the efficient sales clerks in crisp navy suits at the new Estee Lauder store here are a shock to many shoppers in Eastern Europe. Add a play corner with toys for children while mother spends and a brightly lighted seminar room for beauty consultations and customers could be forgiven for thinking they were in an affluent Western city.
The exceedingly modest incomes of most East European women have not stopped the big international cosmetic companies from hunting for new markets in the consumer-deprived region. The opening of the Estee Lauder store recently completed a triumvirate for the company: Budapest in 1989, Warsaw in 1993, now Prague. Guerlain and Christian Dior have glamorous stores in the three capitals and Elizabeth Arden has a spiffy boutique here. 
 Nobody is making any money in what would seem, at first blush, a somewhat frivolous exercise in glamorous image making. The handful of women from the new monied class -- wives of former Communist politicians, some women with businesses of their own -- do not make enough of a customer base for profits.
But the companies say they see big potential. The strategy is to get in fast with modest initial investments. The conversion of the dingy building off Wenceslaus Square here into an exterior confection of pink and white cost the Lauder company just $1 million.
"If you wait until there are enough people to support a big business, they'll be enough competition and the market will be carved up so it will be 10 times more costly," said Leonard A. Lauder, president of the Lauder company and son of its founder.
"What is the prognosis of Coca-Cola on what it will cost to catch up to Pepsi after all those years of Pepsi in the former Soviet Union?" he continued. "We're prepared for several years of no profits because we know as the economy strengthens we'll be well positioned."
The Lauder family, no stranger to Eastern Europe, originally came from Satoraljaujhely, in northeast Hungary, though Estee Lauder herself was born in New York City. Her younger son, Ronald S. Lauder, has bought into television stations in Poland and the Czech Republic.
Guerlain, an early pioneer in the region with a much wider network that includes shops in provincial cities like Gdansk and Cracow in Poland, holds a similar philosophy. "The fact is, it is investment for the future," said Antoine de Fommervault, Guerlain's manager for Eastern Europe.
It's easy to forget after 40 years of Communism that women in Poland and Hungary and to a lesser extent the Czech Republic are no strangers to beauty products and skin care. Between the two world wars, women in these countries took great pride in preserving their skin. Two of the world's most successful beauty entrepreneurs come from the region: Estee Lauder and Helena Rubenstein, who was born in Cracow, Poland.
In part, the cosmetic companies are hoping to tap into this tradition. When Guerlain opened its store in the opera building in Warsaw, the company ran nostalgic ads in the newspapers inviting women to bring in their old Guerlain bottles in exchange for an up-to-date product. "We had a lot of old people with no monetary means come in," Mr. de Fommervault said. "It just showed how passionate women are about the product."
The cosmetic companies have something else they can play off. A jar of cream, say Lauder's Advanced Night Repair priced at $59 -- the best seller on opening day in Prague -- or a lipstick at about $15 is a more realistic purchase than any of the other available Western luxury goods like cars and jewelry. Women's salaries in the Czech Republic are low but gradually increasing. The Czech statistical office reported that Czech women earned an average monthly salary last year of 3,349 crowns, or $124. This year, their average salary rose to 3,540 crowns, or $131.
In Budapest, where an entrepreneurial class has been expanding, there appears to be a group of women with robust incomes, said the Lauder store manager, Laszlo Varadi.
"Statistics are risky, but we estimate there are about 8,000 women earning over $3,000 a month net, probably from banking, insurance," he said. "That's our key target."
The customers on the first day at Lauder's shop in Prague earned good incomes by the country's standards.
"I was amazed, we had five dentists, various professional women," said Jana Brichnacova, 22, a former real estate agent who was chosen among hundreds of applicants as one of the five beauty advisers for the store. "These are women who have been going to Christian Dior and read Cosmopolitan and Elle."
To make the store more accessible and the prices less forbidding, the front counter was loaded with come-ons -- miniature fragrances for $3.60 (100 crowns), a makeup purse with three samples for $5.35 (150 crowns), a mirror for $1.80 (50 crowns).
All the companies have had to devise ways of marketing in countries where there are not many outlets for advertising and where ads are often treated with skepticism.
Early on, Christian Dior found that direct mailing was a no-no.
"We would ask clients for their addresses and they would be very reluctant. In the past if you gave your address to anyone it could be very dangerous," said Elizabeth Robert, the manager for Christian Dior in Eastern Europe. On a recent mailing in Budapest to a select list of 250 clients who had patronized the treatment salon at the store, 25 of the letters came back with wrong addresses, she said.
Special offers, one of the basic selling techniques for cosmetics in the West, don't work either. "We tried special offers when we first opened in Warsaw in 1991 and no one would buy," Ms. Robert said. "They think there is something wrong with the product."
One of the most successful methods of selling is through the salons that Lauder, Dior and Guerlain run alongside their stores. In Budapest, for example, Mr. Varadi estimates that 50 percent of his store's sales of creams and cosmetics come from women who have facials, for about $40, at the salon. After a facial, he said, some of these customers spend up to $500 on skin products.
Another selling point comes from the style of the sales clerks, who are carefully chosen and well trained to give service that contrasts with the almost universal surliness that persists in most stores even five years after the end of Communism. None of the sales clerks cum beauty advisers at Lauder's in Prague had previous store or beauty experience. "I suppose they didn't want people spoiled with bad manners," Ms. Brichnacova said.
Mr. Lauder hopes the Prague store will reach sales of $500,000 to $1 million in the first year. The Budapest store does about $1 million worth of business five years after it opened.
But these are still early days for small investments, he said. "One shop in one country is not like trying to conquer Brazil," he said. "We're not even in Brazil. It would cost us $20 to $30 million."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new Estee Lauder store in Prague is attracting shoppers with its array of Western luxury goods and services. The big cosmetic companies are hunting for new markets in consumer-deprived Eastern Europe. (Pavel Horejsi for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York City Is Vengeful in the Face of a 'Raid' by Connecticut

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Just weeks after losing a spirited battle to keep Swiss Bank from leaving Manhattan, the Giuliani administration has taken out large display ads in Connecticut newspapers urging Connecticut residents to reject "this blatant and unneighborly raid."
The ads, designed by the staff of John S. Dyson, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, were the latest salvo in the on-again, off-again battle for business among New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut, all of which have relied heavily on tax incentives to lure or retain large companies. 
 Warning against a "bidding war which will only hurt both communities," the ads offered a blistering attack on Connecticut's deal with Swiss Bank, which last month agreed to move to Stamford in exchange for tax breaks that could amount to $120 million over 10 years.
"Connecticut taxpayers will pay $60,000 for each job, an unbelievable amount," say the ads, which appeared in the Sunday editions of The Hartford Courant, The Stamford Advocate and Greenwich Time.
According to the standard display advertising rates charged by the three papers, New York City's bill would have been slightly over $19,000 for the one-day marketing blitz.
One Connecticut resident who was not impressed was Joseph J. McGee, the state's Commissioner of Economic Development.
"This shows a lapse in judgment," he said, charging that the New York City ads violated a 1991 agreement between New York, New Jersey and Connecticut not to compete for each other's businesses through ads or aggressive marketing.
Mr. McGee also chided Mr. Dyson, who, in the weeks before Swiss Bank announced its decision to move to Stamford, had flown to Basel, Switzerland, site of the bank's international headquarters, to try to persuade the company to stay in Manhattan.
"We think the Deputy Mayor is suffering a case of jet lag," Mr. McGee said.
Those remarks, while seeming to personalize a debate over economic development strategies, prompted an even more vehement response from Forrest Taylor, a spokesman for Mr. Dyson. "The Commissioner maunders and resorts to personal attacks on the Deputy Mayor, all the while engaging in a game of pernicious poaching that will ultimately cost Connecticut taxpayers millions," he said.
Although Swiss Bank announced its move to Stamford on Sept. 21, final barriers to the deal are expected to be removed this week by the Connecticut Legislature. It must act on measures that will both approve the terms of the tax breaks offered Swiss Bank, and amend a longstanding state law that prohibits foreign-owned banks from operating branches or headquarters in Connecticut.
Swiss Bank said it plans to move 1,300 of its 1,500 workers from Manhattan to a new 20-story office building it will erect near the commuter railroad station in downtown Stamford. It said it would hire an additional 700 workers when the building is completed.
It is doubtful that New York City's ads will influence the votes this week in the Connecticut Legislature, but they may be intended to make Connecticut officials think twice before offering such expensive incentives in the future.
New York City, the ads say, has offered tax breaks to many companies, but they have been "at far more reasonable costs to taxpayers."
Connecticut officials estimate that new tax revenue from Swiss Bank will come to more than $300 million over 10 years and argue that the $120 million they are giving back is a reasonable price to pay.
"The easiest way to describe this deal is that we get 80 percent of something instead of 100 percent of nothing," he said. Indeed, similar rationale has been offered by New York City, New Jersey and other jurisdictions around the nation to explain their use of tax breaks.
The New York City ads urged Connecticut to adopt a "good neighbor policy" similar to one that Mayor Giuliani has embraced elsewhere in the region. Since taking office in January, the Mayor and Mr. Dyson are known to have quietly negotiated informal agreements with officials in New Jersey, Nassau County, Westchester and other New York counties that are designed to minimize their competition for business.
Although it was never before declared dead, the 1991 "nonaggression pact" referred to by Mr. McGee apparently has been undone by New York City's newspaper ads, and by the verbal exchange it provoked.
"If there was ever an agreement, Connecticut has certainly broken it," Mr. Taylor said in an interview.
The newspaper ads suggested a new slogan to replace "I Love New York," which was coined in the 1970's by a state team that included none other than Mr. Dyson.
The slogan -- "New York City. Where The World Does Business" -- appears above the address and phone number of Mr. Dyson's office, which are apparently offered for the sake of Connecticut residents who want to hear more about the benefits of doing business in New York City.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Futures Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury futures ended slightly higher yesterday, while the Treasury market was closed in observance of Columbus Day.
The corporate and municipal markets, which follow the Treasury market closely to price their securities, were quiet. 
 Trading in the futures market was subdued in a holiday-shortened session. The price of the December Treasury bond contract rose 7/32 , to 9814/32 , on a rising perception that the economy may not be growing fast enough to accelerate inflation.
In the Treasury market on Friday, the price of the 30-year bond rose 20/32 , and the yield fell five basis points, to 7.90 percent, after the Labor Department said the economy added 239,000 jobs in September, lower than the market's expectations of a gain of 254,000 jobs. A basis point is one-hundredth of percentage point.
Reports that Iraq had withdrawn its troops from near the Kuwaiti border, an easing in oil prices and some follow-through from Friday's recovery helped bolster the futures market yesterday.
The long end of the market, which saw heavy turnover and rising interest rates last week, could experience some further consolidation this week ahead of two inflation reports. The Government is scheduled to report on producer prices on Thursday and on consumer prices on Friday.
Although the Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates five times this year in an effort to keep inflation in check, investors have shown little patience. Rising rates reflect the market's concern about the effectiveness of the Fed to hold the line on inflation.
The municipal bond market, however, has benefited from this turmoil in Treasury securities.
A lack of supply in new issues has kept municipals from experiencing the same price fluctuation as in Treasuries, said Michael S. Appelbaum, a senior vice president and municipal bond specialist at Paine Webber.
"The supply of new municipal issues for the first nine months of this year is off 40 percent," he said. "In the municipal bond market it's not what you get, it's what you keep."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Drowning In Oil

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The heart of the matter is not what Saddam Hussein will do or can do to harass his enemies in the West and Mideast. It is what they can do and will do to destroy him at last.
Will they allow him one more victory so he can return again to threaten the Mideast and the U.S. next year? Or will they push him finally into the grave he has been digging for himself, his regime and his nation? 
 Basically that has been the question ever since President Bush made one of the more unusual decisions in history. Mr. Bush allowed an enemy smashed swiftly on the battlefield to remain in power indefinitely, his dictatorship intact and his army strong enough to carry on unceasing warfare against millions of his countrymen.
But by his latest adventure -- sending troops to the Kuwaiti border -- Saddam Hussein has shown the West his own desperation and its opportunity. Sooner or later many dictators do that.
Baghdad's promise of the withdrawal of the troops changes neither Saddam's desperation nor the West's choice. It accentuates them.
Until now Saddam used his time since his resurrection by Mr. Bush extremely well. He has rebuilt a substantial part of his army, to terrorize his country, kill Iraqi Kurdish and Shiite rebels, and remind the Muslim world he is still a power.
But one thing prevented him from reconstructing his country as a major economic power, which is the essential step toward again becoming a major military power: the U.N. embargo. It blocked him from selling the oil that had been his indispensable fountain of revenue.
Then, just as the U.N. was about to consider if and when to lift the embargo, Saddam tried to put on heavy pressure -- massing troops against Kuwait and tying their removal to the embargo. This forced the Clinton Administration to move tens of thousands of troops in preparation for the war that another Iraq invasion would bring.
Why did Saddam take this dangerous gamble? He has made dreadful mistakes before but not quite this obvious. This time he had notice that if it came to war, President Clinton was not likely to allow him to remain in power. That of course meant he would not remain alive.
Saddam also knew that France, Turkey and Russia were working to lift the embargo so they could again do oil business with Iraq.
Madeleine Albright, the U.S. representative to the U.N., deserves national bouquets for fighting against ending the embargo. But Saddam also knew that ever since the end of the gulf war European industrialists had been meeting with Iraqi officials to rebuild the reconstruction and arms network that empowered him before the war. They were using their influence to lift the embargo that kept them from the Iraqi treasury. (Kenneth H. Timmerman writes about the resurgence of the Iraqi-Western death lobby in The Wall Street Journal of Sept. 27.)
Saddam was being told by his European friends to lie low and maybe the U.S. would go along in six months or so. But he could not afford just to wait. The oil embargo was not merely crippling the country but inciting rebellion among civilian Iraqis and the armed forces.
Laurie Mylroie, another expert on Iraq, reports in the Times Op-Ed page of Oct. 2 that in both the civilian population and the military, Saddam Hussein has ordered amputation of ears, feet and arms as punishment for rebellion or desertion.
The issue now is not what to do about Iraq if it does invade Kuwait but what to do if it does not. The answer is to tighten the embargo, not loosen it, by insisting that before it can be lifted the Iraqi regime has to end rule by terror against all Iraqis and foreign targets.
Saddam Hussein would of course not agree. Without terrorism he could rule for a month perhaps, not much longer. But when the Iraqi army and civilians understand that the embargo would not be lifted with Saddam in power they might take their own lives -- and his -- into their hands.
The West could destroy Saddam by war. But by his own desperation and stupidity or both, he has shown us that he is drowning in his own unsold oil.
Clintonian policy has been exactly right. One: Send in troops in case Saddam is not only desperate but insane. Two: Try to prevent either France, Russia or the death lobby from throwing the man a lifeline as he sinks and sinks and sinks.

LENGTH: 726 words

HEADLINE: Iraq's Reckless Ploy

 BODY:
Five days of Iraqi deployments and U.S. counterdeployments around Kuwait's northern border have left Bill Clinton looking like a born-again military strategist and Saddam Hussein like a dangerous and clumsy bully. Iraq's announcement yesterday that it was withdrawing troops from the border region vindicates Mr. Clinton's strategy of quick and massive military deterrence of any Iraqi plans for renewed aggression.
The Iraqi leader's motives and intentions are known only to him. But if he thought he could force a resolution of the diplomatic stalemate over oil sanctions by stirring up a new military crisis over Kuwait, he was badly mistaken. By foolishly conducting threatening military maneuvers near the Kuwaiti border, Baghdad has set back its cause among friend and foe alike. 
 Iraq's cooperation with U.N. arms inspectors entitle it to seek limited relief from international sanctions -- permission to again export oil and amass petrodollars. But the Security Council cannot and must not ease sanctions under duress from military threats. If Iraq is really withdrawing and is now prepared to accept Kuwait's sovereignty and borders, it can again begin trying to persuade Security Council members that lifting oil sanctions sometime next year would be in the best interests of all concerned. But its actions in the past few days have set back its chances of success.
Before Baghdad precipitated the latest crisis by moving at least two elite divisions southward toward the Kuwaiti border, it was making diplomatic gains. U.N. inspectors reported that Iraq's nuclear, biological and chemical weapons components and longer-range missiles had been fully located and destroyed. A thorough system for long-term monitoring is ready to go into operation in the coming weeks -- assuming Iraq continues its recent pattern of cooperation with the U.N.
Such destruction and monitoring of prohibited weapons are the only formal U.N. requirements for lifting oil sanctions under the gulf war cease-fire resolution, which was largely drafted by the U.S. China, France and Russia have indicated that they might soon be ready to vote to lift oil sanctions. But even these countries rightly demand that Iraq first firmly and explicitly recognize Kuwait's sovereignty and borders. That condition has now become even more important.
The other two permanent members of the Security Council, the U.S. and Britain, oppose any relief at this time, or perhaps at any time while Saddam Hussein remains in power. They argue that he cannot be trusted to continue his cooperation on arms once sanctions have been eased. That objection now carries added weight.
Iraqi diplomats suggest that Baghdad's menacing military moves were meant to cut through this Security Council deadlock. The idea was to set up a deal where guarantees for Kuwait could be traded for a definite promise that sanctions would be lifted. If that was the plan, it has blown up in Iraq's face. Rather than having to explain to impatient allies why it was rewriting the rules on oil sanctions, Washington can now point to Iraq's continued dangerous unpredictability.
Mr. Clinton shows he has learned the lesson of George Bush's equivocal early response to Iraq's 1990 threats against Kuwait. By quickly moving tens of thousands of troops, along with combat aircraft and ships, toward Kuwait the Administration may be able to claim credit for avoiding a possible invasion and war.
This emergency but precautionary deployment of U.S. troops falls within the President's constitutional powers as Commander in Chief. Unlike the dispatch of American troops to Haiti, threats to Kuwait clearly affect U.S. national interests, and the President's moves have elicited broad public and Congressional support. Still, Mr. Clinton should resist any temptation to strike pre-emptively at Iraq, and, if the military confrontation persists, should seek explicit Congressional endorsement.
For Saddam Hussein, this crisis once again demonstrates that however well he understands Iraqi politics, he badly misreads the outside world. For Bill Clinton, provided the crisis is now defused with no Americans killed, the episode could turn out to be a pre-election gift. The President has reassured a nervous public that, when clearly and urgently needed, he can project force decisively and effectively.

HEADLINE: A Prudent Agreement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Unlike conservative 2 percent wage increases given by New York City to its lawyers, the more prudent Legal Aid agreement reached Oct. 5 provides only for 2 percent bonuses in each of the contract's two years.
Unlike the raises given to city agency lawyers, these bonuses will not add to the base salaries of Legal Aid lawyers. Moreover, the agreement provides arbitration in the second year on allocation of any increased health insurance costs. 
 Portrayals of the striking lawyers as unmindful of fiscal realities are baseless and have failed to address one salient fact: before the strike the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys put a thrifty agreement on the table like the one reached last night. Management rejected the offer.
Mayor Giuliani should reinstate the city's pre-existing contract with the society, which provides economies of scale and supplies expertise not found in a less experienced organization.
ADRIAN A. LESHER
Brooklyn, Oct. 6, 1994
The writer, a Legal Aid staff lawyer, is an alternate vice president, Association of Legal Aid Attorneys.

HEADLINE: Foreign Capitalists Brush Risks Aside To Invest in Russia

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The ruble is crashing amid mounting fears of renewed inflation, and the fledgling stock market is still smarting from its first big downturn. Bankers and entrepreneurs are being gunned down in the streets. There is little financial regulation and considerable fraud.
But for American and other foreign investors, those unpleasant realities are becoming far less important than their growing sense that Russia presents a business opportunity so big that they can no longer afford to hold back. 
 In the last few months, since Russia completed its first round of privatizations, money has been pouring into the country from foreign companies and investment funds that had previously been scared off by the near chaos of Russia's political and economic transition.
Betting that Russia's industrial core remains badly undervalued and that in the long run big parts of it will prove to be vibrant and profitable, foreigners have been jockeying to buy stakes directly from the most promising privatized Russian enterprises and have been snapping up their shares on the open market. The main attractions are big energy, natural resources and telecommunications companies that are being sold at prices that are bargains by foreign market standards.
Much of the Western money flowing into Russia so far has come from institutional investors that are willing to take on big risks in search of short-term returns. But more mainstream investors with longer-term outlooks are also getting involved. Last month, the Templeton funds group, one of the largest and most successful American investment groups involved in so-called emerging markets, said it was considering starting a $400 million Russia fund.
The Ministry of Privatization recently estimated that foreign investment had quadrupled since the beginning of the year, to $600 million a month. Eugene Lawson, president of the Council for Trade and Economic Cooperation, a trade group promoting business ties between the United States and Russia, told a conference in Moscow today that American direct investment in Russia, which was almost nothing at the beginning of the year, could reach $50 billion in the next 10 years.
The amounts flowing into Russia so far are only a fraction of what is needed to rebuild its industry, or even to develop a broad-based equity market. But continued investment by foreigners, who often bring valuable management expertise with them, would greatly aid the development of a market economy and would be perhaps the most concrete sign yet of confidence in Russia's progress toward capitalism.
Still, the flow of foreign capital to Russia could dry up or quickly reverse if the relative political and economic stability of late dissipates. The sharp fall in the ruble -- it dropped 6 percent against the dollar today and has lost a third of its value in the last month -- as well as fears of renewed inflation have made clear that Russia's economic overhaul has a long way to go. Last week, a sharp downturn in stock prices after a recent rally served as another reminder that Russia remains a volatile market.
Until that sharp drop, some stocks had been hitting new highs every few days. With buying by American and European investment funds, shares in oil producers, other energy companies and even GUM, the Moscow department store, had surged. Rostelekom, the long-distance telephone company, saw its share price go from as little as 300 rubles early this year to 16,650 rubles, or about $5.35 at exchange rates at the end of last week.
Investment bankers and analysts from New York and London are fanning out across the country visiting oil companies, aluminum processors and auto makers, many of which will be selling stakes directly to foreign investors in coming months in the second phase of the privatization program.
"The potential for Russian companies to be turned around and transformed is tremendous," said Richard Greer, a research director at Baring Securities, the British investment concern. Baring recently advised its clients that Russia offered "opportunities for investors unmatched in any other emerging market."
Until recently, far more capital had been flowing out of Russia than into it as Russians, wary about their nation's future, moved billions of dollars into overseas bank accounts and investments. Moreover, what investment there has been by Russians in their own country has tended to have little positive economic impact.
Individual Russians have tended to put their money into investment funds, many of which, like the discredited MMM, were nothing more than pyramid schemes promising huge returns. As for Russia's banks, they have found speculating against the ruble easier and more profitable than buying stocks or making loans.
For foreigners, investing in Russia, and especially in Russian stocks, remains extremely risky. Most companies cannot provide reliable financial information. The legal process of exchanging and registering shares is cumbersome and time consuming. There is a growing nationalist backlash against foreign ownership of industry.
The last few days have only made clear how bumpy Russia's trip down the capitalist road can be. After shooting up nearly 50 percent in a month, the most widely quoted stock market barometer, the MT index published by The Moscow Times, fell significantly on Thursday and Friday, the first time it has done so since it was created early last month.
After hitting a peak of 148.17 points on Wednesday, the index, which is based on over-the-counter prices for 30 of the largest privatized companies, dropped 10 percent during the next two days. It stabilized today and closed up 0.21 point at 133.99.
Among the biggest losers have been stocks that were favorites of foreign investors, including most of the oil stocks as well as Unified Energy System, the nationwide electric power utility. Brokers reported that many foreign investors trying to dump shares and lock in their profits could not find any buyers.
The rapidly falling ruble and a recent uptick in inflation -- to around 8 percent a month, about twice its level this summer -- led some analysts to predict renewed economic turmoil and market volatility for some time to come. The currency's decline was set off by concerns that Government spending and the budget deficit would rise sharply as industry demands more subsidies to keep it afloat. Today, in trading on the Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange the ruble closed at 3,081 to the dollar, compared with about 2,900 on Friday.
Viktor Gerashchenko, the head of the Russian central bank, told the Tass news agency today that the central bank had spent $2 billion buying rubles in recent weeks in an attempt to prop up the currency. Although the ruble's plunge makes purchasing ruble assets less expensive in dollar terms, it is worrisome to foreign investors who ultimately want to translate ruble profits back into dollars or other currencies.
"The rise in share prices took place in those enterprises where the foreign interest is the greatest," said Lena Chernyshkova, a manager at Skate Press Consulting Agency, a financial consulting concern that tracks share trading.
"The rise in the market for the last three to four months has been very sharp," she said. "Because the rise was too fast, there's now the threat of a fall. Some of the foreign investors have gotten scared and are trying to sell shares they bought over the last few months, but there aren't really any objective reasons for the fall in the market."
A new wave of investment from American investment funds is expected once they can arrange to meet technical legal requirements for custody of the Russian shares they buy. Big banks like Citibank and Chase Manhattan are considering establishing custodial operations in Russia to solve that problem.
"In terms of foreign investment, three months ago it was primarily the hedge funds," said Danielle Downing, director of Russian investments at C.A. & Company, a Russian-owned brokerage firm. "Now we see some of the big players coming in."
Miss Downing said she expected emerging-markets funds from the United States, which have experienced rapid growth in recent years, to start allocating up to 12 percent of their assets to Russia, making Russia one of the largest targets for investment of that type.
Pioneers in the Russian market like CS First Boston remain dominant in advising Russian companies and in trading stock. But almost all the big investment firms are now providing investors with detailed profiles of the opportunities available in Russia.
"The actual wealth behind the Russian economy is tremendous," said Dan Lubash, an analyst who tracks Russia for Merrill Lynch.
Mr. Lubash said the first phase of Russia's privatization program had left Russian companies a bargain by Western standards. The initial phase, which moved roughly two-thirds of Russian industrial output from state ownership at least partly into private hands, ended on June 30.
The market value of all the privatized industries at that point, he said, was about $7 billion, roughly comparable to the value that Wall Street currently places on a single American retailer, the Kmart Corporation. The market values of Russia's big energy, natural resources and telecommunications companies were about 1 to 40 percent of what they would be in Western markets, he calculated.
Take Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company that is the world's largest. Baring Securities recently calculated that the market was valuing its gas reserves at three-tenths of 1 cent per barrel of oil equivalent, compared with $3.90 for British Petroleum and $10.30 for British Gas.

A front-page article yesterday about a rise in foreign investment in Russia misstated the affiliation of Eugene K. Lawson. He is president of the U.S.-Russia Business Council, not the Council for Trade and Economic Cooperation.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Hurry Up, Knicks: N.H.L. Season Nowhere In Sight

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The National Hockey League commissioner, echoing the words and positions of management in the two-month-old baseball strike, called off the start of the season yesterday for the second time and insured the continued shutdown of two of the four major professional sports leagues.
In extending the owners' lockout of their players, Gary Bettman said the N.H.L. Board of Governors decided unanimously not to open the season until the two sides have a new collective bargaining agreement. That agreement, the commissioner said, "has to address the issues and concerns we have been expressing." 
 Eleven days earlier, Bettman had announced he was postponing the Oct. 1 start of the season until Oct. 15. But now, with 85 games guaranteed to be missed through Saturday, the opening games are not in sight.
"As of this minute, it's not impossible to play 84 games," Bettman said, referring to a full schedule, "but that's something we'll have to monitor on a day-to-day basis."
As his baseball counterparts have done for the past several months, Bettman said the labor dispute could not end until "the union is ready to address our needs." The proposals the players have made, he said, have not addressed those needs. In fact, he asserted, the union took a "step backward" with the proposal it made Monday.
"If they characterize it as a step backward," Bob Goodenow, the players' labor leader, said in a later news conference, "that just highlights our differences."
Based on comments by the chief negotiators, the differences could grow larger in the days ahead. With the first month of the established schedule virtually lost, the owners and players could be heading for the kind of shutdown that abbreviated the baseball season.
Asked how long the shutdown, which yesterday became the longest in league history, could last, Goodenow said, "Long could be months or a year."
The two sides differ on many issues, but the issue at the core of their dispute is the owners' stated desire to retard the escalation of player salaries. It is the same issue that has made October a silent month for major league baseball.
While the baseball owners have proposed a salary cap, their hockey brethren have proposed a tax on payrolls that the players argue would have the effect of a cap. The players have proposed a tax on the payrolls of the 16 teams with the highest revenues, but the owners say that plan doesn't place enough of a "drag" on salaries.
To Bettman, the players' proposal is not realistic. "Their tax doesn't work as a means of keeping player salaries from escalating rapidly," he said. "We've been convinced of that from Day One."
What is the difference in the proposals?
"One will have a drag and the other doesn't, in our view, at all," Bettman said after his news conference at the Sheraton in comparing the two tax plans.
Where would the players have to go to create a tax that would create a sufficient drag?
"They'd have to get up much higher on a graduated basis," he said.
What is much higher?
"I'm not going to negotiate now," Bettman said. "If they want to come have that discussion with me, I'd be thrilled."
But from the sound of things yesterday, the two sides won't be talking any time soon, let alone playing.
Bettman said the owners, at their four-hour meeting at the Waldorf, expressed some sentiment that their tax proposal might not be strong enough, indicating the possibility the league could withdraw the proposal or alter it in a direction away from the union's position.
Goodenow raised the issue of the economic takeaways -- the "Aug. 1 attack," he calls it -- in which the clubs removed preseason benefits and instituted other changes the players have resented bitterly.
"Until the owners appreciate that the players are completely opposed to the N.H.L. takeaway demands," the union leader said from Toronto, "there will be little to discuss."
The players, their labor leader added, "see the approach clearly for what it is and that becomes more and more focused and it becomes more and more daunting for the future."
As he did when he announced the first delay to the start of the season, Bettman refused to use the word "lockout."
Given the opportunity, he said, "It was clear that through Oct. 15 we were in a postponement mode. We're not going to start the season Oct. 15 and on a day-to-day basis, we'll see what has to be canceled."
But, he was pressed, does that mean the league was locking out the players? "We're not opening on the 15th," he said.
In his initial postponement, Bettman said it was possible the season could open Oct. 15 if meaningful progress had been made in the talks. But yesterday he said nothing meaningful has come from the union in the past 10 days, and, in fact, he added, "I'm more discouraged about the course of conduct over the past 10 days than anything else."
The union, he asserted, had made it clear that it wants to maintain the status quo. "That may have been their game plan all along," he said.
Goodenow said it had become clearer that the owners are "committed to a major fight with the players."
"Any concept of a tax on salary is difficult and repugnant for players to take," Goodenow added. "The last few days this committee worked hard to put together a plan to generate the dollars. To have the league come back and say there has been no meaningful progress, it highlights what their intentions are. It highlights what really is going on here and the difficult fight that's ahead."
What would it take to resume bargaining, Goodenow was asked.
"There would have to be a reason for us to talk," he said. "Gary would have to give us a proposal. But right now, given the nature of where we are with the N.H.L.'s takeaway approach, it looks difficult for us to be making much progress in the future."
The owners said the union's latest proposal was a step backward because it lowered the amount of taxes the higher spending clubs would have to pay on payrolls and gate receipts. According to figures the league provided, the Rangers would pay $2,119,000 under the players' latest proposal compared with $2,406,000 under their previous proposal and $3,335,000 under the owners' plan.
Both the union's latest proposal and the owners' proposal call for a 3 percent tax on gate receipts of the 16 teams with the highest revenues.
The union also proposes a 7 percent tax on the payrolls of the top four teams in revenue, 5 percent on the next four, 3 percent on the third tier of four and 1 percent on teams 13 through 16.
The owners' plan focuses on payrolls above the league average. The graduated tax begins at half a percent on all payrolls but grows by 5 percent for every $325,000 above the league average payroll. The rate on the last $325,000 increment would be 122 percent.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Massimino and U.N.L.V. Close to a Parting of Ways

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 11

 BODY:
Just two years after Jerry Tarkanian was forced out as the basketball coach at Nevada-Las Vegas, his former top assistant, Tim Grgurich, may be in.
With four days before the Runnin' Rebels open practice, Rollie Massimino was still officially the coach. But today he sounded as if he were already gone, awaiting only the completion of a buyout deal offered by the university. 
 "I thought this was a really great experience," Massimino said today of his two-season reign as coach.
The interim president of U.N.L.V., Kenny Guinn, was to meet for a second time with Massimino on Wednesday, when an agreement was expected on a reported $1.5 million buyout of the remaining term of his contract.
"It's strictly economics at this point," Guinn said. "It's not a specific item. He's looking to get some things and so am I. He gave us a figure and I gave him a figure. Now, I've got to see if his figure works for us."
Once an agreement is reached, U.N.L.V. is expected to go after Grgurich, a Seattle SuperSonics assistant who spent 12 years helping Tarkanian build U.N.L.V. into a national power.
Grgurich has the enthusiastic backing of Tarkanian, who was ousted by the school's former university president, Robert Maxson, in a power struggle amid revelations that some players had cavorted with a convicted sports fixer.
"He's the guy I wanted to replace me in the first place," Tarkanian said. "He would have kept the program where it was. They would have been in the Final Four the last two years."
Tarkanian, who won a national title in 1990 and had four Final Four appearances in 19 years with U.N.L.V., hinted that he would not mind becoming involved with the team again if Grgurich were head coach.
"I would do anything he wanted me to do," Tarkanian said. "I'd wear a U.N.L.V. shirt again. I'd be a U.N.L.V. man again."
Massimino's teams failed to make the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in his two seasons at U.N.L.V. But it was the disclosure in August of a supplemental contract that was to pay Massimino $375,000 a year in addition to his $511,000 salary that started efforts to remove him.
Guinn, who took over from Maxson in May, was also concerned about an expected $750,000 shortfall in basketball revenue this season because of sinking attendance and declining interest in the program.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: AT THE WHITE HOUSE;
Clinton's Gain: The Big Stick Speaks

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
With his highly visible successes this week at the expense of dictators in Haiti and Iraq, Bill Clinton's political luck may finally have turned, just four weeks before Election Day.
Instead of counting the casualties from what would have been a hugely unpopular Caribbean invasion, which had seemed likely only two weeks ago, the President can revel in the retreat of at least some elements of Saddam Hussein's Republican Guard, the imminent departure for exile of the Haitian leadership and the return to the island of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 Instead of being remembered as the man who flip-flopped on Somalia and Bosnia, who raised taxes and pushed through the North American Free Trade Agreement, the President is suddenly clothed in the politically protective armor of Commander-in-Chief.
Or as The Daily News in New York put it, in one of those page-one headlines that jam a complex truth into a few words: "Clinton 2, Bullies 0."
The news from abroad gave the President a splendid send-off -- "not the usual shot in the foot we've been used to," one of his aides said -- as he began his effort to limit anticipated Democratic losses in the midterm elections with a trip to Michigan today.
Republican and Democratic politicians agreed that Mr. Clinton has helped his own standing in the last few days, even though a CNN poll conducted last weekend, before the good news started rolling in from Kuwait and Port-au-Prince, showed the President's approval ratings unimproved. Presidents almost always get at least a temporary lift from crises abroad, unless they bungle them; Mr. Clinton gained 7 percentage points after he sent American cruise missiles to bomb Baghdad last June.
Several Democrats said they thought the President's gains might help their party in the current campaign, in which his unpopularity has been a major element. But they cautioned that it was too early to tell for sure, and most Republicans said they thought the themes of the races now under way were too thoroughly established for a foreign-affairs issue to change them much.
"This freezes the linebackers for just a moment," said Peter Hart, a leading Democratic pollster. "The Republicans have been wreaking havoc with us. Now, at just the moment when the Democrats have to regroup if they're going to pull some victories out, we get this. We'll see in the next month whether we can take advantage of the opening that he has created."
Don Sipple, a Republican consultant working for several prominent candidates this fall, commented: "This helps Clinton quite a bit, because he's now doing rather well in an area that was not exactly a strong suit for him. It may energize the Democrats a little, but I can't see it redefining the campaign of 1994, which is mostly about crime and taxes and other domestic issues."
George Stephanopoulos, one of Mr. Clinton's political advisers, said tonight, "We're not going to discuss the politics of the situation." The reason, of course, is that doing so would open the White House to the charge that the President had acted out of self-interest, not on principle.
But Robert Squier, a Democratic strategist, said that Mr. Clinton, "given an opportunity to act Presidential, has taken it and has done a pretty good job at it, and Democrats will get credit for it." He even suggested that in an indirect way, the President had addressed his "character problem," by showing that "when he needs to be strong for the whole country, he can be."
Mr. Squier suggested that the White House, "if it is wise," would seek to use Mr. Clinton's new credibility on foreign policy "to bring the public, very gently, back around to his successes on the economy, which is what he was elected for, and which he has never received very much credit for."
For his part, Mr. Sipple said he thought that "the die is already cast for 1994." At moments of great international tension, he said, "the public supports the President, but it doesn't always support his party's candidates for Congress -- and certainly not its nominees for governor."
The historical record bears him out. But this year an unusually large number of races for the Senate, where the Republicans need a net gain of seven seats for control, are rated as dead heats by the polls. Any shift at all in the political mood could have an impact in those. In addition, there were some signs of a modest Democratic comeback in states with tight Senate races like Massachusetts, Tennessee and Oklahoma, even before this week.
There is always the possibility, of course, that things could go sour in Haiti, as Mr. Clinton himself said in his televised speech on Monday night. The same is true in the Persian Gulf, where the Administration is apparently bent on creating and maintaining a kind of demilitarized zone north of the Kuwaiti border, to keep Mr. Hussein from provoking repeated crises.
But for the moment, Mr. Clinton has answered those who called him irresolute and inept when he kept changing his position on Bosnia, decided to pull out of Somalia earlier than planned and temporized on Haiti earlier this year.
For the moment, there are no more jibes from those who argued that he had, in effect, ceded control of American foreign policy to Jimmy Carter by allowing the former President to cut deals in North Korea and in Haiti. But Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana, the most prominent Republican spokesman on foreign policy on Capitol Hill, while praising Mr. Clinton for making "a strong start" and taking "the right course," warned that there will be "insistent voices" suggesting that "someone might be sent to Baghdad."
The whole balance between foreign and domestic policies has been fraught with ironies for Bill Clinton. He charged George Bush, his predecessor, with spending too much time on foreign policy and too little on the economy and other domestic topics.
He has lost ground with the electorate for a number of reasons, including his own personal difficulties in the Whitewater affair and allegations of promiscuity, as well as the failure of some of his domestic initiatives. But the American public, following its habit of caring little about foreign policy unless it thinks the nation's interests abroad are in unsafe hands, has also faulted Mr. Clinton for what has seemed to many a feckless performance.
"You have to pass a kind of test," said a Democratic senator. "Until now, he was a question mark. Now he seems to be turning that around."
In the process, especially if fighting should actually break out on the Arabian Peninsula, there is a chance that he can rescue his party, if not from impending electoral defeat, at least from complete catastrophe.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE TACTICS;
U.S. Sees Signs of Iraqi Retreat but Continues Buildup

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Pentagon officials reported today the first signs that Iraq was beginning to retreat from the Kuwait border. But American troops continued to pour into the area while Washington worked on a plan to keep Iraqi forces in check.
To press Iraq to proceed with its withdrawals, the Pentagon announced that it had sent 100 more warplanes to the Persian Gulf, which would bring the total number of American planes and helicopters in the region to about 650. 
 The Defense Department also announced it was putting 155,000 ground troops on alert, an unusual public statement by the American military, which is not normally inclined to talk about potential deployments. The Administration has already said it plans to send 36,000 troops to the Persian Gulf area.
The new military moves came as Clinton Administration officials began to consult with allies on establishing a large demilitarized zone in southern Iraq to prevent the Government from massing its troops along the Kuwait border in the future.
Administration officials said the idea was to establish in southern Iraq the territorial equivalent of the no-flight zone, which bans all flights below the 32d parallel. Such an action would in effect bar Iraq from moving its forces within striking range of Kuwait. The United States and its allies have barred Iraqi planes from two areas, in the north in an effort to protect the Kurds and in the south to prevent attacks on Shiite Muslims.
Administration officials said they were discussing exactly what form the zone would take and whether it would have to be approved by the United Nations Security Council.
The White House refrained from publicly pushing the plan for fear that it would lead President Saddam Hussein to conclude that he was losing control over southern Iraq and prompt him to attack Kuwait.
President Clinton said that based on intelligence reports, he was cautiously optimistic that Iraq was pulling back from a military showdown. "I'm hopeful," Mr. Clinton said as he campaigned for Democrats in Detroit. "It's a little early yet to reach a final conclusion. We're watching it very closely."
Iraq first announced on Monday that it was withdrawing its troops from the Kuwait border. And today the official Iraqi news agency quoted Foreign Minister Mohammed Said al-Sahaf as saying that most of the troops had been removed and that two brigades near the border would be withdrawn soon.
But American intelligence reports painted a more uncertain picture.
Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at a Pentagon briefing that intelligence reports indicated that Iraqi forces had lowered their alert status and that some Iraqi forces were leaving or heading to rail lines to load equipment for the move north. But many Iraqi troops were still near the border and some units were still moving south.
More important, Pentagon officials said that they had no idea where the Iraqi forces leaving the Kuwait border would go or how far they would be from it.
"The latest information we have now indicates that there is fairly broad movement in most of those units that had been brought down south," General Shalikashvili said. "There is still an indication of considerable units remaining.
"I'm not at all prepared to say the crisis is over in any way."
Top Pentagon officials said that by sending more reinforcements, the Clinton Administration is doing more than establishing a force to defend Kuwait. It is deploying a force that could push Iraqi troops well away from the border of Kuwait, if necessary, and keep them away, Pentagon officials said.
"The force has the capability to make Saddam Hussein pay the price if he chooses not to withdraw those forces and continues to threaten its neighbors," General Shalikashvili said.
Gen. Merrill McPeak, the Chief of Staff of the Air Force, made a similar point in a meeting with reporters today.
"With the forces that are already on the ground in Turkey and Saudi Arabia and the augmentation that has already been ordered, we would have a very substantial likelihood that we can conduct a successful offensive as well as close defense operations," General McPeak said.
As with the 1991 Persian Gulf war, airpower has played a central role in American military planning. On Monday, Mr. Clinton announced that he was dispatching 356 more aircraft to the Gulf, including antitank aircraft and long-range strike planes that could take the war deep into Iraq.
Today, the Pentagon said that another 100 planes were on the way and that 126 more had been alerted to prepare for possible deployment.
Detailing its ground deployment, the Pentagon announced that it now had 3,638 Army soldiers and marines in the gulf area, with more than 32,000 still on the way. The Pentagon raised the number of troops on alert from about 30,000 to 155,000.
The deployment also raised the sensitive question of calling up military reserves. More than 8,000 will be required according to current plans. As the Administration did in Haiti, it will ask reservists to volunteer before calling up others.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry will leave for Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait on Wednesday to consult with Middle East allies and inspect American troops.
One of the key issues for the Pentagon is how to make Iraqi troops that have withdrawn stay a safe distance from Kuwait.
A plan being developed by Administration officials would establish a huge demilitarized zone north of Kuwait. Mr. Perry said that one idea would be to take the no-flight zone over southern Iraq, which is defined as Iraqi territory south of the 32d parallel, and extend it to the ground.
"We are now conducting a no-fly zone south of the 32d parallel, which we do not allow Iraqi aircraft to fly," Mr. Perry said in interview on the ABC news program "Nightline." "And we could conceivably extend that no-fly zone to include prohibition on certain kinds of ground equipment as well."
Mr. Perry said that using airpower to enforce Iraqi compliance with such a zone would be "fairly straightforward."
"We might continue that for some number of years, depending on what develops in the situation," he said.
General Shalikashvili also said that enforcing a weapons-free zone in the barren desert of southern Iraq would be a relatively easy proposition -- much easier certainly than enforcing weapons-free zones in the heavily forested and hilly areas of Bosnia.
But apart from the military aspects of the plan, some tricky political and legal issues remain. Some Administration officials said the United States and its allies had sufficient authority under existing Security Council resolutions to impose such a ban. But it was not clear that all of the United States allies, like Britain, agreed with the plan.
And if Washington were to seek Security Council approval of a new resolution authorizing a tank-exclusion zone, it was not clear whether Russia and China would go along.
In an indication of the possible diplomatic complications to come, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia sent a team of Russian Foreign Ministry officials to Iraq.
Russia has long had close trade and foreign relations with Iraq, and during the 1991 gulf war Moscow made repeated efforts to encourage a diplomatic compromise that may have spared the Iraqi Army from destruction. Before Iraq moved troops to Kuwait's border earlier this month, Russia was sympathetic to Iraq's case for lifting economic sanctions.
"It makes no sense to try and corner Iraq," Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev said today, according to the Interfax news agency. "On the contrary, Baghdad must be encouraged in every way" to comply with the United Nations demands for lifting sanctions.
At the United Nations, the head of a United Nations commission overseeing the dismantlement of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction said Iraq's troop deployment and threats against United Nations inspectors raised new questions about Baghdad's trustworthiness.
The report is important in the debate over whether to lift economic sanctions on Iraq. American officials say they believe that Iraqi military deployments near Kuwait were intended to put pressure on the United Nations to lift the oil embargo and other sanctions.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE DIPLOMACY;
Head of U.N. Inspection Team Says Baghdad Threatens Weapons-Monitoring Effort

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The head of a United Nations team monitoring Iraq's weapons programs said today that threats to inspectors and Iraqi troop movements on the Kuwait border raised new questions about Baghdad's trustworthiness just as the monitoring system was beginning to operate.
Rolf Ekeus, the head of a special commission on Iraqi compliance with a United Nations order to halt production of weapons of mass destruction, released a largely favorable report today on the installation of an inspection system that could have cleared the way for the Security Council to consider lifting sanctions against Iraq. Mr. Ekeus will formally present the report to the Security Council on Thursday. 
 But almost immediately after a news conference during which he said he had warned Iraqi officials not to act impatiently in pressing for an immediate end to a worldwide embargo on Iraqi oil, Mr. Ekeus went to Washington to discuss his concerns for the safety of his arms monitors in Baghdad as a result of the troop buildup on both sides of the Kuwaiti border.
American officials said he would meet with Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser.
Mr. Ekeus said that Iraq's threats not to cooperate with the arms inspectors now based there "creates an obvious question mark around the credibility of our effort."
Mr. Ekeus was in Iraq last week, putting the finishing touches on his report. He acknowledged today that the document seems to have been the "trigger" that set off a new round of Iraqi belligerence.
The threats to arms monitors also play into the hands of the United States, which faced opposition in the Security Council to its determination to keep crushing economic sanctions in place against Iraq as long a possible.
United States officials said that Iraq must do more than allow the arms monitoring to take place before the Council can discuss lifting sanctions to allow Baghdad to resume selling oil or importing most goods. Iraq's position is that it is entitled to begin selling oil as soon as the arms monitoring system is up and running.
American officials here repeated their position today that after the Iraqi troop buildup in recent days, President Saddam Hussein has little credibility on any score. The United States delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, has been canvassing other permanent members of the Security Council for ways to take further action against Iraq, already all but crushed under a mountain of sanctions.
Among the ideas mentioned here today was to establish a zone in southern Iraq below the 32d parallel in which ground forces would be restricted similar to the way planes are in the no-flight zone there. But Ms. Albright spent the day in Washington, and could not attend a meeting of the five permanent Council members scheduled for this evening. She was expected to take up the issue when she returns on Wednesday.
Sir David Hannay, Britain's delegate and president of the Security Council this month, said there had been no discussion of a buffer zone in southern Iraq. But he added that it was possible that Iraqi's troop movements could be interpreted as a violation of a 1991 cease-fire agreement and that the Baghdad Government had "dealt a very serious blow to their credibility."
The Clinton Administration is trying to convince the Security Council that such a violation would give Washington blanket authority to move against Iraq in any way it chooses.
Mr. Ekeus said today that the monitoring system was now operating and that the only significant test would be of Iraq's continued cooperation with the inspectors. In the past, Iraqi officials have been uncooperative and threatening on numerous occasions.
"My honest assessment is that we had a very good chance to get a situation where the Council could be open to, say, in six-month time period, lift the embargo," Mr. Ekeus said a little ruefully. "I felt we had something coming together on this."
He said he had cautioned Iraqi officials that although his report was positive and cleared the way for lifting at least the oil embargo, Baghdad had to understand that these decisions took place in a political context. The Iraqis, he said, "gave me a message of despair, depression, skepticism."
Mr. Ekeus's commission is due to make its next major report to the Security Council in six months. At that point, if not sooner, several Security Council members, including Russia and France, had hoped to press for an easing of sanctions, so that Iraqi oil imports could begin to raise money needed to pay Baghdad's debts.

The Economy
 Three pioneers in game theory won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to three economists. The award underscores a significant shift in thinking in economics. Classical theories that focus on how markets behave are giving way to game theory, an approach that focuses on the give and take among "players." [Page D1.] Profiles of the three economists. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Ethan Allen revamps its furniture, and its stock outlook.

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne 

 BODY:
PERHAPS one of the best-known names in American home furnishings is Ethan Allen Interiors. The company's colonial-style furniture has graced middle-class homes for decades. But after a buyout that brought new management, Ethan Allen has an entirely new design style -- hip, contemporary and fresh -- and that also describes its new investment outlook.
Ethan Allen went public in March 1993 at $18 a share and climbed steadily to a high of $32 in February. Since then, the stock has dropped and recently has been trading between $22 and $24, closing yesterday down 12.5 cents, to $21.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The price slid as rising interest rates cooled investors' ardor on all home-furnishings stocks on the theory that a slowing economy and rising rates make people less inclined to buy furniture or build new homes. 
 But some analysts, while still maintaining that Ethan Allen is indeed sensitive to interest rates and economic cycles, see the company as an attractive long-term investment. And if interest rates should dip and housing starts remain strong, they say, the stock becomes a buy.
Despite its all-American name and a lineage that goes back to 1932, Ethan Allen's rebirth is the result of hard work by a political refugee from Kashmir, M. Farooq Kathwari, the company's chief executive. He was part of a group that acquired the company, which is based in Danbury, Conn., in 1989 and took it public nearly four years later. A former accessories buyer for Ethan Allen, Mr. Kathwari has brought zip by modernizing its manufacturing process, updating the look of the furniture, increasing the annual advertising budget to $47 million and expanding the number of stores, both in the United States and, in smaller numbers, abroad.
Unlike many in the furniture business, Ethan Allen is a manufacturer and a retailer -- and in a fragmented industry it is the only retailer with a national presence. In fact, with 275 stores, it is the nation's largest furniture retailer and one devoted exclusively to its own product.
Throughout the summer, as home-furnishings stocks tumbled by as much as 40 percent, Ethan Allen drifted down, but at a slower rate. Still, analysts are cautiously optimistic. Baby boomers, now in their 30's and 40's, take home furnishing seriously. New-home sales have remained surprisingly strong and Ethan Allen is well positioned to control costs and quickly respond to changing customer demands.
"I'm very excited about Ethan Allen," said Stephen J. Dobi, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, "It's a superb company with excellent management that is doing a marvelous job." Mr. Dobi sees Ethan Allen as undervalued and thinks the stock should reach $27 by next year.
William W. Epperson, an analyst with Interstate/Johnson Lane in Richmond, agrees that investors who see Ethan Allen as just an interest-rate play are shortsighted. He says buying the stock at $22 or so means investors "could make good money," particularly if interest rates should drop again.
Dana Telsey, an analyst with Bear, Stearns, cautions against looking too closely at housing statistics. She points to a lag effect -- it takes about 15 to 18 months after a home is bought before consumers have enough money to furnish it. New-home sales, in this cycle, peaked in the 1993 fourth quarter with a seasonally adjusted rate of 1.5 million units, and the most recent numbers -- a seasonally adjusted 703,000 units for August -- were surprisingly strong.
Linda Killian, an analyst at Renaissance Capital, says Ethan Allen, whose public offering was recommended by her firm, is successfully repositioning itself. "It pioneered 20th-century manufacturing advances in what was essentially an 18th- and 19th-century way of making furniture," Ms. Killian said, "and it's repositioned its look from its boring colonial lines."
