HEADLINE: Game Theory Captures a Nobel

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The 1994 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, a $930,000 award to be divided among three pioneers in the field of game theory, celebrates achievements in building the foundations for analyzing interactions among businesses, nations and even biological species.
But just as important, the prize awarded to John F. Nash of Princeton University, John C. Harsanyi of the University of California at Berkeley and Reinhard Selten of the University of Bonn acknowledges a sea change in economics that has occurred in the last two decades. 
 Economics has been a discipline dominated by the concept of perfect competition -- competition among so many participants that no single buyer or seller need worry about the responses of others.
And perfect competition has proved to be a powerful idea, one that predicted how free-market economies would evolve and gave policy makers a reliable compass for figuring how best to encourage growth as well as a fair division of the economic pie.
But in a world of hostile takeovers, trade wars and big government, classical economics is giving way to game theory, an approach that focuses on the give and take among "players." While classical economics works for the international market in wheat with thousands of buyers and sellers, it takes game theory to try to figure out how Safeway will change the price of English muffins if the A.& P. marks down bagels.
Game theory "opens up terrain for systematic thinking that was previously closed," said Paul Krugman of Stanford University, who has applied game theory to world trade.
John von Neumann and Oskar Morgenstern, economists at Princeton, invented the field. Their book published in 1944, "The Theory of Games and Economic Behavior," was the first to delve deeply into the likely consequences of strategic interactions, where all the actors must consider the potential for reaction. Both men are dead, and, therefore, not eligible for the economics prize, which is not one of the five awards established in the will of Alfred Nobel but rather a special prize created in 1968 as a memorial to Nobel.
John Nash, who received a Ph.D. from Princeton in 1950, is widely credited with laying out the formal mathematical principles of "games" -- think of them as rivalries -- in which everyone knows what everyone else knows and everyone is motivated by self-interest.
"Nash is the point of departure" for all modern game theory, argues Avinash Dixit, an economist at Princeton and a co-author of "Thinking Strategically," the first guidepost for predicting the consequences of rivalries.
One glaring limitation of Dr. Nash's work is the assumption about perfect knowledge of rivals' motives and resources. Compaq does not know exactly what Apple is prepared to invest to build a better laptop computer. For that matter it does not even know whether other companies are preparing to jump into the market, and under what circumstances. And here the work of John Harsanyi, a Hungarian-born mathematical economist, filled the theoretical breach in the late 1960's.
"Harsanyi gave shape to the fog in real-world games," said Barry Nalebuff of the School of Organization and Management at Yale. In the Harsanyi world, nothing need be known for certain as long as it is predictable in terms of chance. Thus when Compaq and Apple are figuring pricing strategies, they need only assign probabilities to the other's uncertain responses and counterresponses.
Another limitation to the Nash approach is that it did not offer insight into what would happen if more than one ending to the game was possible, even if the players acted consistently and in their own best interests. It does not stretch the imagination, for example, to think of the outbreak of World War I as only one of many plausible consequences to the diplomatic and military maneuvering in August 1914.
The German economist Reinhard Selten enriched the Nash model in 1965 by offering theories for discriminating between game outcomes that are reasonable and unreasonable. The mathematics is quite complex, but some of the underlying ideas are intuitive. For example, an outcome dependent on someone's taking an unreasonable threat seriously (as in "buy my rug for $200 or I will kill your first-born child") may be discarded.
All this may seem as abstract and impractical as the theory of perfect competition -- and for many years it was dismissed as just that. Nonetheless by the 1970's many economists were turning to game theory for inspiration, if only because they lacked answers to questions that turned on strategic behavior.
Thomas Schelling, an economist now at the University of Maryland who is in a class by himself in applied game theory, decades ago introduced ideas like the strategic value of brinkmanship. Indeed, some think he ranks with Dr. Nash as a founder of the field.
The great bulk of work by economists in game theory has been in an area where its insights had been most sorely missed: the organization of industry.
Robin Wells, an economist at the Stanford Business School, offers an example. Intel, the microprocessor giant, gave up an effective monopoly on the 86-series chip by allowing Advanced Micro Devices to share the technology. Intel, it seems, decided that computer makers would not lock themselves into a new microprocessor technology unless they were protected from future price-gouging by a monopolist. So by licensing another manufacturer, Intel successfully increased the demand for its own product.
Here, game theory explained corporate behavior that made no sense in nonstrategic terms. Game theorists have also been hired to create corporate strategy from scratch, most notably in the case of the Federal Communications Commission's auction of bands on the radio spectrum for use in wireless communications. "Every major bidder hired academic game theorists as consultants," said Andrew Schotter, an economist at New York University.
In the view of Mr. Schotter, however, the main value of game theory in formulating corporate strategy is more modest: getting executives to think carefully about response and counterresponse in the marketplace. The purer gold, Mr. Schotter believes, will be mined by "institution builders" who must make rules to induce cooperative behavior. Corporations, for example, need to create incentives to minimize the conflict between their own interests and those of their employees.
What works in the private sector might work in the public sector: The F.C.C. did, in fact, hire game theorists to set the rules for the spectrum auction. And the potential is far broader -- changing the tax code to induce voluntary compliance, for example, or designing monetary policy to gain the most credibility for the Federal Reserve as an inflation fighter with the least risk of setting off a recession.


GRAPHIC: Game theory will undergo one of its biggests tests ever in December, when the Federal Communications Commission begins to auction radio licenses for new wireless "personal communication services."
Chart: "The Real World of Game Theory"
 The F.C.C.'s goal is to raise the maximum amount of money, at least $10 billion, and it will use game theory to reach that target.
 Game theory focuses on how "players" in economic "games" behave when, to reach their goals, they have to predict how their opponents will react to their moves. The concepts developed by the Nobel winners were used by other game theorists to devise the auction rules. EDMUND L. ANDREWS
 
Coping with THe Winner's Curse
Like poker, auctions are a 'game of incomplete information.' Bidders have to speculate about both the value of the good being sold and their opponents' strategies. The great fear is the 'winner's curse' of paying too much. But if all bidders are overly cautious as a result, the auctioneer runs the risk that the bids will be below the value of the good being sold.
 
Maximizing Information
 Game theory says bidders become more confident with more information, so the F.C.C. has designed the auctions to be as open as possible. Unlike most auctions, where goods are sold one after the other, bidding for all the F.C.C. licenses will occur simultaneously. By seeing how other licenses are being valued, and how their oponents are bidding, bidders can react without fear of paying too much. In such a case, the F.C.C. hopes, the proceeds will meet its goal.

HEADLINE: Profit News Helps Dow Rise 55.51

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
A flurry of strong third-quarter earnings reports helped propel the stock market to its largest gain in a month.
With corporate leaders like Chrysler, Motorola and Pepsico announcing better-than-expected profits, the Dow Jones industrial average scored its third consecutive double-digit gain, surging 55.51 points. Rising bond prices again allowed the stock market to move higher on its own steam. On the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 7.86 percent yesterday from 7.90 on Friday. [Page D21.] 
 The rally yesterday "was a reaction to an oversold position," said Edward D. Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A. "But things are not attractive for the market as a whole."
Program trading, or computer-guided orders, played a significant role yesterday, accounting for almost half of the market's advance, according to Birinyi Associates, which monitors this activity.
"In a lot of cases when the market runs up, you see money come out a little bit," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst for Birinyi. "In this case, it didn't come out. People wanted to be in this market and the numbers clearly show it."
Shortly after 11:30 A.M., the Dow was up 50 points, setting off the New York Stock Exchange's limits on index-linked trading for the first time since August. Although the limits remained in effect for the rest of the day, the average rose as much as 61.23 points.
At the close, the Dow stood at 3,876.83, up 1.45 percent for the day. Other indexes rose in tandem, with the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index up 6.75 points, or 1.47 percent, to 465.79, and the Nasdaq composite index up 8.76 points, or 1.16 percent, to 765.57.
The list of winners was huge, with 1,560 advancing stocks on the Big Board, compared with 668 losers. And the rally was unusually broad based, with virtually all of the equity groups advancing.
Chrysler led the auto sector, after reporting a profit of $1.76 a share, compared with $1.13 in the corresponding period a year earlier and higher than analysts' forecasts. Chrysler shares rose 5/8, to 46 1/2, while General Motors advanced 1 5/8, to 47 1/8, and Ford increased 1 1/8, to 29 3/8.
Energy issues were buoyed by a Pentagon announcement that Iraqi troops appeared to be ready to withdraw from the Kuwait border area. Some analysts also said oil prices could increase soon, because it was now less likely that the United Nations would lift its economic sanctions on Iraq. Crude oil for November delivery fell 29 cents, to $17.70 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Mobil was up 7/8, to 80 5/8, while Exxon was up 3/8, to 59, and Chevron was up 7/8, to 42 7/8.
Many financial companies moved upward along with the bond market. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, gained 1/2, to 53 1/2; American International Group rose 1/2, to 89 7/8, and Providian advanced 7/8, to 31 3/8.
Both Motorola and Pepsico jumped on higher net income, with Motorola up 1 3/8, to 54 1/8, and Pepsico up 2 1/4, to 34 3/4. Procter & Gamble touched an all-time high of 62 7/8, closing at 62 3/8, up 2 1/2, after the company said it expected to report record third-quarter earnings. Apple Computer also touched an all-time high of 41 7/8, closing at 39 5/8, up 3/4, after forecasting that fiscal four-quarter profits would top Wall Street estimates by at least 38 percent.
Among the special situations, the SFM Corporation, a thinly traded toy maker, spurted 13 7/8, to 46 1/4, a new high. Yesterday, the company announced preliminary third-quarter sales and earnings increases of more than 300 percent.
Shares of SFM, whose stockholders will consider a 4-for-1 stock split next Tuesday, had a huge run-up in August. The highly volatile stock more than quadrupled in less than four weeks before retreating slightly.
SFM also said that it would ask stockholders at a coming special meeting to approve conversion to a holding company format. As recently as April, the stock sold for as low as 7 1/8.
International Paper, which reported higher earnings, nevertheless lost 3/8 to close at 77 1/2. And Sequoia Systems, a computer systems maker, plunged 9/16 , to 315/16 , a day after saying that it expected a smaller profit for the fiscal first quarter.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CRIME;
Pataki Urging Longer Terms In Crime Plan

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
State Senator George E. Pataki yesterday called for holding violent criminals in prison longer as the central element of his anti-crime program for New York. The Republican candidate for governor proposed to do this by lengthening sentences and by denying parole or work release to violent felons.
He would also stiffen sentences for crimes committed with guns and reinstitute the death penalty. 
 As he has campaigned, Mr. Pataki has criticized the parole and work-release programs as a reason for the state's crime problem. But yesterday was the first time he spelled out how he would attack the problem.
His opponent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who questioned how the state could afford Mr. Pataki's proposal, will offer his crime plan today.
Mr. Pataki's plan does not spell out how it would affect the prison population or the state budget. He acknowledged that the proposal, announced a week after his plan for large cuts in the state personal income tax, could mean building more cells at a cost he could not estimate. Correction officials say prison cells cost $100,000 each to build and $25,000 a year each to operate.
Mr. Pataki said he believed he could both cut taxes and, if necessary, build more cells. "We're talking about the tax cuts, and they are a very important and critical part of how we are going to change this state over the next four years because we have to create jobs and opportunity," he said. "But we have to create opportunity with a better economic climate and also with safer streets. They go hand in hand."
If faced with a difficult choice of one or the other, he said, he would opt for his crime plan.
He unveiled the plan at his Manhattan campaign headquarters at a news conference, flanked by the parents of a 29-year-old man with cerebral palsy who was stabbed to death this summer near Poughkeepsie.
"We're going to go after the violent criminals," he said. "We're going to go after the violent felons, and particularly the career felons, who prey on decent and law-abiding people of this state."
Mr. Pataki's proposal changed shape somewhat in the course of the day yesterday. At the news conference, he said simply that if elected governor, he would abolish parole for violent felons. An aide said later that Mr. Pataki meant that no violent felons would be allowed out of prison before serving their minimum sentences.
But by day's end, his plan had become more sweeping: Pataki aides said he would seek an entirely new sentencing structure for violent criminals that would have no provisions for parole. The new sentencing structure would eliminate the state's present system of proscribing a minimum and a maximum term -- for example three to nine years -- in favor of a fixed flat sentence, longer than current minimums.
As governor, Mr. Pataki could propose legislation and could lobby members but he has no independent power to impose such changes. The State Legislature, which is divided on many issues, has been especially divided on how to fight crime.
Mr. Cuomo, who proposed a similar flat sentencing in 1985, only to have it rejected by the Legislature, ridiculed his rival's plan, saying he could never pay for it.
"He doesn't have the $7 billion for the tax cut that he has already asked for," Mr. Cuomo said at a ground-breaking ceremony for a new minor-league baseball field in Syracuse. "Now what he is talking about is spending billions dollars more on prison cells. The absurdity of his position becomes more and more obvious."
The Cuomo administration, while not contesting the high level of violence, called into question Mr. Pataki's assumption that prisoners were being paroled too soon. According to statistics from the State Department of Correctional Services, prisoners for all crimes in New York serve an average of 30 months, compared to 26 months nationally.
James Flateau, a department spokesman, said he could not estimate how much a new sentencing structure for violent felons would cost. But he said exempting violent felons from work-release programs, as Mr. Pataki proposed yesterday, would disqualify one quarter of the 6,300 in work release, which he said would mean the immediate need for an additional 1,575 cells.
At an annual cost of $125,000 to build and operate, the additional cells would cost nearly $200 million the first year, he said.
In a year when voters have clamored for action on crime from government at all levels, Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said his plan to reform sentencing would be modeled on the Federal sentences, which were changed to flat sentences in 1987. She said the present sentencing system would still apply for people convicted of nonviolent crimes, which accounts for about 60 percent of the 65,000 people in state prison.
Beyond his plan for tougher sentencing, Mr. Pataki said he would eliminate the work-release program for violent felons, saying it has wrongly been used as a way to control prison population. He cited figures showing that reliance on work release has increased almost sixfold since 1987, from 4,837 inmates to over 24,000 today. In 1993, he said, 4,000 inmates walked off their jobs and 1,000 never returned.
Mr. Pataki also said he believed his signing of the death penalty would deter crime. "I think the absence of the death penalty costs the people of this state every day," he said. "It costs in terms of lost lives and you can't measure those lost lives in dollars and cents."
He also said that under his plan, anyone convicted of using a gun a crime would face a mandatory 10-year prison sentence. If someone was injured by the gun in the commission of a crime, the mandatory term would rise to 20 years.
He repeated his support for a state version of the new Federal ban on assault weapons, though Cuomo aides pointed out that as a legislator, Mr. Pataki voted this year against an amendment that would have provided for a similar ban. Mr. Pataki has offered various explanations for that vote, but most recently has said it was a partisan vote against a bill he said did not go far enough.
To dramatize his proposals, Mr. Pataki was joined at his announcement by Kevin and Carol McCauliff, whose son, Thomas, who had cerebral palsy, was stabbed to death last July 10 in Red Hook, N.Y.
The couple said the man charged in their son's death, Richard G. Moran, had a long criminal record and had been paroled by the state for a 1988 attempted robbery. "I believe that George Pataki as governor will help us provide answers to our questions and hopefully save another child and parents from what we are going through," she said.
The State Parole Division said that Mr. Moran was paroled in 1990 but that his full sentence had run out three weeks before the July slaying, so he was no longer on parole.

 SYRACUSE, Oct. 11 - Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a former minor league outfielder, helped break ground yesterday for a new stadium for the AAA Syracuse Chiefs with a telling metaphor about baseball's lessons for life - and politics.
 "Teaching you to lose is pretty good. Reminding you that you're not going to win every game, even if you deserve to. Well, you have to learn to live with that for the rest of your life because you're going to strike out a lot when you didn't deserve to, because the umpire isn't always perfect of vision."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO. (IP,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The International Paper Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 47 percent on rising demand for its containerboard and packaging products.
The nation's largest paper and forest products company posted third-quarter net income of $109 million, or 87 cents a share, which matched Wall Street's expectations, compared with profit of $73 million, or 59 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. 
 Revenue in the latest quarter increased 11.8 percent, to $3.8 billion.
"With expanding economies in the United States, Europe and the Pacific Rim, we are experiencing greater demand and higher prices in essentially all of our products," said John A. Georges, chairman of International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y.
Mr. Georges said he expected "even stronger earnings growth" in the fourth quarter and in 1995.
International Paper said third-quarter sales and earnings rose at its consumer packaging and containerboard, or corrugated cardboard, units. The company's printing-papers unit was profitable for the first time in two years, led by a stronger European economy and a strong market for pulp.
In last year's third quarter, a charge of $25 million, or 20 cents a share, resulted in net income of $48 million, or 39 cents a share.

HEADLINE: The Streets Are Paved With Potholes;
In the Inner-City Economy, Flat-Tire Shops Fill a Void

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
For every espresso bar that percolates on the Upper West Side and every fancy boutique that blossoms in SoHo, there is a greasy storefront operation in one of New York City's poorer neighborhoods that solicits business with a simple sign announcing: "Flat Fix."
Just as cafes and boutiques have sprouted in Manhattan's disposable-income districts, these shops where drivers with a flat tire can stop for a quick, cheap patch or an inexpensive used tire have multiplied in areas where money is short, tires are old, roads are rough and immigrant entrepreneurs abound. They prosper in neighborhoods where service stations have been replaced by gas stations whose attendants only take cash through bulletproof glass. 
 On major avenues in the South Bronx, the shops are on almost every block. There, flats are mended curbside by people like Robert Rivera, 22, who sees his new shop as a step to owning a grocery, or Cheo Gonzales, 53, a mechanic from the Dominican Republic with a crescent of grease on his sweatshirt who knows just enough English to say: "Three dollars for plug. Five dollars for patch."
Tire shops are fixtures in the poorer neighborhoods of Brooklyn, in Jamaica, Queens, and in Harlem. "I've never seen one without two or three cars parked in front of it," said Eugene Rodriguez, an official with the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission who lives in East Harlem. "This is America. If there's a need, someone will create a business to fill it."
The business is a peephole into the economy of the poor. Entrepreneurs see an opportunity, and seize it by focusing on people with money to buy luxuries, in this case cars. But it is a stunted landscape.
The entrepreneurs are people like Ramon Santana, who started the B & B Tire Shop on Southern Boulevard in the Bronx 18 months ago by spending less than $5,000 to buy a used machine that removes tires from rims, an air compressor to inflate tires, some used tires and hand-operated jacks. He rents a narrow storefront for a few hundred dollars a month.
Customers at tire shops are often neighborhood residents and car service drivers. They typically have enough money to buy cars, but not enough to afford new tires that would stand up to the mean streets of the city.
Many of the lives in these neighborhoods are like the tires these men work on, endlessly patched together and plugged against the sharp edges. "They've got old cars and they're just trying to get through the day," Pedrito Garcia said about his customers at a shop on Third Avenue in the Bronx.
In this business, one pothole, strategically situated, can be a boon. "There used to be a big pothole out there," said Jimmy Rivera, 25, who was changing flats at a shop on Southern Boulevard in the Bronx recently. "Cars would hit it and you would hear a pop. Business was good then. But that was only one pothole. There are a million more out there."
The streets of the South Bronx can be a giant obstacle course, with drivers forced to weave between potholes and glass and debris and cars parked two and three deep, not to mention the men pushing grocery carts heaped with twisted scrap metal to be sold at recycling yards.
Meil Myers, a clerk in an auto parts store, said his Buick Century gets a flat at least once every three months. He was getting his latest one patched up on East Tremont Avenue in front of Rey Flat Fixed the other day. "The Bronx is terrible, man," he said. "I lost this one to a bottle on the street."
These daily assaults have spawned a growing trade in $5 tire patches and $12 used tires, bought from salesmen who cannibalize tires from junked cars and roam these neighborhoods selling them from the backs of trucks.
Tire shops in the South Bronx are dominated by immigrants, many from the Dominican Republic, who are eager to own their own businesses but limited by scant capital and little knowledge of English. It has become a family business for Juan Santos, who works 60 hours a week and earns about $200 at a Bronx tire shop near one his brother owns. "This is a good business for us because a lot of Dominicans don't speak English," he said.
Lloyd Ultan, a Bronx historian who teaches at Fairleigh Dickinson University, said many gas stations are no longer repairing cars, so the tire shops fill a void.
"People see an opportunity and they take advantage of it," he said.
In an economy of bodegas and car services and fruit stands, flat-fix shops are the bottom rung.
Robert and Pura Rivera are hoping to build a family enterprise at the corner of 167th Street and the Rev. James A. Polite Avenue in the Bronx. They rented a storefront for $1,000 a month and built a wall down the middle. Mr. Rivera opened Los Compadres Tire Shop on one side and his wife plans to open a candy store in the other space.
It is a rough neighborhood, but the couple hope that a new development of middle-class homes nearby will help them reach their ultimate goal: owning a grocery store. Tire-shop owners say business can fluctuate wildly, some days bringing in as much as $200 and other days almost nothing. But Mr. Rivera said he expects that within five months, he will recoup his $10,000 investment, which he saved from earlier earnings as a security guard and warehouse worker.
"There are always flats," he said.
But there's always competition, too. Another flat-fix shop is half a block away from Mr. Rivera's.
In the Bronx, with its web of highways, there are five flat-fix shops along nine blocks of Webster Avenue. Near the intersection of Third Avenue and East Tremont Avenue, there are three within a block and a half. Two, A.A.A. Flats Fixed and L.L.L. Flat Fixed, are barely 50 feet apart. A bumper crop of "Flat Fix" signs has sprung up on Jerome Avenue, Hunts Point Avenue and dozens of other avenues and side streets.
"It's like the Blockbuster Video of the tire business," said Jay Hansel, whose family-run tire business has been in the Bronx for 35 years. He says the flat-fix shops pose no competition to his business, which sells freshly minted Firestones and Goodyears for $45 to more than twice that. He'll fix a flat for $15.
There are no statistics on tire shops since no city or state agency specifically regulates their activities, but both tire-shop owners and community groups say the number of flat-fix operations have increased significantly. Community board leaders in the Bronx and Brooklyn said they have organized protests against tire shops in residential areas because they clutter the sidewalks with tires and fix cars in the street.
Tire-shop owners who have been in the business for a long time say there are too many competitors, and shops often reduce their already cut-rate prices to attract customers. In these areas, a 50-cent or $1 reduction in the cost of a patch can make a difference.
The quality of the work is uneven, customers say, but as Officer Rolando Martinez, who stopped his squad car at a tire shop on Third Avenue for air the other day, said, "They're cheap and they're fast."
And they fill a need in the local economy.
"If you're a professional and you get a flat tire, you say, 'Give me a new tire.' Over here you can't afford to do that," said Juan DelGado, sitting outside his Ponce Tire Shop. "It's a matter of money."
Then he looked at his dirty sneakers. "Let's say I'm going to throw these away," he said, wagging his feet. "Someone will pick these up because he needs them, but I don't need them."
Over the door of his shop hangs a tire painted with the words: "Flat Fix -- New Life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Flat-tire shops have sprouted in the South Bronx, where money is short and tires old. Juan Delgado at his shop on Hunts Point Avenue. The English on the right is a translation of the Spanish on the left. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mayor Reveals Plan to End Illegal Vendors in Harlem

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a plan yesterday to force illegal sidewalk vendors off 125th Street in Harlem starting on Monday, by creating a nearby open-air market for many of them and then moving ahead with police sweeps of unlicensed vendors who remain.
Under the plan, the city would grant special licenses to more than 400 illegal vendors and permit them to sell their wares at an "alternative market" in two vacant lots at Lenox Avenue and 116th and 117th streets. Any vendors who continue to operate illegally on 125th Street would be subjected to fines of $250 to $1,000, confiscation of their goods and possibly arrest. 
 Appearing with supportive merchants and elected officials at City Hall yesterday, Mr. Giuliani sought to portray the plan as an economic boon for the neighborhood and for vendors trying to establish legal businesses.
But the crackdown could lead to a confrontation. When Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a similar plan to open a market two years ago, dozens of vendors staged a raucous protest that disrupted business and traffic on 125th Street, and the administration backed down.
The appearance of illegal vendors on 125th Street and other commercial strips around the city has been a source of recurring complaints from established merchants. While the vendors say they are simply scratching out a living, the merchants say they steal customers, block the sidewalks and create litter, without having to pay the taxes established businesses do.
Mr. Giuliani said vendors had proliferated "out of control," eroding the quality of life along the commercial heart of Harlem, where as many as 1,000 vendors a day turn the street into a blocks-long bustling bazaar of perfumes, books, T-shirts, African artifacts and bootleg videos.
"There's a distinct need to bring this vendor situation under control," he said.
The Mayor's plan prompted mixed reactions on 125th Street yesterday. Michael Yoba, 38, a vendor from Harlem who was selling incense and handmade wooden necklaces near the Apollo Theater, was dismissive. He said the vendors offered an important service and would continue to do so despite the Mayor's warnings.
"I will be here on Monday," Mr. Yoba said. "There's too many people here to get rid of us all. There's too many mouths to feed."
Merchants, however, welcomed the crackdown, though some were skeptical that it would prove lasting. Sue Seo, a Korean immigrant who owns World Fashion, a clothing store nearby, said the city had promised to move the vendors before without success.
"They don't want to pay the tax," she said of the vendors, several of whom crowded the sidewalk in front of the store. "We have to pay the tax, and other business taxes and the rent, which isn't cheap. When they sell something for $1, $2, that's it. It's been real hard for us."
The control of illegal vendors, particularly on 125th Street, has stymied city officials for years.
The city now licenses two types of vendors, who are allowed to operate only on certain streets. The Department of Health licenses about 3,000 food vendors, while the Department of Consumer Affairs issues 853 licenses to general vendors selling everything else.
Officials estimated that there are as many as 10,000 general vendors operating without licenses, generating potential tax revenues as high as $300 million a year.
Under the Mayor's plan, worked out after several months of talks with elected officials and merchants in Harlem, the city will charge vendors $7 a day to operate in the lots on Lenox Avenue. The market will be operated by Malcolm Shabazz Masjid, a mosque on Lenox, which will return 30 percent of the revenue to the city.
The lots are slated for redevelopment and thus will be available for only a year, after which the city hopes to find a new location, possibly an indoor market like Mart 125 on 125th Street.
The city has already accepted 478 applications for the licenses, but that is far less than the number of vendors who congregate on 125th Street. The city will give preference to vendors from Harlem first and from the city second.
While officials cited the number of applicants as a sign of enthusiasm, it remains to be seen whether the market will attract the steady flow of customers of the busier thoroughfare eight blocks north.
Rudy Washington, the Commissioner of Business Services, whose office drafted the plan, said that the goal was to provide opportunities for illegal vendors to establish themselves as legitimate businesses. He said the city would hold orientations for vendors starting today.
Vendors who resist the move will face fines, seizures and possibly arrest. Lieut. Raymond Ferrari, a spokesman for the Police Department, said that officers from the 28th Precinct would begin clearing the streets at 12:01 A.M. on Monday.
"We'll take it step by step," the lieutenant said. "We'll confiscate materials, and we'll arrest individuals if need be. We don't expect any confrontation at this time."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Said to Waste Billions on Computers

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Congressional investigators said today that the Government wasted billions of dollars a year on computers and that the machines were often obsolete by the time they were installed for use by Federal employees.
"The process of acquiring Federal computer systems takes significantly longer than the process of developing new technology," said Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine. And this "increases the likelihood that the technology will be obsolete once delivered," he added. 
 "It takes the Federal Government an average of almost four years to purchase computers, compared with 13 months in the private sector," he said. "Computer technology is developing rapidly, while the Government's acquisition process moves at a glacial pace."
Mr. Cohen is the ranking Republican on a Senate subcommittee that evaluates the management of Government agencies. The Government spends more than $25 billion a year on computers and related services, he said, and it has spent $200 billion on such equipment over the last decade.
But, he said, the Government is not getting its money's worth.
Henry L. Connors, a spokesman for the General Services Administration, which supervises the buying of goods and services for the Government, acknowledged that there were serious problems in many computer contracts. He said Roger W. Johnson, the administrator of the general services agency, had urged some departments to defer the purchase of computers so they could reassess their needs.
Senator Cohen, in a report on his investigation, said, "The failure of the Government to effectively buy needed computer equipment and services has wasted billions of dollars." The Government often buys computers that are "incompatible, obsolete and inappropriate for their intended tasks," he said.
"The current acquisition process is inflexible, bureaucratic, wasteful and overregulated," he said.
He offered these examples:
*The National Institutes of Health spent $800 million on several mainframe computers that its researchers refuse to use. Officials did not ask the researchers, who prefer to use personal computers, what they needed or wanted.
*The Agency for International Development, which runs foreign aid programs, maintains 45 different computer systems to track its property around the world and to manage its operations. But most of these systems cannot share data with one another, and the agency cannot account for thousands of cars and trucks at its offices around the world.
*The Agriculture Department is developing 17 large computer systems at a cost of $6.3 billion. But it has not coordinated development of these systems, so there is no guarantee that the computers can communicate with one another.
*The Internal Revenue Service is using outmoded technology to process tax returns. Antiquated computers have contributed to the I.R.S.'s failure to collect more than $70 billion in delinquent taxes from individuals and corporations.
Senator Cohen said the Federal Aviation Administration, the Social Security Administration, the National Weather Service and the Immigration and Naturalization Service were also using old computers that severely hampered their ability to serve the public.
The Federal process for buying computers was established when the Government dominated the market, but that is no longer the case, Mr. Cohen said. Thirty years ago, he said, the Government bought more than 62 percent of the output of the United States' computer industry, but today it accounts for less than 4 percent.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Lauds His Policies, But Listeners Are Sparse

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton took his autumn campaign for Democratic candidates on its first road test today, flying to a booming Ford assembly line to sit in a red Mustang, lift the hood, check the dipstick and tell auto workers that the Republican Party was determined to ruin their newly found prosperity.
It was a fiery performance, given to a much-smaller-than-advertised crowd and a smaller-than-advertised number of Democratic nominees willing to associate themselves with it. 
 On the first of several Midwest visits that he plans this month, Mr. Clinton repeatedly urged his audience to swallow its anger, however justified, at a Democratic-run Government and view the elections as a choice between the future and what he called a failed Republican past.
If the realization of his own agenda is admittedly incomplete, he declared, the Republican agenda, as outlined in a list of legislative goals that 300 Republican Congressional candidates signed last month, would return the nation to a decade when, he said, Federal spending was uncontrolled and the economy decayed.
"No one would want to go back to the days when we exported jobs, not products," he said. "No one would want us to go back to the days when the deficit was exploding and our economy was going downhill. That is exactly the decision that all of you are going to have to make on Nov. 8: whether we keep going in the right direction or go back to the 1980's trickle-down economics."
White House strategists say that speeches like this one will be common in the next four weeks and that the aim is to direct the public's fury with Washington more at Republicans than at Mr. Clinton and his Democratic allies.
Today the President tried to draw a distinct line between his policies and those of the Republicans, comparing a long list of Democratic legislative accomplishments -- a smaller Federal work force, a smaller deficit, cheaper college loans, more childhood immunizations -- with an equally long list of proposals that the Republicans have blocked in Congress.
He acknowledged that voters had "plenty of good reasons to be discontented."
"But remember the problems we found 20 months ago," he said. "Remember the progress we're making. Remember how many of them fought us every step of the way. And remember now what they want to do to take us back, when we have so much to do to keep going forward."
Today's event, however, made clear that Mr. Clinton still had far to go to surmount a lack of popularity with his own leadership. The White House had predicted that 4,000 or more auto workers would attend his speech, on the grounds of a huge assembly plant in nearby Dearborn, and the United Auto Workers, strongly Democratic, had won a morning off for factory workers so they could be present. But the crowd was far smaller -- less than a thousand -- and its response was lackluster.
So was the enthusiasm of the local candidates who the White House had said would be on hand.
Lynn Rivers, a Democrat trying to hold on to a Democratic seat being vacated by Representative William D. Ford, who is retiring, had been billed as likely to attend an afternoon gathering with Mr. Clinton and auto union leaders. But she demurred. "She had an editorial board meeting that we couldn't schedule around," said her press spokeswoman, Amy Pritchard.
Ditto for Bob Mitchell, a Democrat running for the House seat being left by a Democratic senatorial candidate, Representative Bob Carr. "We're in a tough race against a multimillionaire," a spokesman, Raul Alvarez, said in explaining Mr. Mitchell's absence. "We had to get him out there to raise money."
Then there is Mr. Carr, who trails his Republican rival, Spencer Abraham, by five percentage points in a race that the White House regards as crucial.
"This is not a campaign event for me," Mr. Carr told reporters before the President's speech. Later, for emphasis, he added: "This is not a Bob Carr campaign event. He's got his point of view; he tries to get it across. He can give whatever speech he wants to give."
Mr. Carr, for whom the President is scheduled to raise campaign money at a private event later this month, said that he had not invited Mr. Clinton to Detroit and that "he can go anywhere he wants." Asked how much the President's appearance might help his campaign, Mr. Carr responded: "It's incalculable. I have no idea."

HEADLINE: Giving Poland What It Needs

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is deciding whether to admit Poland and other countries in Eastern Europe to NATO, which is tantamount to committing U.S. troops to their defense. At a recent meeting of NATO ministers, Volker Ruhe of Germany began a drive to broaden membership in the alliance, setting off active discussion in Washington. There are excellent reasons such a commitment should not be made now.
Never mind that Eastern Europe's armies are still largely Soviet-trained and -equipped and not ready to join NATO. Enlarging NATO would oblige the U.S. to defend countries mainly threatened by internal disunity and their own regional rivalries, not Russian resurgence. Furthermore, expanding NATO now could jeopardize the future of Boris Yeltsin and fellow reformers in Russia, increasing Eastern European insecurity. Why run this risk when NATO membership does not meet Poland's most immediate need, which is political reassurance rather than a military alliance? 
 It is understandable why Western-oriented Poles wish to join NATO. NATO for them is Club West. The problem is that most Russians still regard NATO as a military alliance of the U.S., Germany and others against Russia. That may change as Western ties with Russia thicken and Russia's westernizers strengthen their tenuous grip on power. But for now Russia's extremists can use the bogeyman of NATO against Mr. Yeltsin and his allies. If NATO is too quick to swallow Poland, the extremists may swallow Mr. Yeltsin. Poland will be more secure if Russia stays on the road to reform and out of the hands of vengeful nationalists.
Nor is Poland in any immediate danger. If, despite Western efforts, Ukraine falls apart and Russia reverts to aggressive nationalism, it will be years before Russia can mobilize an army that could threaten Poland -- time enough for the U.S. to forge a firm military alliance. In the meantime there are ways to tie Poland more closely to the West without stoking Russian nationalism.
One is admission to the European Union, which would boost Poland's economy. Another is for NATO to make the most of the Partnership for Peace with Eastern Europe and Russia, moving beyond technical military cooperation and joint exercises to foster democratic patterns of civil-military cooperation. A third is to strengthen the web of cultural, economic and political contacts between Poland and the West.
Such reassurances will meet Poland's legitimate economic and political needs without destabilizing a reforming Russia.

HEADLINE: Now or Never for the N.A.A.C.P.

BYLINE: By Roger Wilkins; Roger Wilkins is professor of history at George Mason University.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In dismissing its executive director, the Rev. Ben Chavis, the N.A.A.C.P. put on a show that we watched with the titillation and embarrassment that we would feel from a neighbor's loud, messy divorce.
The board meets tomorrow to begin seeking a new executive director. But we now know enough about the scandal and debt that have dragged down the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to understand that a change of one individual at the top, although necessary, won't restore the association to what we need it to be. 
 Not all of the problems laid at Mr. Chavis's door began with him, but they all developed under the stewardship (if it can be called that) of the leaders of the board of directors. No leaders who permitted a $3 million or possibly $4 million deficit to develop should remain in office.
This interracial organization's complex, arcane politics have produced a board that has become increasingly more ingrown and provincial and has developed a reputation for generous spending on itself.
The outmoded governing structure, including an unwieldy 64-member board, has long needed overhaul. The board ought to dismiss its officers and declare a voluntary trusteeship that would modernize the governing structure, restore the N.A.A.C.P.'s credit and credibility and choose a new leader before relinquishing power.
The trustees might include such eminent citizens as Marian Wright Edelman, Leon A. Higginbotham Jr., Lani Guinier, Winifred Green, Colin L. Powell Jr., William L. Taylor, Angela Glover Blackwell, Harry Belafonte, Geoffrey Canada, David Hornbeck, Johnetta Cole, John Hope Franklin, Dorothy Height and William T. Coleman. Many of these people -- some of them educators, some of them white and none of them now board members -- have spent a good portion of their careers dealing with young people and the grass roots of black America, with which the N.A.A.C.P. has been out of touch.
The organization is not merely of concern to African-Americans. The N.A.A.C.P. has been -- and can be again -- a national treasure. The issues it should confront involve the quality of our national life and nature of our democracy.
All of its activities and capacities are urgently needed. Economic forces are tearing black America apart. The gaps in income and in life experience between the growing but still modest group of affluent African-Americans and their most vulnerable brothers and sisters is enormous.
While economists trumpeted September's 5.9 percent unemployment rate as "effective full employment," the black jobless rate remained in double digits, where it has been for two decades.
The Urban Institute reported recently that in 1993, 53 percent of black males in the prime working and family-forming years -- the ages of 25 to 34 -- were jobless or employed with wages too low to raise a family of four out of poverty.
The incredible burst of prison construction, the harshness of welfare reform proposals and the unwillingness to put black economic distress on the national agenda are all evidence of the strength and pervasiveness of racism. But the N.A.A.C.P. has almost disappeared from serious national dialogue about public policy.
We are experiencing a hardening of racial attitudes, a rising desperation among the black poor, a coarsening of the quality of urban life, a growing willingness to disregard the Bill of Rights when dealing with certain criminal defendants and an inability to debate our social ills honestly.
The nation needs the N.A.A.C.P. with its constructive traditions and its splendid nationwide network. The N.A.A.C.P. needs a renewal of the acute public-policy analyses for which it was once respected. But the organization is in terrible condition and may disappear. It cannot be reinvented, but it can be repaired. The repair job should lie at the top of the board's agenda. If the board is not up to the task, outsiders must put on the pressure needed to force it -- finally -- to do the right thing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Unchanged; Mark Has Surge in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed against leading currencies yesterday as strength from rallies in American stock and bond markets failed to offset the effects of a surging German mark and the receding threat of a Persian Gulf conflict.
The Treasury bond market rallied yesterday as investors continued to buy on signs that the pace of economic growth is not inflationary. The buying began on Friday after a September jobs report that was weaker than expected. Stock prices also surged yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 55.51 points. 
 In recent months, currency traders have taken their cues from American financial markets, because rising asset prices tend to increase demand for dollars. But the rallies yesterday failed to provide much of a lift for the dollar.
"It was a nonevent," said Hubert Pedroli, manager of foreign exchange for Credit Suisse in New York. "It's surprising, given the excellent performance of stocks and bonds. Nothing seems to be able to lift the dollar."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 100.20 Japanese yen, from 100.29 yen on Monday. Trading was very thin in New York and Tokyo on Monday because of national holidays. The dollar also edged up to 1.5455 German marks, from 1.5447 on Monday.
Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Paine Webber Inc., said the dollar was partly undermined by a flood of buy orders for marks.
"The Deutsche mark gained against all of the European currencies," he noted. "When it looked like Kohl wouldn't do well, the mark was heavily sold. As it becomes clearer he will win, there is profit taking."
The mark rose yesterday against most other currencies on growing sentiment that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition would prevail in Germany's federal elections on Sunday. Uncertainty over Mr. Kohl's prospects had driven the mark broadly lower in recent weeks.
Mr. Flanagan noted that speculators continued to take profits yesterday from the dollar's advance late last week, when the buildup of Iraqi forces on the Kuwait border fueled buying of dollars as a safe-haven currency.
"The gulf situation was one of the reasons that the dollar firmed up," said Christopher Low, senior economist at HSBC Securities in New York. "But at this point the market has decided that it's not going to develop into a war."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Take a Tumble As Tensions in the Gulf Ease

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold prices sank to a seven-week low yesterday as tensions in the Persian Gulf eased, inflation fears waned and a Wall Street rally lured investors back to the stock market.
The movement of some Iraqi troops away from the Kuwaiti border sent crude oil prices lower, which put additional pressure on the inflation-sensitive precious metals. 
 "The one prop that had been holding the market up in recent sessions was the Iraq situation," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch. "Even though there is still some uncertainty, it appears that situation is starting to be defused."
On other commodity markets, coffee, livestock and grain futures rose. Despite those gains, the Commodity Research Bureau's index fell 0.05 point, to 227.88.
Gold for December delivery fell $3.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $390.20 an ounce, the lowest daily settlement for that contract since Aug. 26; December silver fell 8.5 cents, to $5.33 an ounce.
Inflation worries drove gold up sharply last month but Friday's unemployment figures did not show signs of a runaway economy. Analysts expect Government reports on producer and consumer prices later this week to show only modest increases.
Mr. O'Neill also cited a twice-monthly report from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission showing heavy speculation that gold futures will rise. Such reports typically cause selloffs because investors fear the speculators will suddenly sell their holdings and send prices down even more sharply.
The inability of spot gold prices to reach $400 an ounce frustrated investors and contributed to yesterday's selloff, said Leonard Kaplan, vice president and chief gold dealer at the Imperial Bank in Los Angeles.
Meanwhile, crude oil futures fell sharply for the second straight day on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting the cooling of Middle East concerns. Light sweet crude for November delivery fell 29 cents, to $17.70 a barrel.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Rise; Bill Rates Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, with much of the activity coming early in the session on buying left over from Friday's rally, which was ignited by a weaker-than-expected employment number.
With no major economic reports due until tomorrow and Friday, when the Government reports on producer and consumer prices, the market managed to find some footing to mount what some market participants called an old-fashioned bear market rally. 
 "If the market did give a sigh of relief, it was on Friday," said Alan W. Kral, a portfolio manager at Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen Inc., a billion-dollar investment management firm. "And with three days off to think, investors may have said: 'Gee, maybe I'm too short in the market. Maybe the inflation numbers this week won't be that bad.' "
The price of the 30-year bond, which had traded up as much as 24/32 , to yield 7.83 percent during the day, later retreated to clsoe up 14/32 , to 9527/32 , for a yield of 7.86 percent, down from 7.90 percent on Friday. The cash market was closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day. Short-maturity bills also did well yesterday on fading expectations of an immediate increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
At yesterday's regular weekly bill auction, rates were mixed. The average rate for a three-month bill was unchanged at 4.92 percent, while the six-month slipped to 5.34 percent, from 5.38 percent last week.
The bond market was also bolstered yesterday by a decline in gold prices. Gold, always a disruptive force for bonds because many economists and investors -- not to mention Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve -- use it as a measure of inflation pressures, fell as much as $4 an ounce in trading on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Gold later settled down $3.10, to $387.60 an ounce, below $390 for the first time in six weeks.
As bond prices pushed higher in yesterday's session, investors with short positions were forced to run for cover a number of times to buy securities, either to protect profits or limit losses.
The market will next turn its attention to the report on producer prices, which will be released tomorrow and the report on consumer prices, which will be released Friday.
Mr. Kral of Trevor, Steward said investors were beginning to accept the idea that the producer and consumer price numbers would not be as bad as they were in August. "I think the market is concluding that if the Fed did not go on the employement report, and if the inflation numbers are all right, than there will be no rate hike until after the November elections," he said.
But Elliott Platt, vice president and director of economic research for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said continued caution is warranted for another three to six months, given that the economy is operating at a high level of resource utilization, and the economy's growth rate continues to exceed the growth rate of potential gross domestic product. Under these circumstances, he said, the Fed will remain poised to raise rates further, with the market inflation expectations remaining fairly high.
"We think its quite possible that during the next three to six months, the long bond yield could rise to an 8.25-8.50 percent range before plateauing," Mr. Elliott said, "while the Fed firms by 100 to 150 basis points." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Following are the results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGNS;
Race for Governor: An Independent's View

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:

CANDIDATE: B. Thomas Golisano.
 PRODUCER: Jay Inc. of Rochester. 
 VISUAL: Most of the ad shows Mr. Golisano, a wealthy businessman, sitting in a wood-paneled office lined with books. Over his shoulder an American flag. Occasionally, a graphic appears on screen that repeats a point Mr. Golisano has just made.
SCRIPT:
Announcer: Straight talk with the Independence Party candidate for governor, Tom Golisano.
Golisano: New York State is on a slow death spiral. You know it and I know it. Businesses are leaving our state and taking jobs with them. Forty percent of jobs lost in America over the last five years were lost here. When you listen to the politicians, they blame each other. Unfortunately, they're both right. Every election they promise you tax cuts and lower spending. After the election, it doesn't happen. It's the same old song. Both parties are obligated to the special interest groups that spend millions of dollars on their campaigns. I have a demonstrated record of managing positive results. When I'm Governor, the only people I will be obligated to are all of the people of New York State.
Announcer: Governor Golisano represents hope for New York. You have the vote, you have the power. That's the bottom line.
Accuracy: Mr. Golisano's portrait of a moribund state economy appears somewhat exaggerated -- for example, there is no evidence that 40 percent of the nation's lost jobs were lost in New York. Comparing the state's overall downturn to the country's downturn -- the period from June of 1989 to November of 1992 -- the state lost 31 percent of the nation's lost jobs. Over the last five years, the period cited by Mr. Golisano, the country has actually gained jobs, and the state has gained back 125,000 jobs since it hit bottom in November 1992.
Both major parties are accepting money from political action committees, as Mr. Golisano suggests. He is financing his multimillion-dollar campaign from his own bank account. Regarding his "demonstrated record of managing positive results," Mr. Golisano's company, Paychex Inc., has been very successful, repeatedly being named by Forbes magazine as one of the 200 best-managed companies in the country.
Scorecard: Mr. Golisano hopes to capture many of the disaffected voters who backed Ross Perot in 1992, and his one-on-one ad, with lines like "straight talk" and "you know it and I know it," is more than reminiscent of Mr. Perot's half-hour commercials. But his ad also reflects qualities that annoyed some voters about Mr. Perot, notably in its vagueness about how his proposals would be implemented and how he would work within a state political system dominated by the two major parties. The ad, with its emphasis on the state's economic problems, seems likely to appeal to some of the same anti-Cuomo voters that State Senator George E. Pataki is courting. DAVID FIRESTONE

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: THE RICH;
Business Owners Fear Chaos at the Hands of Mobs When Aristide Returns

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Up in the hills, where the air is sweet, the lawns are trimmed and life is lived in languor, they call him "the little monkey" and "the little jerk," and add that eight months of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President were enough to lay a road to civil war.
"Wait until the day of his arrival here and you will see scenes of people going crazy," said Olivier Nadal, a Haitian businessman of French descent whose family imports and exports food and operates in the shipping and banking industries. 
 "What scares us most is all the fanatics with Aristide," he added, referring to what he said was violence and disruption by workers and demonstrators during the time Father Aristide served as President in 1991. "They did all kinds of horrible things, and we still have that image in our heads. But Aristide could just stand back and say, 'It's not me.' "
With the clock ticking toward Father Aristide's return three years after his ouster in a military coup, American and Haitian business executives here look with unvarnished dread toward a future that they fear will bring mob violence, deeper class resentment and the destruction of their homes and businesses.
They say that during his seven months in power, Father Aristide signaled to Haitian workers that this was their moment in history. The result, they say, was widespread disruption by workers, scattered strikes and in some cases the destruction of factories.
Now the Haitian elite watches with despair and incomprehension as American soldiers passively observe looting but then mobilize to disarm the paramilitary groups that once provided the elite with a measure of safety. They trade stories of the hardships imposed by the international embargo and lament foreign policy decisions in Washington that have crushed their businesses and may now threaten their safety.
 
Military Government Also Wins Little Praise
 The military-dominated government wins no great praise. The friends and family of well-connected military figures -- many of whom are not members of the old-line elite -- profited immensely both in the legitimate marketplace and in the extravagant black market that flourished after the embargo took effect. But at least there was a sense of security, business leaders say.
"I hate to see him go," said Chris Pomajevich, an American businessman, referring to Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the leader of the Haitian military junta who announced his resignation on Monday. "He was probably the one person in that group who should have stayed. He kept us out of civil war."
Throughout most of modern history, Haiti has been controlled by a tiny, wealthy, light-skinned elite that has dominated farming, business and commerce.
The elite is drawn from a handful of prominent families, many of French descent but increasingly joined by second-generation Haitians whose families migrated from Lebanon and Germany.
They speak French, not Creole. They send their children to exclusive schools and spend their vacations in mountain chalets here, in comfortable houses at the Haitian seashore or in Miami, where they shop for most of their clothing, jewelry and other luxury goods.
The elite has always relied on the military, which draws its troops and most of its officers from the lower classes, as a protector. In opposing Father Aristide's return, it argues that the tenets of capitalism, not the advantages of the few, are at stake.
Father Aristide counters that the elite has molded a society that crushes the vast majority of darker-skinned people.
But to his critics Father Aristide, who was elected by 80 percent of the popular vote in 1990, is not a force for democracy at all, but a dangerous ideologue bent upon revenge. They believe he is naive about international market forces and dogmatic and unrealistic in his hopes for change.
The Aristide Government's political message, they say, left the chronically poor with grand expectations that were always unrealistic but will be even harder to meet now, since a choking embargo has splintered the industrial base, drained financial reserves and given rise to a new class of merchants driven by greed and accustomed to operating outside the thin chains of law.
 
Aristide Blamed for End Of Workers' Docility
 "The rage of the crowd is unquestionable," said Fritz Kenol, 63, the head of Haiti's Mercedes and Fiat dealerships and a co-owner of a textile company. "But the man in the street, you can change his mind if you give him a job. Aristide's rage is ideological. Nothing will stop it."
The kindest words businessmen offer for the exiled President are that his short-lived Government was disorganized, directionless and lost. No effort was made to build the economic base, they say. Instead, energies were poured into revamping a society defined by immense gaps of wealth.
Regular Friday meetings with leaders of the Haitian Chamber of Commerce were canceled, said the group's president, M. Raymond Roy. No regular line of communication existed between the Government and business leaders. What meetings they did have are mostly described as confrontational, ugly and largely without resolution.
Several businessmen tell a story -- which others here believe to be pure fiction -- of a meeting that ended with a burning tire rolled into the room as a grotesque threat.
Most business executives here agree that Father Aristide's sometimes inflammatory sermons as a priest and his election to the presidency brought a profound and perhaps irreversible change in workers' attitudes. His rise to power, they say, destroyed a docility among workers and opened the way to hostile demands backed by the threat of ransacking and looting.
"The election was on Dec. 16, 1990," said Yves Gardere, 64, the owner of a roof and tile company. "When the workers came back on Jan. 4, I found them all on the floor, not working. They told me they wouldn't start working until I fired the director of the company."
When he refused, he recalled, the workers told him he should be happy to find his factory intact. The crisis was resolved, but the threat lingers, he said.
The same tensions invade life at home, where the wealthy live with teams of servants who cook their meals, do their laundry, tend their children and trim their gardens for wages that range from about $15 to $40 a month.
 
If Tables Are Turned, Will the Rich Be Servants?
 One businessman who spoke on condition that his name not be used said he had come home one night to find his daughter in tears. The maid, he said, had told the girl, "When Aristide comes back, your parents are going to come to my home and bathe my children and work for me." The maid was dismissed.
Now, as Father Aristide appears on television addressing the United Nations or speaking with journalists of his plans for peace and reconciliation, members of the business class say they fear another reality -- a dangerous social upheaval with the tacit approval of the returned President.
"What he offers his followers is simple," said Edward Gollon, 47, a commodities broker from Arkansas who has lived here for eight years. "He says to them, 'What you don't have, we will give you.' "
Haitian and American factory owners and business executives talked passionately this week about what they see as deep misunderstandings on Washington's part. They expressed contempt for American officials who ignored their appeals to stay out of Haiti.
The low wages here are adequate for most Haitian workers, they argue, because the cost of living is low. Doubling or tripling wages would knock Haiti out of a marketplace increasingly dominated by low-cost manufacturing in China, they insist, and create a new cycle of poverty, since workers would be deprived of jobs altogether.
 
Bitter Criticism Leveled At American Ambassador
 "The stupid Ambassador kept calling the military thugs and thieves and so on when they were the very people he needed to be talking to," said Mr. Pomajevich, 55, an ex-marine who grew up in Montana but now works here developing hotels and tourism. He was referring to the United States Ambassador, William L. Swing. "The Ambassador lost credibility in the eyes of the leaders. They felt he was too small to talk to."
From their hillside homes and well-tended country clubs in the cool air above the fume-choked city, members of the business class now say they sleep with pistols tucked beneath their pillows.
"I have three acres," said Mickey McLaney, an expatriate American who made a fortune in the casino business and now operates a hotel. "I go out on my grounds sometimes and shoot off a few pistol rounds just to remind them I have guns."
They intend to stay and fight. But they have watched with mounting horror in recent days as thousands of jumpy, camouflage-clad soldiers stood back as crowds looted warehouses and ransacked the headquarters of paramilitary groups.
"We hope that some day they are going to wake up and start controlling these people," Mr. Pomajevich said. "Now you have the police dead afraid of stopping anyone who is doing anything wrong."
Asked about human rights abuses by the military and its supporters, which have left more than 3,000 dead in the three years since the coup, many businessmen respond with tales of the Aristide Government's excesses. They point in particular to the killing of one of Father Aristide's enemies, Roger LaFontant, while he was in prison.
They say that under the rule of General Cedras and the head of the police, Lieut. Col. Michel Francois -- who fled last week to the Dominican Republic -- profitable franchises were passed out to the military's friends and family, further limiting their ability to run legitimate businesses, but at least there was order.
Several businessmen say President Clinton has been manipulated by the Congressional Black Caucus and other groups and has misunderstood a complex society at a difficult time, backing policies that will only further undercut Haiti's suffering economy.
"I made a lot of money in this country," said Ronald A. Georges, 37, a wholesaler of Lebanese descent who was born and reared here. "I have a nice house. I didn't steal. I didn't cheat. People in America have nice houses. But they talk about us as M.R.E.'s: the morally repugnant elite. I'm sick and tired of being called an M.R.E. I'm not saying we are Boy Scouts. But we made money by working."
They stay, and worry, and condemn foreign officials who they say never listen to their side of things. They see no natural leader here and describe the country as directionless, buffeted by forces on and off Haitian soil.
Sometimes, as the sun sets in brilliant streaks of crimson and orange over the sea, they gaze down upon the city and wonder when a surge of anger will rise above their tall stone walls and tear everything they have to pieces.

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S. OFFERS PLAN TO AVOID THREAT FROM IRAQ AGAIN

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
As President Saddam Hussein pulled back most of his troops from the border with Kuwait, the United States sought allied support today for a plan that would require Iraq to permanently withdraw its better-equipped Republican Guards but would allow 50,000 regular Army troops to remain in the area.
The proposal was less sweeping than an idea suggested on Monday by Defense Secretary William J. Perry: a huge demilitarized zone that would have excluded all tanks and heavy artillery and left Mr. Hussein with virtually no military control over the southern part of his country. 
 Despite Iraq's retreat, the United States pressed ahead with its dispatch of troops to the Persian Gulf. The Pentagon ordered 19,000 Marines to Kuwait early today, and said the buildup would continue while allied leaders discussed how to deter further Iraqi aggression.
In Kuwait today, Saudi Arabia and five other gulf nations pledged to Secretary of State Warren Christopher to repay the United States for much of its costs in defending Kuwait, and they backed the Administration's efforts to prevent Iraq from threatening Kuwait again. [Page A17.]
But in a sign of the fissures within the coalition against Iraq, France criticized the Clinton Administration, with the Defense Minister, Francois Leotard, suggesting that the buildup was "not unconnected with domestic politics."
And Russia, which signed a $17 billion economic agreement with Iraq last month and is eager to see the easing of stringent economic sanctions, got on a diplomatic track of its own, announcing in Moscow that Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev would go to Baghdad.
At the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate, began talks to persuade the Security Council to agree to an American formula to prevent Iraq from again threatening Kuwait.
The goal is to require Mr. Hussein to remove 20,000 Republican Guards who were recently moved south to nonthreatening positions, and to demand that he never send them south again, Administration officials said today. But the Iraqi leader would be allowed to keep in place the regular Army divisions that he has used during the last year to repress the Shiite residents, many of whom have been vocal in their opposition to the Government in Baghdad.
But in the face of allied opposition, the United States deleted from a draft resolution a specific threat to use force against Iraq if it violated the provisions, an Administration official said.
In an interview this week on the ABC News program "Nightline," Mr. Perry made a broader proposal: establishment of the territorial equivalent of the no-flight zone in Iraq, which bans all flights south of the 32d parallel.
"We are now conducting a no-fly zone south of the 32d parallel, which we do not allow Iraqi aircraft to fly," Mr. Perry said. "And we could conceivably extend that no-fly zone to include prohibition on certain kinds of ground equipment as well."
Today, however, White House and even some Pentagon officials described Mr. Perry's proposal as speculative.
These officials said one reason the Administration rejected the idea of a demilitarized zone was that it could encourage President Hussein to test the will of the United States by sending a tank or two into the zone and waiting to see whether they would be attacked.
"We wanted to come up with measures that would significantly reduce Iraq's ability to do this kind of thing again, not get into a situation where Saddam could have us on a string," one Pentagon official said.
A second reason, officials said, was that the demilitarized zone would create a military vacuum that could result in the dismemberment of the country. Such a move would prevent Mr. Hussein from suppressing potential Shiite uprisings and could also encourage Iran to attack.
The officials insisted that the less sweeping approach would accomplish the same goals as Mr. Perry's: speeding the return of American troops while preventing Mr. Hussein from terrorizing Kuwait.
As Ms. Albright opened her talks at the United Nations, the White House confirmed that Iraq was withdrawing its troops.
"There has been some movement, such as tanks being loaded up on trains and other things, to indicate they are in fact pulling out," the White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said. "However, some units still appear to be in place so we're continuing to monitor it closely and there's been absolutely no change in our deployment."
President Clinton's swift military response has won broad public approval. A CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll published today showed that Americans supported his decision to send troops to protect Kuwait by more than 3-to-1.
But the movement of more than 70,000 Iraqi troops south over the past week put into stark relief the problem facing the United States and its allies in dealing with the unfinished business of the 1991 gulf war.
Despite the predictions of two Administrations, United Nations economic sanctions have not toppled President Hussein. The longer he remains, the greater the pressure to ease at least some sanctions.
Apparently eager to resume business dealings with Iraq, France today expressed opposition to the American plan to set up a military-free zone in the south. After a weekly cabinet meeting, Foreign Minister Alain Juppe told reporters, "France does not favor an exclusion zone."
Mr. Juppe nonetheless criticized Iraq for sending troops toward Kuwait.
After the meeting, Mr. Leotard, the Defense Minister, criticized the military buildup as politically motivated and argued that Iraq had not violated any United Nations resolutions by moving its troops south.
More than any other of the key members of the coalition that fought Iraq in 1991, France has been counting on an early lifting of the sanctions in order to resume what had been a lucrative business relationship with Baghdad.
Over the past year, the two sides have quietly resumed contacts at both government and private levels. In June a delegation from the French Management Council, which represents major corporations, visited Baghdad to discuss business opportunities once sanctions end.
In particular France's two main oil companies, Total and Elf-Aquitaine, which were active in Iraq before the gulf war, have reportedly signed protocols with Iraq with an eye to modernizing the oil industry and exploring for oil.
But most worrisome is Russia, which was Iraq's largest arms supplier before the 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Baghdad owes Moscow $7 billion.
Together with France and China, Russia has been lobbying the Security Council to consider setting a timetable for an easing of the sanctions if Iraq recognizes the sovereignty and borders of Kuwait and continues to cooperate in the destruction of its weapons arsenal.
Even as the Russian Foreign Ministry urged Iraq on Monday to halt its troop movements, the Iraqi Oil Minister, Safa Hadi Jawad Habubi, arrived in Moscow to prepare a joint oil-production accord for the moment sanctions are lifted.
The First Deputy Foreign Minister, Igor Ivanov, and Viktor Posuvalyuk, head of the ministry's Middle East department, are in Baghdad for talks, and a Foreign Ministry official in Moscow said today that Mr. Kozyrev would visit Iraq as early as Thursday "to help ease tension in the region and promote stability."
Senior Administration officials said that they expected Mr. Kozyrev to try to extract from a vague statement of recognition of Kuwaiti sovereignty, then declare the crisis resolved and call for an easing of sanctions.
"We're not buying it," one official said.
