HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton Campaigning Again As the 'Symbol of Change'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Behind the month of political barnstorming that President Clinton began this week lies a basic calculation by strategists in and out of the White House: unless Democrats do something, Republicans will walk away with the vast -- and growing -- bloc of voters who are dissatisfied with Washington and long for change.
It is a bloc that could wreck not only Democratic hopes for the midterm elections, never very robust, but also Mr. Clinton's re-election prospects two years later. And so the message that the President delivered at a political rally in Michigan on Tuesday, and will repeat through Nov. 8, is tailored for their ears: Democrats want a change for the better; Republicans want a change for the worse. 
 "Bill Clinton is the symbol of change," Tony Coelho, the Democratic Party strategist and former Congressman, said in an interview. "He came to town to change things. Now it's a choice of what you want for the future: a deficit reduction or an increase? Tax cuts for the wealthy or fair tax treatment? Medicare cuts? Veterans cuts?"
In Mr. Clinton's message, change for the worse is a return to the Reagan Administration's economic policies, the course advocated by the House Republican whip, Representative Newt Gingrich, and some 300 other Republicans who endorsed a political agenda they call the "Contract With America."
Change for the good, on the other hand, is a roster of successes that the White House says have been overlooked: anti-crime legislation, cuts in the deficit, low-interest student loans. Some Administration defeats, like the failure of health care legislation, are not mentioned.
The President is the chief Democratic messenger, White House officials say, but not the only one. Mr. Clinton delivers the attack on Republicans in high-minded, Presidential language; he leaves more partisan, crowd-pleasing assaults to surrogates like Vice President Al Gore and Cabinet members.
The Democratic National Committee, meanwhile, is spending $2 million to broadcast commercials containing the same theme in a number of battleground states. The advertisements, which close with the punch line "Why would you want to go back?" will be shown in Michigan, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Ohio, Maine and Minnesota -- all sites of tough Senate contests.
Republicans differ, of course, arguing that Mr. Clinton and his party are the problem with Washington, and not its solution. They have courted angry voters all summer long -- cynically, the President's advisers say -- by blocking Mr. Clinton's legislative agenda and then denouncing Democrats as ineffective leaders. Mr. Clinton is undeniably unpopular, and despite White House arguments to the contrary, even Democratic analysts see him as a drag on many Democratic candidates. But when a politician has nowhere to go but up, almost any effort lifts his standing. And many analysts believe a gifted orator like Mr. Clinton has the ability to help himself and his party.
"Midterm elections are rarely about the President," said William Schneider, a political analyst at the American Enterprise Institute. "But this election is different. I think Clinton is the central issue in this whole election, and his campaigning may make a difference."
The principal target, for Republicans and Democrats alike, is a group of voters who played a central role in Mr. Clinton's 1992 victory over George Bush: supporters of Ross Perot, who now account for about a sixth of the electorate. Mr. Perot is not on the ballot, and the loyalty of his backers is up for grabs.
The White House hopes to convince the Perot faction to support Democrats by addressing its chief worry about the Government: its appetite for money and power.
Mr. Clinton's standard campaign speech emphasizes his Administration's success in reducing the deficit and its commitment to cut the Federal work force. And a consistent theme is that Republicans would return the nation to the greedy 80's, when "trickle-down economics gave us an economy stuck in reverse," Mr. Clinton said on Tuesday.
"We're running against Reaganomics -- absolutely," Mr. Coelho said. "The Perot voters' biggest item is the deficit, and now we're able to make that an issue."
And not merely the deficit. In a memorandum delivered today to Democratic leaders, Mr. Clinton's pollster, Stan Greenberg, urged candidates to employ specific references to Mr. Reagan's policies. Those references, he said, were proven mind changers.
Among them are "trickle-down economics," which Mr. Greenberg said made the message "much more powerful," and catch phrases like "tax cuts for the wealthy" and "jobs going overseas."
The group of voters dissatisfied with the pace of change in Washington has grown since Mr. Perot's run for office, analysts say, to include many Republicans who voted for Mr. Clinton and some Democrats who did, and now appear to regret it.
The Democrats, in particular, began leaving the fold after Mr. Clinton failed to win passage of his health care legislation this summer and after he was widely criticized for indecision in addressing the Haitian refugee crisis, one pollster said in an interview last week.
Mr. Clinton does not mention health care legislation in his speech, in part because the blame for its defeat has been split by many between Republicans and the White House, and because his proposed changes were unpopular.
But he does accuse Republicans of blocking other popular legislation that he has promoted, including campaign finance reform and restrictions on lobbyists. And it is that message -- that he wants to take the nation forward over Republican obstruction -- that the White House hopes will lure voters back to the Democrats' side.
Indeed, Mr. Greenberg argues that Mr. Clinton's message can sharply shift the political balance. In his memo, he said the "go forward-don't go back" argument moved people to slightly favor a trailing Democrat in tests, and gave the Democrat a nine-percentage-point edge over a Republican opponent when it included specific criticism of Reagan's policies. The shift was strongest among Perot supporters and Democrats who are not leaning toward supporting their party's Congressional candidates, Mr. Greenberg wrote.
The political landscape is littered with messages that looked good in tests and failed on the road, and many analysts say the Democrats' position is bleak. Charles Cook, a prominent political handicapper, said this week that Democratic candidates for Congress might face the sort of tidal wave of public rejection that occurs once a generation, sweeping out incumbents who seemed safe only days before the vote. But the Democrats believe that history -- Republican history -- is on their side.
"In '82, Ronald Reagan made a very significant national political speech around Oct. 15 in which he made a strong pitch to 'stay the course,' and provided a theme for his colleagues to run by," said Kirk O'Donnell, a Washington lawyer who is a political adviser to influential Democrats. "And in a day-by-day review of voter demographics in the '82 election, it was apparent that that speech helped slow down a steep decline in Republican support."
In fact, Mr. O'Donnell said, Mr. Reagan's stumping cost the Democrats at least 10 House seats that they otherwise would have gained.

With that in mind, President Clinton is taking a new message to voters: Democrats wants a change for the better, Republicans for the worse. He gave a thumbs-up sign to Michigan auto workers at a Dearborn rally on Tuesday. (Associated Press) (pg. B12)

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
WEYERHAEUSER CO. (WY,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 67 percent as pulp, paper and packaging markets recovered and strong sales continued in its wood-products business.
"The company continues to realize steady improvement in earnings as the momentum in the recovering pulp, paper and packaging markets continues," said John W. Creighton Jr., president of Weyerhaeuser. "At the same time, our timberlands and wood-products performance remains strong in spite of increasing interest rates." 
 Weyerhaeuser, which is based in Tacoma, Wash., and is the nation's third-largest forest products company, reported net income of $144.4 million, or 71 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 25, compared with income from operations of $86.5 million, or 42 cents, a year earlier. The earnings fell below Wall Street's expectations of 77 cents a share.
In last year's third quarter, the company took a charge of $19.9 million, or 10 cents a share, related to tax changes, reducing net income to $66.6 million, or 32 cents.
Sales in its most recent quarter rose 20 percent, to $2.7 billion. (Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Moves Quickly to Calm Fears Over the Ruble

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 12

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin moved quickly today to try to calm Russians and restore confidence in his Government after Tuesday's extraordinary and embarrassing run on the ruble, which lost more than 25 percent of its value against the dollar.
While the financial elements to stop the plunge were put into place Tuesday night -- helping the ruble to recover today to 3,736 against the dollar from Tuesday's close of 3,926 -- Mr. Yeltsin also moved politically. He dismissed the acting Finance Minister, Sergei Dubinin, who had little responsiblity for the run on the ruble; called the Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, home from vacation, and asked Parliament to dismiss the head of the central bank, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, a long-time target of market-oriented reformers.
Parliament postponed any vote on the fate of Mr. Gerashchenko, who was silent on the ruble's collapse today, but lawmakers called for a vote of confidence in the Government for Oct. 21.
In time-honored Moscow fashion, Mr. Yeltsin also ascribed what is being called "Black Tuesday" to sabotage by unidentified enemies and speculators, and he ordered his National Security Council to work with the secret police to investigate. One Government official even called for an "unmasking trial," the phrase used for the show trials that defined the purges of the Stalin era.
But rather than the work of some secret conspiracy, Tuesday's events seemed to result from a confluence of factors, and traders who saw an opportunity took it. Western diplomats, brokers and business executives said today that a correction in the value of the ruble had been inevitable, if badly controlled. They said the Russian inflation rate remained tolerable and that the panic would not have a lasting effect on investor confidence.
"I hope there won't be any re-evaluations on the part of investors," said Maksim Boyko, director of the Russian Privatization Center. "But this whole episode underscores the fragility of the stabilization achieved in 1994. The Central Bank should share at least part of the blame."
Reasons cited to help explain Tuesday's panic included currency speculation, inflationary expectations and a failure of the Government and central bank to act quickly enough to control the market.
After this summer's injection of credits into agriculture and industry, the Government and the central bank have made a coordinated effort to allow the ruble to adjust to higher inflation by slipping gradually from the 2,000 or so to the dollar of early this summer to about 3,000 or even 3,500 to the dollar, the rate at which the 1995 budget is figured.
Although Russians have enjoyed a relatively low inflation rate since August 1993, when inflation stood at 26 percent a month, the monthly rate has increased from about 4 percent in June to about 8 percent in September. (The monthly rate in the United States in August was three-tenths of a percent, about average for recent months.)
Since there is normally a three-month lag here between the release of new credits and an increase in the inflation rate, the estimated 7 trillion rubles of credits issued in July and August, and perhaps 3 trillion more issued in September, will continue to keep inflation running higher. In response to this expectation of continuing price increases, traders have been buying dollars, which has pushed the ruble down for three weeks now.
During the last three months, the Russian Central Bank has spent $2 billion of its reserves of Western currency to support and stabilize the ruble. Wary of spending too much, the bank announced last month that it would lessen its support of the ruble in the foreign exchange markets. On Monday and Tuesday, the bank bought few rubles, doing so only late on Tuesday to prevent the ruble from crashing past the 4,000 to the dollar.
With Mr. Chernomyrdin on vacation, the Government seemed paralyzed and said nothing. Only after trading ended on Tuesday -- followed by a reportedly stormy Government meeting -- did Mr. Gerashchenko of the central bank announce a sharp rise in short-term interest rates to make ruble holdings more attractive and declare that the bank would support the ruble at the start of trading today.
But with outstanding credits, unpaid salaries and a significant budget deficit to finance, economists and diplomats say, the Government had wanted a weaker ruble so that it would take fewer dollars to pay for it all. A weaker ruble also helps protect Russia's domestic industry by making imports more expensive, a demand that is frequently made by farm and industrial lobbies.
During a parliamentary debate today, Mr. Dubinin said that the panic was directly linked to recent subsidies to agriculture and defense industries. "Now we have to decide what we want -- either stabilization of finances with lower inflation or further subsidies to bankrupt enterprises," he said. If the latter, "the ruble will continue to fall."
Adding to the panic on Tuesday, bankers said, was a successful effort by a group of commercial banks, hurting from bad loans made when inflation was much higher, to manipulate the rules of the Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange, or Micex, where the ruble is traded.
As one board member explained it, banks have been allowed to buy dollars and put up the rubles to cover their purchase two days later, a common international practice. But numerous banks, he said, bought dollars and then delayed payment up to four days, waiting until Tuesday night, when the ruble was at its lowest, to cover their purchases.
Now the exchange will return to the old method of requiring money to be deposited before any trade is approved, he said, to discourage currency speculation.
Jannik Lindbaek, executive vice president of the International Finance Corporation, a part of the World Bank, said today that the last few days would not change the fundamental attractiveness of Russia as a place for foreign investment.
"Interest in investing here is definitely a new trend, and it's not a blip on the radar screen," Mr. Lindbaek said. "In this kind of environment, one should expect the currency market to be volatile. If we should go to hyperinflation, that would be different. But the stabilization policy of the Government is correct and necessary, and it is in fact taking hold."
Average Russians, who saw prices for imported goods and even some domestic items zoom up during the course of a day, offered opinions ranging from imminent ruin to bemused shrugs.
Olga, a world-weary 24-year-old who works at the Voyazh kiosk in central Moscow, where a pack of Marlboros went from 1,900 rubles to 2,500 rubles and a Snickers bar from 1,000 rubles to 1,500 in hours, said: "Of course we've hiked our prices. But no one's complaining except the grannies."
Leonid Abalkin, a well-known reform economist of the Gorbachev period, said people trusted the dollar more than their leaders. "In contrast to the Russian Government," he said, "the U.S. dollar will not let you down or deceive you."
Irina, who sells soaps and cosmetics at the Kabul department store nearby, said they had nearly doubled prices overnight, and there were fewer customers than usual. "We understand what has happened better than anyone," she said. "We understand it with our pockets."

HEADLINE: Campaign Briefs;
Democrats' New Ads Attack G.O.P. 'Contract'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The Democratic National Committee today announced a $2 million advertising campaign that portrays Republican candidates as intent on tax cuts for the rich, huge new spending for the Pentagon and "devastating cuts in Medicare."
The campaign reflects an effort by Democrats to turn the "contract with America," a list of promises embraced by Republican candidates for Congress this month, into a liability in the final weeks of the fall election campaign. "A trillion dollars in promises," an announcer in the advertisements declares. "How will they make up the spending gap? Explode the deficit again? Make devastating cuts in Medicare?" 
 The advertisements, one of which is specifically aimed at older Americans, argue that the Republicans are determined to resurrect the economic and fiscal policies of the Reagan years. "Why would we go back to that?" the commercials ask.
Republicans contended that Democrats were twisting the truth because they feared a Republican surge in November that could cost Democrats control of the Senate and perhaps even the House.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the chairman of the House Republican Conference, said, "The White House and Clinton Democrats in Congress have resorted to what's known in politics as the big lie to try to salvage some House and Senate seats in this volatile election year."

HEADLINE: A Painful Year of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
A year after interest rates stopped falling, Wall Street still is not sure what caused the party to end. But the hangover endures, in the form of slower economic growth and intense pain for many investors, who have seen the bond market suffer bigger losses than in any previous 12-month period.
Since Oct. 15, 1993, when the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds sank to a low of 5.78 percent, investors in Treasury securities have sustained hundreds of billions of dollars in capital losses. The 30-year bond yield last week neared 8 percent, and even after a small rally this week, is at 7.89 percent. 
 Over all, investors in Treasury bonds and notes, ranging from the very safe one-year note to the 30-year bond, have lost about 7.2 percent of their money since last Oct. 15, according to an index compiled by Ryan Labs, a money management firm in New York. They have gotten the promised interest payments, of course, but the price declines have swamped them. Prior to this, Ryan says, the biggest annual decline for Treasuries was a loss of 6.1 percent, in the 12 months ended May 31, 1959.
Moreover, the pain has been worldwide, with interest rates rising -- and bond markets suffering losses -- in every major industrialized country.
While the party was going on, the fall in interest rates hugely benefited borrowers -- municipalities, corporations and homeowners -- who were able to refinance their debts and save money. Those savings, which could be spent on other things, provided a big stimulus to the economy late last year. Now that stimulus is gone, a factor that has helped to slow growth.
What ended the party? To some extent, the turnaround in interest rates throughout the world represents the rising demand for capital at a time when no major economy is in recession. "The surge in interest rates was global, and it coincided with an upturn in the global economy," said Edward E. Yardeni, the chief economist of C. J. Lawrence.
The strong economies have also driven up some commodity prices, helping to raise inflationary concerns. The Goldman, Sachs index of industrial metal prices is up 36 percent so far this year, reflecting strong demand for aluminum and copper.
Still, inflation is low, at 2 to 4 percent a year, depending on which index is used. "The last time we had bond market returns this bad, inflation was in the teens," said James A. Bianco, the director of research at the Arbor Trading Group, a brokerage firm in Barrington, Ill. "There must be something else."
That something, he and others say, was the rampant speculation on lower interest rates that had crept into the markets in numerous ways. Much has been written about losses from derivatives, but most of those losses actually involved bets, using derivatives, on lower interest rates. The plethora of new financial instruments has made it easy to place highly leveraged bets on interest rates, and a lot of people could not resist making the bets as rates fell. Big profits from making the bets in 1992 and 1993 turned into big losses this year.
It is not easy to measure just how much speculation there was on interest rates. But Charles I. Clough Jr., the chief equity strategist at Merrill Lynch, said the available data indicate that a lot of the speculative activity, betting either on lower interest rates or at least against a sharp further rise in rates, is continuing. And he added that the high level of speculation produced the need for many investors to sell bonds quickly earlier this year, when the rise in interest rates accelerated. "Bonds didn't just go down," he said. "They melted down." Because the speculation was international, the selling hit many markets.
The Federal Reserve, which began pushing up short-term rates in February, has played a role in raising interest rates. And the Fed has not yet raised rates on short-term borrowings even close to those on longer-term debt. Even now, the yield on one-year Treasuries is 6.02 percent, well below the 6.95 percent available on three-year notes. That has made it possible for many to keep speculating by borrowing money short term and investing it in longer bonds, hoping to earn the spread between the two rates if short-term rates do not rise quickly.
Bonds are clearly a better buy now, with rates up sharply, than they were a year ago. But for bonds to rally, buying may have to appear from some unconventional source. In the early 1980's, when interest rates zoomed into the double digits, that buying came from stock market investors who found the yields irresistible even though bond investors were thoroughly discouraged.
Many bond investors have been discouraged this year. From the end of 1990 through last October, $57 billion poured into mutual funds that invest in either Government bonds or their closely related cousins, mortgage-backed securities. But in the 10 months after that, through August, $30 billion, or more than half of the inflow, was taken out, according to figures from the Investment Company Institute, a trade group.
That has forced mutual funds to sell bonds regularly. And most fund managers still have little in the way of cash reserves, forcing them to sell more bonds as investors bail out.
Mr. Bianco points out that until late 1993, banks had been big buyers of Treasury bonds, but that since then they have not added new positions on a net basis. In part, that may be because new accounting rules force the banks to report losses on many bonds when market prices decline. Previously, it was much easier to keep such setbacks off the income statement.
When will new buyers appear for bonds? Perhaps that will not happen until stock market investors again become disenchanted with their own market, something that has not begun to happen despite a market that has made little progress this year. In 1987, the sharp falloff in bond prices was halted only when the Fed eased, and money poured into the bond market, after the stock market crashed.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Down a Bit as Buying Lags

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices sagged a bit yesterday. Investors and dealers found little reason to buy ahead of today's report on producer prices.
Speculation that the September Producer Price Index may provide a mixed message for the market discouraged buying yesterday, after gains in two consecutive sessions. The market consensus is that the index will come in flat or up just one-tenth of 1 percent over all, with the core rate rising four-tenths of 1 percent. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News said they expect the overall Producer Price Index number to be unchanged in September, compared with a six-tenths of 1 percent gain for August. 
 "If it's in line with the Street concensus, not much will happen," said Stephen D. Slifer, chief financial market economist for Lehman Brothers.
But a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent in the core rate would not be so friendly for the market, he added. The market may sell off a bit on a number within expecations, "just because the market is in a negative frame of mind," he said.
"I think the issue here is what happens with the Fed, and not so much what happens tomorrow and Friday," Mr. Slifer said. "Is there a set of cicumstances that will push the Fed into action before the Nov. 15 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee?"
The price of the 30-year bond fell 11/32 yesterday, to 9616/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.89 percent, from 7.86 percent on Tuesday.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta released a report yesterday on business activity in September. Its national production index showed an unexpected dip to 18.1 from a revised 28.3 in August. The report said prices paid by producers for raw materials were little changed in September at 40.5, compared with 41.0, and the prices received index of finished goods fell sharply to 6.9 from 14.5. Sharp declines were also registered in production, new orders and shipments.
Although the bond market has reacted to lesser data in the past, the Atlanta Fed report is not typically a significiant market mover. And while the report has a national index, it is based on what manufacturers in the Southeast feel about conditions nationwide in their industries.
In the taxable bond market, two global issues dominated yesterday. The first, a $1.96 billion bond offering by the County of Los Angeles to finance the county's liability for employee retirement benefits, was priced through Lehman Brothers.
Of the total, $1.11 billion of the issue consisted of bonds priced to yield from 6.80 percent for an issue due in 1996 to 8.62 percent for one due in 2006.
Underwriters said it was the largest taxable offering ever in the municipal market. The remainder of the financing, rated A by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, also included $600 million of variable- rate securities and $248.4 million in zero-coupon bonds.
The second deal, a $500 million financing by Deere & Company was priced through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The two-part sale, backed by farm equipment loans, included $480 million of senior notes with an average life of 1.2 years priced to yield 12.5 basis points more than the one-month London interbank offered rate, or Libor, which yesterday was about 5.125 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. Dealers said interest on the issue, rated triple-A by Moody's, S.& P., Duff & Phelps and Fitch, will not exceed 18 percent.
The remaining bonds, which are subordinated securities, have an average life of 3.2 years and are expected to be priced to yield between 30 and 40 basis points more than the one-month Libor.

HEADLINE: Legislators Approve Swiss Bank Move

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Mixing political aspirations with hopes for turning around the economy, the General Assembly approved a package of financial incentives tonight intended to lure the Swiss Bank Corporation to Connecticut.
While some lawmakers said they had reservations about becoming embroiled in a bidding war with neighboring states and giving away too much in tax breaks, only one legislator voted against the deal. 
 The rest of the 187-member General Assembly said the financial benefits for the state were worth it.
"The key to this is the state is not writing a check to anybody," said Senator William H. Nickerson, Republican of Greenwich. "It's a terrific deal for every taxpayer."
The General Assembly was called into its third special session of the year by Governor Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who deemed the financial deal with Swiss Bank an emergency needing immediate action.
The legislature gave its approval shortly after 8 P.M., after a day spent wrangling over 14 judicial nominations from Governor Weicker.
The nominations eventually were scuttled The General Assembly is expected to return to the Capitol after the elections to take up the nominations in hopes they will be less prone to political maneuverings.

HEADLINE: A Generally Healthy America Emerges in a Census Report

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
As a people, Americans are living longer, smoking less, spending more money on books, newspapers and magazines, are less likely to get a divorce or own a gun and more likely to belong to a church. They are even eating more broccoli.
These are some of the highlights of the 1994 Statistical Abstract of the United States, a potpourri of facts compiled by the Census Bureau. The report, published annually since 1878, provides a snapshot of changes in American life over 20 or 30 years or more. 
 Coming in a political season in which candidates of both the left and the right are focusing on the United States' shortcomings, the abstract is a portrait of a nation that is remarkably healthy.
"You look around and look through the abstract and see what we own, what we've purchased, the size of our houses -- on those issues there is clear and steady progress," said Ben J. Wattenberg, whose new book, "The Good News Is the Bad News Is Wrong," asserts that the nation is in relatively good shape. "The idea that everything stinks, and the country is stagnant or in decline, is mostly bunk."
While many of the thousands of tables in the report present an overall rosy picture of the United States, others depict significant problems and a marked polarization between the comfortable lives of most people and the despair of those at the bottom.
Rates of violent crimes have remained high, and the number of children born out of wedlock has increased by more than 200 percent from 1970 to 1991. Moreover, in what some economists and politicians say accounts in part for the sullen mood of the electorate in a time of relative peace and prosperity, average hourly earnings and average weekly earnings as measured in constant 1982 dollars declined from 1980 to 1993.
But on some of the most basic measures of well-being, the news is good.
The report indicates that Americans born in 1992 will have an average life expectancy of 75.7 years, up from 70.8 years for those born in 1970. And infant mortality dropped to 8.5 per 1,000 live births in 1992, from 20 per 1,000 live births in 1970.
Per capita income measured in constant 1987 dollars increased to $16,366 in 1993 from $13,922 in 1980, and disposable income rose by nearly $2,300 in that same period when inflation is taken into consideration.
The report also depicts a nation whose level of educational attainment is higher than ever; 21.9 percent of Americans had completed four years of college in 1993, compared with 7.7 percent in 1960.
Perhaps as a result of the increasing level of education, the report indicates that the movement toward a less destructive life style has taken hold. In 1974, for example, about half of those 12 to 17 years of age said they had tried cigarettes and alcohol. By 1992, those in the same age group who said they had smoked had dropped to 33.7 percent, while those saying they had sampled alcohol had declined to 39.3 percent.
Similarly, the abstract indicates that Americans' consumption of red meat and eggs -- two foods associated with stroke and heart disease -- decreased markedly from 1970 to 1992, and the annual per capita consumption of whole milk dropped to 81.4 pounds from 213.5 pounds in the same period.
Even broccoli, which nutritionists have long praised and former President George Bush disparaged, has gained wider acceptance. In 1970, per capita consumption of it was half a pound; by 1992 it had increased to 3.4 pounds.
"For us to make such changes in our food consumption over a 20-year period is really remarkable," said Lars Johanson, chief of the Statistical Abstract Section of the Census Bureau. "To some extent, the nutritionists should pat themselves on the back because they are getting the message out."
The report also offers a wealth of data on the nation's most obdurate problems. Though more Americans are graduating from high school, the median scores on Scholastic Assessment Tests have plummeted. In 1993, the average S.A.T. score for the verbal portion was 424, and for the mathematics section, 468; 30 years earlier, the average was 466 for the verbal part, and 492 for math.
Conversely, while test scores have declined, the amount of money that Americans spend on books has increased -- to $16.5 billion in 1992 from $10.5 billion in 1970 in constant 1987 dollars. And the amount of money spent on newspapers and magazines rose to $20.5 billion from $13.2 billion in the same period.
But that increase is dwarfed by the surge in the amount of money spent for video and audio equipment and personal computers. Spending in that category ballooned to $70.3 billion in 1993 from $8.8 billion in 1970.
At a time when many politicians are decrying the breakup of the family, the report showed that the divorce rate, which peaked at 5.3 per 1,000 population in 1981, declined to 4.8 in 1988. In addition, the median duration of all marriages has increased to 7.1 years in 1988 from 6.7 years in 1970.
And although fear of crime has become a major issue in recent years, the percentage of Americans over the age of 18 who own a gun declined to 40 percent in 1991, from 46 percent in 1974.
The Statistical Abstract of the United States can be obtained through any Government Printing Office for $38 or from the National Technical Information Service of the Commerce Department, (703) 487-4650, for $32.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
After years of trying to fix education, why isn't it fixed?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WHY can't Johnny read? Well, actually, he usually can. After 13 years of public education, most Johnnies (and Joanies) can keep up with Oprah's latest travails in People magazine and even make change for a $20 bill.
So rephrase the question. After decades of breast-beating and trumpeted education reforms, why are most high school graduates only marginally fit for the world of work or college? 
 Eric A. Hanushek of the University of Rochester, along with a dozen other specialists assembled by the Pew Charitable Trust, does not pretend to know for certain. But the Panel on the Economics of Educational Reform, whose new book, "Making Schools Work," (Brookings Institution), is the centerpiece of a conference this week sponsored by the National Academy of Sciences, says the only way to find out is to start thinking systematically about education as a market in which producers are driven by financial incentives.
First the wretched news. After adjusting for inflation, the cost of an average year of public education more than doubled between 1970 and 1990 without any improvement in test scores.
A good chunk of the growth in outlays was driven by what economists call "Baumol's disease": in a world of rising wages, the cost of "people intensive" services will generally outpace the cost of goods produced by processes that can be more easily automated. A bit also went to meet the mandates of the Education for All Handicapped Children Act of 1975, and a bit more was used to beef up bureaucracies. But much of it, by Mr. Hanushek's measure, went to reducing class size and buying the services of teachers with advanced degrees.
So what's wrong with that? Everybody knows that smaller classes and better-educated teachers mean better schooling; indeed it is the primary virtue trumpeted by elite private schools.
The catch, Mr. Hanushek says, is that there is no systematic evidence that smaller really is better, or that teachers with umpty-four credits toward a master's degree are superior instructors. Certainly the overall performance of public education in America doesn't show it.
While black and Hispanic students are doing considerably better on standardized tests, whites have merely held their own in the last two decades. That puts the average American student in the middle of the pack internationally, performing no better and often worse than counterparts in countries that spend far less on education.
To Mr. Hanushek, the only plausible route to successful reform is to build incentive structures that link rewards to educational outcomes. The idea is hardly new; reformers have been promoting it for years. But Mr. Hanushek argues that efforts have foundered on the failure to tie rewards to outcomes within the control of individuals. Merit-pay proposals, for example, have generally been watered down or quietly discarded under pressure from unions or bureaucracies.
What is needed, he argues, is considerable decentralization of decision-making in education combined with systematic efforts to measure results. In such a world, the role of state and local bureaucrats would "change from manager to coach." Schools within school districts and teachers within schools would have far greater freedom, but would also be subject to far greater accountability.
Dale W. Jorgenson, an economist at Harvard who is not a member of the panel, likened the Hanushek approach to "market socialism" in contrast with the existing system of "regulated monopoly." The idea is to simulate competitive markets where they don't (and perhaps should not) exist. What Mr. Jorgenson does not quite say is that market socialism was a bust in Hungary and Yugoslavia because the incentives were hopelessly compromised by the ability of the losers to appeal the consequences to higher authority. Inefficient enterprises were inevitably bailed out to save jobs and face -- a result, by analogy, that might be expected in public education as long as politicians and bureaucrats have the last word.
More specific criticism comes from Richard J. Murnane, another economist at Harvard. While he is entirely sympathetic with the thrust of the approach, he says "it is much harder to get the incentives right" than Mr. Hanushek suggests. He fears, for example, that teachers would teach for the standardized tests, giving short shrift to unquantifiable skills or goals like good citizenship.
Mr. Murnane also wonders whether decentralization does not create its own trap, sacrificing the potential benefits of professionalism because the current rigid system run by professionals has failed. "We'd be asking teachers to do things they don't know how to do," he said.
What virtually all economists seem to agree on is that there has been scandalously little attention paid to measuring cause and effect. Public education has been a wasteland for research, Mr. Murnane argues, in large part because the good folks paying the bills are not interested in unpleasant answers. It is, of course, an open question whether they are about to become more interested.

HEADLINE: American Jews Focus on Preserving Their Identity;
A New Gift of $15 Million for Graduate Studies in Jewish Education Should Help

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
For American Jews, the most unsettling news these days doesn't always come from the Middle East. It's a lot closer to home.
One of two Jews now marry outside the faith. Less than half of all American Jews belong to synagogues. And even if the children of Jewish parents do take classes in Judaism, they are likely to be taught by teachers whose own training stopped when they were bar mitzvahed. 
 Against this background of erosion in the identity of American Jews, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America has received a $15 million gift for a graduate school of Jewish education.
The gift, by William Davidson, a Michigan industrialist who is the majority owner of the Detroit Pistons basketball team, is the largest donation ever made to a single institution of Jewish education in this country.
Dr. Ismar Schorsch, the seminary's chancellor, said he hoped that the gift, to be officially announced today, would send a strong signal that it was time for Jews in America to focus on their own future.
"This is where the battlefield for Judaism is, not the Middle East," Dr. Schorsch said. "The enormous funds that American Jews sent to Israel for its welfare need to be shifted to Jewish education. The most pressing problem for the survival of world Jewry is the survival of American Jewry."
How to deal with the loss of a distinct identity among American Jews, particularly those of Conservative and Reform backgrounds, has received increased attention from Jewish groups since a 1990 survey found that 52 percent of Jews who married after 1985 did so outside their faith. The survey also showed that only 28 percent of the children of such interfaith unions were being raised as Jews.
Dr. Schorsch said other research shows that only 45 percent of American Jews belong to a synagogue, which is where the vast majority of Jewish children receive education in Judaism in supplementary, or after-school, programs until they reach 13 years of age and are bar or bas mitzvahed.
And a survey to be released next month concludes that many of the teachers in those programs have not continued their own education in Judaism after their bar mitzvahs.
"The teaching ranks are thin and poorly prepared," Dr. Schorsch said. "Yet they are the backbone to cultivate and deepen Jewish identity in American society."
Mr. Davidson, 71, who is the chairman and president of Guardian Industries, the world's fifth-largest glass manufacturing concern, with annual sales of $1 billion, as well as the majority owner of the Pistons, said he chose to make his gift to the Jewish Theological Seminary because it had already demonstrated a commitment to Jewish education.
The seminary, at Broadway and West 122d Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, already has professional programs for rabbis and cantors, as well as an undergraduate college and a general graduate school.
"They have the students and the access to those who would want to do graduate work," Mr. Davidson said. "But they have not up to this point had adequate financing."
Seminary officials said the endowment would be used to build on existing graduate studies in Jewish education; they plan to increase the number of students enrolled in graduate studies in Jewish education to 150 from the current 75, beginning in September 1996, and to hire three new full-time faculty members, bringing their total to 10.
In addition to the new graduate school, the endowment will be used to inaugurate continuing education for professionals as well as to start a center for research on Jewish education. (The seminary is not the first school to receive money from Mr. Davidson, who has been the chairman of the United Jewish Appeal for Detroit and is also a past president of Congregation Shaarey Zedek in Southfield. In 1992, his $30 million gift endowed the William Davidson Institute at the University of Michigan Business School, which is dedicated to helping nations in Eastern Europe develop free-market economies.)
Nationwide, Dr. Schorsch said, some 30,000 people work in Jewish education, with only 5,000 of them serving in full-time positions. Training is varied and in many cases, not very thorough.
"A huge number of teachers have not much more education than the students they are teaching," said Alan Hoffmann, the executive director of the Council for Initiatives in Jewish Education. "Most of them are, at best, graduates of Jewish supplementary programs."
Citing a report that will be released next month, Mr. Hoffman said his group surveyed three cities -- Baltimore, Atlanta and Milwaukee -- and found that only 30 percent of teachers in supplementary schools graduated from Jewish day schools. Almost a third received no further Jewish education after their bar mitzvah, and only a quarter of them received one day a week of instruction after their bar mitzvahs.
Those kinds of data are fueling an intense re-examination of priorities in the American Jewish community, which has responded with commissions, task forces and philanthropic involvement at all levels. Some of those discussions have looked at how to make the profession of Jewish education more attractive.
"The failure for most American Jews is that Judaism is a closed book," said Steven Bayme, national director of Jewish Communal Affairs at the American Jewish Committee. "We always prided ourselves as being people of the book. Unfortunately today our capacity to read a Jewish book in the original language has been sharply diminished. We insist on the highest standards in our secular education, but we have yet to transmit that to our Jewish education."
Approaches have ranged from greater emphasis on sending young people to Israel to initiating synagogue programs for the education of young adults who are starting to have children.
Previous efforts to stimulate Jewish education have included gifts by the Wexner Foundation, which provides fellowships for students in Jewish studies courses.
In New York City, the UJA-Federation is for the first time providing grants directly to synagogues to develop new programs, especially for families. It is part of a larger grant plan to develop programs for camps, community centers and students.
The topic of Jewish continuity will also be a major focus of discussions and workshops at the General Assembly of the Council of Jewish Federations, which is to take place next month in Denver. And after years of studying how they could best help Israel, some of the conference participants will try to learn how Israel can help them, as they listen to an address by the Israeli Minister of Education.
"It's part of a broader question of renegotiating the traditional relationship where Israel was the one in need of help and the wealthy diaspora was coming to Israel's aid," Mr. Hoffmann said. "This area is one where there are huge resources of intelligence and spiritual resources in Israel that could be helpful in the training of educators and strengthening the diaspora community."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Challenged Bank Defends Its Derivatives Actions

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation gave its first detailed rebuttal yesterday to the $73 million lawsuit by Gibson Greetings Inc. in connection with losses that the greeting card company took on transactions known as derivatives.
In a reply filed in Federal court in Cincinnati, Bankers Trust argued that Gibson undertook a series of transactions that entailed risk based on the company's opinion that interest rates would remain stable or decline. 
 "Gibson knew it was taking a position as to the direction that interest rates might move and that Gibson would suffer losses if its predictions were wrong," the Bankers Trust papers said.
Gibson filed suit in September contending that the bank had engaged in "deception, cheating and fraud" by luring it into a series of transactions that ultimately lost $23 million. The contracts involved interest-rate swaps, the most common form of the broad category of transactions known as derivatives, which allow companies to switch the interest payments on their debt from a fixed rate to a floating rate or vice versa.
A central point of the suit is that Bankers Trust had a special obligation to look after Gibson's interests and prevent it from doing things that were too risky. Bankers Trust countered yesterday that the derivatives contracts "were arm's-length agreements between sophisticated business entities, involving no advisory or other special relationship."
L. Clifford Craig, the lawyer for Gibson with Taft Stettinius & Hollister in Cincinnati, declined to comment on Bankers Trust's filing.
Under Federal securities laws, brokerage firms have an obligation to see that investments are "suitable" for individual clients, but generally there is no such requirement for corporate or institutional clients.
"Twenty years ago, before swaps or mortgage-backed securities, if you were a corporation, you were automatically assumed to be sophisticated," said Henry T.C. Hu, a law professor at the University of Texas at Austin.
"Now it's not such a binary world," he said. "There is a spectrum of sophistication, and you could imagine a company saying that a product was so complicated that it did not have full knowledge."
In that case, Mr. Hu said, a judge could find that a bank is obligated to determine whether a deal was suitable for a corporate customer. Such a ruling, however, would have wide implications, he said.
Bankers Trust, moreover, contended that it had fully disclosed the nature of the swaps to Gibson. It said that it presented the company with four potential transactions in October 1992. While three of those were "simple swaps of fixed for floating interest rates," Gibson chose the fourth, which involved a complex formula by which the company would gain if rates fell but would have accelerated losses if rates rose.
At the end of 1993, this swap had a negative value of $3.1 million, but because Gibson had received nearly $3 million in cash under the swaps, its net loss was about $200,000 from its derivatives trading, Bankers Trust said.
As interest rates rose unexpectedly in February, the swap lost value rapidly. Bankers Trust said it had offered the company the right to cut its losses at $8 million and again at $13 million, but the company did not act until the losses reached $17 million in early March.
Even at that time, Gibson's chief financial officer, William Flaherty, did not accept the loss, Bankers Trust said. Instead, the bank contends, he chose to engage in a transaction that had the potential for the company to lose an additional $10 million if rates continued to rise but would also enable the company to recoup most of its losses if rates fell. Since then, the company's losses have increased by $5 million, to $23 million.

HEADLINE: D. Bennett Mazur, a Professor And New Jersey Legislator, 69

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
D. Bennett Mazur, who combined service in the New Jersey State Assembly with a career as a professor at Ramapo College, died on Tuesday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck. He was 69.
He died of complications from a stroke he suffered in November 1991, the hospital said. 
 Mr. Mazur was elected to a sixth term in 1991 but suffered a stroke the same day. He was sworn in in January 1992 but was forced to resign a month later because of his illness. Later that year the Legislature passed, and Gov. Jim Florio signed, a bill that Mr. Mazur had sponsored to outlaw discrimination based on sexual orientation.
One of the Assembly's most amiable and popular legislators, Mr. Mazur also sponsored legislation to ban the use of leg-hold traps by hunters and to establish the state's 911 emergency-response system
Born in New York City, Mr. Mazur served as an infantryman in Europe in World War II, winning a Bronze Star and three Purple Hearts after being wounded in action.
He began his political career as a tenant activist after moving to Fort Lee a few years after the war. He served on the Bergen County Board of Freeholders from 1965 to 1967 and again from 1975 to 1980 before winning his first election to the State Assembly the following year. He was a strong advocate of the construction of the Veterans Nursing Home in Paramus and the Bergen County Animal Shelter.
Mr. Mazur served on several boards and commissions, including the Tri-State Regional Planning Commission, the New Jersey Railroad and Transportation Study Commission and the Hudson River Waterfront Planning and Study Commission.
He taught planning and public administration at Ramapo, in Mahwah, for 20 years. Mr. Mazur received a B.S. in economics from Lafayette College, an M.B.A. in economics and finance from Fairleigh Dickinson University and an M.S. and Ph.D. in urban planning and public policy formation from Rutgers University.
He is survived by his wife, the former Betty Greene; their four children, Peter of Princeton, Alexandra and Danielle, both of Manhattan, and Nicole of Australia, and one grandson.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

 BODY:

A Limit for the Dead?
Where have all the Deadheads gone? Concert industry executives are scratching their heads over slow ticket sales for the Grateful Dead's six-night Madison Square Garden stand, which is to begin tonight. As of yesterday, only three concerts had sold out and there were some 5,000 tickets left for each of the other three concerts at the 19,000-seat arena. 
 For almost any other band, this would be considered a successful run. But for the Grateful Dead, who grossed more money than any other touring band last year, it's a shock. The group's concerts have always been a sure thing. The Grateful Dead tour constantly, enjoying strong ticket sales even during periods of recession, and have sold out every show in New York City area in recent memory.
"I never thought I'd live to say this," an executive working on the show said, "but maybe the Grateful Dead have reached their limit this year."
Could it be that Deadheads, who already paid to see the band when it was at Giants Stadium in August, were pumped dry by this summer's high-volume, high-priced concert season? The Grateful Dead's publicity agent, Dennis McNally, said this was part of the reason for the lackluster ticket sales at the Garden. "Ordinarily there's a solid three and half months between our summer and fall shows in New York," he said. "This year, because of the World Cup, we did not get to New York until August. I think that these shows being so close together is 80 percent of the reason."
Bob Grossweiner, the New York bureau chief of Performance, a concert-industry journal, said that the band may also have got overconfident. "They didn't advertise the shows properly," he said, "and a lot of people just assume that Grateful Dead shows will sell out. Also, a lot of people usually buy seats for the whole strip of concerts, and this year the prices, at $30, may be too high."
And that doesn't include the $4-to-$8 service charge.
 
From Lyric to Essay
 "Idle Worship," a new book available only overseas and in Canada, might be worth crossing the border for. It is a collection of essays by writers best known for their songs. Bono of U2 writes an oddly punctuated essay about being "star struck" over Frank Sinatra. The piece includes a behind-the-scenes account of why Bono, who presented Mr. Sinatra with a lifetime achievement award at the Grammys last year, swore during the live broadcast. "Frank heard it and Frank liked it," he writes.
Stephen Malkmus of the alternative-rock band Pavement (which is to perform on Saturday at Roseland) indulges his habit of making elliptical comments that could be interpreted as insults of fellow alternative-rock musicians. In the essay "Vedder as Merton: 2001," he describes a future where U2 has disappeared after switching its charity of choice from Ireland to the Gaza Strip; Mark Eitzel, of American Music Club, and Pearl Jam are involved in a nasty legal battle, and a bitter Eddie Vedder has quit Pearl Jam, become a hermit and taken up the study of Mormon and Shaker history. "Pearl Jam songs are even less catchy than hymns, yet managed to be quite popular in 1993," Mr. Malkmus writes. "Only when melody is the Devil can Stone Temple Pilots be the saviour."
"Idle Worship," which was edited by Chris Roberts, a journalist and musician, also includes a prurient short story by Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth about a young band about to break out of the underground, a sardonic play of sorts by Mark E. Smith of the Fall that lashes out at the bands Therapy? and Soundgarden and an ode to the singer Patti Smith by Kristen Hersh of the Throwing Muses.
 
Loose Notes
 *After wrapping up its tour here, the Grateful Dead are to go into the studio to record their first album of new material since 1989. In the last few years, the band has been working on some 15 new songs in performance, including "Samba in the Rain," "Corinna," "Easy Answers," "If the Shoe Fits" and "Lazy River Road." Also due for release in the spring is a recording from the vaults: a Dead concert in Frankfurt in 1972.
*Both Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center begin their new jazz seasons this week. Carnegie Hall's third Celebration of Jazz series with the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, led by the trumpeter Jon Faddis, is to open tonight with a program of Count Basie music that will buck jazz classicists. It will also include a music and text piece about Basie by the trombonist Dennis Wilson and new arrangements of Basie songs by Slide Hampton and Jim McNeely. At Lincoln Center, the fall-winter series is to begin on Saturday with a Charlie Mingus retrospective that includes early Mingus pieces that haven't been played since the 1940's. The former Mingus sidemen Jimmy Knepper, Charles McPherson and Hamiet Bluiett are scheduled to perform along with some younger players, among them the tenor saxophonists Joe Lovano and James Carter.
*Nirvana is about to return to music-store shelves for the first time since the April suicide of the band's leader, Kurt Cobain. In addition to putting out an album documenting the group's performance on MTV's "Unplugged" show, due Nov. 1, Geffen Records is to release an 83-minute Nirvana video, "Nirvana Live! Tonight! Sold Out!!," on Nov. 15. The video, conceived of by Mr. Cobain, chronicles the band's tour in 1992, after the album "Nevermind" came out. It shows Mr. Cobain bashing a Dallas bouncer over the head with his guitar and eviscerating "Smells Like Teen Spirit" during a performance on the English television show "Top of the Pops."
*Also forthcoming is the first new release since Mr. Cobain's death featuring the former Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl and bassist Krist Novoselic. The pair recently recorded a song, "Against the 70's," with Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam on vocals and Mike Watt, formerly of Firehose and the Minutemen, on bass. This studio session, which is to be on an album of Mr. Watt's collaborations, is probably the source of the rumor that Mr. Grohl was to replace the Pearl Jam drummer Dave Abbruzzesse, who was dismissed from the band last month. (Pearl Jam has denied the rumor.)

HEADLINE: Federal Caller-ID Rule Sparks Privacy Debate

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
IT'S already routine for people who have caller identification: The phone rings and before you pick it up, you can glance at a screen that tells you the telephone number of the person calling. But if the party placing the call does not want to be identified in advance, he or she can enter a special code before dialing your number, three extra strokes that mask the caller's identity.
If you are annoyed by not being able to tell who is calling before you say "hello," you can retaliate. You can tell the phone company that you refuse all such calls; then, the anonymous caller will hear a recording stating that your phone won't ring for unidentifiable callers. 
 Caller ID is now available only for calls that originate and end in the same state, but beginning in April, if the Federal Communications Commission has its way, it will work with calls placed between states.
There is a glitch, though. Utility regulators in about two dozen states, including New York, say the F.C.C.'s plan to expand caller ID infringes on the privacy of callers, and they have asked the commission to rewrite its rule. They propose to allow people to mask their identities automatically on all calls, rather than call by call, a system adopted by many states. Privacy experts and advocates for victims of domestic violence are backing this position.
The F.C.C., however, says that allowing businesses to identify callers will help commerce and economic development. It also says the nation needs uniform rules from state to state.
The result is a debate that would have been unimaginable a few years ago, when finding out who was calling meant saying into the receiver, "Who is this?" If the Federal Government does not reconsider its position soon, California is promising to argue against it in Federal court, and New York has said it may join the suit.
Caller ID is already available in most states. What the F.C.C. rule does is to order the three big long-distance carriers, AT&T, Sprint and MCI, to make their caller information available to local phone companies beginning in April, so they can tell their caller ID customers who the caller is, even if the call is long distance.
"We felt caller ID basically was in the public interest," Rosemary Kimball, a spokeswoman for the commission, said last week. With caller ID, for instance, a bank could let its customers handle more business over the phone, because it would have greater assurance of the identity of the caller. A manufacturer of, say, vacuum cleaners that placed an advertisement in a national newspaper would be able to direct callers to the nearest dealership without the shopper ever having to say where home was. A catalogue merchant could quickly call up data from its computer that would indicate the status of a caller's account even before the sales representative answered.
Caller ID, combined with computer software that provides addresses, would allow a pizzeria to check that the call for 16 large anchovy pies to be delivered to a certain address wasn't coming from a prankster across town.
State utility commissions, which regulate local phone companies, have generally agreed that caller ID can be useful, but they have also declared that privacy is in the public interest. Mark Fogelman, a lawyer at the California Public Utility Commission, said caller ID now exists in 48 states and the District of Columbia -- only Alaska and Hawaii don't have it -- and some form of the service that blocks caller ID is available in 41 states.
In 25 states, Mr. Fogelman said, consumers who choose can block caller ID on all calls from their line, whether they subscribe to caller ID or not.
"It seems ridiculous and unnecessarily costly to require that those states unroll the existing options," he said.
Regulators say that just because a telephone subscriber wants to dial another person or a business, it does not necessarily follow that that subscriber wants to let the person or business have his phone number. A person with an unlisted number, for example, might see a television advertisment for a miracle vegetable slicer and call the 800 number promptly to get the Ginsu knife free, but might not want to give the marketing firm his phone number. (Caveat emptor: caller ID has been standard equipment on 800 and 900 numbers for some years.)
In most states, callers can mask themselves and block caller ID by dialing "* 67" before each call, often for no charge. But if they forget to use this code each time, they lose their anonymity.
To a victim of domestic violence, or even a person arguing with a merchant from his home telephone, masking a call may be important. But Peter A. Bradford, the chairman of the New York Public Service Commission, said in June: "Per-call blocking represents the worst of all worlds. The harassing caller is unlikely to forget to use per-call blocking."
In a letter to Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Bradford wrote: "For every consumer who believes that this technology will allow them to let unwanted calls go unanswered, another (perhaps a family violence center, a probation officer or a psychiatrist) fears inadvertently disclosing a home telephone number to someone threatening."
Advocates for victims of domestic violence are particularly worried. Sigrid Hammond, a volunteer at Family Matters, a group in Saratoga, N.Y., that assists victims of domestic violence, said the caller might be a battered wife calling her husband from a shelter but not wanting him to be able to find her, or a child in such a family calling his father without realizing he was giving away his location.
Worse, Ms. Hammond said, is that the "* 67" command has different functions on different telephones. In New York and many other states, if the telephone subscriber chooses per-call masking, then "* 67" blocks a single call. But if the subscriber has chosen to have all calls masked, the "* 67" turns the masking off for a single call.
A telephone customer in her own home may find it easy to keep straight, Ms. Hammond said, but what about a battered woman who flees with her children to a friend's house, and then maybe a parent's house, and then a shelter, in the space of a few days?
Ms. Hammond said she was disappointed by the F.C.C.'s decision. "There's obviously a lot of financial interest in this," Ms. Hammond continued. "But it's not an interest that represents Mr. and Mrs. Simple Citizen who just want to have a telephone, and don't want the world to have some new access to their home that they didn't have before."
Of course, advocates point out, Mr. and Mrs. Simple Citizen can get in the game relatively inexpensively themselves; a caller ID device that works with existing phones can be bought for as little as $30 and is included on some newer phones. The monthly service fee is fairly low; in New York it is $6.50 a month, unless it is bought as a package with other telephone services, in which case it is even less.
The F.C.C. believes it is protecting privacy adequately. Its rule bars companies that have gathered data through caller ID from reselling that data without the caller's permission. So for example, the company that advertises the vacuum cleaners cannot sell its list of customers' phone numbers to a life-insurance company. And long-distance carriers must tell their customers that their phone numbers can be learned by people they call, the F.C.C. has ruled.
In theory, the F.C.C.'s jurisdiction is over interstate calls only. But many state officials say that Federal policy will prevail over all calls, because the phone companies are not equipped to give per-line masking on intrastate calls at the same time that they give only per-call masking on the interstate ones. California, however, is exploring whether it can require per-line masking in the state even if the Federal Government forbids it interstate.
What the states really want, though, is a Federal policy that defers to the rules of the state from which the call is placed.
And the states are not giving up. Mr. Bradford, of the New York Public Service Commission, has an approach that has won him some allies. Caller ID reduces the value of an unlisted phone number, he argues, because it often results in the customer inadvertently disclosing his number. Therefore, he argues, telephone companies should not be allowed to continue to charge for unlisted numbers.
In New York State, about 34 percent of phone numbers are unlisted, and the company Nynex charges $1.95 a month for this service. Costs are small, and revenues come to millions of dollars a month. For several reasons, probably including that one, Nynex is backing New York State's position against the F.C.C.

HEADLINE: What About Dismissals As Shows Must Go On?

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
In a what may be a harbinger of tougher theatrical labor negotiations, the producers of several Broadway shows have pressured the stagehands union into cutting small numbers of backstage workers in recent months, and then have changed their shows slightly to cover the cuts.
Thus far, the changes are probably invisible to audiences -- a spotlight here, a prop there -- but the pattern of cuts that seems to be emerging is angering stagehands. 
 Individually, the producers, who have long complained about the costs of putting on Broadway shows, say they are not acting in concert; it's only a coincidence that so many shows are asking for givebacks virtually simultaneously, they say. But the union's two new business agents wonder if their mettle is being tested.
Each stagehand cut, producers say, saves a show $1,200 to $1,500 a week: $804 basic salary plus overtime, benefits and payroll taxes.
In the last few months, these cuts have been made from shows:
*"Damn Yankees": one spotlight operator and one stage electrician.
*"Tommy": two spotlight operators.
*"Crazy for You": one spotlight operator.
*"Guys and Dolls": two spotlight operators have been dismissed and the producers are trying to get rid of four more stagehands. To do so, they will have to relight the show, drop some tables from the Hot Box Nightclub dance numbers and convert some automated scenery to painted backdrops in a scene in which Sky Masterson takes Sarah Brown to Havana. The union is fighting the cuts.
In the past, the stagehands union, Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, has gone along with occasional trims from shows that were faltering financially. Union-producer relations are fairly amiable; in 108 years, there has never been a strike or a lockout.
"But this is definitely out of the normal: they've never done it in this vein before," said Ronald Lynch, a union business agent. "You used to get it once a season, when a show was on its last legs, that they wanted to cut someone. Not like this."
Stagehands say they wonder whether several events are working against them: Local 1's powerful longtime business agent, Robert McDonald, retired in May and producers may be testing his replacements, Mr. Lynch and Alan Myers. Also, the union's contract with the League of American Theaters and Producers expires on July 31, 1995; two sides in union negotiations often try a little early swaggering. And, third, a younger generation of independent producers has come to Broadway and is hinting at tougher tactics.
Under the union contract, a stagehand cannot be cut from a show unless whatever equipment he or she operates -- the spotlight, the prop or the sound equipment -- is cut, too.
All the shows involved are long-running productions struggling with declining audiences.
Labor differences aside, can audiences tell the difference? So far, probably not (except the diehard fans who see the same show repeatedly). If "Guys and Dolls" succeeds in changing its Havana set, though, the difference may be more apparent.
David F. Segal was asked to return to "Damn Yankees" and relight with one fewer spotlight and one fewer rolling bank of lights in the Act II "Who's Got the Pain?" mambo scene.
"It's an unfortunate reality," Mr. Segal said, "but you're not going to hear a sob story from me. My assistant and I spent two weeks -- paid -- relighting, and I insisted that the choreographer sit next to me, and I said 'O.K., Rob, who's in the dark?' and fixed it. No one's being cheated. It isn't what opened, I'm sorry to say. But it's still fabulous."
Chris Parry, who won a Tony for his lighting of "Tommy," was asked to relight it with four spotlights instead of six.
"They were backstage lights used mainly to give Tommy a specific aura," Mr. Parry said. "I liked the version we had. But when a producer asks you to relight, I don't see that there's much you can do but acquiesce."
The producers involved say that cutting two or three people from a payroll keeps 120 others working, and add that artistically the shows are substantially unchanged. "If you saw the two side by side, you could tell," said Sherman Warner, a producer of "Guys and Dolls."
"Is it what Jerry Zaks or Tony Walton would have agreed to in the first place?" he said of the show's director and scenic designer. "Probably not. But it still leaves the Broadway show substantially larger than the road company, which got spectacular reviews."
The dismissed employees are, naturally, unhappy. "A couple of salaries aren't going to save a show in trouble," said Jess Ferrara, whose electrician's job was eliminated from "Damn Yankees." (Although, since the union controls hiring, he later replaced a carpenter who left the show.)
Backstage employees at "Damn Yankees" particularly resent recent cuts because, they say, a friend of the producer was in effect added to the payroll at the same time as two stagehands were dropped to save money.
Nancy Ticotin, who lives with Mitchell Maxwell, the show's lead producer, was in the show's chorus and understudied the role of Lola, the seductress. She danced and sang the part from Sept. 4, when Bebe Neuwirth left, to Sept. 20, when Charlotte d'Amboise took it over. Since then, she has remained the understudy -- drawing that salary -- but refused to return to the chorus, so another actress had to be hired.
Mr. Mitchell defended that decision recently. The show still got standing ovations with Ms. Ticotin, he said, and using an understudy during the two-week gap saved tens of thousands of dollars that costuming a new Lola and rehearsing her with the cast would have cost. And since she will be leaving soon to work on a movie, keeping her on the payroll briefly while a new understudy is rehearsed makes economic sense, he argued.
"If I kept Nancy as a standby for a year, that would not be a good business decision," he said. "But it's only going to be for six weeks."
The lead producers of the shows involved say they are not in league to soften up the union.
"No other producers came to me," said Roger Horchow, the producer of "Crazy for You," his first show. "I live in Dallas, Tex. I only know one other producer."
The other two shows, "Tommy" and "Guys and Dolls," are produced by Dodger Productions, an affiliation of Mr. Warner, Michael David and Ed Strong.
"It's not orchestrated," Mr. Warner said. "If it sends a message about next summer's negotiations, that's all to the good. But that was not in the plan."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Among the Small Skirmishes, War Still Rages

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
Major league club owners and striking baseball players are expected to beckon each other to the negotiating table by next week at the latest. What they will find there will most likely be the same old issues and probably the same old stances.
What they might also find, though, is a possible source of relief emanating from Washington. For yesterday, rumblings of efforts to renew talks were accompanied by rumblings that the executive branch might try to spur the two sides to resume efforts to settle what has become the longest work stoppage in the history of professional sports. 
 An official familiar with Washington's interest in the situation says some activity could be imminent, and if so, it would not be the first time Washington has been interested in the labor wranglings of a sport that was shut down by a players strike Aug. 12. Congress considered but failed to act on legislation that would have either tinkered with the owners' antitrust exemption or threatened binding arbitration if players and owners couldn't come to solutions on their own.
And Federal mediators entered the fray in late August, managing to engineer two negotiating sessions in a sport in which only four formal sessions have been held during the strike, the last back on Sept. 9.
President Clinton as well as Robert Reich, the Secretary of Labor, have also implored both sides to settle. But their efforts have mostly ended with pleas as well as continued offers to make the Federal mediators available if both sides so desired.
Those mediators were unable to keep the parties at the table. The two sides couldn't even do that themselves last month, even as the owners' self-imposed date to cancel the World Series was reached and remaining regular-season games as well as the post-season were eventually canceled on Sept. 14.
No movement or formal initiatives have taken place since. Yes, Donald Fehr, the head of the players union, has held informal discussions with owners, specifically Peter Angelos of the Baltimore Orioles and Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies. But their involvement did not signal a change in the core issues or the owners' positions.
Still, the fact that the two parties are seeking a return to the table spurred intrigue, if not cautious optimism, yesterday. There wasn't a hint of compromise, mind you. But, as Bud Selig, the acting commissioner and owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, succinctly pointed out, if the two sides don't meet, there isn't even a reason to hope for a settlement. "If we're meeting, at least there's discussion," Selig said.
It's not really all people could ask at this point, but it's something. And providing something, anything, isn't merely for appearance's sake any more. Players and owners have come to realize that they are more in need of answers now then they were when the final 52 days of the season were dropping off the calendar. And the reason is the uncertainty surrounding off-season courting rituals.
What to do with player contracts is the topic of the day. And there could be informal talks between the two sides on the owners' proposal to freeze off-season signings until Nov. 15 as early as today.
Still, negotiating sessions on the larger economic issues probably won't take place until next week because of scheduling difficulties, mainly because Fehr spent part of this week touring Latin America to brief players. The availability of McMorris is also a key because the Rockies' owner remains the primary figure in the informal as well as formal talks.
The informal talks between Fehr and the owners have naturally fueled talk of disgruntlement on management's part. But Selig and the owners' chief negotiator, Richard Ravitch, dismiss such talk. The deal, Ravitch said, will ultimately come at the bargaining table. It will, Ravitch said, "because the owners have not budged from their view that there are problems in the game that must be addressed."
Players aren't putting much stock in rumors of owner unrest, either. "As far as I'm concerned, the guy who speaks for the clubs is Bud Selig," said Gene Orza, the associate general counsel of the Major League Baseball Players Association. "And the last time I heard, Bud was still wedded to a salary cap."
As for the possibility of wavering on the players' part, Orza said that's even less of a possibility. "The clubs knew when they proposed a salary cap there was only one way to get it and that was to break the union," he said. "So we're exactly where I thought we would be and where I think we will be in March, unless a ray of light infuses a greater number of club officials."
This gap represents the reality owners, players and perhaps Washington will face next week. The larger war still rages. Smaller skirmishes over issues of the signing ban and its possible implementation loom. That does not suggest that the cooling-off period both sides now see coming to an end doesn't necessarily mean a warming in relations. The opposite could be true.
But, as Selig says, at least another effort will be made. By this time next week, maybe all involved will know if that effort accomplished more good than harm. If it's the former, it would truly be a development that would be welcome for a game much in need of a good turn or two.
