HEADLINE: Essay;
What's With Assad?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I spotted Shimon Peres, the Israeli Foreign Minister, on a flight to L.A. last week and plunked myself down in the seat next to him.
How did he explain the latest polls in Israel that show the opposition leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, running neck-and-neck with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin? A fast man with an aphorism, Peres replied: "Polls are like perfume -- nice to smell, dangerous to swallow." 
 That playful parrying was O.K. because the answer is apparent: (1) inflation under the Labor Government is over 14 percent; (2) Rabin's answer is a cockamamie capital gains tax, undermining much-needed investment; (3) the P.L.O. is unable to restrain the murders and kidnappings of Israelis by its rival Hamas, and (4) Syria's dictator, Hafez al-Assad, wants every inch of the Golan Heights before granting Israel the favor of peace.
What's with Assad? I asked.
Sometimes a non-penetrating question draws a revealing response. "Assad may miss again the boat," ruminated Peres. "He waited 17 years for nothing, and now he thinks he should be paid for it. He thinks if he waits, he'll get more, as if the Americans could deliver Israel. He's afraid to bargain because he's worried he may not get the best bargain. He thinks his comment that he is for peace was a great concession and we have to pay for it, and we're not impressed."
Let's assume that is a dovish diplomat talking tough in the hope of turning up the heat under a frigid interlocutor. From other sources, both in and out of touch with the Syrians, I get this assessment of what's with Assad:
1. For all his reputation for shrewdness, he has outsmarted and isolated himself. Egypt's Anwar el-Sadat, despised by Assad, got "every inch" of land back; Assad, 17 years later, finds it painful to settle for less. The penniless Yasir Arafat went into negotiations without Syria; that in turn gave the hungry King of Jordan leave to negotiate a peace treaty with Israel, even as it encouraged the Saudis to ease the boycott. Assad is standing on the platform watching the train of Arab leadership leave the station.
2. Accordingly, he is dropping hints of flexibility. His controlled TV shows King Hussein in Israel; his Foreign Minister gives an interview to Israeli journalists. His negotiators, who demanded a first-phase negotiation lasting only six months after a token Israeli withdrawal from the Golan, now agree to one year, a concession extracted by Secretary Warren Christopher.
3. At the same time, he positions himself for a classic double-cross. Damascus remains the capital of terrorism. Assad has conquered Lebanon and does not trouble its Hezbollah. He is adding to his force of 4,200 modern tanks, and is buying missiles from North Korea and other weaponry from Russia. If fundamentalists take over in Egypt and Assad's allies in Iran buy or develop a nuclear bomb, Syria could lead the Arabs into a Mideast Armageddon.
Taken together with his need for economic sponsors to replace the Russians, these omnidirectional tugs suggest the Israelis are wise to try to reach a territorial compromise with Syria, but would be foolhardy to totally abandon the Golan -- a military position that cries out to be shared, offering security to both nations.
Secretary Christopher, at his best as a shuttling lawyer, spends six hours closely analyzing each point with the suspicious Assad for every hour he spends with the forthright Israeli leader.
What's with Rabin? He is willing to negotiate ultimate total withdrawal in return for a "warm peace," with a force of 1,000 Americans permanently stationed on the heights to guarantee against a surprise attack. (Thirty Israeli troops are on their way to Haiti, as a kind of advance repayment.) Honorably, Rabin -- who promised not to take this gamble -- is prepared to ask Israelis to ratify such an agreement in an unprecedented referendum. A regular election beforehand would be better.
Rabin's motive is noble, and his military career gives his strategic judgment weight. But I think Americans on a Syrian Golan would be a mistake, as is the current positioning of Americans in the Egyptian Sinai; Israel should not rely on another nation's monitors for its defense, and America should make its interventions decisive and brief.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Arts Groups Should Avoid Lobbying for Corporate Sponsors;
Yet More Jobs Lost

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For several days I've watched a parade of civic leaders stepping over themselves, huffing and puffing over Philip Morris's threat to leave New York if the City Council passes new smoking restrictions. Is the company's attitude so hard to understand?
What Philip Morris is saying is that if the Council uses flawed science to justify legislative grandstanding, the company might just take the hint and go elsewhere. 
 It's time to think about the negative impact of Intro 232 on the local economy. This ill-conceived bill imperils hundreds of jobs that rely on revenue generated by tobacco. How ironic that it is being considered when some are working to bolster the city's shaky employment base.
Council members should become familiar with the facts before passing a law that will damage the city's economy without benefiting public health.
 
JOEL J. SHERMAN
New York, Oct. 10, 1994
 
The writer is president of Nat Sherman Inc., tobacconists.

HEADLINE: High-Level Dispute On Who Will Redo Health Care Policy

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
As the White House regroups to devise health care proposals for the next Congress, a dispute has broken out within the Administration over the future role of Ira C. Magaziner, the chief architect of President Clinton's ill-fated health plan.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, has been discussing ideas for a new policy-making process in which Mr. Magaziner's responsibilities would be reduced. But Administration officials said Mr. Magaziner was lobbying to keep a major role, with some support from one extremely influential patron, Hillary Rodham Clinton. 
 Mr. Magaziner supervised a beehive of more than 500 people who developed Mr. Clinton's health plan last year. And as the battle over health care played out, he puzzled many Washingtonians. In public speeches, Mr. Magaziner, a soft-spoken Rhodes scholar, seemed diffident and self-effacing. But co-workers, members of Congress and lobbyists said he could also be intellectually arrogant. He anguished over criticism of his work, but did not seem to know how to rebut it.
A business-strategy consultant in Rhode Island before he joined the White House staff in January 1993, Mr. Magaziner often described himself as an outsider with no experience in Washington. Many people agreed with him after seeing the complex health plan he drew up. Indeed, he was said to lack a sense of what was politically possible in a process that was deeply political.
Under the most likely new arrangements, White House officials said, health care proposals would be developed through a more conventional process managed by the National Economic Council and the Domestic Policy Council, with a larger role for people who have more experience in Washington.
Mr. Magaziner will be involved in the process, White House officials said, but will not necessarily be in charge. Lorrie McHugh, a White House spokeswoman, said today that Mr. Magaziner, a member of the Domestic Policy Council, would "still be part of the health care effort." Another White House official said, "Ira's role will be different, but he will be integrally involved."
A third official, who is eager to reduce Mr. Magaziner's role, said: "He's a symbol of what went wrong. That may be unfair, but it's a fact."
Mr. Clinton said on Friday that he intended to "come back full force" with fresh proposals to control health costs and make health insurance available to more people next year. By all accounts, Republicans are expected to gain seats in the midterm elections, so the political challenge for the President will be formidable. Lawmakers and lobbyists predict that the next Congress will take an incremental approach to health care, pursuing changes much more modest than those initially proposed by the President.
Mr. Magaziner, a longtime friend of the Clintons, has told people inside and outside the Government that he expects to play a role in shaping any scaled-back proposals for health care that might emerge from the White House next year. But Ms. McHugh said Mr. Magaziner was not available to discuss his role in policy making.
An aide to Mrs. Clinton said: "Some people think we should start anew, get rid of Ira and make a clean start. But the President and the First Lady still respect his judgment and have trust in his policy sense. That doesn't mean he would lead, initiate or direct the process, but I don't think they have any intention of asking him to step aside. You don't throw the baby out with the bath water."
Other officials at the White House, the Treasury and the Department of Health and Human Services, Democrats in Congress, Congressional aides and outside experts on health policy are lobbying for the selection of someone else to run the Administration's health-policy operation.
"They ought to make Ira Magaziner the Ambassador to Kazakhstan," said Alain C. Enthoven, a professor at Stanford University who has occasionally advised the Administration on health policy.
A friend of Mrs. Clinton, who has worked with her for years on social policy questions, said the First Lady "wants Ira to press the effort on health care reform again." But the friend, who has worked inside the Administration, said she herself had received calls from White House officials asking her to intercede and emphasize the need for new faces.
Republican members of Congress and candidates for Congress are less diplomatic. They invoke Mr. Magaziner's name as a political epithet when disparaging what they describe as "Clinton care." Senator Judd Gregg, a conservative Republican from New Hampshire, said "utopian elitism" ran through the work of Mr. Magaziner and Mrs. Clinton.
Representative Jim McDermott, the Washington State Democrat who advocated a "single payer" health plan financed with taxes, said: "The Administration should search for a new leader of its health care reform effort. Ira had a good shot, a full shot. He had two years. I have no doubt of his intellectual capacity. But he simply doesn't have what it takes to put this effort together and get it done. Once you have failed and everybody has seen you fail, it will be harder to get people to follow you in the future."
Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said: "We have heard that Mr. Magaziner is trying to resurrect himself as the chief policy guru in the health area over there. In response to inquiries from my staff, that has not been denied by people in the Administration."
While Mr. Magaziner is closely identified with the Clinton plan, some people say it is unfair to hold him responsible. They say Mr. Magaziner has become a scapegoat because Democrats find it easier to criticize him than to criticize the President or Mrs. Clinton.
Lawrence O'Donnell Jr., who worked with the White House as staff director of the Senate Finance Committee, said: "Ira came up with a construction that would not work in the real world. But that's never been ground for condemnation in Washington. All his ideas were approved by the President and Mrs. Clinton. There's no way Ira could just ram his ideas through the White House and the Administration."
While acknowledging some mistakes, Mr. Magaziner has defended his work on the President's health plan. "Conventional wisdom is that the President and his Administration overreached, proposing a radical, big-Government, grandiose plan hatched by policy wonks with political tin ears," he wrote recently. In fact, he said, important elements of the Clinton plan were also found in bills offered by moderate Democrats and Republicans.
In 1984, Mr. Magaziner was the chief architect of a $248 million industrial development plan for Rhode Island. He wanted to use state policies and subsidies to nurture promising industries. The plan was overwhelmingly rejected by voters in a referendum that, in ways, foreshadowed the debate over the Government's role in health care.
White House officials say Mr. Clinton's next health care proposal will probably emphasize cost controls and will be included in his budget request, prepared by the Office of Management and Budget. Big Presidential initiatives are customarily included in the budget, but last year was an exception because the health plan was not ready when Mr. Clinton sent his budget and economic proposals to Congress in February.
Alice M. Rivlin, the new budget director, is an expert on health policy. She serves on both the National Economic Council and the Domestic Policy Council.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 18, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about President Clinton's fall political strategy referred incorrectly in some editions to his standard campaign speech. It indeed mentions the failed attempt to enact sweeping health care legislation: it says Republican lawmakers thwarted the effort.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: LONG ISLAND;
Cuomo Suggests State Buy Lilco, And Utility Is Considering Offer

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, locked in a fierce re-election battle, proposed yesterday to have the state buy the Long Island Lighting Company. The company said it would seriously consider the offer, which would cost the state about $9 billion.
Mr. Cuomo, speaking at a news conference in Mineola, L.I., asserted that a state takeover would lower electric rates for Lilco customers -- who pay among the highest rates in the country -- by about 10 percent, or $250 million a year. He said the savings would come through elimination of shareholder dividends and Federal taxes and through lower capital costs. 
 Industry analysts said they believed that if the deal went through, it would be the first time any state successfully acquired a major utility. The cost of the takeover includes about $2 billion for the company's stock and about $7 billion for its debt, state officials said.
Lilco, which lost a bitter, decades-long fight to open the Shoreham nuclear power plant, has long been the object of ratepayers' scorn, and criticizing the company has often been a useful political tool for candidates in search of Long Islanders' votes. But Mr. Cuomo denied that the dramatic announcement was in any way tied to Election Day, a little more than three weeks away.
"If you want to excite people's political curiosity and suggest to them, 'Maybe this is all political,' maybe you ought to make clear that the test of whether this is desirable is not whether this is good or bad for any of the candidates but what you, the ratepayers, get for it," Mr. Cuomo said. "If it works out the way I think it works out, it will be an excellent deal for the public."
Mr. Cuomo's Republican challenger, State Senator George E. Pataki, issued a statement yesterday evening saying that while he had not seen the details of the plan, "for him to act on this issue three weeks before an election is the height of political opportunism."
"Certainly," he added, "Mario Cuomo's motivation is not good government -- but politics."
Mr. Cuomo said state officials had sent a letter to William J. Catacosinos, Lilco's chairman, offering $21.50 a share to stockholders for their common stock, or about 25 percent more than it is now worth. Lilco common stock closed yesterday at $16.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, unchanged from the day before. The Governor's announcement came after the close of trading.
The takeover would be financed through tax-exempt bonds issued by the Long Island Power Authority, the state agency that oversaw the decommissioning of Shoreham. Lilco would then be operated by another state agency, the New York State Power Authority, the Governor said. But he said no deal would be made if in the end it could not be demonstrated that ratepayers would save money.
The deal is subject to approval by the boards of the state authorities and by Lilco's board. Suzanne Halpin, a Lilco spokeswoman, said that Mr. Catacosinos, the chairman, had received the offer yesterday afternoon and that the utility's board would mull it over in the near future. "The Lilco board will evaluate the proposal and will be seeking to receive more details about it," she said, declining further comment.
When asked who would need to approve the deal, Mr. Cuomo said that the Long Island Power Authority already had the authority to issue the bonds but that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Justice Department would also have to give their assent.
Dan Scotto, a utility analyst for Bear Stearns, said the Governor's proposal had no precedent. "We've never seen a state come in and try to take over a major utility," he said.
He said it would be important for the state to come up with a long-term plan to bring down the operating costs of the utility so that it could indicate to the financial community that Lilco would remain viable under state control. "They will have to develop a broad plan to show how Lilco is going to survive," he said.
The notion of a state takeover of Lilco has long been a topic of debate on Long Island, particularly at the height of the fight over the Shoreham plant, which many had fought to keep from operating because of fear that the Island could not be safely evacuated in the event of a nuclear accident. Several years ago, state officials made an offer to buy the utility, but it was not considered a serious offer because it was for less than the book value of Lilco's stock.
Mr. Cuomo said a combination of factors, including the increasing amount of competition among utilities and what he described as a change in attitude among Lilco's top officials, had made this the right time for such an offer. "I say this is a different time because the utility outlook has changed in the very recent past as a result of this new push for competition that they never had to deal with before," he said.
Some veterans of the fight over Lilco welcomed the Governor's proposal.
"It's encouraging news," said Nora Bredes, a Suffolk County legislator and a former trustee of the Long Island Power Authority. "I think the Long Island economy is in large part depressed because of Lilco's high rates. It is very hard to attract business when you have such inordinately high electric rates."
But others questioned the need for such an action.
Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, said other less ambitious approaches might be tried to reduce rates. He said, for instance, that changes in the Federal regulation of utilities allow customers to buy cheaper power from other producers and pay a transmission fee to their local utility.
"There are other alternatives that have to be considered," he said. "The concept of taking over Lilco is something that has been discussed for over a decade, and before the Long Island Power Authority was created."
As far as the expense of buying Lilco, the Governor has made the offer at a time when Lilco stock is trading at far below its historic trading range. Lilco stock has been dropping since it reached a high of $28.75 in August of 1993 and struck a low of $16.125 on Sept. 23 of this year.
Lilco stock, like that of electric utilities across the country, has been depressed by competitive pressures. Mr. Scotto, the analyst, said a reason for the drop was that Lilco became caught up in the uncertainty of how the state and its utilities were going to grapple with the problem of rising rates. In addition, experts say, utility stocks generally do not do well in periods of rising interest rates because utilities need a great amount of capital and must borrow at the higher rates.
Lilco's net income in 1993 was $296 million, down from $302 million in 1992 and $305 million the year before that.
As a public entity, the state would not have to pay dividends to shareholders. Last year, Lilco declared dividends of $1.76 a common share, or about $197.2 million. That came to about 6.8 percent of revenues, which were $2.88 billion. The state, however, would probably be faced with the same bills for fuel for its power plants, which in 1993 was $828 million, and with similar labor costs. The company employs 6,500 people.
The state would also have to pay dividends on preferred stock, which came to $56 million last year -- unless the state bought the preferred shares, too.
How the state might fare at running the Island's electric system is not clear. New York State's own utility, the Power Authority, has had management problems at both its nuclear power plants. One of the plants, Indian Point 3, has been shut for more than a year and a half.
Lilco's electricity supply in 1993 was 33 percent oil, 19 percent gas, 7 percent nuclear from its share of the Nine Mile Point 2 reactor, which is operated by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and is near Oswego -- and 41 percent purchased from other producers.
Lilco serves about 1.01 million electric customers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens. The electric service territory is 1,230 square miles, with a population of about 2.7 million. The company also serves about 442,000 customers with natural gas.
State ownership would also eliminate Lilco's tax payments to the Federal Government, but not state and local property taxes. Lilco reported in its 1993 annual report that it owed $6.3 million in Federal taxes and had deferred payment of an additional $178.5 million.
The 1986 legislation that created the Long Island Power Authority specified that if it ever took over Lilco, the authority would have to make payments in lieu of taxes to local governments and payments to the state equal to the taxes that Lilco would have paid. In 1993, Lilco paid $385.8 million in state and local taxes.
Mr. Cuomo told the news conference that one of the advantages of the buyout was that those Long Islanders who have complained for so long about Lilco will no longer have to deal with the company. "Are there any downsides?" he asked. "I don't see any." He added that bringing the state in would mean "a new accountability" for the utility.
"You can make demands on it and it has to respond to you," the Governor said.
To some Long Islanders, Mr. Cuomo's offer sounded good. Steven R. Quigley, a swimming instructor from Bayville, said he liked the idea of giving the public more say over rates. "The state would be breaking up a monopoly, breaking up some of its power," he said. "They can decide what they want to charge and we are powerless to stop them."
But others did not believe the takeover would benefit consumers. "I'm not sure that if the government purchases the utility, it will necessarily keep the price down," said Linda Watson, another Bayville resident. "I'm really for more privately-owned companies rather than more government."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Says Connecticut Broke Truce

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Still smarting from the Swiss Bank Corporation's decision to accept incentives to move from New York City to Connecticut, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would begin aggressively trying to woo businesses out of Connecticut.
Mr. Giuliani and his Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, John S. Dyson, said the city would no longer abide by a 1991 agreement reached between Connecticut, New Jersey and New York State to avoid bidding wars over one another's businesses and jobs. 
 The officials said that Connecticut already violated the agreement last month by persuading Swiss Bank to build a new North American headquarters in downtown Stamford, in what Mr. Dyson called "a shameless raid."
Mr. Giuliani's announcement came a day after the General Assembly in Hartford voted overwhelmingly to pass legislation approving the state's $120 million package of tax breaks and incentives for the bank, which is based in Zurich. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is scheduled to sign the legislation today, a spokesman said yesterday.
At Mr. Dyson's instigation, the Giuliani administration took out large display ads in three Connecticut newspapers on Sunday denouncing the incentives for Swiss Bank as overly generous and costly for taxpapers -- partly in the hope of blocking final approval of the deal and sending a warning for the future.
With the approval now certain, the Mayor and Mr. Dyson said they would begin talks with corporations in Connecticut on incentives to relocate in New York City. They declined to specify the companies, but Mr. Dyson said that about 10 had already called his office after seeing his telephone number in the ads.
"If you start a border war, you don't really give us much choice but to fight back," Mr. Dyson said, appearing with the Mayor at City Hall. "New Yorkers are not widely considered to be patty-cakes."
Officials in Connecticut said yesterday that the state had no intention of making a policy of bidding against New York for businesses. But they accused the Mayor's office of misrepresenting the situation, since they said Swiss Bank had approached Connecticut, rather than the other way around. They said that if the city wanted a border war, Connecticut would fight and win its share of battles.
Joseph M. Cohen, a spokesman for Connecticut's Department of Economic Development, accused the Giuliani administration of amateurism by using "increasingly nasty rhetoric" and warned that a fight over corporations could hurt the economy of the entire region.
"Connecticut is a lot more cost-effective, has a higher quality of life and is more business friendly," Mr. Cohen said yesterday. "That is not to say New York City isn't one of the great places in the world for businesses to be located. It simply wasn't the choice for Swiss Bank."
Then, tweaking back, he added, "Rather than behave like pimply-faced freshmen, New York City should show the class of a sophisticated senior."
The skirmish came as Mr. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city had offered $15 million in tax breaks and incentives to Viacom Inc., the entertainment and communications giant, to keep its headquarters and 4,450 jobs in New York City for at least 15 more years.
After Viacom's recent acquisition of Paramount Communications Inc., Viacom had considered moving at least some of its office and studio space to New Jersey, Mr. Giuliani said.
The Mayor said the incentives that Viacom received were similar to those offered to six companies over the first 10 months of his administration to retain a total of 30,000 jobs -- more, he said, than the total jobs retained in the four years under Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Under Mr. Giuliani, however, the city has lost two major corporations: Swiss Bank, which plans to move 1,300 of its 1,500 jobs now in Manhattan by 1998, and Mastercard International, which announced in July that it would move its headquarters and 540 jobs to Westchester County.
Mr. Dyson said that the city's packages of incentives, which usually involve energy credits and exemptions from sales and business taxes, varied from case to case, but generally equaled about $10,000 for each job retained.
By comparison, he said, Connecticut offered Swiss Bank about $60,000 a job, though Mr. Cohen said that the incentives would not come out of taxpayers' pockets but out of tax revenue expected to be generated by the bank.
Mr. Giuliani said that until now, the city's efforts had focused on retaining jobs, particularly during the economic downturn of the late 1980's and early 1990's, when corporations sought to grow smaller or move. He said the city had already begun efforts to attract businesses from other parts of the United States and from abroad.
Mr. Dyson said the city would continue to honor the 1991 agreement not to entice businesses from New Jersey, an accord that Mr. Giuliani has publicly reaffirmed with his fellow Republican, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.
"We never had an acquisition policy, as compared to a retention one," Mr. Dyson said. "But now that Connecticut has refused to honor our good neighbor policy, we have no choice."
Mayor Stanley J. Esposito of Stamford, which has praised celebrated Swiss Bank's relocation as a boon for its downtown, said that economic development was important to every city. But he considered New York City's response unsportsmanlike.
"You win some and you lose some," Mr. Esposito said. "In this particular case, it turned out well for Stamford and Connecticut."

HEADLINE: THREATS IN THE GULF: THE DIPLOMACY;
Russia and Iraq Work Out Plan to Ease Gulf Tension

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 13

 BODY:
As the United States lobbied hard for a new Security Council resolution to deter Iraq from repeating its recent threatening military moves, Iraq and Russia announced tonight in Baghdad that they had reached an agreement that would lead to Iraqi recognition of Kuwait.
The Iraqi concession, which would also recognize Kuwait's borders as demarcated by the United Nations, would be linked to the lifting of some of the international sanctions now imposed on Iraq within six months. 
 The accord was reached in talks between President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who was in Iraq in an effort to defuse tensions in the region. Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, is in Baghdad for consultations with his Government after making a speech here last Friday attacking the United States, just as Iraqi troops were moving toward Kuwait. Mr. Kozyrev and Mr. Aziz are to brief the Council next week on their agreement.
Iraq's linking of a pledge to recognize Kuwait in return for the easing of an embargo at some fixed future date is not new. The Hussein Government has been arguing that when a United Nations weapons monitoring system is in place and has been adequately tested, Iraq will have met its obligations under one of several sanctions resolutions and would be entitled to resume selling oil.
The monitoring system is now functioning and a report to the Security Council on its operation is due in six months.
The United States and its allies on the Council have said repeatedly that there will be no bargaining between the United Nations and Iraq over terms of easing sanctions. Under resolutions now on the books, Iraq must not only unconditionally recognize Kuwait and the borders recently redrawn by an international demarcation commission but must also return stolen Kuwaiti property, account for Kuwaitis still missing from the 1990 Iraqi invasion and meet other conditions.
Tonight Kuwait's representative at the United Nations, Mohammed A. Abulhasan, said that recognition of his Government was only one step in a process of meeting commitments, and that it was too early to judge the depth of Iraq's promises.
As Mr. Kozyrev was in Baghdad trying to wring concessions from the Iraqis, a war of words between the Clinton Administration and the French Defense Minister over how to deal with President Hussein grew sharper today when Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate here, accused the minister of "giving comfort to a brutal dictator who is a repeat offender."
On a day when the United States continued to lobby for a Council resolution on restraining the Iraqi President from further threatening the Persian Gulf region, Ms. Albright reacted angrily to comments on Wednesday by the French official, Francois Leotard, who said the American troop buildup in the gulf was motivated by domestic politics.
In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry spokesman tried to smooth over the dispute by reiterating France's unambiguous criticism of Iraqi troop movements, which he characterized as an attempt to intimidate the international community. He said that the French and Americans were working closely and in mutual trust in Security Council consultations. Ms. Albright and French diplomats here also made that point.
The heated exchange with Mr. Leotard came just as the United States began circulating among the French, British and Russians here some draft language for a resolution that would demand a return of Iraqi troops to their original positions.
No formal action on such a resolution is expected before next week, until after the Council has heard from Mr. Kozyrev and Mr. Aziz. The draft language now being circulated for discussion by Ms. Albright would threaten serious consequences if President Hussein menaced Kuwait again. American officials said this week that they believed that they had the authority to attack Iraq without further recourse to the Council if the Iraqis defied these warnings.
The Americans seem confident that the British and French could be convinced to support a resolution. There are also hopes that Russia can be brought into a consensus. The fifth permanent Council member, China, has said only that it wants to see the dispute resolved through dialogue.
With most of today's Council activities going on behind closed doors, in corridors or over lunches, attention centered on Ms. Albright's unusually harsh attack on Defense Minister Leotard. She described as "ludicrous" his remark that the movement of American forces was ordered for domestic political gain.
"There are times when you've got to turn the other cheek, and there are times when you've got to tell it like it is," Ms. Albright said of the French Defense Minister's comments as she talked with reporters outside the Council chamber. "And here I believe that the comments by the French Defense Minister are very ill-informed and counterproductive."
Continuing the attack, she added that "there are countries who have commercial interests with Iraq and I think one ought to look into that and consider reactions in that guise."
This was a fairly direct reference to French oil interests in Iraq. Baghdad owes French companies and French Government insurers nearly $5 billion, and this situation has been thought to be behind France's willingness to begin easing sanctions on Iraq, now that a weapons-monitoring system is in place.

Companies
 
Microsoft is poised to dominate personal finance software, the only niche of the software market it does not already lead, by agreeing to acquire Intuit Inc., the producer of the Quicken program, in a stock swap valued at $1.5 billion. The deal would be the largest software acquisition ever. [Page D1.]
 

Gas stations are welcoming back credit cards as more oil companies team up with banks to issue cards. Another reason for the shift is that credit card technology has become simpler. [D1.]
 
Matsushita repeated that MCA was not for sale. But that could change if the company received an offer too good to refuse or if its executives decided that MCA and its Universal subsidiary would have little value without Steven Spielberg and David Geffen, who have formed an alliance with Jeffrey Katzenberg. [D1.]
 
Liberty Financial will buy Colonial Group for $310 million. The merger would create the nation's 25th-largest mutual fund company as part of a diversified asset-management firm. [D2.]
 
Eli Lilly delayed its purchase of PCS Health Systems amid signs that the F.T.C. may challenge it on antitrust grounds. [D2.]
 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed that Long Island Lighting be acquired by New York State. A deal would cost $9 billion. [A1.]

The Economy
 
Producer prices declined unexpectedly in September. While the report heartened investors at first, analysts asserted that the data showed little overall lessening of inflation pressure. [D1.]
 
Mutual funds could be required to include a single-page summary of the risks and expenses that investors face in their prospectuses, under a proposal by the chairman of the S.E.C. [D1.]
 
International
 
The ruble bounced back, but insecurities remain within the Russian economy and political leadership. News Analysis. [A15.]
 
Markets

despite rallies in United States bond and stock markets. [D13.]

Big marketers are increasingly trying cause-related marketing, hoping to burnish their images as well as build their sales. In one such example, Campbell Soup and Chrysler will promote a national day of volunteerism. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D16.]

HEADLINE: Board Chairman of N.A.A.C.P. Is Focus of Dispute on Finances

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Two months after firing its executive director, the N.A.A.C.P. is embroiled in another dispute involving one of its top officers, William F. Gibson, the chairman of the board.
In three columns written over the last week, Carl T. Rowan, the syndicated columnist, has asserted that Dr. Gibson has used his position as chairman for personal gain. 
 Mr. Rowan, a former official in the Johnson Administration, alleged that the chairman had used an American Express card provided by the civil rights organization to charge more than $500,000 in airline travel, hotel expenses, car rentals and personal items since 1986.
Citing financial records of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Mr. Rowan also alleged that Dr. Gibson had received $300,000 in questionable reimbursements since he became chairman. Some of the checks carried the notation "receipts to be provided," according to Mr. Rowan, while others noted that the disbursements did not match purchase orders.
Copies of N.A.A.C.P. financial records viewed today indicated that for 1990 Dr. Gibson received either $2,800 or $3,000 a month. Copies of the checks list the reason for the payments as "board travel and per diem" or "office expenses." But the fact that the monthly payments were always either $3,000 or $2,800 raised the question of whether they constituted a stipend.
Financial records also indicate that in 1986, Dr. Gibson, a dentist from Greenville, S.C., who, like all board members, is a part-time, nonsalaried volunteer, billed the organization $30,579 for travel, hotel and restaurant costs and car rentals. That is nearly three times the $11,479.07 billed to the organization by Benjamin L. Hooks, who was the group's full-time, paid executive director at the time.
There is also evidence that Dr. Gibson tried to charge a speaking fee for an appearance at an N.A.A.C.P. branch. In a letter dated Jan. 7, 1991, officials of the Monterey Peninsula Branch in Seaside, Calif., rejected Dr. Gibson's request for a $1,000 fee to appear at their Life Membership Banquet.
"The branch realizes it must pay your transportation at an economic rate ($300-$400)," wrote Ruthie Watts, the branch's membership chairwoman. "Hotel room is complimentary of the hotel. So what is the $1,000 for?"
In a telephone interview, Ms. Watts confirmed that the incident had occurred but declined to discuss it in detail. She said Dr. Gibson did not appear at the banquet.
Dr. Gibson has denied using the organization's money for personal use, and last week the board's executive committee released a statement supporting him against the allegations raised by Mr. Rowan.
"After receiving an explanation from Dr. Gibson, the Executive Committee is totally satisfied that he has done nothing improper and that any reimbursements received during his tenure were properly authorized expenditures," the statement said.
The 64-member board is scheduled to meet on Saturday at the N.A.A.C.P.'s headquarters in Baltimore to review the progress the organization has made in putting its financial affairs in order. Several board members say the allegations against Dr. Gibson will be discussed. Some of his critics on the board say there will be a move to ask him to resign or at least step aside until an independent audit of spending by board members is done.
"There are individuals on the board who will be calling for his resignation," said Joseph Madison, a board member from Washington. "It's a decision as to how much they value the integrity of the organization."
At a news conference today to announce an agreement with a group of black newspaper publishers to provide free advertising for the N.A.A.C.P. as part of an effort to boost membership, Dr. Gibson declined to answer questions about the accusations of financial impropriety.
In August, the board dismissed Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. as the organization's executive director after it determined that he had committed the N.A.A.C.P., without the board's knowledge or approval, to pay as much as $332,400 to a former female employee after she threatened a sexual discrimination suit.
The latest accusations come as the N.A.A.C.P., the nation's oldest and largest civil rights group, struggles with an acute financial crisis. The group is more than $3.5 million in debt and has said that employees making more than $22,000 annually will have to take a two-week unpaid furlough before the end of the year.
Corporate and foundation donors have been reluctant to help the organization until they believe that procedures are in place to insure sound financial management. People at the N.A.A.C.P. familiar with the situation say that the Ford Foundation, which helped bail the organization out of a financial hole in 1992, has been holding back a $500,000 two-year grant until outside financial experts are brought in to oversee the organization's finances.
Lloyd Garrison, a spokesman for the Ford Foundation, declined to discuss the situation, except to confirm that the money had not been released.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The board chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., William F. Gibson, center, has denied accusations that he used organization funds improperly. At a news conference called today to promote a membership drive, Dr. Gibson declined to answer reporters' questions about his finances. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The widely watched Government gauge of producer inflation dropped sharply in September, suggesting that price pressures were markedly less intense last month than economists had predicted. But closer examination of the Labor Department report showed little, if any, overall lessening of inflation pressure.
The news touched off fresh rallies in the bond and stock markets in the morning. But these rallies subsided as the data were examined and investors looked ahead to the release of the September Consumer Price Index and other important economic data on Friday. [Pages D5 and D6.] 
 "On the surface you'd say that inflation paused in September," said Eugene J. Sherman, research director at M. A. Schapiro & Company in New York, commenting on the five-tenths of 1 percent decline in the Producer Price Index for finished goods, the biggest monthly fall in more than a year. "But inflation is not an event, it's a process," he said, expressing concern at hefty price increases for goods at earlier stages of production.
While the prices for finished goods, like a suit of clothes, did decline last month, the prices for intermediate goods, like a bolt of cloth, and crude goods, like a bale of cotton, have now posted large advances for four straight months, excluding the volatile food and energy items.
"The economy is looking pretty strong," said James W. Coons, economist at the Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio, taking no comfort in today's report and predicting that the "upstream" pressures would lead to a 4 percent inflation rate for consumers by spring, about a point higher than the current rate.
Patrick McCoy, treasurer of Hinkley Lighting Inc., a Cleveland producer of chandeliers and other lighting fixtures for new homes, said today that the 7 percent price increase his company put through in July -- on top of a 9 percent rise a year earlier -- was sticking and that there was little sign of slackened demand.
Hinkley's costs for brass, sheet metal and other materials have risen about 4 percent this year, Mr. McCoy said.
Economists also tended to dismiss the notion that today's report would have any significant effect on the Federal Reserve, which is still expected to raise interest rates again this autumn in its drive to keep inflation at bay.
Some, however, expressed fresh hopes the Fed would at least wait to make its move until its next policy meeting on Nov. 15.
"If the Federal Reserve raises interest rates anytime soon, it won't be giving business enough credit for its continuing ability to contain operating costs and price pressures," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors.
"Our member companies, who pay the prices measured by the P.P.I., are experiencing some upward price pressures in the pipeline," he added, but "they're telling us that chairman Greenspan should holster his interest-rate gun for the time being."
The biggest inflation factor, economists agree, is what happens to wages. So far, despite shortages of some types of workers like long-haul truck drivers, these seem contained.
In a separate report, the department said today that first-time claims for unemployment benefits eased 5,000 last week, to a total of 314,000. This helped bring the average for the latest four weeks down to 316,000, the lowest point in more than five years.
In addition to the Consumer Price Index, the Government is to issue September figures for retail sales, industrial production and capacity utilization on Friday.
The sharp, presumably temporary, downdraft in the Producer Price Index last month was mainly the result of a 1.1 percent decline for passenger cars, a 7.5 percent drop for gasoline and a 10.3 percent tumble for roasted coffee.
Not counting food and energy, finished goods edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, a better than expected performance for the "core" rate that some specialists said resulted from quirks in the way the department made its seasonal adjustment for cars.
"Are car prices really going down?" asked David Orr, chief economist at the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C. "When forced to choose between economic statistics and common sense, use common sense," he said.
On the other hand, the report said that prices rose smartly for tobacco products (2 percent) and accelerated for prescription drugs (nine-tenths of 1 percent), books, alcoholic beverages, mobile homes, furniture and over-the-counter drugs.
Before seasonal adjustment, the overall index for finished goods dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent for the month.
Among intermediate goods, prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent over all and six-tenths of 1 percent for the core rate, which excludes food and energy, the report also showed.
Nondurable materials used in manufacturing, like chemicals, jumped 1.7 percent after a 1.4 August surge, lifting the annual pace for the latest three months to 17 percent, nearly double that of the second quarter.
Construction materials rose five-tenths of 1 percent to raise the quarterly pace to 4.5 percent, from 3 percent in the March-June period.
For factory durables, like copper and brass mill shapes, the advance was eight-tenths of 1 percent after an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in August. For the quarter, the acceleration was more modest than for nondurables, to an 8.6 percent pace from 8.1 percent.
Crude goods dropped 1.6 percent, mainly because of slides in crude oil and natural gas that drove the energy category down 5.3 percent after being virtually unchanged in August. Crude goods other than food and energy rose 1.3 percent last month and soared at a 20.4 percent annual rate for the quarter after falling 2.1 percent in the spring.

HEADLINE: At the Pump, Cash Bows to Credit

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Twelve years ago, ARCO shocked the gasoline business by canceling all the credit cards it had issued -- even blowing one up in a television commercial -- and stressing prices instead. That ushered in an age of discounts for cash at the pump. But now the pendulum is swinging the other way.
Oil companies have not only eliminated their discounts for cash, they have also begun to offer a new type of credit card that offers rebates on future gasoline purchases. It's a kind of frequent-flier program for people whose "flying" is limited to brief jolts on bumpy roads. 
 Last month, Exxon dropped its discount for cash payments, one of the last companies to do so, and joined Shell, B.P., Amoco, Sunoco and Unocal in promoting a credit card offering rebates.
So consumers who were once offered a discount of 3 or 4 cents a gallon if they paid cash are being offered savings of that much or more if they use credit.
Since last November, when Shell and the Chemical Bank started the so-called co-branded cards, Shell has issued 3.3 million cards, and other oil companies, teaming up with other banks, have issued additional millions. Most of the cards do not charge annual fees.
The number of co-branded cards is small compared with the number of traditional gasoline-only credit cards that oil companies have issued for more than 60 years. About 60 million of those are in circulation. But the co-branded cards are "just up and getting started," said the president of The Nilson Report, David Robertson.
The co-branded cards, generally Mastercard or Visa, offer rebates of 1 or 2 percent on general purchases, while gasoline purchases generally earn 2 or 3 percent rebates. Both kinds of rebates can be spent on anything sold at the gasoline stations or their attached mini-marts.
The new cards are one reason for an increase in the use of plastic in place of cash to buy gasoline. The proportion of gasoline sold through credit and debit cards, including cards for automatic teller machines, was about 1 in 3 last year. Five years earlier it was 1 in 5, according to The Nilson Report, a credit-card newsletter in Oxnard, Calif.
Mobil now sells 42 percent of its gasoline with plastic, and in some markets well over 50 percent, said Nancy B. Carlson, the marketing development manager.
"There has been a significant shift in attitudes toward the use of credit," said Bruce Tackett, a spokesman for Exxon.
Another reason for the change is that credit card technology has become simpler. No longer do oil dealers have to sort little squares of paper and carbons. Now electronic devices that read the magnetic strips on the backs of the cards are cheap enough to attach to pumps, adding $3,500 to the price of a $10,000 six-hose fuel dispenser. The control console at the cashier's station adds an additional $10,000, but the big oil companies will often subsidize dealers' costs.
Dealers like the card-activated pumps because they save labor and mean that each car spends less time at the pump -- even if that risks allowing customers to complete their transactions without ever coming in sight of the beef jerky and cheese dip inside. An open pump, after all, beckons a passing driver; a car left vacant at the pump while the driver pays a cashier warns away potential customers.
Mothers are said to especially favor the pay-at-the-pump credit cards over leaving the children and walking into the convenience store to pay -- or taking them along and trying to avoid the candy rack. "You could lay it at the feet of the women," said Trilby Lundberg, president of the Lundberg Survey Inc. of North Hollywood, Calif., a company that tracks gasoline prices and trends. "There are more women with kids in the car than there are men."
And cards of any kind build customer loyalty, experts say. "Once you've got the credit card in the driver's hands he's a very loyal customer and he's more likely to buy product he doesn't need like a midgrade gasoline or a premium," said an industry analyst who insisted on anonymity.
Ms. Carlson of Mobil said the use of credit cards to buy gasoline was strongest in California, where the cards first became popular, and weakest in New England, where people think that "it's never good to use plastic," she said. New Englanders have taken to using bank A.T.M. cards, though, she added.
Customers can reap substantial benefits. Shell says its customers have earned $40 million in gasoline rebates since November.
But how much that means to a typical customer is not clear, and the dollar value may be small. Shell said when it started the program that an average driver would probably save $70 a year. A spokesman, Michael Sternesky, said on Friday that it was too soon to tell what the average saving was.
Earning the rebates means accepting the interest rate, which may be higher than the rate on competing cards, warned Ruth E. Susswein, executive director of Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer group in Salem, Va. At the American Automobile Association, Peter Crescenti, a spokesman for the New York State chapter, said customers might be better off "going to Joe's Brand X, where gas may be 7 or 8 cents cheaper."
Customers with such cards generally earn some rebates on nongasoline purchases, Mr. Crescenti said, but "you need to scrutinize your buying habits" to determine whether a card is worth it. "A lot of consumers don't get into this heavy kind of figuring," he said. "It boils down to convenience and perceived value."
Not everyone is in the parade. Amoco continues to offer discounts for cash, and so does Texaco at some stations that are operated by dealers. A spokesman for Texaco said the decision was generally made market by market, according to competitive conditions in each area.
Moving credit card readers to the pump has had another effect, Mr. Robertson said. Credit card fraud is a challenge in many areas of the economy, but the pumps have become a magnet for stolen cards, he said.
"That self-activated terminal serves to tell the person whether that stolen card has been reported stolen," he said. When thieves obtain a stolen card, he said, "the first thing they do is go to a gas station, find out if it's on a hot list." At a gasoline pump, they need never show their faces.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Advance but Ease at End

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of government securities posted a strong advance yesterday after an unexpected drop in September producer prices but Treasuries gave up some of their gains by the end of the day.
All maturities rallied sharply on the producer price report, as the data eased investor concern about accelerating inflation. The report convinced most market participants that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates immediately and would probably wait until its next policy meeting on Nov. 15 to act. Early declines in gold and oil prices helped bolster the bond market. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to 96. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.85 percent, from 7.89 percent on Wednesday. Traders said the price of the long bond was up as much 16/32 after the release of the producer price report before retreating later in the day. The Labor Department's report on producer prices -- the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers -- suggested that the Fed's five increases in short-term interest rates this year may have begun to have some impact on inflation, analysts said. But other analysts saw yesterday's gains as merely one rally in a bear market. Greg Jones, an economist for MMS International, said the Producer Price Index report put off for now any promise of a tightening by the Fed, although there was still concern about more data coming out today, including September consumer prices, capacity utilization and retail sales. Analysts are expecting a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index and an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in the index's core rate, which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy prices.
The market has a pattern of rallying into the consumer price report, Mr. Jones noted, but whether the consumer index is good or bad, the pattern also shows that bonds frequently stumble in a big way after it. Even if today's data are good for the bond market, analysts say sellers who emerge on uptick opportunities may limit the extent of the market move.
"There is always the chance that the Fed could still pull the trigger if the C.P.I. is ambiguously strong and inflationary," Mr. Jones said. However, the general market consensus suggest a more mixed outcome, with the Fed inclined to err on the side of restraint.
The Producer Price Index showed that prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers fell five-tenths of a percent in September. It was the index's largest dip in more than a year. The core rate rose one-tenth of a percent, much less than the market had expected. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News were expecting a gain of one-tenth of a percent in the overall index and a rise of four-tenths of a percent in the core rate.
Donald H. Straszheim , chief economist for Merrill Lynch, in his market commentary, noted that while wholesale prices were likely to edge higher in the coming months, there were still no signs of an inflation pickup for finished goods.
Also released yesterday but largely ignored was a report on initial unemployment claims for the week ended Oct. 8, which declined a moderate 5,000 claimants, to 314,000. Analysts say the initial employment claims continue to show steady improvement in the labor market.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Mark, Settling at Seven-Week Low

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell to a seven-week low against the German mark yesterday, despite rallies in United States stock and bond markets.
Bonds surged in early trading yesterday, pulling the dollar higher, after the United States Labor Department said the Producer Price Index fell an unexpected five-tenths of 1 percent in September. 
 The report eased investors' concern about inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments. Stocks also gained, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 14.80 points.
Bonds retreated later in the day amid speculation that the drop in the producer prices was an aberration and that today's reports on consumer prices, retail sales and factory use would not bring the same easing of price pressures.
"We're not out of the woods yet on inflation," said Lisa Finstrom, currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc. "Producer prices are just one piece of the puzzle."
Currency dealers have been following the bond market closely this year to gauge foreign investors' appetite for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them. But the dollar's turnaround yesterday was much more severe than the retreat in bonds, in part because of a wave of selling of dollars by currency-trading funds, which control billions of dollars in capital in the foreign exchange market.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5283 marks, its lowest level since Aug. 23, and down from 1.5422 marks on Wedneday. The dollar rose as high as 1.5445 marks just after the producer prices report was released at 8:30 A.M. The dollar fell to 99.35 yen, from 99.77 yen on Wednesday.
The mark has been strong against other currencies this week, bolstered by expectations that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition will win a clear majority in Sunday's federal elections.
Some traders and analysts attributed the dollar's losses yesterday to the currency's dismal performance so far this year, given the strength of the United States economy.
"The dollar has left people with a bad taste in their mouths," said Amy Smith, senior currency-market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm. "It has no resilience. The dollar falls no matter what happens."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Latest Inflation Data Send Silver Prices Into Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Silver prices skidded to a seven-week low yesterday after a Government report offered evidence that inflation was under control.
The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index, a measure of wholesale price inflation, fell a half-percent in September, the biggest drop in more than a year. 
 Inflation concerns were also calmed by the eighth straight daily decline in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity prices. It slipped 0.20 point, to 227.54, reflecting lower prices for crude oil, wheat, cattle and gold, as well as silver.
"The higher interest rates are starting to have an impact on the economy," said George Milling-Stanley, a precious metals analyst with Lehman Brothers. The Federal Reserve Board has pushed up interest rates five times this year to thwart inflationary pressures.
Silver for December delivery fell 13 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $5.385 an ounce, the lowest daily settlement for that contract since Aug. 26. December gold fell $2, to $388.60 an ounce.
Gold futures posted steep losses on Tuesday in anticipation of weaker inflation signals. With those expectations confirmed, traders are looking to today's consumer price report and the factory utilization report for further evidence of economic cooling.
But if consumer prices rose strongly in September, "it could undo everything done today," Mr. Milling-Stanley said. "If it's lower than expected, I expect there's still going to be downside pressure on gold and silver."
Meanwhile, crude oil futures fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the fourth straight day, despite a late rally. Light sweet crude for November delivery finished 6 cents lower at $17.13 a barrel after trading as low as $16.80.
Oil prices initially fell sharply on reports that American warships had intercepted a Greek tanker suspected of trying to smuggle Iraqi oil past a United Nations embargo, but they later rebounded.
Now that tensions in the Persian Gulf have eased, news from that part of the world is less of a market factor, Ric Navy, a vice president of Paribas Futures, said.
"The market is going to fight its way back to the fundamental type of arena," he said, referring to basic supply-and-demand factors.

HEADLINE: Where Antiques Reflect The Latest Fashions

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
WHEN the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show first opened in Manhattan six years ago, droves of Europe's top dealers leaped at the chance to exhibit at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Since most of their best customers were Americans, the chance to give them shop-at-home service seemed irresistible.
And it was. For the first time, America had a showplace that rivaled Grosvenor House in London, Maastrict in the Netherlands and the Biennale in Paris. This year's fair, which opens today and runs through Thursday, still ranks with those extravaganzas. Viewers have a chance to see objects as varied as a third-century A.D. Roman glass bottle for $120, a 1944 Picasso oil for $435,000 and a $3.5 million Chinese bronze. It's also a place to follow current fashions in collecting. (Asian art is hot right now; so are Continental furniture and animal jewelry.) 
 The show has also come to be known as the event that kicks off the fall art and antiques season. Besides a number of smaller antiques shows being held around the New York metropolitan area this weekend, the auction houses are showing such big-name collections as those of Alice Tully, Henry Francis du Pont and Bertram K. and Nina Fletcher Little.
But despite its clout, the show is not aging gracefully. While most of the 78 dealers have brought rare and handsome objects, many seem just a bit too familiar. The art business has traditionally depended on high-class recycling, and this season what's been going around seems to have landed at the armory. A number of objects on display this year have been on the market recently.
It's understandable. As the number of art and antiques shows has grown faster than the economy, the dealers' mission to keep producing fresh offerings is getting noticeably tougher. Harder still is the problem of timing. This year, the show is sandwiched between Grosvenor House (which was in June) and the Paris Biennale (which opens next month). Few dealers who participate in more than one of these events have the financial muscle to keep bringing new pieces to each fair.
But money is only part of the problem. Fewer truly extraordinary pieces are coming on the market, since people who don't have to sell would prefer to wait until prices start rising again.
"Just because something has been around doesn't mean there's anything wrong with it," said Anna Haughton, who with her husband, Brian, organizes the show. "If the quality is high enough to be in the Biennale or in Maastrict, we don't see it as a problem. Each show has a different crowd."
Those who missed Grosvenor House will be able to see some of its highlights. From Pelham Galleries in London, there is a pair of 17th-century Neapolitan cabinets, circa 1675, with 50 painted glass panels, each depicting scenes from such literary sources as Ovid's "Metamorphoses" and Virgil's "Aeneid." "Grosvenor House is the only other place they've been shown," said Alan Rubin, the owner of Pelham.
Some pieces have had far more exposure. A rectangular commode of rosewood and lemon wood with inlays of ivory, jade, soapstone and Chinese lacquer, stamped R.V.L.C. (which stands for Roger Vandercruse called La Croix) and dated 1755, has been seen at Michel Meyer's shop in Paris, at Didier Aaron's gallery in London and at an antiques fair in Monte Carlo. Now it's on view at the armory in the Paris furniture gallery Perrin, one of this year's first-time exhibitors. Patrick Perrin, one of the directors, confirmed that the piece is owned jointly by a group of Paris furniture dealers. "It's very special," he said. "It was in the collection of Marie Antoinette."
Another commode, this one semicircular and intricately inlaid with different woods, once belonged to J. P. Morgan. It is believed to have been made by Christoph Furlough, cabinetmaker to the Prince of Wales, in the 1770's and 80's and is on view at Mallett of London. "We sold it and have taken it back," said Henry Neville, Mallett's junior director. "It's been on and off the market for about eight years now." At one time, the piece was also owned by Glenn Randall, the Newport dealer.
Some works have been bought recently at auction. Two pieces at the New York porcelain dealer Chait, a Tang Dynasty horse and a large iron figure dating from 1120 A.D., were auctioned at Sotheby's in New York in June. "Great things are getting scarce," said Ralph Chait. "I always like to sell, but the problem is I no longer know how I can replace the objects."
Mr. Chait is in good company this year. Asian art is represented in many forms. Among the star pieces is an 18th-century Chinese bronze vase inlaid with silver and gold at Earle D. Vandekar, a New York dealer. Even more extraordinary is a green patinated bronze horse and chariot from the second century A.D. at the booth of Robert Ellsworth, a New York dealer. The piece is related to the famous flying horse excavated from a tomb in Gansu, a province in northern China. The price, $3.5 million, doesn't seem to worry the dealer. "I have people panting to buy it," Mr. Ellsworth said. "And hopefully they'll give it to a museum."
Khalil Rizk, owner of the Chinese Porcelain Company in Manhattan, calls this "the year of Asia." He believes the renewed interest in Asian art is linked to the opening of the Irving Galleries for the Arts of South and Southeast Asia at the Metropolitan Museum this summer and the exhibition of Asian art from the Rockefeller collection that opened last week at the Asia Society in Manhattan. Mr. Rizk's booth is devoted to Famille Verte porcelain of the Kang-hsi period. There is an interesting selection of objects: miniature figures of Chinese boys, a wine pot and cover with rectangular panels that depict figures standing in a trellised garden, a plump toad with bulging eyes and bowls with many decorations. "Famille Verte is wonderfully old-fashioned," said Coner Mahony, president of the Chinese Porcelain Company. "It's for people with refined taste."
Doris Wiener, a private New Yorkdealer who is participating in the show this fall for the first time, has a spectacular booth of Southeast Asian art. "Ever since the Vietnam War, the interest in Southeast Asia has grown steadily," she said. At the entrance to her booth is a Ganesha, a Hindu god with an elephant's head and a little boy's chubby body, dating from the seventh century A.D., which she bought from a private collection in England. "Ganesha was the remover of obstacles, the god of wealth and of literature," Ms. Wiener said. "He was one of the favorite deities."
While Asian art has proliferated this season, the number of serious paintings and drawings has declined. Since the show's organizers began the super-successful International Fine Art Fair: Renaissance to Impressionism in Manhattan last May, a number of dealers have opted to show paintings in that more specialized venue. Among the few fine-art dealers left, one of the most impressive small booths belongs to Mark Brady, a New York dealer. One of his star pieces is a 1784 portrait of Jonas Brooke by Hugh Douglas Hamilton from Mere Hall in Cheshire, England. "It's one of the single greatest pastels by Hamilton," Mr. Brady said. "The last great one on the market went to the National Gallery in Washington." Mr. Brady bought the pastel recently from the country-house sale at Mere Hall held by Christie's in May. Even the frame is special, intricately carved with acanthus vines interwoven with a beaded ribbon and carved florets.
Some of the smaller booths are easy to miss, but walk carefully, for they hold some treasures. Among them are two newcomers: David and Constance Yates from New York City and G. Sarti from London. The Yateses, who specialize in 18th- and 19th-century European drawings and sculpture, are showing a group of bronze plaques, many made to be mounted on furniture, designed by Alexander Charpentier, a French sculptor and decorative artist. The booth also features a plaster bust by David D'Angers depicting a man in pain. "This was the first glimmer of Romanticism in French sculpture," David Yates said. "It won the Prix de Rome in 1811. We have four museums in line for it."
G. Sarti has a 16th-century Roman marble table richly inlaid with trophies and geometric motifs.
Less exotic, but always a staple of the show, are the several dealers who carry Continental and English furniture. At Didier Aaron, the New York dealer, there's an opulent Austrian giltwood armchair circa 1790. And the London dealer Ciancimino has a selection of objects ranging from a pair of drop-dead gilt-bronze hall lanterns, circa 1800, from Corby Castle in Cumbria to a fine Regency bookcase. "I'm worried because things are getting so much more expensive; I hope collectors will understand," Jean-Claude Ciancimino said. "The old-timers are overstocked; they've been buying so much for so long. And whether there's a new crop of potential clients, well, that remains to be seen."

HEADLINE: On the Graying of Japanese Consumers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell expresses concern in his Oct. 6 Economic Scene column over White House failure to have a Japanese trade agenda. Mr. Passell says the few Clinton Administration members who understand the "importance of fiscal and monetary measures in balancing trade" have "given up trying to explain the point to Congress or the public." 
 Then you report (Business Day, Oct. 7) that "natural forces could eliminate Japan's huge trade surplus." To expect the aging of Japan's public to fix the Japanese-American trade imbalance would be a sanguine mistake and would buy the Japanese time to tighten the trade noose. What we need is a policy and a strategy to counter the Japanese, who realize that exchange rates fluctuate widely and are using the situation to their advantage.
As the Japanese purchase raw materials from the United States, cheap greenbacks benefit a Japanese economy in its early stages of recovery. Cheap dollars also mean that yen invested in the United States are well spent.
By allowing the Japanese to produce locally, capital investments in the United States also dampen the adverse effects of exchange rate swings. While the Japanese jockey for position in the trade war, you report that Americans need only wait for the Japanese to grow old, at which point they will blow their life savings on American goods.
Meanwhile, Tokyo may transfer the new income tax break into a sales tax, selectively exercising more control over what the Japanese will spend their savings on.
If Americans realize this and demand a numerical rise in imports of American-made goods (President Clinton's abandoned policy), the Japanese will be ready to comply. They will be able to import American-made, but Japanese-owned, goods. This will satisfy Japanese internal corporate pressures and also meet American-mandated quotas.
Well, the White House made some progress after all in opening Japanese markets to the American insurance industry, and this should allow our insurance sales people to use their marketing savvy by selling Japan's senior citizens Hondas built in Tennessee.
 
THOMAS HARTIGAN
Cos Cob, Conn., Oct. 9, 1994

HEADLINE: Pataki Misconstrues Anti-Bias Laws Affecting Gay People

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for New York governor, suggests in your Oct. 10 interview with him that laws prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation provide "special rights" to lesbians and gay men, he displays misunderstanding of civil rights law. Such laws promote equality and help eliminate bias that causes quantifiable economic and personal harm. 
 Mr. Pataki's concern that gay people could win discrimination claims by proving that an employer's work force did not reflect the percentage of gay people in that community is wrong. Anti-bias laws require that employees be judged on their performance, not on sexual orientation.
Mr. Pataki's attempt to characterize civil rights protections for gay people as "special rights" recalls the misinformed rhetoric that 1960's civil rights opponents used to argue against race discrimination protections. Civil rights laws protect all, regardless of sexual orientation.
So, when Mr. Pataki hints that an employer will have to lay off a heterosexual or a closeted gay person, rather than a gay person, to protect against a lawsuit, he is again wrong. His statement that the person whose sexual orientation is unknown to the employer "is not a member of the protected class" reflects a misconception.
 
SUZANNE B. GOLDBERG
Staff Attorney, Lambda
Legal Defense and Education Fund
New York, Oct. 11, 1994

HEADLINE: Pataki Misconstrues Anti-Bias Laws Affecting Gay People;
For Tax Cuts, and Soon

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 6 news analysis on the tax cut plan of George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for New York governor, perpetuates the myth that tax cuts lead to decreased government revenues and that tax increases lead to increased government revenue, a myth disproved by New York's fiscal reality. 
 New York is one of the highest taxed states in the Union, yet it has one of the poorest debt ratings. Obviously, high taxes have not been a fiscal salve.
The relationship between tax rates and revenue is not direct, but it is simple. Government revenue is related directly to economic activity and seems historically to bear little relationship to tax rates, high or low.
According to your reporting, the Federal Government's revenue base has held steady between 19 percent and 21 percent of gross national product each year over the last 30 years despite wild gyrations in tax rates and policies.
While tax rates have little evident impact on government revenue, they have shown a powerful influence on economic activity. We need only observe that the tax cuts under Presidents Kennedy and Reagan were immediately followed by periods of sustained, noninflationary growth.
High tax rates erode the tax base when economically mobile individuals and corporations choose to leave the state. Just look at the rash of companies and jobs that have moved to New Jersey, Connecticut and almost every other state over the last 12 years.
New York's population has stagnated while the rest of the country has grown, and a larger fraction of today's New Yorkers are poor. This trend will only accelerate as the information age brings economic mobility to more and more workers and businesses. How much can New York afford to cut state taxes? To use a cliche, we can't afford not to.
 
PAUL J. MOTTOLA
Mahopac, N.Y., Oct. 10, 1994
