HEADLINE: For MCA's Japanese Parent, No Signs Yet of Letting Go

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Matsushita's responses to the prospect of selling its Hollywood film and entertainment company, MCA Inc., have ranged from the poetic to the cryptic, but they have always conveyed the same meaning.
"Matsushita has purchased a beautiful and tasty apple," Tsuzo Murase, the executive in Osaka, Japan, who oversees the movie operation, said in March, when rumors were circulating that the parent company, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, was considering selling a stake in MCA to John C. Malone, the powerful cable television executive. "If half the apple is cut and sold, the remaining half would not be as tasty." 
 Now it is the two American executives who actually run the movie and entertainment business, MCA and its Universal Pictures unit, who might want to buy a slice of the apple. And Mr. Murase's response, in telephone conversations on Thursday night and today, was to reiterate the general principle that MCA was not for sale.
That stance could change, presumably, if Matsushita received an offer too good to refuse from MCA's chairman, Lew R. Wasserman, and president, Sidney J. Sheinberg, who are said to be considering resigning if Matushita does not accept their terms.
And Matsushita might also have second thoughts if the company concluded that MCA and Universal would have little value without the creative talents of Steven Spielberg, the filmmaker, and David Geffen, the head of MCA's record unit, who intend to start their own movie and entertainment company with the former head of Walt Disney Studios, Jeffrey Katzenberg.
But from the beginning, when it bought MCA for $6.1 billion in 1990, Matsushita has viewed its investment in the American company as a long-term proposition, not subject to the vagaries of year-to-year financial results or the comings and goings of specific executives.
"We thought this would be a great asset or treasure for us in the 21st century, when we see the multimedia age," Mr. Murase, an executive vice president, said in the March interview. "We do not have any intention of selling part or all of MCA and I can make a very clear statement about this."
In the telephone interviews on Thursday night and today, he said nothing to contradict that position. Mr. Murase said Matsushita was unaware of the purported intentions of the two MCA executives and could not comment in detail.
"This news broke really suddenly," he said today. He said a Matsushita official in the United States had contacted MCA executives and had received a response suggesting that some of the reports from Hollywood were speculative.
"We haven't confirmed their position very clearly," he said, referring to the MCA executives. But he added that the initial message "suggests not to worry too much."
Mr. Murase said MCA had a banner year last year, largely because of Mr. Spielberg's blockbuster film "Jurassic Park," and that this year looked to be even better.
Industry executives in Hollywood said Wednesday that Mr. Wasserman and Mr. Sheinberg were chafing under the ownership of Matsushita, a conservative consumer electronics manufacturer. They said the two MCA executives would meet next Tuesday with Matsushita officials to discuss the future of MCA.
Susumu Ishihara, the head of public relations for Matsushita, said on Thursday that he was surprised by the reports that the MCA executives might want to buy the company. "We never heard that kind of complaint directly from them," he said.
Mr. Murase said today that he did not think there would be a meeting next week between Matsushita and MCA executives, although a quarterly executive committee meeting was scheduled for around the end of this month.
Mr. Murase and Mr. Ishihara said they could not comment on what stance Matsushita would take if it was indeed confronted by demands to sell all or part of MCA.
Mr. Wasserman and Mr. Sheinberg might be backed in a bid for the company by Mr. Spielberg, Mr. Geffen and Mr. Katzenberg. But in any event, some of the possibilities discussed in Hollywood on Wednesday could mean trouble for Matsushita.
Mr. Wasserman and Mr. Sheinberg have run the company together for 22 years, so their departure would leave a vacuum. Mr. Geffen is likely to leave MCA next year. And Mr. Spielberg, who is responsible for many of Universal Studios' greatest hits, is now likely to distribute his movies through his own new studio.
Matsushita executives seemed remarkably nonchalant on Thursday about the developments, but said they still needed information on the events in Hollywood. Mr. Ishihara said he did not think company officials had even met today to discuss the reports of unrest in the MCA ranks. In mid-afternoon trading today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, Matsushita's stock was down 20 yen, to 1,670 yen.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, American depository receipts of Matsushita closed at $169.50, down 37.5 cents.
Mr. Murase said today that the fact that Mr. Spielberg was starting his own studio did not necessarily mean that Mr. Spielberg's relationship with Universal would worsen. He said Mr. Spielberg already distributed some of his films through other studios.
Matsushita bought MCA after its archrival, the Sony Corporation, purchased Columbia Pictures for $3.5 billion in 1989. Both Japanese companies thought the entertainment "software" business could provide higher profit margins than the intensely competitive, and now largely saturated, consumer electronics appliance business. They also thought that there would be synergies between the hardware and the software business.
But the synergies have been sparse, and analysts still debate whether the Sony and Matsushita purchases in Hollywood were worth the billions spent on them.
In the interview last March, Mr. Murase acknowledged that there had been initial difficulties in the relationship with MCA executives because of a lack of understanding and common culture. But he said the executives had "learned to know each other better."
As for the synergies between hardware and software, Mr. Murase said he was confident that they would develop over time.
"We wanted to be exposed to the latest developments in technology in the U.S. by purchasing an American company," he said.
MCA is only a small part of Matsushita, which makes video recorders, television sets, washing machines, rice cookers, telephones, robots, semiconductors and many other products that are sold under the brand names Panasonic, Technics, National and Quasar.
And yet MCA remains a financial bright spot at a time when Matsushita has been hit hard by the recession in Japan, the rise of the yen and the lack of new hit products. Matsushita's earnings have declined for three consecutive years, though there are now signs of an upturn.
In the fiscal year that ended on March 31, the company's entertainment business, of which MCA is the main part, contributed 586.8 billion yen, or roughly $5.7 billion, which is about 9 percent of the total consolidated revenue of $64.3 billion. Operating profits in entertainment were 23.2 billion yen, or $225 million, about 13 percent of the total operating profits.

HEADLINE: California's Woes on Aliens Appear Largely Self-Inflicted

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Gov. Pete Wilson, condemning the failure of Federal immigration policy, is pushing the Clinton Administration to declare an "immigration emergency" and reimburse the state for what he calls a "multibillion-dollar problem."
Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat who is running for re-election, is calling for a $1 border toll to raise money for stronger border enforcement. 
 And polls show that Californians, convinced that their state is being overrun by illegal immigrants who are draining the state's coffers, seem likely to pass a ballot proposition that will deprive illegal immigrants of health, education and welfare benefits, which the Governor's office says will cost California $3.2 billion this year.
But a close examination of the record shows that to a significant degree California has brought its immigration problems on itself. Policies promoted by the state's leaders in the 1980's actively encouraged illegal immigration into California, and as a result hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants came.
Now some of the same leaders are complaining that public money is being used to treat those immigrants in hospitals, send their children to school and incarcerate illegal aliens who commit crimes. Governor Wilson, for example, has endorsed the proposition on ending benefits, while Ms. Feinstein has not yet taken a position, saying she is still studying its costs.
Reflecting on California's earlier policies, Leslie Goodman, the Governor's deputy chief of staff, ruefully acknowledged that "in some ways there have been self-inflicted wounds."
Ten years ago, the mood in California could not have been more different. "The attitude of the time," said Alan C. Nelson, a Californian who was then Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, "was that illegal immigration was O.K."
In fact, in 1984 and 1985, city councils in Los Angeles, San Francisco and many other cities around the state and the country passed resolutions and ordinances declaring their cities to be sanctuaries for illegal immigrants from Central American countries that were regarded as centers of repression supported by the United States.
"We told them, 'You guys are sending a signal that will be heard all over the world,' " recalled Harold Ezell, who was the Western commissioner in the Immigration and Naturalization Service at the time. " 'Just get here to California, and it'll be a free zone.' And that's exactly what happened."
But those were only the first of several decisions that helped cause some of California's problems today. In 1986 Mr. Wilson, then a Senator, and others from the California Congressional delegation held up passage of the Immigration Reform and Control Act until a provision was added to allow several hundred thousand immigrants into the country temporarily so that they could help harvest crops. Under the provision that eventually resulted, more than one million came to stay.
Two weeks ago, Attorney General Janet Reno, irritated by Mr. Wilson's continued attacks on the Administration's immigration policies, shot back, saying, "It is very, very important that we understand that Governor Wilson and others during their time in the Senate fostered some of the illegal immigration that we're now trying to deal with."
Mr. Wilson's response was instant, and bitter. He called her comments "a shameful attempt to turn the spotlight away from the Clinton Administration's total failure to secure our border."
No accurate records exist to document the flow of illegal immigration. The only approximate measure is the number of illegal aliens apprehended by the Border Patrol.
Presumably, this figure increases when the number of people trying to cross the border goes up. And in 1985 and 1986 the number of illegal aliens apprehended along California's southern border increased by 45 percent -- to 724,842 in 1986 from 499,291 in 1985. That was the largest one-year increase ever.
It was late in 1985 when San Francisco began considering creating a "sanctuary," declaring that police officers and city employees were not to bother illegal immigrants from El Salvador and Guatemala -- or to help the immigration service to find or deport them.
"We begged them," recalled David Ilchert, then director of the San Francisco office of the I.N.S. "We told them they would be inviting illegal immigration. Even as the resolution was being debated, we were apprehending aliens who said they'd heard about it in Central America."
But San Francisco passed the resolution and Ms. Feinstein, then Mayor, signed it -- reluctantly, her allies say now.
In Washington, meanwhile, Senator Wilson was pushing to include a "guest worker" provision in the immigration reform bill being debated in 1985. He proposed to allow 350,000 aliens into the country temporarily to help with harvests.
House Democrats balked at that idea -- worried, they said, that temporary workers would be exploited. But without a farm worker provision it was clear that Mr. Wilson and the other members of the California delegation in Congress would not vote for an immigration bill.
So a small group of House Democrats drafted a substitute plan -- the Special Agricultural Worker, or SAW, program. It offered legal residency to immigrants who could prove they had been agricultural workers. As legal residents, the reasoning went, the immigrants would be less subject to exploitation.
Mr. Wilson, his former aides say now, was not entirely comfortable with that plan. "But I remember him coming into the room and telling us he was going to support it," said Representative Howard L. Berman of California, a Democrat who was one of the authors of the plan.
Governor Wilson declined a request for an interview. But Ms. Goodman, his aide, said: "To say he had huge objections to the SAW program, no he didn't. He wanted a migrant worker program."
Congress passed the immigration bill with the SAW program. Afterward, Mr. Nelson, the immigration commissioner, said he "got into a jousting match" with Mr. Wilson over efforts to put the plan into effect. To be eligible for residency, aliens had to prove that they had been agricultural workers in the recent past. Mr. Nelson wanted immigrants to provide that proof before allowing them into the country.
Mr. Wilson opposed that. In a letter to President Ronald Reagan, the Senator said crops were rotting in the fields while the I.N.S. carried out "burdensome SAW application procedures." Immigrants should be allowed into the country on their word alone, he wrote, and required to present proof only later. Mr. Wilson prevailed.
In the end, the farm worker program became the catalyst for widespread fraud. To become a legal resident, an alien had only to present any letter or document, real or forged, showing that he had been an agricultural worker. And across the state, vendors began selling forged documents to immigrants.
Under the SAW program, about 1.6 million people applied for legal residency, though farmers had said they needed only about 350,000 workers. About 1.1 million immigrants won legal status under the program, and most of them moved to California.
Wayne Cornelius, an immigration expert at the University of California at San Diego, said the farm worker program "had a powerful stimulating effect on family migration." Many newly legal residents brought their spouses and children with them and moved to cities in California.
But the program did not offer legal status to these spouses and children. So hundreds of thousands of family members became illegal immigrants, "and these women and children were the ones most likely to use state health and education services," Mr. Cornelius said.
At the time, those new immigrants were welcomed and protected. San Francisco in 1989, after Ms. Feinstein had left office, passed an ordinance forbidding police officers or city officials from assisting in the enforcement of Federal immigration law.
And Bill King, then a regional officer for the I.N.S in California, said, "The cooperation between us and law enforcement just disappeared for a while."
Since then, attitudes have changed, partly in response to a 1990 Federal law that said certain Federal law-enforcement funds would be withheld from cities that did not cooperate with the immigration service in the search for aliens with criminal records.
But the real change came when hard economic times hit California several years ago. With an illegal immigrant population now estimated by the Federal Government at 1.8 million in California, Ms. Goodman said Governor Wilson began to see how much the social services were costing.
Looking at all of that now, Mr. Cornelius, the immigration expert at San Diego, said: "Absolutely, this is partly a self-inflicted problem. And here we are in this morass today."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS DEMANDING A QUICK U.N. VOTE ON IRAQI PULLBACK

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Risking a Russian veto, the United States pressed today for a quick vote on a Security Council resolution requiring Iraq to pull back its troops from the Kuwait border. It warned that it might attack Iraq with or without the Council's support.
The Security Council plans to meet on Saturday to continue consultations on Iraq. They were adjourned this evening after the Clinton Administration formally introduced its resolution. 
 Brushing aside Russia's pleas to delay the vote until next week, the chief American delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, delivered a tough message to Council members: While Washington would prefer to have the Council behind it, it is prepared to take punitive action alone against President Saddam Hussein if the resolution fails.
And President Clinton, in an interview with The Washington Post, warned today that he would do "whatever is necessary" to force Iraq to remove its military units that remain near the Kuwaiti border. In addition, The Post reported, he expressed irriation with Russia for trying to negotiate the easing of sanctions against the Iraqis.
The draft Security Council resolution, jointly sponsored with Britain, would condemn the recent Iraqi troop deployments and demand that those forces return immediately to their original bases. It would also order Iraq to cooperate fully with United Nations inspectors now monitoring Iraqi weapons stocks and production.
Sir David Hannay, Britain's chief delegate and this month's Security Council president, declined to speculate on Russia's intentions beyond saying that it was willing to continue discussing the measure now on the table. As a permanent member of the 15-seat Council, Russia, like the United States, France, Britain and China, can veto any resolution.
American officials insist that they are not bluffing in putting the Russian delegation on the spot. Since elite Iraqi troops moved south a week ago, the Clinton Administration has contended that it has the authority to take punitive action under the 1991 cease-fire resolution that ended the Persian Gulf war.
The United States seems intent on keeping maximum pressure on the Iraqi leader, militarily as well as diplomatically, so that elements of two or possibly three Iraqi units are not left in their new positions. The Iraqis insist that they had pulled back all their troops by Wednesday night, but American officials repeated today that several thousand elite Iraqi troops were digging in near the southern city of Nasiriya.
Visiting Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, Defense Secretary William J. Perry warned today that the United States would take military action if Iraq did not complete its pullback. "If these forces stay in the south, we will expand our current deployment plan and take appropriate action to deal with this threat," he said.
Russia has been struggling for days to broker a deal under which Iraq would recognize Kuwait's sovereignty and the United Nations would respond by lifting economic sanctions within six months.
Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, left Iraq for Kuwait today after talks with President Hussein that the Russians called a breakthrough on the issue of Kuwait's recognition. Mr. Kozyrev is expected to arrive in New York on Sunday night to report to the Council early next week, when Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, is also due here.
The Clinton Administration says that Mr. Kozyrev and Mr. Aziz are primarily pursuing talks on the recognition of Kuwait and the embargo on Iraq oil sales, while the American resolution focuses strictly on the renewed threat President Hussein has posed in the gulf region.
Many diplomats here expressed skepticism about President Hussein's assurances to Mr. Kozyrev that he would recognize Kuwait, saying that the communique circulated by the parties after the talks in Baghdad was vaguely worded. In the communique, Iraq "confirmed its readiness to resolve the problem of the recognition of Kuwait's sovereignty and border with it in accordance with the U.N. Security Council's Resolution 833."
In The Washington Post interview, President Clinton expressed irritation with Mr. Kozyrev's statement. The President said that Mr. Kozyrev's finding good intentions on the part of the Iraqis was not consistent with conversations that Mr. Clinton had this week with President Boris Yeltsin, The Post reported.
The Security Council has demanded that Iraq must go beyond statements of intent. It requires formal action by President Hussein conveyed to the United Nations and approval of his action by Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council, which declared Kuwait to be Iraq's 19th province in 1990. Much work remains undone, diplomats here noted.
The joint Russian-Iraqi statement appears to confirm that Iraq is still seeking to link Kuwait's recognition to a Russian promise to get the sanctions partly lifted in six months, when the weapons monitoring system set up by the United Nations in Iraq has been fully tested.
"Following Iraq's official recognition of Kuwait's sovereignty and borders," said the communique, quoted by the Itar-Tass news agency, "Russia will support an official commencement of long-term monitoring in accordance with U.N. Security Council Resolution 715 and a simultaneous start of a limited 'deadline' period, which in the opinion of Russia should not exceed six months, to check monitoring efficiency, after which the U.N. Security Council would decide on the enactment of Point 22 of Resolution 687 -- fully and without additional conditions."
Paragraph 22 allows for the end of the embargo on "commodities and products originating in Iraq." In other words, Iraq could again sell oil, though under some continuing United Nations restrictions.
The American draft resolution does not raise the prospect of lifting economic sanctions. There has also been discussion of a possible clause that would require Iraq to notify the United Nations Secretary General two weeks in advance of any unusual troop movements in the future, a United States official said.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CAMPIGN STOP;
In One Democratic Suburb, Allegiance to Cuomo Erodes

SERIES: Campaign Stop: Long Beach, L.I. - A periodic report on reaction to the New York gubernatorial race.

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, L.I.

 BODY:
A great divide has opened up in this densely Democratic Long Island city, sundering Democrat from Democrat, and setting off a small fissure one recent afternoon in the offices of Station Realty.
Four brokers were jawing about the governor's race -- about the governor they had voted for in the past and about the Republican running against him with the help of the home-grown United States Senator from the neighboring town. 
 "If the good Senator is supporting him, he must be a good man," said Bill Baer, one of the brokers.
"To me, anybody the Senator would back is suspect," said Ellie Hanen, another broker.
"Time for new blood," Mr. Baer said.
"Even if it's bad blood?" Ms. Hanen said.
"I'm willing to take that chance," Mr. Baer said.
Long Beach is the kind of place that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been able to count on -- a slice of barrier island moored off Long Island's south shore, a longtime haven for weary urbanites slipping out of New York City with their liberal values and Democratic habits in tow.
But this year, even Long Beach voters are in turmoil. After 12 years, many are tired of Mr. Cuomo. They fear for the future of Long Island, with its job losses and high tax and utility rates. They worry that the quality of their lives is fraying, that their children and grandchildren will move away.
So Mr. Cuomo is there constantly these days, talking about Long Island's favorite issues, like defense conversion and jobs -- and, on Thursday, proposing a state take-over of the Long Island Lighting Company in an attempt to lower its notoriously high electricity bills (for which he regularly gets blamed).
The voters' disaffection is bad news for Mr. Cuomo, because Long Island is considered crucial to his chances of re-election. He must win heavily in New York City and at least hold his own in the suburbs if he hopes to match his opponent's strength upstate and in the more conservative suburbs.
But in interviews in Long Beach, many Democrats said they would be voting Republican. It's not that they really believe that the Republican candidate, State Senator George E. Pataki, will lower their taxes, as promised. And it's not that they especially dislike Mr. Cuomo. They just want to try something new.
"He's been around long enough," said Stuart Klar, 52, a Democrat, longtime Cuomo voter and father of three who runs a sports-memorabilia store in the town's West End. "I really totally believe that he's done whatever he can possibly do. There's nothing else he can do."
Even the Lilco announcement failed to win over some skeptics. The early-morning coffee club at Patty Cake's Bakery scoffed at the news. "We all had a good laugh over that," said Joseph Gluck, the bakery's owner. "Everybody was unanimous that this guy had some gall to bring it up now. The State of New York run a utility? Every politician and his mother would have somebody working there."
The coffee club notwithstanding, Mr. Cuomo will probably still carry Long Beach. Democrats outnumber Republicans here by a ratio of 3.3 to 1. In past races, Mr. Cuomo has received from Long Beach voters two to three times the votes cast for his closest competitors. And many people here still see Mr. Cuomo as a man of convictions with an oratorical gift (instead of a blowhard), or as a seasoned leader (instead of a pol who has overstayed his welcome).
But the margin of victory is expected to be narrower than before. Not only is Governor Cuomo paddling against an anti-incumbency riptide, but also Mr. Pataki has the backing of Mr. D'Amato, the Republican who carried Democratic Long Beach in his last Senate race, despite a strong Democratic opponent.
"This is the most fragile time I've seen for Governor Cuomo since his primary with Ed Koch 12 1/2 years ago," said Eugene Cammarato, chairman of the Long Beach Democratic committee. "You see apathy, not the enthusiasm you should see when you have your Governor running."
Long Beach is a Democratic enclave in a Republican county, once heavy with Jewish and elderly residents. But many of them have died or moved South; younger people and families have moved in.
During the 1980's, this was the one Long Island community that got younger. The average age dropped from about 40 to 36, and the average income went up. After selling off a school to a developer, the school district found itself suddenly forced to start building new elementary-school classrooms.
In the town's West End, single-story bungalows squat shoulder to shoulder along narrow streets. On their concrete patios, the marigold is king. Farther east, the neighborhoods grow more affluent. Along the south shore, high-rise apartments and condominiums tower over the boardwalk and shimmering beach.
In coin laundries and law offices and beauty parlors and the surf shop, in backyards and at bus stops and heading home from work, Long Beach residents talked in recent days about the Governor's race. They appeared to be deeply split, not only among but occasionally within themselves.
Those who still like Mr. Cuomo after his three terms in office described him as a man of experience, intelligence and backbone -- perhaps a victim of economic forces beyond his control, but the candidate most capable of leading the region and state out of lingering doldrums.
"He's a man for the people," said Jack Leinwand, 85, a retired accountant walking his Lhasa apso, Pepper, by his waterfront condominium. "They say he's raised taxes. Well, it's true. So has the Federal government. If people want their services, they've got to pay for it."
But others, many of them Democrats, had soured on Mr. Cuomo. They blamed him for their taxes and utility bills, for job losses, crime, empty storefronts, even for the time they had wasted stuck in traffic because of repairs being done on multiple Long Island highways all at once.
Some said they now favor capital punishment, which Mr. Cuomo opposes. "Everybody's getting away with too much," said Karen Negri, 44, a drug-store employee. "I'm tired of supporting all the people in jail. You read about the TV's, and the crime guy who's getting the special meals."
Others accused Mr. Cuomo of neglecting Long Island. Mr. Klar at the sports store suggested that the Governor had favored Albany. "There's more shopping malls in Albany than all Nassau County," said Mr. Klar, who until recently owned a log cabin upstate. "He looks out for it. That's where he spends his time."
But most of all, people blamed Mr. Cuomo for sticking around too long. They said he had run out of new ideas and innovative fire. Some accused him of rigidity and arrogance, and said the same was true for the people around him.
"Being an old businessman, I think it's time for a change," said Morris Murray Fried, 79, an auctioneer, sitting at a cluttered desk in a warehouse jammed with old furniture and housewares. "Because after you're entrenched in certain jobs for a number of years, you're lackadaisical."
Mr. Fried said he had voted for Mr. Cuomo twice. "It's nothing against him personally," he said. "I think he's a fine gentleman. And you never hear any scandals about him." Mr. Fried said it mattered little that he knew almost nothing about Mr. Pataki: "I just want a clean sweep."
Few people seemed to know much about Mr. Pataki -- though that seemed often to be working to his advantage. As for his promise to cut the income tax rate by 25 percent, some Long Beach residents seemed willing to suspend their disbelief, while others laughed out loud.
"Come on, give me a break," said Darrol Block, the owner of David's Family Jewelers, where he said business is down by two-thirds over what it was five years ago. "How can you do that? To bring an economy back on line, there have to be tremendous incentives to businesses."
Tommy Lee, 39, a Republican who works in repossession, agreed. "It's ridiculous," he said. "I don't feel a tax cut is what the state needs. It just needs control and accountability. If they did that, everybody would be happy to pay their taxes. They would go to sleep saying, 'It's a bargain!' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
Reports on consumer prices, retail sales and industrial production showed an economy still expanding at a robust, but slackening pace, while price pressures remained moderate. Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September. Retail sales climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, and industrial production was flat. [37.] 

Many working women feel they are not getting the pay, benefits or recognition they deserve, a new Government survey shows. [9.]
 
Companies
 
Shopping with a Visa card from a home computer may be made as secure and simple as using a credit card at a store under a system to be introduced by a start-up company, First Virtual Holdings of San Diego. The system is initially intended for the selling of electronic documents and other information. [37.]
Fox continued to be on the defensive as a partner backed down from its original plan to buy four television stations. The partner, SF Broadcasting, said it would restructure the financing of the company after a challenge from NBC. [37.]
AST Research plans to cut jobs by 10 percent and close a factory as it struggles with a price war in personal computers. [37.]
Nestle is now looking to expand through new markets for its foods and drinks after a decade of large acquisitions. [37.]
The F.C.C. settled a dispute involving Motorola's satellite project. The decision is a step toward approving global satellite systems that would relay calls via hand-held wireless telephones. [37.]
Toys "R" Us said it would stop selling any toy gun that could be modified to look like the real thing. [9.]
A takeover of Lilco by New York State could be good for rate payers and good for the company, which faces an uncertain future if it loses it monopoly status. News Analysis. [24.]
 
International
 
The chairman of the Russian Central Bank resigned, a day after saying that the ruble's plunge was no reason for him to quit. [3.]
 
Markets
 
Stocks advanced. Chemical issues were strong gainers, while some technology stocks fell. The Dow closed up 20.52 points. [38.]
The dollar weakened against other leading currencies, falling to 1994 lows against the mark and the pound. [45.]
Orange juice prices surged amid concern that dry weather in Brazil was damaging the world's largest orange crop. Coffee prices, however, fell on a report of rain in a Brazilian state. [45.]
Treasury securities rose for a second day on buying encouraged by the report on consumer prices. [48.]
 
Your Money
 
The increase in the Consumer Price Index means, for one, that some 50 million people who receive Social Security and other Federal benefits will receive 2.8 percent more next year. But the index affects virtually every citizen in some way. [35.]
The tax paperwork for hiring nannies would be streamlined under a bill passed by Congress last week. The bill comes a year and a half after Zoe Baird's nomination for Attorney General was derailed by her failure to pay taxes for two household workers and after a public uproar for changes in the complex law. [35.]
Investors can make a straight bet on interest rates with interest-rate-based options. These options -- which are keyed to the 13-week, 5-year, 10-year and 30-year Treasury yields -- include no rights over Treasury securities. The rate is all. [35.]
Low-cost checking accounts will be mandatory in New York, under a rule passed by state regulators. Such basic, or "lifeline," banking accounts are already required in several states. [36.]

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up Modestly

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose modestly in September while retail sales climbed and industrial production slowed, the Government reported today.
Over all, the unusually heavy batch of figures portrayed an economy still expanding at a robust, but perhaps slackening, pace, while price pressures that have developed in various areas remained bottled up before reaching consumers. But even if that outlook continues, the Federal Reserve is still expected to raise short-term interest rates another time this year in an attempt to hold growth and inflation in check. 
 "We've got a healthy economy on our hands," said Joan D. Schneider, an economist in Chicago for BA Securities Inc., an arm of the Bank of America. "And we haven't seen the inflation rate yet pick up."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.52 points, to 3,910.47, while the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 7.83 percent from 7.85 percent. [Pages 38 and 48.]
Retail sales climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in September and sales were revised somewhat higher for July and August, the Commerce Department reported. The Federal Reserve found industrial production unchanged last month as the operating rate of factories, mines and utilities declined for only the second time since mid-1993.
The report on inflation, which followed Thursday's unexpected decline in prices received by the nation's producers, showed the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month.
As a result of the inflation report, some 50 million Americans receiving Social Security and other Federal benefits will get 2.8 percent increases for 1995, the third-slimmest cost-of-living raise since the payments were automatically coupled to inflation in 1975. [Page 35.]
The average monthly benefit for all retired workers is to rise $19, to $698, with an elderly couple who both qualify for benefits getting a $32 increase, to $1,178, the Social Security Administration calculated.
The Labor Department reports two consumer price indexes, the Consumer Price Index-U, for all urban consumers, and the Consumer Price Index-W, for all urban wage earners and clerical workers, which rose one-tenth of a percent last month.
The index for all urban consumers is the more widely followed of the two but the index for urban wage earners and clerical workers is used to calculate increases in the Federal benefit programs.
The impending 2.8 percent raise reflected how much the Consumer Price Index-W rose between the July-September quarters of 1993 and 1994.
The September increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in the more widely followed Consumer Price Index came after three straight months in which it climbed three-tenths of 1 percent. The so-called core rate, which leaves out the wide-swinging food and energy components, also rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
Over the last 12 months the index has advanced 3 percent, the performance of its main elements ranging from a 4.7 percent increase for medical care to a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent for clothes.
A downturn in energy prices last month was the chief reason for the slightly lower September advance but a stabilization in coffee prices, up about 22 percent in each of the two preceding months, also contributed. Gasoline and airline fares fell but the price of new motor vehicles rose five-tenths of 1 percent -- they were lower in the Producer Price Index -- while used cars rose 1 percent.
Automobile finance charges rose an additional 2.2 percent, to a point 15.6 percent higher than at the end of last year, the Labor Department's report also showed.
In the New York metropolitan area, one of five regions for which September figures were reported today, prices edged down one-tenth of 1 percent and now show a 2.4 percent rise over the latest 12 months.
The retail sales tally showed that consumers spent $188.43 billion in stores last month, six-tenths of 1 percent more than in August and 8.1 percent more than in September 1993. These figures are adjusted for seasonal and holiday differences but not for inflation.
Sales of durable goods climbed 1.1 percent, with home furnishings up 1.4 percent, automotive up six-tenths of 1 percent and the building materials-hardware-mobile home category up 1.6 percent.
In nondurables, up three-tenths of 1 percent over all, sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent at stores selling general merchandise, two-tenths of 1 percent at food stores, 1.1 percent at gasoline service stations, 1 percent at bars and restaurants and three-tenths of 1 percent at drugstores. The only decline was at stores selling clothing and accessories, where sales dropped 1.5 percent last month.
This retail spending, which accounts for about one-third of economic activity, was aided by a four-tenths of 1 percent rise in real average weekly earnings last month, the Government also reported.
The Fed's figures on industrial production, which include factories, mines and utilities, showed a slackening in production, with factory output up just one-tenth of 1 percent after a 1 percent August gain. A brief strike at General Motors was a negative factor but when motor vehicles and parts are excluded the gain was still just two-tenths of 1 percent.
Motor vehicle assembly was at a 12-million-unit annual pace, down from 12.3 million in August, and appliance production was down for the second straight month.
Output at mines and utilities each posted a third straight decline.
The operating rate for industry edged down to 84.6 percent last month, two-tenths of a point lower than in August and the first decline since April.
But analysts seemed not to find this persuasive evidence that the progressively greater strains on industry this year have eased.
"It doesn't change my overall impression that the amount of excess capacity as well as skilled and semiskilled workers is essentially used up," said Kelly K. Matthews, chief economist at the First Security Corporation in Salt Lake City.
Calculations by the Social Security Administration today showed a widowed mother with two children getting a $37-a-month increase, to $1,365; an elderly widow or widower $18, to $656; a disabled worker with a spouse and at least one child, $30, to $1,118.
A couple on Supplemental Security Income for needy aged, blind or disabled people will get an $18 increase in their monthly maximum, to $687.
A year ago it was announced that the average retirement benefit would rise $17, to $674, but the benefit actually turned out to be $679, today's report showed. A spokesman said the extra $5 reflected more higher-income people retiring during the year, one in which taxes were raised, than had been estimated.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: WELCOME;
Joyous Haitians Decorate The Capital for Aristide

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 14

 BODY:
With the return of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's exiled President, just a day away, Haiti was swept by a wave of joyous anticipation and a sudden burst of energy today as people across the country poured their efforts into preparing a welcome for their leader.
Security precautions for Father Aristide's Saturday arrival were also being stepped up, with American troops taking the lead role. 
 Apparently fearful of retribution from the populace, the police assigned to at least five stations here fled their posts today, which allowed jubilant crowds to gut and sack the buildings and post pro-Aristide posters on the mustard-yellow walls.
Throughout the capital, people were painting tree trunks, walls and light posts in stripes of red and blue, the national colors, and putting up posters of Father Aristide. Many others picked up shovels, rakes, brooms and hoes to clean their neighborhood streets, or climbed trees to trim branches, a symbol of Father Aristide's Lavalas movement, for use in demonstrations planned for Saturday.
As these ordinary people worked to prepare the city for the arrival of their leader, many sang once-popular songs that were banned by the military dictatorship but have begun reappearing on the radio in recent days. Others chanted slogans praising Father Aristide, or broke into impromptu dances when other pro-Aristide groups riding on the backs of pickup trucks passed by and honked their horns, applauded or raised clenched fists.
"Everything is going to change; everything is going to get better," said Solange Joseph, one of those who was mixing work and celebration by stringing bunting along Avenue John Brown, a main thoroughfare in the capital. "Our father is coming home at last, and we want to be ready for him."
Some residents said they felt it was safe to begin festivities only after they were certain that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and other military leaders had begun their exile in Panama, where they landed early Thursday.
"We had to make sure they were really gone," said Roger Clermont, who had joined a group of his neighbors in sweeping away debris. "We remember what happened last October." That was when General Cedras defied the United States and broke the Governors Island agreement requiring him to step down.
In the countryside, villagers were whitewashing trees, houses and small stones, which they arranged on smoothed-out patches of dirt along the roadside to spell out messages of welcome to their returning President and thanks to the American forces who made his restoration possible. Many of them proclaimed "Vive Titid," using Father Aristide's nickname, but "Merci, Americains" and "Thank You, Clinton" were popular choices too.
Gaily painted political murals in vibrant tropical colors also began appearing on walls. One, being painted by two adults and several children in the sprawling slum of Cite Soleil, an Aristide stronghold, showed an American soldier with his gun raised, a helicopter and a tank behind him, while in the background Father Aristide descended from the heavens on a cloud.
Tonight, in foretaste of the outpouring of emotion that is expected Saturday, euphoric multitudes took to the streets to dance, sing and wave branches. Even in the suburb of Petionville, a bastion of the economic elite that has always rejected Father Aristide and his gospel of social equality, elated crowds snaked their way up and down the cobblestone streets.
There was also a pronounced increase in the visibility of American troops and weapons on the streets, with tanks deployed at intersections and many more patrols than usual stationed on corners. It was not clear, however, whether the increased military presence was intended to protect Father Aristide from possible attack or to discourage his followers from too exuberant a response to his return.
"I am confident that our presence will deter the enemies of democracy from any disruptive acts," said Col. Barry Willey, a spokesman for the 19,000 American troops here. "But my personal belief is that if they test us, they will regret it."
Colonel Willey also said Haitian police and army units, which overthrew Father Aristide in a coup on Sept. 30, 1991, and have been blamed for widespread human rights abuses since then, "will be present" on the streets Saturday. He said the Haitian forces would be armed, but added that they would be accompanied by international monitors.
At least five police stations, including two in Cite Soleil and another in a neighborhood called Bel Air, were abandoned by the Haitian police today and quickly attacked by local residents, who smashed furniture, broke down iron doors and, in one case, dug up the yard looking for bodies. At the main police station downtown, American soldiers blocked the entrance to prevent looting, but said the crowds milling around were friendly.
Concerns about the security of Father Aristide and other members of his government have grown since Lieut. Gen. Hugh Shelton, commander of American troops here, said two Haitian Army colonels appeared to have dropped from sight and might be organizing an anti-Aristide underground.
A reminder of the dangers Father Aristide will face once he returns was sounded this morning at a memorial Mass for Guy Malary, his former Minister of Justice. Mr. Malary was assassinated a year ago today by gunmen believed to be in the service of the military, and his death, which also signaled the final collapse of the Governors Island agreement, became a symbol of the brutality of the dictatorship.
Under a large framed photo of Mr. Malary, the Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, who delivered the homily at the Mass, urged all Haitians to be patient and promised that the abuses of the past would not be repeated.
"Deliverance has begun for those with faith who have been waiting," he said. "Many have fallen, but their blood has not been spilled in vain."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 20.52 as Data Show Modest Inflation

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Blue chips led the stock market yesterday after a mixed bag of government economic reports for September indicated that inflation was under control.
The reports showed a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index, an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales and unchanged industrial production. 
 Taken together, the reports showed the economy is still expanding but that inflationary pressures have not yet reached the level of consumers. While traders expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again this year, the reports confirmed that the Fed was unlikely to do so before its policy-making committee next meets on Nov. 15.
"The market spent most of the day trying to digest all of this economic news," said Gail Dudack, chief market strategist of S. G. Warburg & Company. "And the strength at the close was driven by earnings."
Weakness in the dollar helped to push the Dow Jones industrial average down as much as 11.44 points early in the session. But at the closing bell, the Dow was up 20.52 points, to 3,910.47, its first close above 3,900 since Sept. 19 and a significant gain in what has traditionally been the worst month for the stock market.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index increased 1.31 points, to 469.10, but the Nasdaq composite index dropped 0.81 point, to 767.08. The yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond was 7.83 percent, compared with 7.85 percent on Thursday.
Declines narrowly topped advances on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,054 to 1,022. Total volume of 252.7 million shares was much lower than the previous day's turnover of 337.9 million shares and also under the three-month daily average volume of 282 million shares.
Chemical stocks were strong yesterday, as third-quarter earnings reports were buoyed by overseas sales. Union Carbide advanced 1, to 33 3/4, and Du Pont increased 3/4, to 59 1/4.
In contrast, some technology stocks eased, like Novell, off 1/8, to 16, and Cyrix, off 1/16 , to 37 5/8. Microsoft fell 15/16 , to 5515/16 , after announcing that it had agreed to acquire Intuit for $1.5 billion in stock, largely because of ears that Microsoft's earnings might be diluted. Intuit, however, surged 17 1/8, to 67 3/8.
Alcoa jumped 3 5/8, to 87 -- fueled by soaring aluminum prices that moved to a four-year high -- and contributed almost 10 points to the gain in the Dow. I.B.M. was another cyclical on the upside, rising 7/8, to 73 1/8. And Long Island Lighting climbed 1 1/8, to 17 5/8, a day after New York State proposed to take over the utility.
AST Research declined 1 1/2, to 10 3/4, after an announcement that it expected a fiscal first-quarter loss. Colonial Group, which is scheduled to be bought by the Liberty Financial Companies yesterday reported lower third-quarter earnings and fell 1 1/4, to 35 3/4. Acclaim Entertainment, which on Thursday announced higher fiscal fourth-quarter earnings, nevertheless declined 15/16 , to 17 1/2, on a day that one analyst lowered the company's rating and another reduced earnings estimates. And Dallas Semiconductor dropped 1 5/8, to 13 3/4, after reporting third-quarter earnings just a cent below analyst estimates.
In Tokyo, stocks finished lower after four days of gains. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 179.54 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 19,969.29. For the week, the Nikkei gained 224.54 points.

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns Iraq to Complete Pullback

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KUWAIT, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The United States will take military action against Iraq if it does not complete the withdrawal of Republican Guard forces from southern Iraq, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today.
He said intelligence reports confirmed that "a major part" of a division of Republican Guard troops was digging in near Nasiriya, a southern city along the Euphrates, instead of returning to their base farther north. An Iraqi division numbers roughly 10,000 troops. 
 The Defense Secretary said it was not clear whether the Republican Guard troops were planning to stay near Nasiriya or resume their northward movement. But he added that the unit was still too close to Kuwait and would enable Iraq to intimidate the small Persian Gulf nation.
"We cannot accept that deployment, which we consider threatening and destabilizing," Mr. Perry told reporters today in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, before departing for Kuwait. "Indeed, if these forces stay in the south, we will expand our current deployment plan and take appropriate action to deal with this threat."
Asked to elaborate, Mr. Perry said simply, "We're talking about military action."
The threat to strike at the Republican Guards and expand the American troop deployment in Kuwait well beyond the 30,000 marines and Army troops already planned came as Russia continued its efforts to work out a diplomatic compromise. Russia has been seeking a deal that would not only spare Iraq from American air strikes but would lead to a lifting of economic sanctions.
Today Kuwait City was the scene of dueling agendas, with the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, flying here virtually on the heels of Mr. Perry to present Moscow's latest peace plan.
It is a familiar role for the Russians, who have long had military and economic ties to Iraq. Before the gulf war began in 1991, the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, sent Yevgeny M. Primakov on an unsuccessful quest to broker a compromise to avert the fighting.
Moscow has been pushing for the removal of economic sanctions that have remained in place against Iraq since the war ended. Because Iraq owes Russia $7 billion, Moscow would stand to gain from a United Nations decision to allow Baghdad to resume oil exports.
Under the latest proposal backed by Russia, Iraq would recognize Kuwait's sovereignty and allow United Nations weapons experts to continue their work if the Security Council agreed to remove the economic sanctions in six months.
Mr. Kozyrev said he had held a detailed discussion with President Saddam Hussein and that the Iraqi leader would soon issue a decree recognizing Kuwait's independence and sovereignty.
"Today I have brought good views to the people of Kuwait," Mr. Kozyrev said, "Russia now presumes that the hard page in relations between the two countries may be turned."
Mr. Perry brushed aside the Russian-brokered proposal again today, saying that Baghdad had to satisfy United Nations demands that Iraq eliminate its program to develop weapons of mass destruction and stop threatening its neighbors before sanctions could be eased.
For the American troops and the Kuwaitis, it is President Hussein's Republican Guard forces, not his promise to recognize Kuwait, that seem to be the main preoccupation.
For many of Mr. Perry's aides, today's trip was like traveling back in time to the months after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.
Mr. Perry surveyed troops in Dhahran, a sprawling Saudi air base that was a key installation for American warplanes during the gulf war and one of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's first stops four years ago. Like Mr. Cheney, Mr. Perry watched Air Force pilots ready their warplanes and Army troops set up their Patriot anti-missile batteries around the base.
In devising a plan to contain Iraqi military power, the Pentagon has tried to deal with the fact that it is far easier for Iraq to move forces to threaten its neighbor than it is for Washington to dispatch troops from 7,000 miles away.
One way the Administration has chosen to compensate is to send more troops and planes to the region.
When the Iraqis first began sending forces toward the Kuwait border at the beginning of this month, the United States had only a small number of planes at Dhahran with the ability to attack ground troops -- 18 F-16's. Counting British Tornados and Saudi warplanes, the forces allied against Iraq had only about 50 planes that could bomb Republican Guard troops during the early days of the crisis, according to Brig. Gen. William Michael Guth, the commander of the Air Force unit at Dhahran.
Another way to blunt the Iraqi threat is to push them back from Kuwait by establishing a buffer zone around the tiny gulf state. In explaining how such a zone might work, Mr. Perry said that all Republican Guard units would be required to withdraw north of the 32d parallel. If they went south, they would be subject to allied air attack.
Mr. Perry said today he did not think United Nations approval was needed to establish such a buffer zone but that important details needed to be worked out with allies. The Republican Guard forces near Nasiriya are right in the middle of the proposed buffer zone, some 50 miles south of the 32d parallel.
Speaking of the Iraqi deployment near Nasiriya, Mr. Perry said that the United States would withdraw the 30,000 ground troops it is planning to deploy to the region if Iraqi forces in southern Iraq returned to the positions they held in September.
"If the Iraqi forces return to their original location, we will terminate our deployment when it is completed, and shortly thereafter we'll start phasing a redeployment back to the United States," the Defense Secretary said.
He added, "No U.S. redeployment will begin as long as the Iraqi forces remain in a threatening or destabilizing position."
Mr. Perry even threatened to expand the American deployment beyond the 30,000 troops and 400 to 500 aircraft already planned, in an apparent warning that Washington could build up an offensive force to evict the Republican Guards from southern Iraq if necessary.
Another way to counter the Iraqi threat is to store equipment in the Persian Gulf area that American forces could use in a crisis. But that would require cooperation from Saudi Arabia and other gulf states.
Officials familiar with Mr. Perry's discussion with Saudi officials on Thursday said that the Saudis gave a noncommittal response to the idea of storing American tanks and other Army equipment in the kingdom.
Nor did the Saudis give a direct response to a proposal by Lieut. Gen. Richard Neal, deputy commander of the United States Central Command, that the United States and Arab troops hold a major land and air exercise in Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Prices Rise For 2d Consecutive Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday for the second consecutive session after a Government report showed moderate inflation pressures at the consumer level in September.
The report on consumer prices provided the bond market with further evidence that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise short-term interest rates before the Fed's policy-making committee meets on Nov. 15. 
 "Price pressures are not yet showing through to consumers," said Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company in New York, adding, however, that "the operative word is 'yet.' "
The price of the 30-year bond rose 8/32 , to 968/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.83 percent, from 7.85 percent on Thursday.
The economic reports yesterday showed a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in consumer prices, an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales, no growth in industrial production and a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in capacity utilization.
But Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said, "These benign pieces of data are very likely temporary, particularly production and the rate of utilization, which should once again start to climb as the auto industry moves into high gear during the fourth quarter."
He said the increase in September retail sales strongly suggested an acceleration of economic growth in the fourth quarter. Sales were not only stronger than market expectations, but were once again led by the durable goods component -- a strong indication that higher interest rates have yet to make their impact on consumer spending.
"All of this clearly points to further Fed tightening," Mr. Fine said, "with the next move expected at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Nov. 15, and more to follow thereafter."
Despite the positives in yesterday's reports, Mr. Sherman of M. A. Schapiro said, previous data have shown inflationary pressures intensifying. Among them, he said, have been capacity utilization rates, low unemployment rates, rising commodity prices, purchasing managers' reports and expectations for higher prices among both business people and consumers.
"The last point, being expectations," he said, "is important because price increases are easier to pass along if people are expecting them."
The market moved higher yesterday after the release of the Federal Reserve's report on industrial production in September, which was weaker than expected. But the flat figure follows a healthy gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in August. Analysts said the report should not be read as a sign of the economy cooling off substantially.

HEADLINE: Clinton Administration Reports a Breakthrough in North Korea Nuclear Arms Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials said today that they are on the verge of a "significant breakthrough" with North Korea that would permanently freeze its threatening nuclear weapons project and provide for a resumption of international inspections.
In return, the officials said, Washington is offering a number of concessions, including an agreement to assure the Communist Government a steady supply of coal and fuel oil, and later to arrange for America's allies in Asia to construct nuclear power plants in the North worth billions of dollars. 
 In another concession that could stir considerable criticism here and in South Korea, the Administration would agree to defer a special inspection of two sites that would likely reveal information about North Korea's past production of weapons-grade plutonium.
The West's insistence on such an inspection has been a central dispute with North Korea for a year and a half. The history of Washington's negotiations with North Korea has been filled with false starts, near agreements, collapsed negotiations and accusations. But American officials said they were convinced that this time there was reason for optimism.
"We believe we're on the edge of a possibly major agreement," said Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, at a State Department symposium on economic cooperation in Asia.
Mr. Lord gave no details of the negotiations that have been underway for the past two weeks in Geneva between North Korean officials and an American team led by Robert L. Gallucci, the senior State Department official in charge of nonproliferation.
But other officials involved in the talks described the agreement in detail, and said that a final accord could be reached as soon as next week. "We are very, very close," one senior official said today.
Mr. Gallucci refused to give any details of the pending agreement to reporters in Geneva today, saying only, "We are going to continue meeting for a while."
Some American officials, however, speculated that the North could be attempting to complete the accord before the formal installation of Kim Jong Il as North Korea's paramount leader. Mr. Kim has apparently met little resistance to his taking the job since the death of his father, Kim Il Sung, in mid-July.
But the younger Mr. Kim has yet to assume several of his father's titles, an event that could take place as soon as the end of this month, when the 100-day mourning period for the elder Mr. Kim ends.
As described by American officials, a draft agreement being refined in Geneva calls for North Korea to permanently freeze operations of its five-megawatt nuclear reactor, whose waste fuel can be purified into weapons grade plutonium. It would also freeze the construction of two larger reactors that would have given the North a far larger supply of plutonium, the core ingredient of nuclear weapons, in coming years.
The North would also agree to full, regular inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency, whose inspectors have been barred from many sites since early last year, when the North threatened to withdraw from the Nuclear NonProliferation Treaty.
North Korea would also would be required by the agreement to fully re-enter the treaty, which it first signed in 1985, the officials said.
But as part of the deal, the Clinton Administration also appeared ready to back down on a key demand, that the North send its recently acquired inventory of 8,000 nuclear fuel rods, enough to make four or five bombs, to a third country.
Instead, Pyongyang would be permitted to keep them in a cooling pond for a lengthy period of time, perhaps years. That would essentially create an insurance policy for the North, assuring that it would keep a supply of plutonium at hand in case the United States, South Korea, or Japan reneged on their parts of the agreement.
The accord now being made final would also apparently delay, perhaps for several years, a "special inspection" of a suspected nuclear waste dump that could reveal how much plutonium North Korea has produced in recent years.
The North has steadfastly refused to allow that inspection to take place, saying the site was a military facility unrelated to its nuclear program.
If the United States agreed to put off such an inspection, it would constitute a significant change of position for President Clinton and his aides. Since last year they have repeatedly said that such an inspection is a prerequisite for any comprehensive agreement.
South Korean officials, who have expressed sharp reservations in recent weeks about the wisdom of striking a deal with the North's new leadership, said in Seoul that they thought an agreement could come as quickly as this weekend.
Last week, in an interview with The New York Times, South Korea's president, Kim Young Sam, accused the Administration of naivete in dealing with the North, and said that the West should do nothing to prevent the Communist Government from an economic and political crisis that could sweep it from power.
Getting the South's full agreement to any deal with the North is essential, because Seoul would be stuck with much of the bill for aid to Pyongyang. The Adminstration is considering sending Defense Secretary William J. Perry to the South Korean capital next week, after his trip to Kuwait, China and the Philippines, apparently to try to sell the deal to South Korea's leadership.
For the North, the most important feature of the pending agreement is likely to be the assurance of a steady source of energy to keep its few remaining factories running. While there are no reliable measures of North Korean output, American intelligence agencies have estimated that half to two-thirds of North Korea's industrial facilities have ground to a stop, largely because of a lack of power.
Under the accord, the North would receive coal and fuel oil in sufficient quantity to make up for the power that would have been generated by the three nuclear power plants it has agreed to abandon. It is unclear who would provide the fuel, but experts speculate that most of it would come from the South, under terms that would not require the bankrupt Communist government to pay for it for years.
Pentagon officials have been concerned for some time that any fuel given to the North could be diverted to the military, worsening the threat to South Korea. State Department officials said that problem has now been resolved.
"The way we are structuring the deal, we are making sure the North does not get any fuel they can pour into their tanks," said one American official.
Over time, the North would also be provided with several light-water nuclear reactors, a type that produces waste that is far more difficult to convert into weapons-grade fuel.
The reactors would be financed and built by a consortium led by South Korea, whose leaders expect to make use of the facilities if the Korean Peninsula is eventually reunified. Japan would also invest heavily in the power project, but the United States, which is barred by law from providing aid to the North, has said it would not be a financial contributor.
The agreement also calls for a gradual upgrading of relations between Washington and Pyongyang, following the model used with Vietnam. If the North carries out its early agreements, officials said, the two countries would exchange liaison offices. But full diplomatic relations would remain years away.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nestle's Aim: New-Market Growth

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VEVEY, Switzerland

 BODY:
Nestle S.A., the Swiss conglomerate best known for its chocolate and coffee, is looking for further growth through finding fresh markets for its foods and beverages rather than through more costly acquisitions.
Nestle's purchase last month of Alpo, the American dog food brand, from its British competitor Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. was the latest in a string of takeovers that included the British chocolate maker Rowntree in 1988 and Source Perrier of France in 1992. More recently, Nestle bought Buitoni of Italy, and deepened its ties with L'Oreal, the French cosmetics group that Nestle hopes to control fully some day. 
 Helmut O. Maucher, Nestle's chairman and chief executive, is generally credited with having awakened a sleeping giant during his 13 years in office. He says that roughly two-thirds of Nestle's growth over the last decade came through acquisitions and one-third through internal expansion.
"In the next 10 years the ratio will reverse," Mr. Maucher said in an interview at Nestle's headquarters here near Lake Geneva. "We're in all the fields we want to be in."
Management experts say they like the focus of Mr. Maucher, who is noted for his strategic planning.
Nestle is a corporation with a "very clear business mission," said Fredmund Malik, a professor of management at the School of Business Administration in St. Gallen, in eastern Switzerland. Nestle had a "relatively well-manageable business," he said, adding, "For that reason, maybe, Nestle is no fashionable corporation."
Mr. Maucher, whose father worked for Nestle, joined the company in his native Bavaria in 1948, and worked his way up to chief executive in 1981. In December he will turn 67, well short of the company's compulsory retirement age of 72.
Under his stewardship, Nestle had sales totaling $39 billion last year. The company employs 209,000 people and does 98 percent of its business outside Switzerland, with 490 factories in 69 countries.
Nestle's cash flow -- it was $3.4 billion in 1993 -- and operating profits are daunting. Net earnings in the first half of this year amounted to $990 million. A disappointing growth in earnings of only 1.7 percent over the corresponding period in 1993 was largely caused by the strength of the Swiss franc, Nestle's accounting currency, which deflated revenues earned in strong markets like Germany or the United States.
Mr. Maucher estimated that 13 to 15 percent of Nestle's equity was held by American investors, generally through American depository receipts. Last February Nestle reversed plans to have its stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Its chief financial officer, Reto F. Domeniconi, attributed the change of mind partly to American reporting requirements, but the pressure placed on management by the scrutiny of quarterly reporting also annoys Nestle executives.
"If you're looking for a go-go stock, don't buy Nestle," Mr. Domeniconi said.
Still, some of Mr. Maucher's international competitors must envy Nestle's single-mindedness. Unilever N.V., the giant British-Dutch group whose food division competes with Nestle, has seen its management distracted by the Procter & Gamble Company's recent onslaught against Unilever's soaps and detergents. Philip Morris, another international player whose Kraft foods and Maxwell House coffee compete with Nestle brands in many countries, continues to be hobbled by controversy over its tobacco business.
Mr. Maucher is hardly averse to further takeovers. But the main impetus for future growth, he says, will come from geographical spread and internal expansion. This includes developing new products and adapting existing products in some markets to other untapped markets.
For example, Mr. Maucher talks about selling Buitoni pastas or Kit Kat chocolate bars in Japan or about making Maggi dehydrated soups, which are popular in Western Europe, in Slovakia. The trend in industrialized countries toward healthier convenience foods with longer shelf lives enables Nestle to extend its strong stable of brands like Carnation, Nescafe, Contadina and Buitoni.
For the moment, the strongest growth is coming from Nestle's geographic spread. Credit Suisse, in a recent report, estimated that Nestle's growth outside the mature North American and European markets was averaging about 15 percent a year.
The leading region is East Asia, where Mr. Maucher says the company's business is growing between 10 and 13 percent annually. Last year Nestle opened six new factories in Asia, among them plants to make dim sum in China and Kit Kat chocolate bars in Japan.
The revival of Latin America's economies has made the region Nestle's second-largest growth area, after Asia. And in Eastern Europe, Nestle has bought chocolate factories in Poland and the Czech Republic and is packaging Nescafe instant coffee and Nesquik chocolate in Hungary. To soften up the huge Russian market, it is importing instant coffee from its factories in India.
Analysts say Mr. Maucher has introduced an unaccustomed pragmatism into Nestle during his tenure, stifling distaste for deals with the competition by entering into successful joint ventures. Nestle now cooperates with General Mills Inc. to sell breakfast cereals like Cheerios in 25 countries outside the United States, cutting into Kellogg's market predominance in Europe and Asia. Over the last year, Nestle's cereal sales with General Mills have grown 24 percent, to $390 million.
Working with the Coca-Cola Company, Nestle sells soft drinks like Nestea iced tea and coffee in cans. Earlier, it formed a joint venture, called Clintec, with the Baxter Healthcare Corporation in the United States to develop hospital nutrition products.
Mr. Maucher's acquisitions have focused on Nestle's core businesses of food and beverages, where the goal was a commanding market share for Nestle brands. An illustration of this was Nestle's push into the mineral water business, where it became the world leader after taking over Perrier in France. Another buying spree in the United States acquired Arrowhead water in California and Poland Spring in Maine. As a result, Nestle now commands a quarter of the American market.
"Springs are like petroleum," Mr. Maucher said. "You can always build a chocolate factory. But springs you have or you don't have."
Perhaps less clear is what Mr. Maucher intends to do over the long term with Nestle's nonfood businesses, particularly pharmaceutical and cosmetic products. Nestle owns a profitable American manufacturer of eye care products, called Alcon and based in Fort Worth. It also holds a 49 percent share of the financial holding company that owns two-thirds of L'Oreal, the world's largest cosmetics group.
"In future I see these areas growing, and I say, 'Why not?' " Mr. Maucher said. "But food and beverages remain our priorities."

HEADLINE: Goldman, Sachs Lays Off 70

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it had let go 70 employees in its fixed-income and J. Aron commodities operations, or about 5 percent of the employees in those units.
"Due to the prolonged, industrywide turndown, some belt-tightening has been necessary," Goldman said in a statement. "Each business unit and office did its own reassessment and made small, selective staff reductions." 
 Goldman partners said last week that the firm planned to cut about 5 percent of its 9,200 employees. The 125-year-old firm, Wall Street's oldest and richest investment banking partnership, earned $2.3 billion last year before partners' taxes. Goldman is on track to earn $600 million to $700 million for the 1994 fiscal year, which ends next month, a partner said.
Goldman announced the cuts three days after it named 58 new partners, the largest group of new partners elected at one time to the firm.
Profits have dwindled at many Wall Street firms because of a rising interest rates and slumps on bond markets worldwide. A number of firms, including Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers, CS First Boston, Paine Webber and Smith Barney, have cut jobs this year.
Goldman dismissed about 56 people in New York and the rest in London. More cuts are expected in the firm's other divisions, which include equities and investment banking, a person familiar with Goldman's London operations said.
