HEADLINE: METHOD AND MADNESS;
Truly Gross Economic Product

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
Suppose you consume about 10 pounds of food and drink a day. If you live to be 80, then a total of 146 tons of consumables will have swilled down your gullet. Enough to turn the scale against two M1A1 Abrams tanks.
Nature averts such portliness with the equivalent of a built-in thermostat that keeps that body at a more or less fixed weight. Considering the torrents of high-calorie food that flood through every day, this device works with amazing accuracy. Unfortunately, its settings are easily deranged by greed, genetics and the influences of culture. 
 The human weight-control system was designed for our paleolithic past when starvation, not gluttony, was mankind's most constant threat. Hence, the body has the capacity to pile on excess poundage whenever its owner feels compelled to crash satiety's amber light.
From minute flaws, calamities of grossness flow. In 1980, one in four Americans was overweight, defined by the National Center for Health Statistics as being 20 percent above the ideal weight. By 1991, one in three Americans had waddled past this benchmark. Obesity experts are not sure how to explain the phenomenon. "I must say I am absolutely stumped by it and I think most people are," says Albert J. Stunkard of the University of Pennsylvania and co-author of a leading obesity textbook. Though no trend carries on forever, it's arresting to imagine how far this creeping national expansion might go before something gives.
The steady inflation of the national girth is imperceptible day to day. But you may have noticed the warning signs: how often you are squashed in a bus or plane seat by an overlarge person next to you; how the people in the placid heartland are even more overweight than those on the frenetic coasts (Wisconsin has the highest prevalence of obesity in the nation).
But to see the national fat crisis in truly stark perspective, fly to Tokyo. Once you've recovered from the shock of discovery that large cities can be immaculate, orderly and virtually free of street crime, you may notice another discomfiting comparison: the sidewalks are thronged with slim, fit-looking people among whom the only corpulence belongs to American tourists or the occasional Japanese teen-ager who may have passed too often through the golden arches of Makudonarudos.
The excuse will rapidly suggest itself that American obesity is a disease of civilization and that Japanese are slim because they continue to eat a traditional diet of rice and fish. But the Japanese are at least as civilized as anyone else and have long been affluent enough to afford an American diet if they wanted it.
For another lesson in the nature of obesity, consider the inhabitants of Nauru, a Pacific isle northeast of Australia, where everyone was dirt poor until the eons of bird droppings that formed much of its territory proved to be a rich source of minable phosphate. The inhabitants found sudden wealth. They also became the most blubbery folk on earth. Nine out of 10 people on Nauru are obese.
Affluence makes obesity possible; some cultural difference must keep Japanese lithe but nudge Americans toward excess. I blame our economists, who have set consumption and consumer fulfillment as the highest purpose of an economy. Japan's have long favored the opposite goal: heavy saving by consumers with sumptuary spending reserved for the captains of industry to invest in conquering new markets. The economist's meaning of consumption is broader than the literal sense of the word, but in practice the distinction is not so significant. In accord with their respective economic philosophies, American consumers are deluged with urgent invitations to indulgence, while Japanese are beset with high prices that encourage frugality.
It's tempting to speculate on other ingredients of the Zeitgeist that have promoted American embonpoint, like the fading of the cold war and competing ideologies, but more interesting is the strange complacency surrounding the subject. Many people go on diets or intend to, even to the point of spending some $30 billion a year on weight-loss efforts. But most dieting is just eating in another form. If real worry about weight is to be measured in terms of actually sweating off calories, it's indicative that less than 10 percent of us take exercise even three times a week. A recent article in The New Republic accused the "medical-health-beauty" establishment of wielding the concept of obesity to stigmatize the nonsvelte and scare up business.
Then there is the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance, which claims to speak for some 80 million Americans. "People think that if we wanted, we could all be thin," says Sally E. Smith, the group's executive director. "But dieting programs don't work. The more you diet, the fatter you become. Instead of how do we make fat people thin, it should be how do we make them healthy." Her position amounts to saying it's society that should change, not fat people. She's right to fight prejudice against the fat, many of whom inherit a genetic disposition that may make weight nearly as impossible for them to control as height. Fatness runs through populations like a bell-shaped curve and inevitably some of us are more bell-shaped than others. But the circumstance of individuals who cannot help being fat is quite different from that of a whole society slipping complacently into tubbiness.
The fat acceptance group is also on shaky ground in denying the ill health effects of fat. Some kinds of fat can be serious, especially for men, even though it is women who throng the fat clinics.
Some people find an excuse for our bloat in secular trends. Donald Bliwise, a sleep disorder specialist at Emory University School of Medicine, notes that Americans are getting an hour less sleep a night than they used to because of overwork. People may eat more, he suggests, to compensate for the lack of sleep.
We're fat because we work too hard? A seductive explanation, but there's little evidence to support it. We've lapsed into stoutness because we lead a sedentary life style; we slouch in front of televisions that preach instant indulgence over thrift and forbearance and we love pigging out on fat-laden foods. Is it wrong to be Rubenesque? That's a matter for moralists and arbiters of fashion. But we'd surely be healthier in not straying so extravagantly from the lean and hungry world for which nature designed us.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 40; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1512 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Ten Little Houses and How They Grew

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio

 BODY:
THE BUILDING OF NEW MU-
seums was a major architecture story of the 1980's. Learning how to use them is turning out to be one of the big stories of the 1990's. In the past few years, a new generation of architecture and design curators have joined the staffs of American museums. They are only beginning to figure out how these institutions can best serve architecture. It is not going to be an easy process, to judge from "House Rules," a show of residential architecture at the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio. This is a flawed exhibition. But it is also just the kind of experimental venture that museums with a serious commitment to architecture must support.
Up to now, the Wexner Center has presented only traveling architecture shows initiated by other museums. With "House Rules," it initiates its own architectural program, and perhaps it is not surprising that the show has much in common with the architecturally ambitious building in which it is presented. Designed by Peter Eisenman, the Wexner theoretically provides a cultural bridge between the ivory tower and the city beyond. But Eisenman's cryptic meanings probably escape those who don't work the academic side of the street. 
 "House Rules" suffers from a similar form of introversion. Though the show grapples with social issues, it disdains the pragmatic tools traditionally employed by architects to effect social change. There is little of practical value for American homemakers in this show of largely theoretical designs. There is nothing to comfort the homeless. But the show does open up an important set of questions about the right of architects to redefine what is "practical" and about the value of museum shows that help them to assert that right.
Organized by Mark Robbins, the Wexner's curator of architecture, the show sets out to explore connections between the design of houses and such social factors as race, class and sex. Each of the 10 projects on view was produced by a team of architects working in collaboration with a social critic or theorist. Ostensibly chosen to represent a rainbow of social perspectives -- feminist, gay, Latino, black -- the participating architects include Michael Sorkin; Hank Konig and Julie Eizenberg; Adobe L.A.; Henry Smith-Miller and Laurie Hawkinson; Joel Sanders, and Mabel O. Wilson. Their critic-collaborators are Joan Copjec, Bell Hooks, Margaret Crawford, Silvia Kolbowski, Jonathan Crary and Heidi J. Nast. Each team was asked to design a house for a standard 80-by-100-foot lot. Beyond that, the teams were given little guidance on how to carry out the show's ideological agenda.
Clearly, this is a highly polemical show, though the argument is somewhat veiled. At heart, it is a response to the conservative crusade for family values and to the "neo-traditional" housing in places like Seaside, Fla., which embody that crusade in architectural form. The 10 projects add up to a protest against attempts to impose rigid social norms on a diverse society. If there's any logic to the idea that private houses can perform this political function, it goes something like this: Families live in houses. Architects design them. Their designs reflect prevailing social attitudes. As those attitudes change, the designs change. And perhaps designers can accelerate social change by representing progressive attitudes in built form.
There are sound historical reasons for proceeding with this logic. The ideal home plan proposed in 1869 by Harriet Beecher Stowe and Catharine Beecher in "The American Woman's Home" recognized the emancipation of women. The open floor plan of Frank Lloyd Wright responded to the increased social informality that accompanied suburban growth. In both cases, design both reflected social changes and helped make them a reality.
But a world of difference separates these precedents from the work on view at the Wexner. Beecher and Wright were designing for the cultural mainstream. They sought to define new middle-class norms. The projects at the Wexner are pitched against the mainstream. Their designers want to break the grip of homogenized norms and allow heterogeneity to flower across the land.
Whether noble or knee-jerk, the show's social agenda is not easily translated into buildings. Aren't we reinventing the wheel here? Has there ever been a more heterogeneously housed nation than present-day America? Lofts, log cabins, luxury high-rises, trailers, brownstones, ranch houses, studios, Victorian charmers, inner-city casitas, bungalows: American architecture is already far more diverse than the society it houses. Pay your mortgage, take your choice.
Nor do we lack a sign language to identify the subcultural affiliations of those who dwell within. From the mezuza by the door to the political sticker in the window, there is no shortage of symbols with which residents can proclaim their identities to the outside world. Of course, when architects begin to prescribe such devices, they run the risk of perpetuating social stereotypes.
For the most part, the Wexner projects studiously avoid this risk. The designs emphasize flexibility and openness as architectural metaphors for an enlightened society that has progressed beyond pigeonholes. But such a neutral approach contradicts the show's underlying premise that buildings should reflect cultural difference. And weren't flexibility and openness already hallmarks of the neutral modern house?
There's another contradiction in this show. Diversity is not encompassed by individual visions. It results from a multiplicity of visions, many of them incompatible. In theory, one might expect 10 individual architects to produce 10 very different projects. But many of the projects on view are quite similar. Most of the collaborating social critics have been strongly influenced by literary deconstruction. While only three of the projects resemble the deconstructionist esthetic of architects like Zaha Hadid and Coop Himmelblau, all of them are, in effect, "deconstructions" of the single-family dwelling unit. It is hard to see how diversity would gain by lifting people out of Seaside and setting them down in Decon City.
Architects should be developing alternatives to the neo-traditional models. But "House Rules" does not propose genuine alternatives. What it presents, rather, are examples of a hermetic, self-sufficient strain of contemporary architectural culture, one so self-absorbed that it neither expects nor desires to make a significant impact on the material world. Instead, this strain finds fulfillment in the realm of the school, the museum and the academic publication. How can these architects present alternatives if they inhabit another sphere altogether?
One project, "House, 20 June 1994," made the whole show worth doing, and it clicked not only because of an eminently sensible design -- a complex of four units grouped around a central courtyard -- but because the collaboration took the form of disagreement. Julie Eizenberg, an architect whose firm has produced some of the most impressive housing in Los Angeles in recent years, is a pragmatist with little patience for theoretical convolutions.
What architects need to reckon with, Ms. Eizenberg wrote to Bell Hooks, her collaborating critic, is not theory but "planning regulations, banks, economics and structures for the protection of personal assets." Ms. Hooks, in reply, insisted that architecture is influenced by theories, whether they are explicitly stated or concealed, and that it's better to be aware of them. The exchange, reproduced on a Plexiglas box containing the model, conveyed a completeness of vision that the show as a whole did not. Together, the architect and the writer discovered that architecture is a medium with a unique capacity to connect the conceptual and material realms.
OTHERWISE, "HOUSE RULES"
illustrates a breakdown in that connection. It suggests that the most conceptually sophisticated young architects today are unable or unwilling to embrace the practical tools of their profession. While the Wexner deserves credit for exposing that breakdown, it would be even more commendable if the museum helped repair it. Instead of match-making architects with theorists, why not pair them with developers or public officials? Don't architects have enough theories of their own? Surely the architects at the Wexner don't seem to be running short.
The issue isn't whether architects should be designing conceptual projects. It is what museums should be doing with them. Sixty years ago, when the Museum of Modern Art pioneered the idea of presenting architecture in an art museum, it pursued a twofold mission: educating the public and persuading builders and manufacturers to embrace modern design. This mission wasn't the result of excess ambition. It reflected the view that architecture differs fundamentally from painting and sculpture; it finds fulfillment not within a museum's finite frame of esthetic experience but in the world beyond it. That theory is worth holding onto.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The kitchen of "Sight Specific," above, a project at the Wexner Center, and at right, "House, 20 June 1994" -- Flexibility as a metaphor for a society that has gone beyond pigeonholes. (Wexner Center for the Arts)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2525 words

HEADLINE: Breakthroughs That Conquer Space

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
COMPLETELY hemmed in by their two young children's large plastic cars and plastic make-believe Dutch door and plastic house and pile of strollers, Lynda and Steve DeLott wait eagerly until they can knock a door through to their neighbor's apartment, which they have a contract to buy.
As their older son sleeps a few feet away, in what was once the dining alcove, they whisper: "Only three more days until we close, and then the adults are taking back the living room." 
 Sixteen blocks south, Elizabeth B. Grant says that since the archway was cut in the wall connecting the living room of her two-bedroom rental apartment to the living room of the rental studio next door, she doesn't feel so claustrophobic.
"I sat in that chair last Sunday and wrote my whole psychology paper," she said, surveying what has become a 24-foot expanse. "I never would have done that before."
High above the traffic at 64th Street and West End Avenue, Peter Claman, an architect who has worked in New York City for 40 years, points to a switch panel and some pipe risers in the skeleton of a fast-rising rental tower.
"We now design apartments so people can combine them," he said. "We keep the major electrical and plumbing out of the way, and we lay out adjoining apartments so the right rooms line up to make sense when the apartments are joined."
Combining apartments, it seems, has become a Manhattan trend.
From parents who only a few years ago would unhesitatingly have moved to the suburbs, to wealthy couples who have developed a taste for 40-foot drawing rooms, there are, real-estate brokers say, more people than ever out there looking for more space.
Real estate agents are knocking on the doors next to apartments that have been stagnating on the market, often explaining to the surprised neighbors that if they agree to offer their apartment for sale at the same time they may be able to make more money than if they tried to sell their apartment by itself. As a combination, agents say, the apartments can be sold a lot faster.
"THE sum is greater than two parts," said one agent, echoing verbatim the comments of three others.
In some cases joining apartments is actually restoration. Apartments in buildings erected around the turn of the century often were split up into several smaller apartments, which landlords found easier to rent in the post-Depression era, although the floor plans seemed a little truncated.
Even in the heyday of the late 80's these cut-up apartments -- by then turned into co-ops -- were hard to sell, but as the recession hit, their awkward layouts made it even harder to attract buyers.
Co-op boards in these once-grand buildings may now encourage combining apartments, notably when the separate apartments were one in the original layout. There are currently two apartments for sale in the Dorilton, at Broadway and 71st Street, that, if combined, would reattach an almost unsalable back apartment with two bedrooms, and another bedroom pressed into service as a living room, to its much more elegant front half -- which suffered from a lack of bedrooms. The apartments, which together total 2,750 square feet, are being offered together for $599,000.
Similarly, an original 2,000-square-foot, eight-room apartment at 160 Riverside Drive, at 88th Street, that had been split into two apartments recently was reunited at a closing, selling for $490,000.
The New York City Department of Buildings acknowledges the trend and has proposed legislation to make it easier for landlords and co-op and condominium owners alike to merge apartments.
In an effort to stop apartment dwellers who had bought or rented the adjoining apartment from ripping out walls illegally -- without building permits -- Joel A. Miele Sr., the Buildings Commissioner, wants to cut down the time it takes to get city approval for such work.
"We want to make it so easy for the customer that he won't even consider going around the process," said Mr. Miele, whose proposed changes would let the tenants' licensed architects and engineers give the go-ahead to start work without waiting for time-consuming city building inspections. The legislation to change the city's Building Code is being reviewed by the city's Corporation Counsel.
Thus far, the urge to combine apartments seems to be mostly limited to Manhattan, according to a Buildings Department spokesman, who speculated that this was because most large apartment buildings were there. In brownstones and rowhouses, requests to combine apartments are rare, the official said.
C. B. Whyte, a real estate agent with Ambrose Mar-Elia, said the first flurry of combining apartments began in the late 80's in postwar buildings east of Lexington Avenue on the Upper East Side, which were designed with mostly one-bedroom apartments.
"For whatever reason -- either a good rental deal or they weren't able to sell -- people who would have moved out decided to annex the next apartment and stay in the building," said Ms. Whyte, who has participated in the sale of two combinations recently. Many of the new combinations, she said, are made by young couples with toddlers "who can't afford to move to Park Avenue," where large prewar apartments have been left intact.
In the case of the DeLotts, it was a mixture of not being able to sell their one-bedroom apartment and a hard-fought decision -- which Lynda DeLott insisted upon and Steve DeLott is continually rethinking -- not to move to the suburbs and, instead, to enroll their 4 1/2-year-old, Joshua, in a Manhattan school next year.
"I HAD a lot of reservations," said Mr. DeLott, an associate with one of Manhattan's blue-chip law firms. "Maybe buying the apartment next door will become part of an exit strategy. We tried to sell our apartment, but we paid $212,000 at the height of the market, August 1988."
"We figured we'd start at what we paid, then we dropped it to $205,000, then to $199,000 and then we stopped," he continued. "We weren't getting offers, or I guess we got a couple but any offer we got would've required us taking a $40,000 or $50,000 loss."
Then the DeLotts were approached by their neighbor Lenore Kramer, who is moving to Sutton Place.
"I thought he was a natural," Ms. Kramer said, referring to Mr. DeLott. "He's in that little apartment, but at first he said, 'Nah, we're moving to the suburbs.' I put the apartment on the market for six months and I was just about to rent it out. My phone rang off the hook -- nobody wants to buy, everybody wants to rent -- but two days before I was going to rent he knocked on my door."
The DeLotts are buying Ms. Kramer's adjoining apartment for $161,000, "significantly lower than her original asking price," Mr. DeLott said. The deal was "done in five minutes," Ms. Kramer added.
They were lucky because the two apartments fit well together. Their bedroom exactly lines up with Ms. Kramer's master bedroom, making an easy pass-through. The DeLotts' present bedroom will become their formal dining room, while their dining alcove will become the library. Ms. Kramer's apartment will house the combined apartment's three bedrooms.
For the present, the DeLotts will leave the kitchen in the Kramer apartment, taking advantage of a large loophole in the city building code. By making the connecting door a fire door and leaving the kitchen intact, the DeLotts will not have to file for a certificate of occupancy change: "You can take two apartments and open a door and it'll still remain two apartments," Mr. Miele, the Buildings Commissioner, said. "If they take out the kitchen, it then can no longer be occupied by two separate tenants so you're reducing the number of apartments in the building."
The DeLotts were also lucky because maintenance charges in their building, 425 East 79th Street, are relatively low, making a combined monthly payment of $1,573, considered low for a full three bedrooms and a formal dining room with 1,800 square feet.
Their decision, they say, is hardly unusual.
"It's catching on," said Ms. DeLott, a lawyer who has chosen not to practice while the children are young.
"Friends with a two-bedroom on East 73d off Third had their third child a year ago," she said, "but the wife wasn't ready to move to the suburbs so they went to the woman who lived in the studio next door and offered her money to leave. She left."
"Other friends bought a two-bedroom at a bank foreclosure," she continued. "They're trying to unload their junior four and if they do, they'll buy the apartment next to the two-bedroom and break through, but they won't do that until they sell theirs."
SUCH juggling can pay off, real estate agents say. If the layout is good and the maintenance is reasonable, the combined apartment often brings more money than the two separate apartments.
Even if the separate maintenances are high, the combined maintenance may end up being reasonable because two additional bedrooms may be gained by converting the second living room and the second kitchen to bedrooms. Thus, one two-bedroom apartment plus another two-bedroom apartment can become a six-bedroom apartment, or a five-bedroom plus den or formal dining room.
According to I. Dolly Lenz, a Sotheby's agent who specializes in big condominiums, combinations have been occurring at such notable condominium buildings as Trump Tower, Museum Tower, Olympic Tower and the Galleria. At 1049 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, Jack Heller, the owner, is working with Ms. Lenz to design and market a combination of two high-floor 3,350-square-foot apartments, which are being converted into a duplex.
Ms. Lenz said that the separate apartments, which had not sold, were being marketed separately, at a total of $3.5 million.
"They were nice-sized apartments but not big enough," she said. The new combination will list for $4.5 million.
Ms. Lenz said combining apartments "never occurred to people five years ago."
"They just sold their apartment and moved," she said. "But that was because they could sell at a profit."
BOTH real estate agents and lawyers specializing in residential real estate caution anyone considering buying the apartment next to, underneath or above their own to check out several issues carefully before signing a contract to buy.
"Ideally, you should try to get the contract of sale conditioned on approval of the board of directors to combine the apartments," said Mark E. Zimmerman, a midtown lawyer who specializes in real estate matters. Conceding that the likelihood of a seller's signing such a contract was "slim," he said the next best thing was to check to see if the board had allowed other tenants to combine apartments.
Combining apartments reduces the total number of units in a building and almost always requires a change in its certificate of occupancy. Any changes requiring building permits need the approval of the co-op or condominium board. For a certificate of occupancy change, the city may require new plans of the whole building, as well as a rigorous new inspection for code violations.
"Some of the older buildings may not welcome such an inspection," said Deanna Kory, the Halstead Property Company's top-selling agent, who noted that in the last year she had seen more separate apartments being combined than ever.
At 60 Riverside Drive, at 78th Street, Ms. Kory said, one woman is leaving a four-bedroom apartment she created by merging two apartments and is moving to a five-bedroom in the same building that she created by combining three apartments. Ms. Kory called 60 Riverside a "combination-friendly building."
But even if a building is "combination friendly," Ms. Kory and Mr. Zimmerman said, mortgage banks may not be. Bankers, Mr. Zimmerman said, may not understand or believe that buying two apartments with two separate entrances and two kitchens isn't being done strictly as an investment, a venture they are reluctant to finance. The banks may even require an escrow deposit in the amount of the work projected to remove the second kitchen and make other necessary improvements.
"BUYERS should get their financing lined up in advance," the lawyer said.
With rentals, it can be even more time-consuming as tenants wait for a rent-stabilized neighor to move.
Elizabeth Grant, a student, and her husband, David, a Manhattan public relations agent, first asked their landlord about renting the studio next door in combination with their own two-bedroom apartment at 250 East 63d Street in 1986. Within hours, they said, the landlord put under their door a floor plan showing the combined apartments. But like their own apartment, the studio next door was rent stabilized and it took until this year for the man who occupied it to move out.
"We spent months wrangling over the new rent," said Ms. Grant, explaining that with such a deal the rent on the studio rises to market value and that when she first called the landlord, "I offered him a figure and he accepted. Then he called back a couple of days later and raised the price by $300 a month, but I accepted because I was afraid we'd lose it."
Under rent regulations, it can be to the landlord's advantage to agree to such a combination. When two apartments are combined, accompanied by the major work such a change usually entails, the rent for the combined apartment may rise to market value, according to a spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which oversees rent regulation. Once the new rent is set, that amount is stabilized, he said. If the landlord had merely rented out the newly vacated studio, he would have been allowed to raise the rent a maximum of 9 percent above what the former tenant had paid.
Ms. Grant declined to say what rent she was paying for either apartment, but said that the addition of the studio doubled their previous rent for the two-bedroom. To create the large archway connecting the two apartments, complete with carpentry, paint and the reinstallation of several electrical outlets, cost the Grants about $5,000.
CHARLENE KEOGH, a Manhattan interior designer currently working on three combinations -- including the Grants' -- gave the following estimates for typical costs associated with joining apartments:
* Filing and permit fees, plus the fees of a building-code consultant and an expediter: $3,000 to $5,000.
* Removing the second kitchen's cabinets and capping the plumbing pipes: $100 per cabinet and $150 each to remove the sink and dishwasher.
* Installing a closet in what had been the second living room to make it a bedroom: $1,600 to $2,000 for a 5-foot-long closet with light and standard pole and shelves.
With the demolition of the second kitchen and the renovation of both bathrooms, plus hiring an interior designer, a code consultant and an expediter to help with the bureaucracy for a certificate of occupancy change, the Grants now have made a sizable investment in a rented apartment.
"I've never thought of it as anything other than our home," said Ms. Grant. " Still . . . " She paused and laughed, "with what we put into this apartment, they're going to have to carry me out of here."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Keeping Budgets Honest

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
A REGULAR fall ritual in New York City co-ops is the budgeting process. This time around, some major concerns are looming as officers and managers make their projections for 1995.
Those concerns include rapidly rising water and sewer charges and increased scrutiny of budgets by lenders and prospective buyers. Moreover, opportunities to keep maintenance from rising are dwindling as some costs that had stabilized or dropped in the last five years -- interest rates, fuel, insurance, among others -- begin once again to inch upwards. 
 All of which means that shareholders should prepare for a maintenance increase over and above what might have been customary in recent years.
The added scrutiny by lenders and buyers, said Stephen Beer, a partner with Czarnowski & Beer, Manhattan accountants specializing in co-ops, is a natural outgrowth of the financial problems that co-ops have been facing. It will require more accurate forecasting to avoid losing credibility in the marketplace.
"It used to be location, location, location," said Mr. Beer. "Now it's becoming financials, financials, financials. Nobody ever used to ask for the budget before. Now I get requests all the time."
Buyers and lenders expect to see at least $100,000 in a reserve fund, or $2,000 to $5,000 per unit, and mortgage debt under $20,000 to $40,000 per unit, Mr. Beer said. If that is not the case, the budget may need to bolster the amount set aside for capital reserves and for paying down the principal on an underlying mortgage.
If it turns out that the co-op is continuing to underestimate its line-item costs -- even if enough cash is in the bank at the end of the year to cover any shortfall -- it raises a red flag and that is "going to look very bad," predicted Mr. Beer.
Stuart M. Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, agreed. In the documents accompanying newly financed underlying mortgages, he said, lenders are demanding a break-even budget and the right to intrude on the board's own determinations, yet another reaction to the co-op turmoil of the early 90's.
In addition, he said, the co-ops should also start a regular pattern of half-yearly reviews to see where adjustments may be needed before the numbers get out of hand, even if this means raising maintenance charges in midyear.
He further recommended discounting anticipated maintenance income to allow for continued shareholder defaults. The percentage of income the co-op lost during 1993 could serve as an estimate, he said.
Although it has never been customary for co-ops to include a contingency amount -- since this puts added pressure on maintenance charges -- it might now be advisable, Mr. Saft said, to include a cushion of anywhere from 5 to 10 percent.
Another way to keep the budget looking good, said Mr. Beer, is to set up a separate account for the larger bills that are paid quarterly or yearly, like taxes and insurance, so there's always enough cash on hand when these come due. He said he had seen too many co-ops unable to meet these larger charges in a timely fashion because cash on hand was temporarily too low. This way, $500 might be set aside each month, say, for a $6,000 yearly charge.
The only good news results from state legislation earlier this summer that altered the way real estate taxes were calculated for Class II properties, which cover the city's co-ops and condominiums.
A result should be a saving of about 45 cents for each $1,000 of assessment during the first half of 1995, said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives. And it should lessen any potential rise for the remainder of that year.
But Ms. Rothman said that treasurers and managers should confirm that the tax escrow collected by the holders of the building's underlying mortgage had been adjusted downwards to reflect those changes. Labor costs should similarly stabilize as a result of the most recent union agreements, she said.
Water and sewer charges are among key costs that may continue to rise during 1995, predicted Barry Manson, president of ABM Management of Great Neck, L.I. "Every one of our buildings has seen a doubling of these costs over the past eight years whether they changed over to meters or not," he said. And with no effort to challenge those increases on an industrywide basis, he said, everyone is left wide open to further price rises. He recommends a 9 percent increase for water and sewer costs. However, Steven Ostrega, executive director of the New York City Water Board, does not expect the increase to exceed 5.5 percent.
Insurance is another charge widely predicted to increase. Co-ops have saved substantial amounts over the last seven years as premiums regularly declined because of competitive price-cutting. That benefit is now gone.
Carla Vel, vice president of Kaye Insurance Associates of Manhattan, which also specializes in co-ops, warned that the underwriters had to rebuild reserves as a result of large payouts stemming from the unusual number of recent natural disasters -- storms, hurricanes, floods and earthquakes. They cannot afford to make further cuts in premiums, she maintained. But she doesn't expect them to rise by more than 5 percent.
Management costs may also rise as those managers who used to take kickbacks from vendors cannot count on this added income anymore, putting an upward pressure on legitimate salaries. The extensive investigation by the Attorney General of those kickbacks -- which has been continuing all year -- may also cause the demise of certain firms, lessening competition.
Oskar Brecher, president of American Landmark Management, argues that management costs may go up by as much as 10 percent for yet another reason. Sales operations at management companies used to subsidize management, he said, but now the two functions are increasingly being separated as sales divisions are no longer willing to see their profits undercut to make up for management contract shortfalls.
Mr. Brecher further warned that repairs might cost more as the bidding process also comes into the open -- another result of the management kickback scandals.
"When you have to make a formal bid for a job you tend to charge more just to make sure," he said.
However, a contrary argument could be made suggesting that the elimination -- or near elimination -- of kickbacks should actually lower contract costs.
A more complete discussion of the 1995 budgeting process is available by attending a workshop called "The Budget," part of the 14th annual conference of the Council of New York Cooperatives. The workshop is scheduled for 11:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. on Sunday, Nov. 13, at Hunter College. Call the Council at (212) 496-7400 for further details.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Stamford, Conn.;
From Corporate Campus to Service-Industry Hub

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
LAST month, when Swiss Bank announced it would leave New York for Stamford, Conn., it was big news in both cities. New York, still smarting from the defection of small-but-high-profile Mastercard to Westchester, now faces the prospect that 1,300 Swiss Bank jobs -- and 700 planned new ones -- will vanish up Interstate 95. Stamford not only gets the jobs, but also a new office complex in a seedy part of town.
Stamford officials and landlords profess delight, but not surprise. After all, Connecticut gave Swiss Bank tax breaks that could amount to $120 million over 10 years. And, they note, Swiss Bank is just the latest -- albeit the largest -- company leaving New York for Stamford these days. 
 "Swiss Bank is just an exclamation mark to what is happening here," said H. Darrell Harvey, president of The Ashforth Company, a Stamford real estate concern.
Indeed, Stamford is going through a renaissance. According to Christopher P. Bruhl, president of the Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut, more than 300 companies have relocated to Fairfield County -- most to Stamford -- in the last five years. Very few of those, Mr. Bruhl notes, were given incentives to come.
"Those relocations aren't because of incentives or cheap rents," Mr. Bruhl said. "If you want cheap, you go to Brazil or North Carolina. We're about value."
Stamford afficionados predict even more newcomers in Swiss Bank's wake.
"All the service companies that will follow, the accounting firms, the legal firms, even the messenger services, will gobble up the remaining space," said Michael J. Cacace, a partner in Cacace, Tusch & Santagata, a Stamford law firm.
Apparently, investors believe that, too. In the last few years Zell/Merrill Lynch has spent $132 million to buy five office buildings. Equity Office Properties has paid $146.45 million for another five Stamford buildings and has been renovating them.
"We feel all of these buildings are undervalued assets and that the Stamford market has hit bottom," said Patrick Lerch, Equity's northeast regional manager.
Stamford's nascent revival is being actively nurtured. Local officials persuaded the state to put a University of Connecticut campus in downtown Stamford, at the site of a closed Bloomingdale's. A new cultural center has opened. So have nightclubs, discos and restaurants that cater to a young, lively crowd. The train station will be getting a $50 million overhaul next year, which will double its capacity for trains by 1998.
BUT all that is nothing compared to Stamford's overhaul in self-image. Over the years, the city has gradually metamorphosed from an old-line manufacturing center into a service industry hub. The Business Council's statistics show that employment in finance, insurance and real estate -- the so-called FIRE sector -- in the greater Stamford area has grown 45 percent in the last five years.
"This area has a tremendously well-educated, highly professional labor pool," said Mr. Harvey. "Those companies that can afford to tap into it are getting the best."
The new service emphasis has been a wrenching change for Stamford. During the 60's and 70's, Stamford evolved into a corporate campus city, a place where industrial companies like Olin, Xerox and Combustion Engineering built palace-like headquarters. Lawyers, accountants and others looking to serve the industrial behemoths soon followed. Well-paid executives for those companies moved nearby, to parts of Stamford and to such neighboring communities as Greenwich, New Canaan, Darien and Westport. For no small reason is Fairfield County known as Connecticut's Gold Coast.
But in the late 80's the lagging economy forced many corporations to cut staff, and thus space. Many others subscribed to the growing belief that American corporations had too many layers of management. They, too, began pruning their staffs.
The effects of downsizing, as well as of the highway congestion that had accompanied the earlier expansion, rippled throughout Stamford. Many downtown stores closed or moved to the Stamford Mall. The F. D. Rich Company, for decades Stamford's premier office-building developer, lost its buildings to its lenders one by one.
"By 1991 Stamford real estate was dead in the water," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W & M Properties, which owns two Class A office buildings in the city.
The aftershocks continue. According to the Edward S. Gordon Company, the real estate concern, the International Business Machines Corporation, Olin and ABB Combustion Engineering returned more than 650,000 square feet to the Fairfield County market in the second quarter of 1994.
Cummings & Lockwood, perhaps the area's largest law firm, Champion International and Lone Star Industries each put big blocks of space on the market for sublet. GTE and other companies that are not looking for sublet tenants have nonetheless shrunk enough to rattle around in their buildings.
BUT the good news has been considerable, too. Stamford never relied heavily on now-beleaguered industries like military contracting. GE Capital, now its leading corporate citizen, has expanded to several buildings and is buying Olin's 277,000-square-foot headquarters.
A few other large companies are looking at Stamford with renewed interest. Brokers say Elizabeth Arden is looking for 100,000 square feet and that two computer-related companies are also looking for large chunks of space. Swiss Bank is expected to rent more than 100,000 square feet of interim space while its new downtown complex is being built.
And Stamford has been enjoying the same "flight to quality" that buoyed much of Manhattan's midtown during the recession. Small companies found they could move into a premier Stamford building like Metro Center or the General Reinsurance building for annual rents in the low $20's per square foot and operating costs that, at about $8 to $10, are half what they are in midtown.
"Twenty dollars will buy you a lot more here than in Manhattan," said Michael Trolle, a first vice president of the CB Commercial real estate brokerage.
"Stamford has become a place where 5,000-square-foot deals are the norm and where a 30,000-foot tenant can drive a hard bargain," said Michael Siegel, an executive director of Edward S. Gordon.
The influx of smaller companies has lent a new aura of stability to the market.
"In the 80's, four tenants moving could mean 600,000 square feet of vacant space," said Mr. Malkin. "Today, you'd have to lose 30 tenants before you had a 150,000-foot vacancy. It's the end of the corporate elephant as the dominant factor."
INDEED, owners are actively courting smaller companies. Realty Venture Capital Associates recently bought a 140,000-square-foot Stamford office building from its lenders. Harold Siegelaub, a general partner, says he thinks the going market in town for space in a property like his is about $22 a foot. "But," he says, "I'll do $3 or even $5 a foot better for a software company, a marketing firm, any company in a business that I feel will grow with us."
And tenants, do, indeed, grow. JMW Consultants moved from about 5,000 square feet in midtown Manhattan to 15,000 square feet in Metro Center in July. "We came because of real estate values, but we love it here now," said one JMW employee.
Thompson Publishing's information publishing group moved from Park Avenue, where its corporate headquarters was, to Metro Center in 1989 because "there was no business reason to be in New York City, so why pay twice the rental," said Gerald D. Tenser, a vice president. Since then Thompson has brought over an operation from Teaneck, N.J., and is about to move its headquarters staff to Stamford.
"Yes, there's an energy level, excitement, work pace in New York that we don't get here," Mr. Tenzer concedes. "Frankly, it's boring. But it costs less, and the quality of life is just terrific."
Indeed, even shrinking companies seem disinclined to move out. Savin Corporation, an office machine company, emerged from bankruptcy in December. It has moved from a total of 37,000 square feet in two Stamford buildings into 26,000 square feet in a third Stamford building.
"We're in a building with a health club, a sundry shop, a cafeteria, and we even got an incentive from the state to stay," said a Savin spokeswoman, Louise Stix.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
For Commercial Leasing, '94 Has Been a Good Year

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
WHEN Mastercard made it official last month that it would move its headquarters from Manhattan to a former I.B.M. building in Purchase, brokers predicted the move would result in a sharp decrease in the year-end office vacancy rates and an overall market rebound that might last into the middle of 1995.
Mastercard is expected to complete the purchase of the 472,000-square-foot building at 2000 Purchase Street by Nov. 30, said Michael H. Siegel, executive director of the Westchester/Fairfield offices of the Edward S. Gordon Company of White Plains, which is handling the sale for the International Business Machines Corporation. 
 That deal -- coupled with the expected signing of a lease by the Ciba Corporation, the chemical company, by the end of the year for 575,000 square feet in Tarrytown -- could result in a decrease of 4 percentage points in the vacancy rate, Mr. Siegel predicted.
According to the Edward S. Gordon Company, the vacancy rate for the third quarter of this year is 20.8 percent, down slightly from 21 percent the same time last year. Other concerns that track vacancy rates are also reporting steady levels and overall vacancy rates hovering in the low 20's.
"The Mastercard and Ciba deals alone represent one million square feet of space," Mr. Siegel said. "And we've already had one million square feet of space leased so far this year. We're on track to have one of the best years in Westchester since numbers have been recorded, which started in the late 1970's."
Mr. Seigel and other brokers cautioned, however, that just as a few good deals could make the picture look suddenly bright, the reverse could happen if one or two companies decided to vacate a large block of space.
Nynex has already announced its plans to vacate two buildings, 1111 and 1113 Westchester Avenue in Harrison with a total of 350,000 square feet, by the middle of next year. That move affects 800 employees who, the company said, will be relocated to Manhattan.
"We won't feel that impact until the middle of 1995," Mr. Seigel said. "So maybe there's just this little window of time where things will look very positive."
The overall feeling in the market is that while corporate consolidations will continue, they will not happen at the same rate or be as large as in previous years. In the third quarter, for instance, I.B.M. vacated 134,156 square feet at two sites and Nynex decided to sublease 40,000 square feet.
Vacancy rates have held steady, brokers say, because of a higher-than-expected volume of leasing. According to the CB Commercial Real Estate Group, in White Plains, in the first three quarters of this year a total of 1.6 million square feet was leased. "That's excellent leasing activity in any year," said Frank Tomasulo, first vice president with the company. "That's the best we've seen in the last 10 years."
ANOTHER positive sign brokers point to is the size of the average transaction. "We're seeing a greater number of 10,000- to 20,000-square-foot deals," said Terry Brown, a managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. "Recently the Westchester market has been dominated by 2,000- to 5,000-square-foot deals. The appearance of more midsize companies is what we've been seeing in Fairfield County for a while now. It's a healthy sign and shows a broader and more diverse base."
One of the largest transactions in the third quarter, reported by Edward S. Gordon, was the purchase of a 51,000-square-foot building in Mount Kisco by the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts, which had been looking for a new home for six years. Last month, the not-for-profit organization moved from 4,000 square feet in Goldens Bridge.
"We had outgrown that space a long time ago," said Bira Rabushka, executive director of the center.
Yet with so much space available in the county, the center still had a great deal of trouble finding the right place. "Sometimes we had problems with the neighbors who didn't want an arts center in their backyard," Ms. Rabushka said. "In some cases, the building was right, but the location was wrong."
The building was bought at auction for $775,000, said Ms. Rabushka. And even though the organization has increased its space more than tenfold, she said, "we already have every square inch earmarked."
The center is now trying to raise $3 million to make needed repairs and refurbish the interior to create a "multi-arts space," Ms. Rabushka said.
Some of the other larger deals in the third quarter included Avon Products, which expanded to 35,000 square feet in Rye, and Marshall Cavendish Corporation, the publishing company, which acquired 31,477 square feet in Tarrytown.
"THERE'S no question that the larger company is interested in Westchester," said Mr. Tomasulo. "I'm talking with Fuji Photo Film U.S.A., which would take 100,000 square feet and Allstate, which wants 25,000."
In recent months, several companies have been in contact with the county's Office of Commerce and Economic Development, according to Margaret Soter, director of the office, who said, "We're busier than ever."
Ms. Soter said that five "very large companies" had recently expressed interest in moving to Westchester. "These companies each represent hundreds of jobs," she said.
Ms. Soter attributes some of the interest to the publicity attending the Mastercard move. "It's had a very positive effect," she said "It's an image-building thing."
Nevertheless, the main reason companies like Mastercard and others eventually move to Westchester is to save money, according to John Rostenberg, principal of Rostenberg-Doern, a commercial brokerage in Purchase.
"The time is right because New York City's rents are rising," he said. "And with the market there tightening, companies can now find tenants for the space they have."
If present trends continue, Mr. Rostenberg added, Class A space will no longer be available. "That's when you'll start to see build-to-suit construction starting again, which is something we haven't seen in several years," he said. "I wouldn't be surprised if companies were taking out old plans and dusting them off. It might not happen this year or even next, but it will happen."

HEADLINE: The Oil-Futures Bloodbath: Is the Bank the Culprit?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
IT'S a classic mystery twist: No sooner do the police arrest the obvious suspect than a brainy private eye comes on the scene and says that they've got the wrong guy -- the real villain is innocent-looking Mr. X.
That's more or less the latest turn in a real life financial whodunit involving a $1.3 billion loss from trading in oil futures, Germany's most powerful bank and the New York subsidiary of one of Germany's largest industrial concerns. 
 Last winter, when Deutsche Bank whisked Metallgesellschaft, a sprawling metals and oil conglomerate, from the brink of ruin, most observers accepted the bank's version of events: A bunch of financial cowboys at Metallgesellschaft's American subsidiary, MG Refining and Marketing, were making hugely risky bets with oil futures. When an unexpected plunge in oil prices threatened staggering losses, Deutsche Bank, Metallgesellschaft's biggest shareholder and creditor and the power behind the company's supervisory board, did what it had to do: It fired the old management, brought in a SWAT team to liquidate the bets, installed a new management and lent the company money to cover the losses.
That was last winter. Now, three American financial sleuths -- Nobel Prize-winning economist Merton Miller, former bank examiner and doctoral candidate Christopher Culp and futures and options expert Steve Hanke -- are saying that far from being the good guy, Deutsche Bank is the culprit. It misunderstood a prudent, fully hedged oil marketing strategy, they contend, and, in a blind panic, sold off the hedges with catastrophic consequences.
"They thought it was an oil bet that had gone sour," said Professor Miller, who is on the faculty of the University of Chicago's business school. "But that's not what happened. They cut the hedge off too soon. If they had done things right, they wouldn't have lost $1.3 billion."
Mr. Hanke, a professor at Johns Hopkins, added, "Old management was doing a very clever hedging program. It was people on top that did precisely the wrong things."
Normally, traders, dealers and other financial market pros don't pay much attention to "pointy headed intellectuals" -- Professor Miller's term -- but the professors' analysis, contained in several articles, has had an electric effect. When it surfaced this fall, investors hammered Metallgesell schaft and Deutsche Bank stock -- and Metallgesellschaft's new management, along with Ronaldo H. Schmitz, the Deutsche Bank director who is chairman of Metallgesellschaft's supervisory board, fired back.
A news conference last week in Frankfurt, called by Metallgesellschaft to criticize a draft of one of the Miller-Culp articles, shows just how raw a nerve the academics struck. At the conference, senior executives of Metallgesellschaft handed out their own paper, which said that while the professors' theoretical points were valid, "where Miller and Culp go wrong is moving from theory to reality." Metallgesellschaft would have faced a $50 billion loss if it hadn't liquidated the hedges, the executives said.
"Preposterous," was Professor Miller's reply. "I deny the allegations and I defy the allegators."
As for Deutsche Bank, when asked for comment about the flap last week, a spokesman, Helmut Hartmann, said, "It is not a Deutsche Bank matter. It is a Metallgesell schaft matter. We have no comment."
One reason for all the commotion is that many people in banking and oil were already privately questioning the official account. "Nobody else could say it publicly," said Mark C. Brickell, a Wall Street banker. Merton Miller, Mr. Brickell added, "has his Nobel Prize, he has tenure. He doesn't have anything to lose except his reputation as an intellectual."
THE stakes in the debate are huge. The German and American governments are investigating the Metallgesellschaft debacle. Several lawsuits are in the works. Conceivably, Deutsche Bank could wind up being liable for the loss, as could the old management at Metallgesellschaft.
The howls of outrage delight Mr. Miller, a witty, fast-talking Boston native who compares himself to military historians who come in after "the smoke, noise and confusion have cleared" and draw "the diagrams with the triangles and arrows."
Professor Miller, a public director of the Mercantile Exchange in Chicago and an ardent fan of free markets, was drawn to the Metallgesellschaft affair as much by the fear that the scandal would prompt a wave of regulation as by sheer curiosity.
"We in the futures industry in Chicago wouldn't be paranoid if people weren't always picking on us," he said.
Sitting in his cluttered office last February, Mr. Miller asked Mr. Culp to help him look into the case. Both men thought it would make a nifty assignment for a graduate futures and options course.
Their first discovery, based on court documents, was that MG Refining and Marketing seemed to have been engaged in a hedging strategy rather than simple speculation. "I could understand how you can lose $1.3 billion by speculation," said Professor Miller. "But I couldn't see how you could lose $1.3 billion hedging."
Complicated as hedging strategies often are, they all boil down to the same thing. Hedging is a technique for offsetting the price risk inherent in any cash market position by taking an opposite position in the futures or options market.
From court records and press accounts, it became clear to Professor Miller and Mr. Culp that MG Refining's problems began with a unique marketing strategy. To break into the American market, in 1991, it began offering small retail customers -- gas stations and fuel oil dealers -- fixed-price contracts for 5 to 10 years for heating oil and gasoline. Oil prices had just dived in the wake of the Gulf War and lots of customers were keen to lock in cheap supplies. By mid-1993, MG Refining had entered into contracts to deliver some 160 million barrels over the next 10 years.
To protect itself against the possibility that oil prices would rise above the selling price minus some margin to cover costs and profits, MG Refining bought futures contracts. These were bets that oil prices would rise. If they did rise, MG Refining would reap large short-term profits to offset looming losses on its long-term delivery contracts. Because futures contracts typically are purchased to cover deliveries just three to six months down the line, MG Refining had to keep rolling them over to hedge its long-term commitment to deliver the 160 million barrels.
IF oil prices fell, MG Refining would lose money on its futures contracts, since it had agreed to pay a higher amount for the oil involved in those deals. But those would be paper losses as long as the futures contracts were rolled over. The losses would be offset, over time, by bigger profits on MG Refining's long-term supply contracts because in that case the company would be buying oil at a substantially lower price than its customers had agreed to pay for it.
"Our intellectual contribution was showing that contrary to public perception," said Mr. Culp, "you can hedge long-term commitments with short-term contracts, if you do it right."
In March, Professor Miller went public with his views in a keynote speech to the annual meeting of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association. Addressing an audience of active users and dealers in derivatives -- a term that applies to all financial instruments, including futures, whose values are linked to changes in the market price of a commodity or security -- Professor Miller mentioned that what MG Refining had been doing might not have been as bad as news reports suggested.
But it wasn't until they had pored over the documents and constructed their diagrams that Professor Miller and Mr. Culp figured out what, in their view, really had gone wrong: That Deutsche Bank panicked as MG Refining's paper losses mounted.
MG REFINING's hedging strategy had huge cash flow requirements once paper losses grew, since that forced the company to ante up bigger cash deposits, or margins, to back up its investment. The parent company's $1.5 billion standby line of credit was supposed to finance that effort.
But last December, as MG Refining's paper losses grew, Metallgesellschaft's supervisory board refused to let it use the credit line. After dismissing virtually the entire management of Metallgesellschaft and MG Refining, Mr. Schmitz and other supervisors ordered the futures contracts liquidated. That not only turned paper losses into real ones, the professors said, but it left MG Refining exposed to the risk that oil prices would rise, which they did, causing losses on the long-term delivery contracts, a classic double whammy.
"I originally thought it was a liquidity problem," Professor Miller said. "There's some of that. But in my current conception, it was a case of intellectual risk. The classic case occurs when your staff is bid away and you now have nobody at home that understands the strategy. In this case, the staff wasn't bid away, it was fired."
Professor Hanke, who taught Mr. Culp when the latter was an undergraduate at Johns Hopkins, got involved in May after he read a draft paper prepared by Professor Miller and Mr. Culp. He saw that its conclusions were important because the Metallgesellschaft debacle was being cited as an excuse for legislation he regarded as unwarranted. "There are now four pieces of legislation in the pipeline in the U.S. to regulate derivatives," Professor Hanke said.
Professor Hanke and Mr. Culp then wrote an essay for International Economy magazine stating the Miller-Culp thesis in nonacademic language. At around the same time, Professor Miller and Mr. Culp mailed out their draft paper to three dozen or so people in the industry and academia. A month or so later, in mid-September, Professor Hanke turned up the heat in a Forbes column in which he reckoned Metallgesellschaft would have come out nearly even if the hedge hadn't been sold off.
At that point, Metallgesellschaft's stock nosedived, falling more than 20 percent on Sept. 26 and 27, to 118 marks, and Mr. Schmitz talked to reporters to rebut the professors personally. "The quick unwinding of the futures positions was the correct professional move," he told reporters. (The stock, which traded at more than 400 marks a year ago, closed Friday at 172.)
Mr. Schmitz's basic point is that hedges were too expensive to keep in this case, and some traders think he is partly right and have criticized Messrs. Miller, Culp and Hanke for not taking all costs into account.
Still, there is little sympathy for Mr. Schmitz, who was already under heavy criticism for not spotting the problems at Metallgesellschaft sooner. And there is a certain amount of glee among Deutsche Bank's rivals that it has egg on its face.
The hedging strategy "might have been considered aggressive, but it wasn't outrageous or even unusual," said a senior executive at another European bank. In any case, "you would expect group management to be aware of it. The notion that they were bamboozled is absolute hogwash."

HEADLINE: The Good Life After Goldman

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
IT is Wall Street's most elite club, and every two years its new members are selected, capping months of anxiety with elation for the chosen ones. They are the new partners at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the last major investment banking partnership in America.
Goldman added to its inner circle last week, when the firm named 58 new partners, a record crop. They are mostly in their 30's, and nearly all men, plucked from the ranks of the firm's more than 9,000 employees. The partners do assume risk because, as owners, they share in losses as well as profits -- and this year has been a tough one for Goldman and the rest of Wall Street, as rising interest rates brought spectacular trading losses. 
 Still, being a partner at Goldman is about as close to a sure thing as there is anywhere in the business world -- a ticket to wealth and prestige. A Goldman partnership, says Samuel Hayes 3d, a finance professor at the Harvard Business School, is "the epitome of professional recognition on Wall Street." And financially, he adds, it is "the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow."
Yet under the partnership pact, the partners have to wait for the pot of gold. The Goldman partners enter into a kind of Faustian bargain, exchanging years of exhausting toil and relative wage restraint for the lure of early retirement with multimillion-dollar payoffs. The new partners agree to work 12-hour days and more, some travelling constantly, always at the beck and call of the firm. An unwritten code of behavior applies as well. Teamwork and understatement are part of the Goldman ethos. Sharing credit for victories is appreciated. Flashes of ego are not.
Long hours and grueling travel schedules, of course, are routine in the upper echelons of investment banking. But the work regimen at Goldman is notoriously demanding and the partners are expected to pay that personal price.
Stephen Friedman, the firm's 56-year-old senior partner, who recently announced that he would step down at the end of November, explained, "I missed seeing my children grow up. I want to see my grandchildren grow up."
Typically, Goldman partners retire -- or "go limited," in the firm's parlance -- well before Mr. Friedman, most of them in their late 40's. And they certainly have the financial freedom to do so. Their financial arrangement with the firm is the ultimate forced savings program. Every year, each partner is allocated a share of Goldman's profits, but those profits must be reinvested in the firm until retirement. One result is that during their partnership years, they collect modest salaries, by Wall Street standards, of $200,000 annually, supplemented by interest payments on their capital.
But the arrangement also means that before they reach 50, each partner can count on a nest egg of at least $10 million. And Goldman now encourages youthful retirements both to make room for new partners and keep the partnership ranks lean -- and extremely lucrative for the partners. Even with all the new ones coming aboard, Goldman's total count of active partners will be only about 180. In the last two years, 29 partners stepped down. Average age: 47.
Given its wealth and early-retirement policy, Goldman is a launching pad for second careers and second chances. Former partners are in all kinds of fields including government, academia, the arts and, to the dismay of some at Goldman, back on Wall Street at rival firms.
Some went to high-profile, high-pressure jobs like Robert E. Rubin, a former senior partner, who is now one of President Clinton's trusted policy advisers as the head of the National Economic Council. Kenneth D. Brody, who ran Goldman's real estate division, is now president of the Export-Import Bank. On Wall Street, Leon Cooperman, Goldman's former head of research, runs a successful fund that invests aggressively for wealthy clients. Geoffrey Boisi, who ran mergers and acquisitions at Goldman during the takeover boom of the 1980's, quit to set up his own investment boutique.
But others took the money and the opportunity to stray far away from their careers in finance. Here are three who embarked on entirely different careers -- and lifestyles -- after Goldman:
 
Study, Charity -- and an Airplane
 Michael Coles never went to college. As a teen-ager, the Briton thought he wanted to be an engineer. But by the time he was 18 in 1950, Mr. Coles decided that engineering was not for him. With little idea what he did want, he joined the Royal Navy, learned to fly and ended up piloting single-engine fighter-bombers from an aircraft carrier during the Korean War.
After eight years in the service, he decided to apply to Harvard Business School, which he said was "kind enough to ignore my lack of formal education."
Mr. Coles joined Goldman, Sachs right after graduating from business school in 1961. After several years in the firm's corporate finance department, he was named a partner in 1968 and asked to head up Goldman's international business.
For the next 18 years, he opened offices for the firm in London, Zurich, Tokyo and Hong Kong. By the mid-1980's he became convinced that it was time to leave the business to younger people.
"If someone comes in on a Friday afternoon before a holiday weekend and announces that we are going to have to work through the weekend, the Young Turks say, 'O.K., let's do it,' " he said. "But the 50-year-old says, 'Hey, wait a minute guys, do we really have to do this?' "
MR. COLES became a limited partner at the end of 1986 at age 55. The limited partners are given an office at Goldman and a secretary, but they usually take most of their capital out of the firm in the few years after they step down. For his part, Mr. Coles decided that he wanted to go back to school. "I had always had an interest in history, and I wanted to write history," he said.
Admissions administrators at Columbia University were not so obliging. "It was kind of hilarious because they could not grasp the idea that someone who did not have an undergraduate degree could go to graduate school," Mr. Coles recalled.
When he told an administrator that he already had a master's degree from Harvard, Mr. Coles said the man replied, "Even Harvard makes a mistake sometime."
After taking some courses on a part-time basis, Mr. Coles convinced a few professors in the history department to help him gain admission as a full-time graduate student.
His years at Goldman gave him model study habits. "When you went into a meeting with a client, you made sure that you were prepared," he said. In his studies, Mr. Coles quickly found that it was possible to be too prepared. "My main frustration was having to keep quiet," he said.
He ultimately received a second master's degree, writing his thesis on China's intervention in the Korean War and is currently at work on a study of British-American naval relations in the Pacific during World War II that he hopes will be published as a book.
Like most of the Goldman limited partners, Mr. Coles is also involved in charity work. He is chairman of the Manhattan Theatre Club and is on the executive committee of the Foreign Policy Association. He and his wife are also active in the Nature Conservancy and the Inner City Scholarship Fund.
He also maintains his links to the firm, serving as a part-time investment banking adviser to Sumitomo Bank, which has $625 million invested in Goldman.
But he also makes time to fly his antique biplane and to go sailing. "I would never say that since going limited I've spent every day with my nose to the grindstone," he said.
 
Restoring an Inn
 Robert Mnuchin describes his decision to retire from the front lines at Goldman as a "wrenching" one. "I loved my career," he said. Last week, Mr. Mnuchin's son, Steve, who trades mortgage-backed bonds, was named a partner at the firm.
Mr. Mnuchin landed a job as a trainee in the firm's equity department in 1957 after a brief stint in the Army, and spent 33 years on the trading floor, rising to become one of the most influential people in the equities business.
Under the tutelage of Gus Levy, Goldman's legendary leader in the 60's and 70's, Mr. Mnuchin helped pioneer the now-common practice of "block trading," which allows pension funds and other institutional investors to buy and sell large numbers of shares in one company in a single transaction.
"I had no dissatisfaction," he recalled recently. "I simply decided, after a lot of soul searching, that I would like to create the opportunity to have other experiences in life."
Although he didn't have a plan when he decided to become a limited partner in 1990, a project soon came along. Mr. Mnuchin and his wife, Adriana, a successful businesswoman who created the retail clothing franchises Tennis Lady and Cashmere-Cashmere, decided to buy and restore an inn near their weekend home in Washington, Conn.
The Mayflower Inn, which first opened in 1920, had a long history of distinguished guests, including Eleanor Roosevelt. But it had fallen into disrepair and had closed a few years before the Mnuchins bought it.
THE couple had all but one of the five buildings demolished, and started over. They hired a local architect and took pains to recreate the feeling of the old inn with antique furnishings and formal landscaping, while adding modern amenities like a fitness spa.
Since reopening in 1992, the Mayflower has received favorable reviews, though with room rates ranging from $225 to $495 per night not including meals, you practically have to be a Goldman partner before you can afford to stay there.
Mr. Mnuchin has since turned his attention to his other great passion: modern art. During his years on Wall Street, he and his wife amassed an impressive collection of works by American abstract expressionists including Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning and Mark Rothko.
LAST year, Mr. Mnuchin converted the bottom two floors of the couples' five-story townhouse on East 78th Street in Manhattan into C&M Arts. The gallery specializes in selling the works of postwar American artists such as those represented in the Mnuchins' private collection.
One of the major differences between being a collector and running a gallery, Mr. Mnuchin said, is the difficulty finding exceptional works regularly. "When you set your goal to have a gallery that is going to specialize in artists who are historically very important, you want to present high quality from within their oeuvre," he said, sitting in a room at C&M Arts surrounded by works of de Kooning and Rothko that each sell for more than $1 million.
Nevertheless, Mr. Mnuchin has established a reputation for himself as a shrewd dealer and the gallery has been praised for the high quality of its exhibitions. "I would not want to sacrifice quality to make money but the gallery is a serious business and it is making money," he added.
Despite his devotion to Goldman and his years on Wall Street, Mr. Mnuchin said that he neither trades nor follows stocks now. "I loved watching the tape then," he said. "I'm deeply immersed in other things now."
But all is not rosy. The Mnuchins recently ran into trouble when it was discovered that their new $900,000 home in Connecticut is 6 feet higher than local zoning regulations allow. Their application for a variance was denied, and they are unsure what they will do next.
 
Becoming a Local Pol
 William Gruver understands the Mnuchins' plight. "That's exactly the type of thing that I get involved in," he said.
Mr. Gruver was recently elected mayor of Eagles Mere, Pa., a tiny lakeside resort community of 123 registered voters with a summer population of 500.
"Being a resort community, my biggest job is serving as an intermediary between the summer people and the people who live here all year long," he said.
FOR Mr. Gruver, being able to live full-time in Eagles Mere was the draw of giving up his partnership at Goldman. "As much as anything else, I surrendered to New York City," he said. "I loved my job to the day I left. If I could have lived a rural lifestyle and still been able to commit myself to the job at the level I needed to, I might have stayed."
Mr. Gruver joined Goldman in 1972 after 4 years in the Navy serving on submarines in the Pacific. He rose to head the firm's securities sales department, was named a partner in 1988 and went limited in 1992 at the age of 48.
"I had enough to get by," he said. "A few friends of mine had already died. There were things that I wanted to do."
Unlike Messrs. Mnuchin and Coles, Mr. Gruver planned his exit carefully. He knew that he wanted to live in Eagles Mere, where he and his wife had been spending weekends for many years, and he decided that he wanted to teach, so he wrote letters to all the deans at colleges within commuting distance.
The best prospect was Bucknell University, a small liberal-arts college with about 3,000 students in Lewisburg, 42 miles away.
He had never visited the campus, nor even known an alumnus. "I can get mystical about it," he said. "It was really love at first sight."
The Bucknell campus bore a strong resemblance to the campus of Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., where Mr. Gruver had been an undergraduate. And the dean who interviewed him turned out to have grown up near Mr. Gruver's home town of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.
But it was not, as they like to say on Wall Street, a slam-dunk. When Mr. Gruver described how he planned to leave Goldman, the dean became suspicious.
"They figured I was an escaped convict or something," Mr. Gruver recalled.
"They did some pretty good checks on me and then got interested real fast," he added. Nevertheless, Mr. Gruver was offered a job as a lecturer, the lowest rung on the faculty, for a single semester.
Although he had no experience as a teacher, he was confident. "I had no doubt that I could do this," he said. "I don't know why. It was totally unjustified. But other than my first marriage, I've been pretty good at what I've wanted to do."
After the semester ended, the college offered him a multi-year contract and raised him to full professor, the top rank.
He teaches three courses, including a seminar on investment banking. He has spent the past two summers hiking and climbing in the Alps and the past two Januaries doing the same in New Zealand.
Does he have any regrets about leaving Goldman? "Not this year," he said, referring to the firm's plummeting profits.
"I miss the collegiality," he continued. "Scholars are very solitary people. That's not good or bad. But the kind of collegiality that the nakedness of a trading floor forces on you. I miss that."
