HEADLINE: New Flare-Up in Region's Border Wars Kills an Oft-Ignored Truce

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
Border War II?
It sure sounded like it last week when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened to pull out his big guns in retaliation against Connecticut for luring the Swiss Bank Corporation from New York City to Stamford with a package of tax incentives. The angry words -- Hartford's "shameless raid" versus accusations that New York City officialdom was whining like a "pimply faced freshman" -- recalled the battles over corporations and jobs that have bedeviled the metropolitan area for years. 
 But there is much less to this latest case than meets the eye. In fact, the breakdown of the 1991 truce that forbade New York, Connecticut and New Jersey from luring away each others' businesses is unlikely to have much of an impact one way or the other on companies in the metropolitan area, experts say.
"This is a great way of getting attention, but it's just a distraction from the larger economic challenges facing the region as a whole," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at the Shawmut National Corporation, a bank holding company with headquarters in both Hartford and Boston.
The primary reason to expect little change is that there never was much of a truce to violate in the first place. In recent years, the pact did not prevent Trenton from providing generous assistance to several big Wall Street firms that relocated back-office operations to cheaper sites in Jersey City and elsewhere.
Just last year, Connecticut granted major incentives to Dun & Bradstreet and the Witco Corporation to move their headquarters to Fairfield County. And Mastercard turned its back earlier this year on a New York City offer worth millions of dollars to stay in the city and instead decided to move its headquarters to a much less expensive location in Westchester County.
Meanwhile, state and city officials were forced to put together costly incentive packages of their own to keep big companies like Morgan Stanley in New York and to persuade the two major commodity exchanges in the city to build a joint trading operation in downtown Manhattan rather than Jersey City.
Yet all of these gifts, analysts say, probably had little effect on corporate decisions that were driven more by personal preferences, technological changes and shifts in local real estate markets than by promises of aid from local and state governments.
Moreover, while lots of companies may continue to migrate out of Manhattan even as many other enterprises take root in the city, the Swiss Bank relocation was prompted by unusual circumstances that are unlikely to be duplicated again soon.
For New York, a shotgun approach is the least likely to succeed. It makes little sense for City Hall to target the surrounding region in its efforts to reinforce New York City's strengths as a center for financial transactions and business services. Nor will it do much to improve New York's position as one of the few prime crossroads -- along with London, Tokyo and Los Angeles -- for global enterprise.
"Face it, Connecticut is not the most fertile ground to be hunting," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "We're much better off these days going to Hong Kong and Korea."
Mr. Moss added: "New York City's borders extend far beyond the tristate region. But Connecticut can only think of attracting firms from Manhattan."
What prompted the latest escalation was the decision last month by Swiss Bank to move 1,300 of its 1,500 employees from Manhattan to a 20-story office tower it will build on the last remaining major parcel of land in downtown Stamford, where it plans to hire an additional 700 workers. Connecticut provided the bank with a $120 million package of tax breaks to put the deal together -- worth $60,000 a job in savings to the owners of the bank based in Basel, Switzerland.
That was far more than New York City was prepared to offer to keep Swiss Bank's North American headquarters. The size of the offer pushed New York officials over the edge.
"If you start a border war, you don't really give us much choice but to fight back," John S. Dyson, New York City's Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said on Friday, adding that he planned to begin talks of his own with corporations in Connecticut on incentives to relocate to New York. "New Yorkers are not widely considered to be patty-cakes."
No one is expecting any significant business moves from the suburbs back to the big city, though. Two years ago, New York State officials opened a similar campaign against New Jersey. That came after Trenton, with its share of Port Authority rental income from the World Trade Center, put together a $224 million fund in part to lure companies across the Hudson River. Nothing much happened.
"This is mostly political grandstanding," said Gabrielle Belson Rattner, vice president at the Regional Plan Association, an influential nonprofit organization that promotes regional cooperation for economic development and environmental improvement. "Everybody recognizes by now that these border wars are pointless."
Though not particularly consoling, the brutal recession in the region and the collapse of the real estate market in the early 1990's, which, by opening up many office spaces in existing buildings and bringing Manhattan prices more in line with the rest of the metropolitan area, did more to slow the exodus out of the city than anything else.
State officials now concede that they never expected the earlier retaliation against New Jersey to accomplish anything more than warn Trenton to be more prudent. Still, they say, it would be nice now if Connecticut got a little taste of its own medicine.
"There's a difference between legitimate inducements and this kind of ridiculous financial package where it gets really crazy," said Vincent Tese, New York's Commissioner of Economic Development. "Our focus has always been on retention, not solicting firms from our neighbors. But we agree with John Dyson that Connecticut deserves to be taught a little lesson."
For their part, Connecticut officials insist they didn't go to Swiss Bank; they say the bank's foreign owners, after deciding to leave New York City, came to them. And the price tag for the tax breaks, while costly, is not coming out of the pockets of Connecticut taxpayers, they say, but out of extra tax revenues Hartford stands to receive only because of the bank's move into the state.
"Swiss Bank is a great company," said Joseph M. Cohen, a spokesman for Connecticut's Department of Economic Development. "But I doubt if most New Yorkers would have even noticed the loss if Mayor Giuliani and John Dyson hadn't turned it into a cause celebre."
Whatever the merits of the arguments, the Swiss Bank deal is unlikely to be duplicated.
"This is like locking the proverbial barn door after the horse has left," said Christoper P. Bruhl, president of the Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut. "Nobody is going to stop companies from moving when they want to, but the reality is that this relocation came together because of a unique combination of factors. It's not starting a new trend."

HEADLINE: Idea of Chlorine Against Zebra Mussel Vexes Trout Fishermen

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
A proposal to use chlorine to kill zebra mussels if they enter New York City's reservoir system has Catskills trout fishermen upset.
Although none of the mussels, which invaded the United States from Eastern Europe six years ago, have appeared in the reservoirs, anxious city officials have been preparing for a major battle if they arrive. As part of the defenses, the city has applied to the state for permission to use chlorine to poison the black-and-white-striped mussels if they foul the tunnels and intake valves in the reservoir system. 
 The freshwater mussels, which can survive in brackish water, have caused millions of dollars in damage in other parts of the country when they have had to removed from reservoir systems. They have appeared as far south and west as Louisiana and Oklahoma and as far north as Minnesota and into Canada. In 1990, Washington allotted $37 million to eradicate the mussels.
But trout fishermen worry that chlorine might upset the delicate biological balance in the Esopus Creek, one of the finest trout streams in the country. The Esopus snakes for 12 miles through the mountains between two city reservoirs, the Schoharie and the Ashokan. Rainbow trout, some as long as two feet, abound in the stream.
City officials say the anglers' worries are groundless. They maintain that they will not use chlorine unless the mussels show up and that they will dechlorinate the water before it enters the stream.
"We do not believe we are going to have an impact on that stream," said Sharon Neuman, deputy chief of drinking water quality at the Department of Environmental Protection. "We're only planning to add something to the water if zebra mussels appear there. They may never come. We understand the value of that trout stream."
The fishermen remain skeptical. They say that even minute amounts of chlorine could kill tiny creatures the trout feed upon when they come upstream in the spring and fall to spawn. Trout fishing not only provides recreation, they said, but is also one of the area's biggest tourist businesses.
"You talk to people up here and they are angry," said Jerry Bartlett, a fishing guide and the vice president of the New York Council of Trout Unlimited. "If they kill one fish up here, New York City's drinking water is in trouble."
Trout Unlimited, the Sierra Club and other groups protested the chlorination plans at public hearings earlier this year. State officials are still considering the city's request.
Mr. Bartlett said that if chlorine were to leak into the river accidentally, it would kill all life in the stream. "Economic survival up here is no picnic," he said. "Everything is based on tourism. The river is the real center of it."
The Esopus Creek is one of the few streams in New York with enough life to sustain the wild rainbow trout during spawning season, Mr. Bartlett said.
Ms. Neuman said it is unlikely that the mussels will appear in the Schoharie Reservoir because the reservoir has little calcium, a nutrient mussels need. If they do appear, the plan is to add chlorine around the exit gates of the reservoir to keep mussels from fouling the 18-mile-long Shandaken Tunnel that leads to the Esopus Creek. Then a second chemical would be added at the end of the tunnel to neutralize the chlorine.
The city is also examining alternatives to chlorine, like manually cleaning out the mussels with blasts of pressurized water or using an alternate chemical treatment, potassium permanganate.
The zebra mussels, small freshwater mollusks with striped shells, arrived in the Great Lakes in the ballast water of trans-Atlantic ships. They were first discovered in 1988 in Lake St. Clair, east of Detroit.
With each female producing up to one million eggs, the mussels have rapidly spread, causing economic havoc from the Great Lakes to Louisiana. They have attached themselves by the millions to boats and piers and have clogged intake pipes at power stations, water plants and industrial plants.
In 1990, the mussels were found in the Hudson River. Four years ago, city officials began steam cleaning all boats on the city's reservoirs to make sure that none of the mussels hitched a ride from other bodies of water. Officials have also started a campaign to educate boaters about the dangers of a mussel infestation.
So far, Ms. Neuman, said the city had paid a consultant $4.8 million to devise strategies for combating the mollusks. The city has also committed itself to spending $16 million on water-monitoring equipment and chemicals to avert the feared disaster if the mussels got into reservoirs.
To protect creeks like the Esopus and fish in the reservoirs, Ms. Neuman said the plan calls for introducing chlorine into the water in bursts, once every 9 to 14 days. The biocidal chemical would be dripped into the water in barely detectable amounts at first, then slowly raised to 0.25 parts per million and eventually to 0.5 parts per million if the mussels persisted.
The water from the Schoharie Reservoir would be treated with sodium bisulfate to neutralize the chlorine at a point in the Shandaken Tunnel just before it enters the stream, she said.
"It's a real problem, and we live in a real world," Ms. Neuman said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Four Players Fire the First Salvo of the Free-Agent Wars

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Baseball's free-agent wars began yesterday.
Jim Abbott of the Yankees, Jack McDowell of the Chicago White Sox, Erik Hanson of Cincinnati and Kenny Rogers of Texas put themselves on the front line of the newest skirmish between owners and players by filing for free agency on the first day of the 15-day filing period. 
 Nine other players, including Mark Grace of the Chicago Cubs and Kevin Brown of Texas, put their names on the list, and they most likely will become another phase of the dispute over free agency.
When the Players Association filed the Abbott group along with the other players yesterday, the 65th day of the players' strike, management's Player Relations Committee instantly rejected the four names, saying the players were ineligible because they didn't have the required six years of major league service.
The P.R.C. accepted the other players, though clubs may be told in the next two weeks not to sign them until a new system is in place. The Players Association will challenge both stances, and the triple-damage provision of the expired collective bargaining agreement could play a role in the dispute.
Gene Orza, the association's associate general counsel, said he wanted to speak with the P.R.C. tomorrow before taking any steps to challenge the clubs' position on the Abbott group. But he is pretty certain he knows the answer he'll receive.
"I assume they'll say because of the strike, you don't get service credit," Orza said.
Indeed, Chuck O'Connor, the P.R.C. general counsel, said just that. "My own belief is they have no right to service credit after a strike is called," he said.
The Abbott four and 10 other players needed all or part of the 52 days of the season that the strike wiped out to have the six years of major league service needed to be eligible for free agency.
Abbott, for example, entered the 1994 season with an even five years of service and needed 172 days of the season to reach six years. Although a season is 183 days long, for service credit purposes, one year is 172 days. The strike ended the season when it was 131 days old.
"The basic agreement says you have to be on the active roster to get service credit," Orza said. "Roster moves were made during the strike. I assume there was a reason. They obviously can't have it both ways. They can't have the benefit of maintaining an active roster and also say they didn't have an active roster."
Orza referred to roster moves clubs made after the strike began when they recalled players from the minor leagues so they wouldn't have to pay their salaries. The union challenged those moves with default notices and grievances.
Lou Melendez, a P.R.C. lawyer, said Orza can argue that players should be credited with service time during the strike, but "to what extent any arbitrator is going to give it a lot of credence, I don't know. I think we're on better ground than the Players Association on this one."
Melendez cited strikes in 1981 and 1985 as precedents. "In both instances," he said, "the Players Association sat down in a back-to-work agreement and negotiated the service back for the players who were on strike. Not withstanding the language in the basic agreement as it exists, which could be subject to any interpretation, a person on strike shouldn't derive any economic benefit, and service credit is just that."
Other players affected by the dispute are Randy Velarde of the Yankees, Ken and Bob Patterson of California, Tom Gordon of Kansas City, Gregg Olson of Atlanta, Marvin Freeman and Greg Harris of Colorado, Chris Gwynn of Los Angeles, Mark Parent of Pittsburgh and Alvaro Espinoza of Cleveland.
The approximately 170 players who are eligible have until Oct. 29 to file for free agency. Clubs other than their own are not free to begin signing them until Oct. 30. However, the Player Relations Committee has talked of imposing a freeze on player signings and may impose it before Oct. 30.
If clubs do not begin negotiating with and signing free agents, the union most likely will file a grievance, contending that the clubs are acting in concert against free agents and thus violating the free agent rules.
After the clubs were found guilty of collusion in three different years and agreed to pay $280 million in damages, they agreed in the 1990 collective bargaining agreement to be subject to triple damages if they colluded again.
"I have no expectation about what they'll do," Orza said, when asked about the freeze phase of free agency. "Whatever they do, we'll respond to it."
When the union files a grievance over the Abbott group, it also could seek triple damages. Orza gave no indication if the union would file a grievance immediately for those players.
Others players who filed yesterday were Jeff Blauser of Atlanta, Darren Jackson of the White Sox, Jesse Orosco of Milwaukee, Tim Wallach of Los Angeles, Bill Swift of San Francisco, Rick Sutcliffe of St. Louis and Candy Maldonado of Cleveland.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York Yankees pitcher Jim Abbott was one of four players who started the free-agent wars by filing for free agency yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Whose Gain From Whose Pain?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What would Paul Krugman say to the eight million American workers now unemployed? For them and their families, "short-term pain" may mar the rest of their lives and the lives of their children. Economists seem well-prepared to record, identify, analyze and interpret statistical data but unable to translate into human terms the possible options for solving the problems that confront us. 
 To be told that the ultimate effect of economic disparities in our social and political health is "unlikely to be pleasant," amounts to the suggestion that victims can never again be participants. Are there really no solutions to these problems?
 
EDWARD MEYER
Fairfield, Conn., Sept. 26
 
The writer is an independent market researcher.

HEADLINE: Germany Will Survive Its Confusion

 BODY:
Judged a likely loser last year, then viewed as a certain winner only six months ago, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany heads into his most confusing and least predictable election today. His problem is not with his Christian Democratic Party, which is leading in the polls. His problem rather is the possible collapse of his indispensable junior coalition partner, the Free Democrats, whose votes have assured Mr. Kohl's parliamentary majority since he first became Chancellor in 1982.
Fortunately there are enough brakes in Germany's federal Constitution so that a lurch toward real instability seems highly unlikely. Americans can watch with interest, not alarm, as 60 million Germans choose a government in a newly unified country now pulling out of economic doldrums. 
 Under Germany's complicated electoral system, the balance could be tipped if the Free Democrats fail to meet the 5 percent threshold required for parliamentary seats. But what makes the vote a real sweepstakes is that each voter, who first casts a vote for the party of his choice, casts a second ballot to elect an individual local representative. If a minor party does well in these local contests, it gets a windfall bonus that, depending on its share of the national vote, could greatly increase its representation.
Thus, in a peculiar twist, the free-market and libertarian Free Democrats could lose out, while the authoritarian East German Communists, now calling themselves the Party of Democratic Socialism, could bounce back. Discontent is highest in eastern Germany, where jobless rates are painfully high, giving the party a solid local base among the aggrieved. East Germany may be gone, but its old ruling party is emphatically not forgotten.
This resurgence is a major headache for the opposition Social Democratic Party and its low-key new leader, Rudolf Scharping. With the Free Democrats out, the party might just be able to cobble together a parliamentary majority in partnership with the leftish environmental Greens. But he has been rattled by Chancellor Kohl's charge that the Social Democrats might also depend on the support of former Communists, whose ideology is anathema to many veteran Social Democrats in western Germany.
If no coalition with a minority party is possible, the remaining way out for the two big parties is to form a "grand coalition," dividing the Cabinet seats between them. It would not be a happy outcome. Germany's last grand coalition, in the late 1960's, saw a surge in support for extreme right-wing parties, which filled the void left by a true opposition party.
However, should Germany again experiment with a partnership between Mr. Kohl and Mr. Scharping, Europe will not totter nor the mark collapse. Germany's far-right party, the Republicans, seems unlikely to get any parliamentary seats. It is the perplexities of democracy, not its survival, that are at issue in today's vote.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 521 words

HEADLINE: President Aristide Returns

 BODY:
For the overwhelming majority of Haitians, the return of Jean-Bertrand Aristide is a joyous occasion. For a small but important minority, particularly among the economic and military elite, it is a nightmare come true.
For President Clinton, it is a foreign policy victory but by no means an undiluted one. It took three years, many policy reversals and finally a dubious use of U.S. military force to get to this point. The road ahead could be even more militarily treacherous and politically complicated than the recent past. 
 These cautions take nothing away from President Aristide. He won Haiti's first and only democratic election overwhelmingly. Though he then needlessly antagonized political allies and spoke in ways that seemed to countenance mob violence, his seven-month tenure was marked by fewer human rights violations and fewer boat people than any comparable period in modern Haitian history. After the military ousted him in a September 1991 coup, Father Aristide's supporters never deserted him; they suffered for him and kept dreaming of his return. Now he calls for reconciliation, justice and an end to bloodshed.
But the very novelty of Haitian democracy means there are no institutions to carry out orderly change and to reassure members of the old elite that their rights and even their lives will not be sacrificed. No court system worthy of the name exists. The only forces of order Haiti ever knew were partisan defenders of the old regime. Now that these have been broken by American power, only unreliable recruits of dubious loyalties are available to replace them. The Clinton Administration must steel itself against any temptation to move into this vacuum. U.S. troops must try to limit their involvement in police activities while an interim U.N. peacekeeping force is recruited and trained.
That will be harder than ever now that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and his cronies have finally gone and President Aristide has physically returned. Even if Father Aristide heeds U.S. pleas to put aside his radical electoral mandate, his supporters have high expectations and may be tempted to take matters into their own hands.
So may his enemies. If property owners recruit armed men to defend their estates from vigilante seizure, should U.S. troops try to disarm these private defenders? If so, should the Americans protect these threatened estates themselves, using deadly force if necessary? Anything Washington does or does not do under such circumstances would have serious repercussions both in Haiti and at home. The best thing the Clinton Administration can do is to keep the U.S. military mission limited and brief.
The U.S. has a human interest in helping Haitians out of their pain and misery. So long as the new Government lives up to its promises of democracy, reconciliation and human rights, Washington should be generous with aid and technical support. But with an elected Government now in charge and no real national security interests at stake, the U.S. military occupation of Haiti, never a good idea to begin with, must be wound up as soon as possible.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
